    "pages": }\n\n'''William James Campbell''' (born April 8, 1942) is a  politician from . He was a man from 1996–2002, Assembly  from 2000–2001, and a member of the  from 2003–2013.\n\n\nBorn in , Campbell grew up in . Campbell earned a  in  from  and a  from the .\n\n\nAfter initially working as an , Campbell and his wife founded BIMA Corporation, a company that specialized in  .\n\nIn 1996, Campbell was elected to the represent eastern 's 71st District in the State Assembly with 71% of the vote. He was re-elected with 69% of the vote in a three-way race in 1998 and 67% of the vote in a four-way race in 2000. Campbell served as Assembly Republican Leader from 2000 to 2001. During his time in the Assembly, he also served as Vice Chairman of the  Committee and was a member of the Banking and Finance Committee, the Education Committee, and the Utilities and Commerce Committee.\n\nIn 2002, Orange County Supervisor  won 73% of the vote to replace the  Campbell. Campbell, in turn, won 75% of the vote in the 2003  to fill the vacancy on the Board of Supervisors left when Spitzer resigned to become an Assemblyman. Both men suffered criticism for their apparent job swap, which required changing Orange County from a general law county to a  county to allow an election to fill the supervisorial vacancy under the county charter instead of having then-  fill the vacancy by appointment under general law. However, this controversy seemed to have little effect on the election results, as 53% of County voters approved the creation of the charter and 3/4 of the voters supported the two men in their respective districts.  Indeed, Campbell was unopposed for re-election to a full four-year term on the Board of Supervisors in 2004.  In 2008, he won 80% of the vote in his bid for a second full four-year term.  In 2012, Spitzer won 67% of the vote in his bid to return to the Board to replace the term-limited Campbell.\n\nCampbell served as  of the Board of Supervisors from January 4, 2005 – January 9, 2007 and from January 11, 2011 – January 10, 2012.\n\n\nCampbell and his wife, Mary, have lived in  for over a quarter of a century. They have three adult sons, Patrick, Chris, and Brian, and five grandchildren.\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Juanita Millender-McDonald''' (September 7, 1938 – April 22, 2007) was an  who served as a member of the  from 1996 until her death in 2007, representing , which includes most of  and the city of . She was a member of the .\n\nOn December 19, 2006, Millender-McDonald was named Chairwoman of the  for the . She was the first African-American woman to chair the committee. She was also a member of the  and of the  and was considered a front-runner for the job of  if  had been elected President in .\n\n\nMillender-McDonald was born in . She was educated at ; at the , from which she received a business degree; and at , from which she earned a masters in educational administration; and the , from which she completed her doctorate in public administration.\n\nShe worked as a teacher, a textbook editor, and later as director of a nonprofit organization working for gender issues. She was a member of  sorority. Millender-McDonald served as a member of the City Council of  and was a member of the  (after beating two sitting incumbent Democrats that had been reapportioned into the same Carson based assembly district in 1992) before entering the House.\n\nShe was first elected to the House in a March 1996 special election to replace Congressman , who resigned due to corruption charges and was later sentenced to 27 months in prison. While she won a difficult nine-candidate primary in her first election run (fellow assembly member  came in a close second) she did not face any serious opposition in any of her reelection campaigns.\n\nIn Congress, she was known for her commitment to protecting international human rights. Millender-McDonald worked to aid victims of genocide and human trafficking. In 1996, she also led an inquiry into allegations that the CIA was working with cocaine traffickers to fund Contra rebels in .\n\nWithin a week of her requesting a leave of absence to deal with her illness, on April 22, 2007, Millender-McDonald died in hospice care, succumbing to  at the age of 68 at her home in Carson. She left a husband, James McDonald, Jr., and five adult children.\n\n\n at a hearing of the House Administration Committee.]]\nCongresswoman Millender-McDonald's seat was vacant until  won the August 21, 2007, . Under California law,   announced a special election date of June 26, and because no candidate received more than 50% of the total vote, the candidates with the most votes in their respective parties participated in an August 21 runoff. In the June Primary,   lost to  , with Richardson continuing to the August special election, when she defeated  John M. Kanaley,  Herb Peters, and  Daniel Brezenoff.\n\n\n\n\n*Write-in and minor candidate notes:  In 2000, Herb Peters received 3,150 votes.\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  campaign finance reports and data\n*  issue positions and quotes\n*  campaign contributions\n*  profile\n*  profile\n*  \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| children     = 5\n| education    =  ()\n| allegiance   = \n| branch       = \n| serviceyears =\n| battles      = \n}}\n'''Jesse Marvin Unruh''' (, ; September 30, 1922 – August 4, 1987), also known as '''Big Daddy Unruh''', was an American politician who served as speaker of the  and as the .\n\n\nBorn September 30, 1922 in , , Unruh served in the  during . After the war, he enrolled at the , receiving a  degree in  and  in 1948.\n\n\n\n\n meets with California state legislators. Left to right: Chairman of the California Assembly Committee on Ways and Means, ; California State Assembly Speaker, Jesse Unruh; President Kennedy; Chairman of the California Senate Finance Committee, ; and President Pro Tempore of the California State Senate, . Oval Office, White House, Washington, D.C.]]\nUnruh's political career began as an unsuccessful candidate for the  in 1950 and 1952. He was elected as a member of the Assembly on his third attempt in 1954. In 1956, he was an unsuccessful candidate for  for California as a Democrat. In 1959, he wrote California's , which outlawed discrimination by businesses that offer services to the public and was a model for later reforms enacted nationally in the 1960s and 1970s. Unruh was Speaker of the  from 1961 to 1969 and a delegate to  from California in 1960 and 1968.\n\n\nAs a national official of the Democratic Party, he often feuded with   (1959–1967), a fellow Democrat, and was a case-study of 's treatise on machine politics, ''The Amateur Democrat''.\n\nUnruh was California campaign manager for  in 1960 and a close Kennedy associate throughout his presidency. He helped convince Senator  to enter the 1968 presidential race and managed his California campaign. Kennedy won the California primary, but was assassinated shortly after his victory speech at the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles.\n\nU.S. President  once described Unruh as \"probably one of the most selfish men\" he had met in politics.\n\nAfter an unsuccessful effort, managed by Unruh and Mayor  of , to draft Senator , Unruh released California delegates to vote their conscience and announced that he would support  at the  in Chicago.\n\nUnruh left the legislature to campaign unsuccessfully for governor against  in 1970. One of his campaign workers was , who a decade later was the  for the unsuccessful reelection bid of President . In 1973, Unruh ran unsuccessfully for .\n\n\nWhen he campaigned for state treasurer in 1974, the post was considered insignificant. Unruh's radio advertisements assured voters, \"Make no mistake about it, I really want this job.\" Once elected, Unruh politicized the office. ''The Wall Street Journal'' noted he became \"the most politically powerful public finance officer outside the U.S. Treasury\". California pension funds were a major source of revenue for Wall Street underwriting companies, and Unruh secured campaign contributions in exchange for doing business with them. '''' said he had gained control of \"an obscure post whose duties had long emphasized bookkeeping. In characteristic fashion, he soon transformed the job into a source of financial and political power that reached from California to Wall Street.\" Because as Treasurer he was an ''ex officio'' member of many California boards and commissions, Unruh supervised \"the raising and expenditure of virtually all the state's money and consolidated his influence over billions of dollars in public investments and pension funds\".\n\nHe served as state treasurer from 1975 until his death from  on August 4, 1987, 8 months into his 4th term as treasurer. Unruh remains the second longest-serving California State Treasurer behind only  (who served 33 years between 1923 and 1956).\n\nThe  Department of Political Science includes the Jesse M. Unruh Institute of Politics.\n\n\nUnruh's nickname \"Big Daddy\" apparently derives from a character in the  play, ''''. Former Senate President pro Tempore  in his book ''A Disorderly House'' insists it was given to Unruh by then-Assemblyman .\n\nUnruh was a  and belonged to the . He married twice, and had five children.\n\nHe died of  at his home in , California on August 4, 1987. He is buried in , California.\n\n\nThe California State Treasurer's Building was rededicated and renamed the  by Gov.  on August 19, 1987.\n\nThe California State Capitol building's hearing room #4202 currently holds a picture of Jesse M. Unruh.\n\nThe California State Assembly Fellowship Program was renamed the Jesse Marvin Unruh Assembly Fellowship Program to honor the former Assembly Speaker and State Treasurer.\n\n\n:On campaign contributions: \"Money is the mother's milk of politics.\" 1966\n:On lobbyists: \"If you can't eat their food, drink their booze, screw their women and then vote against them you've got no business being up here.\" Other versions exist, for instance \"If you can't eat their food, drink their booze, screw their women, take their money and then vote against them, you have no business being up here.\"\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* Boyarsky, Bill. ''Big Daddy: Jesse Unruh and the art of power politics'' (U of California Press, 2007) \n* Cannon, Lou. ''Ronnie and Jesse: A Political Odyssey'' (New York: Doubleday,1969) \n* Herzberg, Donald G., and Jess Unruh. ''Essays on the State Legislative Process'' (New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston, 1970)\n* Mills, James R. ''A Disorderly House, The Brown-Unruh Years in Sacramento'' (Berkeley: Heyday Books, 1987)\n* Putnam, Jackson K (2005) ''Jess: The Political Career of Jesse Marvin Unruh''.     "pages": }\n\n'''Marc Berman''' (born October 31, 1980) is an American lawyer and politician who has served as a member of the  since 2016. He is a  representing the , encompassing parts of the  and , including , , and . Before being elected to the assembly, Berman was a member of the  .\n\n\nBerman was born in ,  and raised in . He graduated from , where he served as student body president. In 2002, Berman earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Political Science from . He then earned a  from the . In college, Berman worked in Congresswoman 's office and as an analyst in the .\n\n\nAfter graduating from law school, Berman worked as an attorney at  and Merino Yebri, LLP. He also worked provided pro bono representation to clients seeking protection under the  and individuals seeking  from the . Before being elected to the , Berman served as a member of the Palo Alto City Council.\n\nBerman has taken a pro-housing stance, favoring policies to encourage the production of housing to address the . His stance contrasted with the stance of other politicians from , who favor policies that slow down housing production.\n\nIn 2019, Berman introduced legislation to ban the knowing and malicious distribution of manipulated videos and pictures (\"s\") that falsely depicts the acts or words of a political candidate within 60 days of an election, unless the material is accompanied by a disclaimer that discloses that it contains manipulated content; the bill passed the California Legislature and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuring the , Berman and fellow Democratic Assemblyman  were drawn into the same district; Low moved to a neighboring district, averting a  between two incumbents.\n\nIn 2022, Berman introduced AB 2584, which made changes to the state's recall law. The bill raised the number of signatures required on a notice of intention to recall. AB 2584 also requires recall petitions to be made available for public inspection during the 10-day time period in which the election office is determining whether the petition can be approved for circulation and allows recall elections to be consolidated with regular elections scheduled within 180 days of the petition qualifying for the ballot. The bill was signed by the governor in September 2022.\n\nIn May, 2023, the  city clerk filed a lawsuit to remove \"false\" statements made in a citizen-initiated recall petition seeking the removal of the mayor and two city council members. The clerk cited state law, including AB 2584, for allowing the clerk to remove false or misleading statements. The city offered a settlement to the recall proponents to dismiss the lawsuit, but the proposal was rejected in September.\n\nBerman is a member of the .\n\n\nBerman is .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Malia M. Cohen''' (born December 16, 1977) is an American politician serving as the 33rd  since 2023. A member of the , Cohen previously served as Chair of the  from the 2nd district from 2019 to 2023 and as President of the  from District 10 from 2011 to 2019.\n\n\nCohen was born in  on December 16, 1977. The eldest of five girls, she grew up in the  in San Francisco and graduated from . Her mother was a social worker and her father a telecommunication worker.\n\nCohen earned a bachelor's degree in political science from  and a graduate degree in political science from .\n\n\nCohen worked as a field organizer for  in the  and as his confidential secretary for two years when he was mayor. After leaving Newsom's office, Cohen worked as a legislative aide for  supervisor Rose Jacobs Gibson.\n\nIn the  for District 10 of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, she was third in receiving first place votes out of a field of 22, but eventually won the election based on .\n\nIn October 2013, Cohen introduced legislation that expanded an existing San Francisco law making it illegal to sell firearms with magazines capable of holding more than 10 rounds. The gun-control legislation passed unanimously.\n\nIn 2013, Cohen and  authored the Fair Chance ordinance, a \"\" legislation barring employers and landlords from asking applicants to state their criminal history on applications, which passed the Board of Supervisors unanimously.\n\nIn 2014, Cohen was re-elected for a second term to represent District 10 after being challenged by Marlene Tran and Tony Kelly.\n\nIn 2015, Cohen publicly defended San Francisco's  laws, which drew the attention of  Host . After the shooting death of  by an illegal alien, O'Reilly had been critical of San Francisco and its elected officials. O'Reilly said that Cohen should be placed under arrest for her comments defending San Francisco's sanctuary city policy.\n\nIn 2016, Cohen introduced legislation, in reaction to lobbying by sitting judges, that could result in pension boosts for some of those judges or for other individuals who become judges after working for the city government. The  reported that according to analysis by the San Francisco Employees Retirement System (SFERS), the proposal would increase the pensions of four current judges, with an average expected additional lifetime benefit of $147,000 per judge affected. The SFERS report did not name those judges, and SFERS spokesman Norm Nickens said the agency does not release the names of active members.\n\nCohen succeeded  as president of the Board of Supervisors on June 26, 2018, following Breed's election as . Later that year, she was elected to represent District 2 on the California State Board of Equalization.\n\nAccording to the , Cohen's social media consulting firm, Power Forward, was suspended in March 2021 for failure to pay and file taxes.\n\nCohen ran in the  for  against Republican  winning the race with 55% of the vote, the lowest margin of victory for any statewide candidate that election cycle.\n\nAfter the death of Senator  in September 2023, Cohen was discussed as one of several possible people to serve the remainder of Feinstein’s term.\n\n\nShe married workers' compensation attorney Warren Pulley in May 2016.\n\n\n\n\n\n   \n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n''' Anthony Joseph Cannella''' (born March 22, 1969) is an American  who previously served in the . A , he represented the , which encompasses all of both  and  counties, as well as parts of , , , and  counties. Prior to his election to the State Senate, he served as the mayor of .\n\nHe is the son of , a former   who also represented portions of the Central Valley.\n\n\n\nAnthony Cannella was elected to the State Senate in 2010, defeating state Assemblywoman  in a surprise, with assistance from the , and easily re-elected in 2014 as one of few Republicans endorsed by the .\n\nIn April 2017, he was the only Republican Senator to vote in favor of Senate Bill 1, the Road Repair & Accountability Act of 2017 (more widely known and reported as the \"Gas Tax\"); he was promised transportation assistance for the , and an extension of the  rail line to his district.\n\nThe Senate bill includes a 20-cent per gallon increase in diesel taxes, a 12-cent per gallon hike in gas taxes and a 5.75 percent increase in diesel sales taxes. Vehicle license fees would be raised an average $38 per vehicle. Drivers would also face a new annual fee to be paid with their vehicle registration, ranging from $25 to $175 depending on the value of their vehicle. The taxes and fees rise each year with inflation. Funds would be used to improve roads, highways and transportation systems in California.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  at Vote Smart\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert J. Blumenfield''' (born September 13, 1967) is an American elected official in . Blumenfield is the member for the  which encompasses the southwestern  neighborhoods of Los Angeles, including , , , , and . Blumenfield took office on July 1, 2013. Blumenfield previously represented the  in the , which also covers the southwestern San Fernando Valley.\n\n\nBlumenfield was born on September 13, 1967. He is a graduate of  and the .\n\nFrom 1989 to 1996, he worked in Washington, D.C., as a staff person to Senator , Congressman  and as staff designee to the . He later worked as Director of Government Affairs for the Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy and then as District Chief of Staff to Congressman Berman in the .\n\n\n, 2023.]]\n\n\nBlumenfield took office as a member the California State Assembly in 2008 after defeating Republican candidate Armineh Chelebian in the general election. During his time in the Assembly, Blumenfield represented the San Fernando Valley in District 40 and, following redistricting in 2012, District 45. He served as the chair of the Budget Committee.\n\n\nBlumenfield was elected to the Los Angeles City Council in March, 2013. He represents the 3rd Council District, which spans the northwest portion of Los Angeles in the San Fernando Valley, including the communities of Canoga Park, Reseda, Tarzana, Winnetka and Woodland Hills.\n\n\nBlumenfield currently lives in  with his wife Kafi and their two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Deane Dana, Jr.''' was a member of the .\n\nDana was born July 9, 1926, in ., retrieved November 8, 2011. He studied engineering at  in .\n\nAfter moving to California with his family, he lived in  and later, . He worked as an engineer for 27 years at , and became an active participant in the local  and a close friend of future governor , working in each of Deukmejian's campaigns from 1962 on.\n\nIn 1980, Dana was elected over  to represent District 4 on the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors. He served until he retired in 1996, when his friend and chief of staff, , was elected to replace him. Dana served as  and was president of the Coliseum Commission and the Southern California Regional Airport Authority. The Deane Dana Friendship Park and Nature Center in  is named in his honor.\n\nDeane Dana died April 21, 2005, at Torrance Memorial Hospital in . He is buried in Green Hills Memorial Park in Rancho Palos Verdes.\n\nHis son Deane Dana III ran unsuccessfully for the Sacramento City Council in 2014.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Raymond Neal Haynes Jr.''' (born August 26, 1954)  is an American politician and member of the  from the state of .\n\n\nBorn in , Haynes graduated from . Prior to his service in the Legislature, Senator Haynes community activities included service on the board of the Riverside Youth Service Center, an organization dedicated to helping the troubled youth of the City of Riverside, the board of the Riverside County American Red Cross, and Chair of the Moreno Valley Community Assistance Program, which provided food and clothing to those in need in the City of Moreno Valley in Riverside County.  He also served on the Planning Commission of the City of Moreno Valley.  He received his Bachelor of Arts in Political Science from  in 1976, his Master's in Public Administration from Eastern Kentucky in 1981, and his Juris Doctor from the University of Southern California in 1980.  Senator Haynes was admitted to the practice of law in California in 1980. He moved to  and practiced law in , starting a solo law practice in 1988.\n\nHaynes' has three daughters: Jennifer Salwender and Caitlin and Sarah Haynes, and two grandchildren, Joshua and Annika Salwender. He is currently married to Maria Amparo Villamor-Haynes, a Filipino lawyer.\n\n\nHaynes was first elected to the  in 1992, serving in that body from 1992 to 1994. Haynes was then elected to the , serving in that body from 1994 to 2002 and serving as Senate Republican Whip from 1996 to 2002. During the , Haynes  candidate , calling him a \"homosexual liberal;\" Takano ultimately lost the election to . In 2000 he served as National Chairman of the  (ALEC), a conservative group that produces proposed model legislation. He ran for the U.S. Senate in 2000, losing in the Republican primary to then-U.S. Representative . Haynes was again elected to the Assembly in 2002, representing District 66, which includes western  and northern  counties. Haynes was also the Assistant Republican Leader in the Assembly from 2003 to 2006. Haynes left the Legislature as a result of California’s term limits law in 2006, and opened a private law and government relations practice with an emphasis in environmental issues. In 2006, he was Chairman of .\n\nIn the Senate, Haynes was Chairman of the Senate Constitutional Amendments Committee (one of the two Republicans to serve as chair of the over 20 committees in the Senate), Vice Chair of the Senate Health and Human Services Committee, Vice Chair of the Senate Education Committee, Vice Chair of the Senate Public Employees and Retirement Committee, Vice Chair of the Assembly Human Services Committee, and he served on the Senate Budget and Judiciary Committees, as well as the Assembly Budget, Appropriations, Judiciary and Health Committees.\n\nHaynes ran for the  in 2006, losing to  in the Republican primary. He ran for  in the  to the  but was not elected.\n\nHaynes supports and has advanced a conservative case for the .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Barbara Sue Boxer''' ( '''Levy'''; born November 11, 1940) is an American politician, lobbyist, and former reporter who served in the , representing  from 1993 to 2017. A member of the , she served as the  for  from 1983 until 1993.\n\nBorn in , New York City, Boxer graduated from  and . She worked as a stockbroker for several years before moving to California with her husband. During the 1970s, she worked as a journalist for the '''' and as an aide to U.S. Representative . She served on the  Board of Supervisors for six years and became the board's first female president. With the slogan \"Barbara Boxer Gives a Damn\", she was elected to the  in 1982, representing California's 6th district.\n\nBoxer won  for the U.S. Senate. Running for a third term , she received 6.96 million votes, becoming the first person to ever get more than 6 million votes in a Senate election and set a record for the most votes in any U.S. Senate election in history, until her colleague, , the senior senator from California, surpassed that number in her . Boxer and Feinstein were the first female pair of U.S. senators representing any state at the same time. Boxer was the ranking member of the  and the vice chair of the . She was also the Democratic . Boxer is known for her liberal perspectives.\n\nBoxer did not seek re-election in . She was succeeded by then– and future  . In January 2020, Boxer joined -based  Mercury Public Affairs as co-chairwoman. In January 2021, it was reported that Boxer was working as registered foreign agent for , a Chinese state-sponsored surveillance company implicated in human rights abuses. After initially defending her work for Hikvision, Boxer reversed course and deregistered as a foreign agent. In October 2021, Boxer and others led a high-profile mass exodus of employees from Mercury's California office to form their own public affairs and consulting company.\n\n\nBarbara Sue Levy was born in , New York City, to Sophie (née Silvershein) and Ira Levy,\",\" ''History, Art, and Archives, house.gov. Retrieved 26 Jul 2021. a  couple. She attended public schools, graduating from  in 1958.\n\nIn 1962, she married Stewart Boxer and graduated from  with a  in . Barbara and Stewart Boxer moved to California in 1965.\n\n\nBoxer worked as a  in the early 1960s while her husband went to . In 1968, after relocating to California, she worked on the presidential primary campaign of antiwar challenger . In 1970, she co-founded the anti- Marin Alliance.\n\nBoxer first ran for political office in 1972, when she challenged incumbent Republican Peter Arrigoni, a member of the , but lost a close election.  From 1972 to 1974, Boxer worked as a reporter and editor for the ''''. She then managed the Marin campaign of , the brother of , who then was the congressman representing southern . John Burton intended to run against incumbent Republican District 6 Congressman  from . The district would be renumbered as the 5th District in January 1975. However, Mailliard resigned on March 5, 1974, so John Burton also ran in the special election to fill the remainder of the incumbent's 6th District term. Burton narrowly won both crowded races and was sworn into office in 1974, and Boxer became his staff aide.\n\nIn 1976, Boxer was elected to the , serving for six years. She was the board's first female president.\n\n\n\nBoxer, then a Marin County supervisor, was elected to the  in 1982, succeeding . Her slogan was \"Barbara Boxer Gives a Damn\". In the House, she represented  for five terms. She narrowly won her first election with 52 percent of the vote, but easily won re-election in her subsequent races.\n\nBoxer was a member of the original , ''United States House of Representatives'', Washington, DC, 28 April 1984, Original document retrieved 19 January 2014 from ERIC at Ed.gov: Institution of Education Sciences.  that was established in 1983. She sat on the Armed Services committee throughout her tenure in the House.\n\nIn 1992, Boxer was implicated in the , which revealed that more than 450 congressional representatives and aides, herself included, wrote overdraft checks covered by the House Bank's overdraft protection. In a statement, Boxer said, \"In painful retrospect, I clearly should have paid more attention to my account\". She wrote a $15 check to the Deficit Reduction Fund for each of her 87 overdrafts.\n\nIn 1991, during the  Senate hearings, where Hill accused U.S. Supreme Court nominee  of sexual harassment, Boxer led a group of women House members to the , demanding that the all-white, all-male Committee of Senators take Hill's charges seriously.\n\n\n\n\nFour-term incumbent Democratic Senator  did not seek re-election in 1992. Boxer opted to run for Senate. In what was billed as the \"Year of the Woman\", Boxer beat fellow Rep.  and Lieutenant Governor  in the Democratic primary, winning 44% of the vote. In the general election, Boxer defeated Republican  by 4.9%. A last-minute revelation that Herschensohn had patronized a strip club at least partially affected the outcome. In 1998, Boxer , beating sitting California State Treasurer  by 10.1% of the vote. In , after facing no primary opposition, Boxer defeated  candidate , the former , by 20%. In 2010, Boxer defeated  candidate , former chief executive officer of , by 10%. Boxer did not seek re-election in 2016.\n\n\n* \n** \n** \n** \n** \n** \n*  (Ranking Member)\n* \n** \n** \n**  (Chair)\n** \n*  (Vice Chair)\n\nA member of the Senate Democratic Leadership, Boxer served as the Democratic chief deputy whip, which gave her the job of lining up votes on key legislation.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\nOn January 6, 2005, Boxer joined   (D-) in filing a U.S. congressional objection to the   votes in the . She called the objection her \"opening shot to be able to focus the light of truth on these terrible problems in the electoral system\". The Senate voted the objection down 74–1; the House voted the objection down 267–31. It was only the second congressional objection to an entire state's electoral delegation in ; the first instance was in 1877.\n\n\nAs a , Boxer had declared that she would support the winner of the , which was won by . However, she reneged on that pledge and remained neutral, only officially backing 's candidacy the day after the last primaries, once he had garnered enough delegate votes to clinch the nomination.\n\n\nPrior to 's announcement, on October 20, 2013, Senator Boxer was one of sixteen Democratic female senators to sign a letter endorsing Clinton as the Democratic nominee in the .\n\n\n\nAfter leaving the U.S. Senate, Boxer has given paid speeches; raised money for her political action committee (PAC for Change); hosted a weekly podcast with her daughter, Nicole Boxer; and worked as a lobbyist.\n\nIn April 2017, Boxer served as the keynote speaker for the Environmental Student Assembly's Earth Month at the .\n\n\n\nIn January 2020, it was reported that Boxer had become co-chair of Mercury Public Affairs, a prominent lobbying and public affairs firm, whose corporate clients have included  and , along foreign governments such as  and .\n\nPrior to joining Mercury Public Affairs, Boxer had worked as a paid advisor to , during which time she advocated against the passage of , a California law that Lyft opposed which reclassified as \"employees\" many workers, including Lyft drivers, who had previously been classified as \"independent contractors\" under state labor law.\n\nBoxer also has worked as a paid consultant on behalf of Poseidon Water as part of that company's effort to install a , and also for CityLift Parking, a company in , California, that designs automated parking lifts.\n\nIn October 2021, Boxer, former Los Angeles mayor , and former  speaker  led a high-profile mass exodus of employees from the California office of Mercury Public Affairs to set up their own public affairs and consulting firm. At the time of their departure, the press reported Mercury's California based clients included , , the California Charter Schools Association, and the , the utility that oversees the heart of the state's agricultural lands in the .\n\n\nOn January 12, 2021, it was reported that the inaugural committee of president-elect  returned a $500 donation from Boxer after Boxer registered as a  on behalf of , a Chinese state-owned manufacturer of surveillance equipment. The company has been accused of involvement in the  in the  region. In an emailed statement to the press regarding the returned donation, Boxer defended her work as a registered foreign agent by saying, \"When I am asked to provide strategic advice to help a company operate in a more responsible and humane manner consistent with U.S. law in spirit and letter, it is an opportunity to make things better while helping protect and create American jobs.”\n\nLater that same day, Boxer reversed course and publicly announced on Twitter that she would deregister as a foreign agent for Hikvision, writing, \"Due to the intense response to my registration I have determined that my continued work has become a negative distraction from my effort to preserve American jobs and make the company better. Therefore I have deregistered.\"\n\n\nBoxer has been described as a \"liberal lion\", as well as a \"progressive force\".\n\n\nBoxer and  Senator  were the only two Senate Democrats to support  Senator 's 2006 resolution to  President .\n\n\nDuring the confirmation hearings for the  nominee  in January 2005, Boxer challenged her to admit to alleged mistakes and false statements made by the Bush administration in leading the United States into the . Along with 12 other senators, Boxer voted against confirmation. The 12 \"no\" votes were the most votes against a secretary of state nominee since 1825, when  was so named.\n\nBoxer voted against 's nomination for  in the  and ed him on the Senate floor. Because of the strong  opposition, Bolton could not obtain Senate approval. However, President Bush bypassed the Senate by employing the constitutional right of .\n\nBoxer voted against the confirmation of  nominee  and against the confirmation of  nominee .\n\n\nOn October 1, 2008, Boxer voted for the .\n\nOn August 26, 2013, Boxer told '''' on  that the  should be raised to $10.00 an hour.\n\n\nBoxer established the Excellence in Education award to recognize teachers, parents, businesses and organizations working to make positive changes in education. Beginning in 1997, Boxer presented the Excellence in Education Award to 38 recipients.\n\n\nBoxer voted for the 2002 , which mandated the use of voting machines across the country, among other provisions. On February 18, 2005, Boxer and others introduced the Count Every Vote Act of 2005, which would have provided a voter-verified paper ballot for every vote cast in  machines and ensured access to voter verification for all citizens. The bill did not pass.\n\nBoxer introduced a bill on November 15, 2016, calling for a constitutional amendment to abolish the Electoral College and to select future presidents by a simple national vote only. This bill was introduced six days after Donald Trump won the 2016 election despite losing the national popular vote to Hillary Clinton.\n\n\nBoxer opposed the  deal between the United States and India. She believed that India should not receive aid from the U.S. in the civilian nuclear energy sector until it broke .\n\n\nBoxer successfully led the 2003 Senate floor battle to block oil drilling in the . In 2005, Boxer voted again to block oil drilling at ANWR.\n\nBoxer introduced the National Oceans Protection Act (NOPA) of 2005.\n\nBoxer was an original cosponsor of Senator ' (I-VT) .\n\nBoxer was the Senate sponsor of the , which was signed into law by President  on October 17, 2006. The bill protected  of federal land as  and  of stream as a , including such popular areas as the  and .\n\nBoxer, along with her colleague Dianne Feinstein, voted in favor of subsidy payments to conventional commodity farm producers at the cost of subsidies for conservation-oriented farming.\n\n\nIn 1997, the Senate passed a Boxer resolution calling on the United States not to recognize the  as the official government of  because of its human rights abuses against women.\n\n  in 2005.]]\n\nShe voted against the first  while a member of the House in 1991.\n\nIn 2012, Boxer and a bipartisan group of six senators introduced a resolution condemning Russia for aiding  's government as the country .\n\n\nIn October 2002, Boxer voted against the  passed by the  to authorize the use of military force by the Bush administration against .\n\nIn June 2005, Senators Boxer and  of Wisconsin, cosponsored Senate Resolution 171 calling for a timeframe for .\n\nIn 2005, Boxer criticized  's judgment in relation to the : \"I personally believe&nbsp;– this is my personal view&nbsp;– that your loyalty to the mission you were given, to sell the war, overwhelmed your respect for the truth.\"\n\nBoxer was sharply critical of US Army General ' testimony regarding the political and military situation of Iraq in 2007, charging him with reporting while wearing \"rosy glasses\".\n\nIn January 2007, Boxer was in the news for comments she made when responding to . \"Who pays the price?\" Boxer asked Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice. \"I'm not going to pay a personal price. My kids are too old and my grandchild is too young. You're not going to pay a personal price with an immediate family. So who pays the price? The American military and their families... not me, not you.\" When Rice interjected, Boxer responded by saying, \"Madam Secretary, please. I know you feel terrible about it. That's not the point. I was making the case as to who pays the price for your decisions. And the fact that this administration would move forward with this escalation with no clue as to the further price that we're going to pay militarily... I find really appalling.\"\n\n\nSenator Boxer joined colleagues to pass a  on various s and established the COPS program.\n\nIn the wake of the 2016 , Boxer posted on Facebook that it was an \"unspeakable tragedy\" and she encouraged others to support \"common-sense gun safety laws to protect our communities from these weapons of war.\"\n\n\nBoxer co-sponsored the , which expanded the federal definition of hate crimes to include crimes based on the victim's  and .\n\n\n\nBoxer was part of a coalition to increase medical research to find cures for diseases. In 2007, she authored successful bipartisan legislation with Senator  to combat HIV/AIDS and  globally. In 1997, she authored a Patients' Bill of Rights. She has written a bill to make  tax-deductible and a bill to allow any American buy into the same health insurance program that members of Congress have. She supported comprehensive prescription drug coverage through  and the right of all consumers to purchase lower-cost prescription drugs re-imported from Canada.\n\nIn October 2002, Boxer urged the  to take specific steps to address the causes of the  cases in California.\n\nBoxer advocated for embryonic , asserting that it has the potential to help those with , , , spinal cord injuries, and other diseases.\n\n\n\nBoxer supported .\n\n\nIn 1996, Boxer was one of 14 senators to vote against the . She also voted against the  in 2004 and 2006, although when San Francisco Mayor   to the city-county clerk to issue  licenses to , she stated that she supported  but believed that marriage was between a man and a woman. She opposed , a constitutional amendment that prohibited same-sex marriage in California, and supported the .\n\nDuring her 2010 campaign, Boxer stated her strong support for same-sex marriage.\n\n\nBoxer opposed reforming marijuana policy and opposed a California ballot measure to legalize and tax marijuana for those 21 and older in the state.\n\n, 22 March 2005.]]\n\n\n\nAs a senator, Boxer was an outspoken supporter of abortion rights. She authored the  of 2004 and participated in the floor fight for passage of the .\n\nBoxer was critical of the  to Obamacare.\n\n\nBoxer supported the then-current system of , and opposed President 's plan for partial privatization of Social Security.\n\n\nIn June 2008, Boxer spoke in the Senate in opposition to the , a pending bill in the United States Congress to amend the , and later broke with her counterpart  and voted against it.\n\n\nAt 4'11\" (150&nbsp;cm), Boxer was one of the shortest members of the Congress. When addressing the chamber, she would sometimes stand on a portable platform, dubbed the \"Boxer Box\", which was carried by an aide.\n\n\nBoxer has made cameo appearances as herself in several television shows, including '''' (1994), '''' (2002) and '''' (2007), as well as a cameo (as herself) in the 2000 film ''''. On November 2, 2005, she made an appearance on '''' to discuss her new novel, ''A Time To Run''.\n\nIn September 2012, it was reported that Boxer and Republican Senator  would appear together in an  sitcom. On September 20, 2012, she and Senator Snowe appeared in the  of ''''. Boxer later returned to ''Parks and Recreation'' alongside several other U.S. senators in early 2015 in the  episode \"Ms. Ludgate-Dwyer Goes to Washington\".\n\nIn November 2016, Boxer appeared in an episode of '''', presented by , entitled \"Do Not Despair About Our Country\", filmed shortly after the result of the  was known, during which Handler wept about the result.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* , July 20, 2005\n* \n* \n* \n\n\nBoxer's first novel, '''', was published in 2005 by San Francisco-based . Her second novel, ''Blind Trust'', was released in July 2009 by Chronicle Books.\n\n\nBarbara and Stewart Boxer had two children, Doug and Nicole. On May 28, 1994, Nicole Boxer married , the younger brother of , in a ceremony at the  attended by 250 guests., '''', May 30, 1994. Last accessed March 23, 2008. (This was the first White House wedding since  married  in 1971.) Before divorcing, Boxer and Rodham had a son, Zachary, in 1995.\n\nIn 2006, Barbara and Stewart Boxer sold their house in Greenbrae, California and moved to .\n\nOn July 26, 2021, Boxer was ed and  of her mobile phone in the  section of Oakland, California. A $2,000 reward was offered for information leading to an arrest. Boxer was not seriously injured in the attack.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* Johnston, Robert D.     "pages": }\n\n'''Maxwell Lewis Rafferty Jr.''' (May 7, 1917 – June 13, 1982) was an American writer, educator, and politician. The author of several best-selling books about education, Rafferty served two terms as  from 1963 to 1971 under Governors  and later eventual future   and ran unsuccessfully in 1968 for the U.S. Senate as the Republican nominee, losing to Democratic former State Controller . As of 2024, Rafferty is the very last Republican to have officially serve as California State Superintendent of Public Instruction to date.\n\n\nRafferty was born to Maxwell Rafferty Sr. (1886–1967), and the former DeEtta Frances Cox (c. 1892–1972) in , one of two children. His younger sibling was actress , a co-star of the 1954-1959 CBS Television sitcom, ''''.\n\nMax Rafferty spent most of his childhood in , where his sister was born in 1922. The family relocated to California in 1931. In 1944, he married Frances Longman, and the couple had three children: Kathleen, Dennis, and Eileen.''Who's Who in America, 1968-1969'' (, : Marquis Who's Who, 1968), p. 1780\n\n\nRafferty graduated in 1933 from . He earned his  (1938) and  (1949) from the . He earned his  (1955) from the . While attending UCLA, he was a member, and president, of the  fraternity chapter.\n\nAs an undergraduate at UCLA, Rafferty \"took umbrage at many of the things\" in the college newspaper, the '''', \"particularly the editorial page ... to the point of charging into the office and physically attacking me\", recalled editor  in 1970.\n\nIn 1937, Rafferty wrote a letter to the '''' in which he described ''The Bruin'' as \"one of the most prejudiced newspapers on the Pacific Coast\" and complained that its \"radicalism is not so funny if it keeps you from getting a job.\"\n\n\n\nRafferty's first job, during , was as a classroom teacher in the  in the  portion of , California. In his newspaper columns, Rafferty often remarked with nostalgia how his first teaching jobs in California had been the most satisfying ones of his career.\n\nAfter World War II, Rafferty became vice-principal, principal, and school superintendent in various California school districts, including Big Bear High School in  from 1948–51. He was the superintendent at  (1951–55),  (1955–61), and , a prosperous northeast Los Angeles suburb (1961–62). \n\nIn 1962, he was elected to the nonpartisan office of California education superintendent, defeating Los Angeles school board president Ralph Richardson. He held the office for two terms, from 1963–71.\n\nIn 1968, Rafferty challenged and defeated incumbent    in the Republican primary election in what has been described as \"one of the biggest primary upsets in Senate history.\" \n\nRafferty ran as a  while Kuchel was a moderate. A series of newspaper articles by  reported that Rafferty had been less than eager to serve his country during World War II after being classified 1A: fit for military service. Rafferty, Shaw reported, twice appealed the classification and was reclassified 4Fphysically, mentally or morally unfit for servicebecause of what Rafferty said was a case of \"flat feet\". \"The standing joke in the town\", Shaw wrote, referring to the Mojave Desert community of Trona where Rafferty spent much of the war years as a teacher, \"is still 'Max Rafferty celebrated V-J Day by throwing his cane away'.\" The stories damaged Rafferty and he lost the  to Cranston, the former state controller.\n\nTwo years later, in 1970, Rafferty failed in his bid for a third term as Superintendent of Public Instruction, losing to , the first  to be elected to statewide office in California and a Democrat in the nonpartisan race.\n\nHe then moved to  to serve on the faculty at  in , serving as Dean of Education from 1971–81, and as Sorrell Chairman of Education from 1981 until his death in 1982. Shortly before his death, he was appointed by President  to a national advisory board on the financing of elementary and secondary education.\n\nRafferty was the author of several books on educational philosophy, including ''Practice and Trends in School Administration'' (1961), ''Suffer, Little Children'' (1962), ''What They Are Doing to Your Children'' (1964), and ''Max Rafferty on Education'' (1968). His newspaper column, \"Dr. Max Rafferty\", was syndicated nationally. He also received the  from the .\n\n\nRafferty was described by ''The New York Times'' as an \"outspoken antiprogressive educator\" who \"built a national reputation attacking busing, sex education and the 'New Left'&nbsp;\".\n\nHis books ''Suffer, Little Children'' and ''What They Are Doing to Your Children'' attacked progressive education and urged a \"return to the fundamentals\" in education. In particular, he wanted schools to focus on , memorization, and drill; use American history and children's classics in teaching from the early grades forward; and drop  and \"life adjustment\" approaches from education. Among his controversial actions as state schools superintendent was his attempt to stop schools and classrooms from using books that he considered obscene, such as 's '''' and 's ''''. He threatened to revoke the teaching certificate of any teacher who used such works. He attempted to get the ''Dictionary of American Slang'' removed from school libraries. Rafferty has also espoused hero-worship of the founding fathers in history classes saying “Dwelling on their human faults distorts the overall picture.” Holding the image of the founding fathers even above objectivity:\n\n\"Balancing virtues with vices, belittling the heroes, dwelling unduly upon the scandals of the pastthese are the techniques that produce in the minds of the children a balanced, bland, tasteless, lifeless image of the country, and all in the sacred name of objectivity.”\n\nPolitically, he was known as an \"articulate spokesman for the far right\" who had a \"nationwide reputation as a Fourth-of-July style orator and writer.\", ''Miami News'', October 17, 1968 In 1968, while running for the Senate, Rafferty said that those caught in  should be shot.\n\nHe urged quick, stiff punishment for crimes: \"Retribution is what I'm talking about, friends, and ever since we crawled out of caves, retribution has followed wrongdoing as the night does the day.\" He promised never to vote for higher taxes or for  to \"dictators who hate us,\" and he criticized judges who \"coddle criminals,\" saying he could not have voted to confirm any of the then  Justices.\n\nIn 1972, he campaigned for and served as a stand-in speaker for Alabama   during the latter's Democratic campaign for U.S. president.\n\n\nRafferty was active in the  and . He died on June 13, 1982, at age 65 when his car plunged off an  into a pond near .\n\nHis papers were donated to the  Department of the  Libraries in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*, Published 1963 by New American Library in New York (OpenLibrary.org)\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n|website     = (discontinued)\n}}\n\n'''Patrick Layton Paulsen''' (July 6, 1927 – April 25, 1997) was an American comedian and satirist notable for his roles on several of the  television shows, and for his satirical campaigns for  between 1968 and 1996.\n\n\nPaulsen was born July 6, 1927, in , a small fishing town in . He was the son of Beulah Inez (née Fadden) and Norman Inge Paulsen, a Norwegian immigrant who worked for the . The family moved to California when he was 10, where he graduated from  in  in May 1945.\n\nPaulsen joined the  after high school, when  was still being waged, but it ended before he was shipped overseas. However, he did experience overseas duty, including guarding captured Japanese soldiers during their repatriation. He returned home after the war and worked as a posting clerk, a truck driver, a hod carrier, a Fuller Brush salesman, and a gypsum miner. Later, he was employed as a photostat operator for several years. He attended , then joined an acting group called \"The Ric-y-tic Players,\" and he formed a comedy trio that included his brother Lorin.\n\n\n\nPaulsen developed a solo act, appearing as a comedic guitarist in various clubs on the West Coast and in New York City. He met the Smothers Brothers during an appearance in San Francisco. '''' premiered in 1967, and Paulsen said that he was hired because he sold them inexpensive songs and would run errands. At first, he was cast as their editorialist, but his deadpan, double-talk comments on the issues of the day propelled him into the national spotlight. His work on ''The Smothers Brothers' Comedy Hour'' earned him an Emmy Award in 1968.\n\nPaulsen made a guest appearance on '''' in the 1968 episode \"Monkees Watch Their Feet\", playing the Secretary of National Defense. He also made many appearances on ''''. In 1968, he appeared as timid Federal Agent Bosley Cranston in \"The Night of the Camera\" in Season 4 of ''''. During the inaugural season of '''' in 1969–1970, he appeared in a series of comic skits. He was featured in the 1970 '''' episode \"The Mess of Adrian Listenger\". Early in 1970, he headlined his own series '''', which ran 13 weeks on . Guests on the first show were former Vice President  and an animated , whom Paulsen interviewed.\n\nIn 1971, Paulsen performed in the play '''' at Cherry County Playhouse  in . He enjoyed this professional summer-stock theater so much that he became business partners in 1976 with television writer and producer Neil Rosen and bought Cherry County Playhouse. He starred in a production every summer except 1973, all the way through the 1995 season. He starred in 24 different plays, including '''', '''', '''', and ''''. He appeared in nightclubs, theaters, and conventions throughout the country. In 1984, he co-starred in the film '''', a vehicle for .\n\n\nAfter  sold five minutes of airtime on ''The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour'' for a political ad, the show's writers came up with a bit in which Paulsen disclaimed association with the ad and stating that the ad was unfair to him as a candidate. CBS refused to air the bit, but the incident became the impetus for the ''Smothers Brothers'' writers launching a Pat Paulsen presidential campaign. His campaign in 1968 and succeeding years was grounded in comedy, although not without serious commentary. He ran the supposed campaigns using obvious lies, double talk and tongue-in-cheek attacks on the major candidates, and he responded to all criticism with his catchphrase, \"Picky, picky, picky\". His campaign slogans included \"Just a common, ordinary, simple savior of America's destiny\", \"We’ve upped our standards, now up yours\" and \"United we sit\". He gave essentially the same answer to every question on social issues: \"To get to the meat of the matter, I will come right to the point, and take note of the fact that the heart of the issue in the final analysis escapes me.\" In announcing his candidacy on the Smothers Brothers show, Paulsen said, \"Now I ask you: Will I solve our economic problems? Will I ease the causes of racial tension? Will I bring a peaceful end to Vietnam? Sure, why not?\"\n\nPaulsen's name appeared on the ballot in  for the Democratic primary several times. In 1996, he received 921 votes (one percent) to finish second to President  (76,754 votes); this was ahead of real politicians such as Buffalo mayor . In 1992, he came in second to  in the . In the , he received 10,984 votes total.\n\n\n\nIn 1971, Paulsen and his then-wife Jane opened Pat Paulsen Vineyards, a vineyard and winemaking operation in . Shortly after  was elected mayor of  (1986), Paulsen proclaimed himself \"mayor\" of Asti, the small town near his vineyard. The office was of his own invention.\n\n\nIn the 1980s, Paulsen began a relationship with social worker Linda Chaney, whom he met at a Denver comedy club. She began serving as his booking agent and the two were married in 1988. However, he learned that she was diverting his funds into her own personal accounts and he filed for divorce after only 40 days. He later sued her and was awarded a judgment of $233,000, but Chaney said that, even if she had the money, she would \"go out and shred it rather than turn it over\" to Paulsen. \n\nIn 1995, Paulsen was diagnosed with colon cancer and doctors discovered that the cancer had spread to his brain and lymph nodes in 1997. He sought alternative medicine treatment for his cancer in , Mexico and died there from complications of pneumonia and kidney failure on April 25, 1997. Paulsen was fondly remembered by fans who enjoyed his mockery of the entire electoral process. \"Whenever I’d walk around with him,\" Tom Smothers said, \"people would yell, 'Hey, Mr. President.'  We miss him.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*''Pat Paulsen for President'' (1968)\n*''Live at the Ice House'' (1970)\n*''Unzipped'' (1998)\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \"Pat Paulsen for President!: America's Favorite Also-Ran!\" article by Wayne Hicks, ''Filmfax'' magazine, May–July 2016,  (cover). Filmfax, Inc., Evanston, Illinois USA.           }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Carlos Villapudua''' (born March 10, 1968) is an American politician who is currently serving in the . A , he represents the , which encompasses western , including the city of .\n\n\nVillapudua was born in . He received a  in  from the  in 1997.\n\n\nVillapudua worked as a legislative assistant for Supervisor Steve Guttierez, then served two terms as a member of the   and was CEO of the San Joaquin County Hispanic Chamber of Commerce.\n\n\nVillapudua ran for  in . He placed third in the first round election with 24.10% of the vote, behind eventual winner  and incumbent  respectively.\n\n\n\nVillapudua first ran for  in , challenging incumbent Democrat  in the . He placed third in the primary election with 16.9% of the vote, behind Eggman and Republican Antonio Garcia respectively.\n\nIn 2020, Eggman retired to successfully run for . Villapudua ran for Assembly again and won, defeating County Supervisor Kathy Miller with 53% of the vote.\n\nIn 2022, he was re-elected and defeated  City Council member Veronica Vargas with 60.6% of the vote.\n\n\nVillapudua introduced legislation that would allow certain prisoners to engage in job training and other activities in a community campus on prison grounds. In '''', Shirin Bakhshay writes \"While Villapudua's bill is commendable, his comments [on rehabilitating prisoners] reflect the type of thinking about criminal actors that continues to impede wide-spread reform efforts...\"\n\n\nVillapudua's wife, Edith, was a candidate for  in the , the seat Eggman is vacating due to term-limits. The couple switched races on the day before California's candidate filing deadline, with Carlos running for Senate and Edith running for his Assembly seat. The move was characterized as a ploy to better each of their electoral prospects; however it drove former   to join the Senate race and Edith's original opponent, Rhodesia Ransom, to also switch into the Assembly election. Despite the last-minute switch, both he and his wife lost their respective races.\n\n\nVillapudua lives in Stockton with his wife, Edith. His brother, Brando, is a member of the  City Council and his cousin, Miguel, is a member of the  .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Richard Charles Ackerman''' (born December 5, 1942) is an American   , who was a  for the , representing inland , from 2000 to 2008.\n\nBorn in , Ackerman earned a  in  from the  in 1964 and a  from  in 1967. Ackerman and his wife, Linda, who married in 1968, have three children, Lauren, Marc, and Brett, and four grandchildren, Caitlin, Elizabeth, Robert & Delaney.\n\nElected to the  City Council in 1980, Ackerman served three terms on the council, also serving as Mayor in 1982 and 1986.\n\n\n\nAckerman was elected to the  from the 72nd District in a 1995 special election to replace Assemblyman , who vacated the seat after winning a special election to the .  He was unopposed for re-election in 1996 and won 68% of the vote in 1998.  During his tenure in the Assembly, Ackerman served as Assistant Republican Leader, Republican  , Vice Chair of the Assembly  Committee, Vice Chair of the Assembly  Committee, a member of  Committee, and a member of the Legislative  Committee.\n\n\n\nAfter those three terms in the Assembly, Ackerman was elected to the State Senate in 2000.   In first year in the Senate, he became Vice Chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee.  Ackerman and his family moved from their long-time Fullerton residence in the northern part of his Senate District to  in the central part of his Senate District.  In 2002, Ackerman agreed to run as a  against     in the latter's bid for a second term, as no Republican sought the nomination for Attorney General and Ackerman could retain his Senate seat since it was not up for election until 2004. As expected, Lockyer won re-election and Ackerman stayed in the Senate.  On May 10, 2004, Ackerman was  elected to serve as .  Six months later, he won re-election to the Senate with 69% of the vote. On April 15, 2008, Ackerman officially handed over California Senate GOP leadership to fellow Long Beach-born State Senator .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Tom Daly '''(born July 26, 1954) is an American  who served in the . He is a  who represented the , which encompassed central , including the cities of , , , and .\n\nPrior to being elected to the Assembly in 2012, Daly served as Orange County Clerk-Recorder, as well as . He first sought elected office in 1986 for the Anaheim Union High School District.\n\n\nA native of Orange County, Daly was born and raised in Anaheim. He attended four local schools, starting in kindergarten at Lincoln Elementary, then moving on to St. Anthony Claret's, Sycamore Junior High, and Anaheim High.\n\nDaly's father was a longtime Latin and English teacher at Anaheim High School.  Both his parents were active in civic affairs, providing Daly's introduction to local politics.\n\nAs a child, Daly was an All-Star player in the North Anaheim Little League.  In high school, Daly went on to play on the Anaheim High Varsity Baseball team, producing one of the leading records among Orange County pitchers.\n\nFrom his roots in Anaheim, Daly went on to receive his Bachelor of Arts degree from Harvard University in 1976.\n\nAfter graduating from Harvard University and returning to Anaheim, Daly served as an aide for Orange County Supervisor Ralph Clark for eight years.  A Democratic leader in a Republican-dominated county, Supervisor Clark was elected to four terms on the Orange County Board of Supervisors after serving on the Anaheim City Council and Mayor of Anaheim.\n\nDaly first sought elective office in 1986, winning election to the board of trustees of the Anaheim Union High School District. Daly went on to run for Anaheim City Council in 1988 and then he was elected mayor in 1992.\n\nDaly still lives in Anaheim. He is married and has three children.\n\n\nFrom 1992-2002, Daly served as the directly elected mayor of the City of Anaheim, the tenth largest city in California.\n\n\nIn the 1992 Mayoral election, Daly defeated then-Mayor Fred Hunter by a margin of 57% to 43%.  The decisive issue in the campaign was an unpopular citywide utility tax supported by then-Mayor Hunter, which was strongly opposed by Daly while he served as a City Councilmember.  His 1994 re-election as mayor set a record for the most votes ever received by an Anaheim mayor.\n\nIn 1998, Daly defeated a strongly backed Republican and fellow council member Bob Zemel.\n\nAs mayor, Daly supported the candidacy of Loretta Sanchez for U.S. Congress.  Daly served as an adviser to her successful upstart campaign against longtime incumbent and conservative Bob Dornan, in which Sanchez won by 984 votes.\n\n\n\nIn 1997, the Anaheim City Council took the unprecedented step of hiring a special prosecutor Ravi Mehta to investigate alleged campaign violations during the 1996 election.  Only two out of the five-member council approved the hiring after the Anaheim City Attorney refused to file charges saying the allegations against Daly and Councilmember Irv Pickler were unfounded.\n\nThe probe by Mehta, a former chair of the state Fair Political Practices Commission, led to misdemeanor complaints against Daly and Picker.  The complaints were ultimately rejected by an Orange County Municipal Judge, who also stated that the council had \"no authority [to hire] a special prosecutor, period.\"  The investigation ultimately cost the City of Anaheim more than $302,000 in legal fees.  No other city or county in California had ever hired a special prosecutor to investigate suspected campaign finance violations.  The investigation came during a time in which Daly considered running for the Orange County 4th Supervisorial District but ultimately declined to run citing personal reasons and his intent to run for reelection for mayor in 1998.\n\n\nAs mayor, Daly oversaw a billion-dollar expansion of the Anaheim Resort area, including the expansion of the Disneyland Resort with Disney California Adventure and Downtown Disney as well as an expansion of the Anaheim Convention Center.  With these developments, the tourism industry grew tremendously in Anaheim, leading to more jobs and increased City revenue.  Revenue from the hotel bed tax doubled from $28.7 million in 1991-92 to $57.7 million in 2001-02.  Daly also oversaw the renovation of .  While Mayor, the Anaheim Angels won the 2002 World Series.\n\nDuring his tenure, the City developed eight new city parks, reduced crime, established higher standards or citywide planning and land development, and created the Anaheim Colony Historic District with tax incentives for owners who maintain historic homes.\n\nWhile mayor, Daly also served on the board of directors for the Orange County Transportation Authority, where he helped oversee the Measure M $3 billion improvement program.\n\n\n\nAfter serving as mayor, Daly ran for Orange County Clerk-Recorder, a countywide position responsible for handling county documents, including birth certificates, marriage licenses, and property transactions.\n\nDaly defeated Bruce Peotter, a Newport Beach attorney and recording document executive, by a margin of 53.9% to 46.1%.  The office was left vacant by the death of Gary Granville, who had introduced a number of innovations to the department and merged the clerk's department and the recorder's office in 1995.\n\nAs the Clerk-Recorder, Daly opened branch offices in historic downtown Fullerton and Laguna Hills Civic Center, providing more access to North and South County.  He reopened the Orange County Archives as well as implemented Orange County's innovative Electronic Recording System.  He also developed a number of online based system, improving efficiency for Orange County residents.\n\nIn his 2010 countywide re-election as the Clerk-Recorder, Daly set a record with the highest countywide winning percentage in fifty years (in contested races.)\n\nDaly was named Orange County's Manager of the Year for 2010 by the . In 2011, his department was honored with a Bright Ideas in Government award for \"creative and innovative\" customer service by the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.\n\n\n\nOn March 6, 2012, Daly announced his candidacy for the newly drawn 69th Assembly District to replace termed-out assemblymember Jose Solorio.\n\nIn the June 2012 primary election, Daly emerged with the highest number of votes and 39.2% of the overall vote.  Democratic challengers Santa Ana councilmember Michele Martinez and -backed candidate Julio Perez failed to garner enough votes to reach the November general election.\n\nIn the November 2012 general election, Daly beat a relatively unknown Republican challenger, Joe Moreno, by a 67.6% to 32.4% margin.\n\n\nAssemblymember Daly was sworn into the Legislature on December 3, 2012.\n\nDaly served on the following committees:\n* Chair, Insurance \n* Appropriations\n* Governmental Organization \n* Veterans Affairs \n* Transportation\n* Joint Fairs and Allocation \nIn 2013–14 he chaired the Budget Subcommittee No. 4 on State Administration.  In this role, Daly championed efforts to reduce business filing processing delays and backlogs in the Secretary of State's office as well as speed up Veteran Affairs claims by returning service members from Iraq and Afghanistan.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n'''Toni Gayle Atkins''' (born August 1, 1962) is an American politician who served as the 51st  from 2018 to 2024. A member of the , she previously served as the 69th  from 2014 to 2016 and the California State Assembly majority leader from 2012-2014. She has represented the  since 2016, encompassing most of .\n\nUpon her election as speaker of the State Assembly, she became the third woman and first acknowledged lesbian to be elected to the position, as well as the first lawmaker from San Diego holding the office. She served on the  from 2000 to 2008, including a term as acting  in 2005. She also served as acting  for nine hours on July 30, 2014, which made her California's \"first openly gay governor\" and again on July 6, 2023 where she became the first openly LGBT person to sign a bill into law in the state. In 2018, she was elected as , becoming the first woman and the first openly  person to lead the , and the first woman and LGBT person to lead both chambers of the state legislature . On January 19, 2024, she launched her campaign for governor in the .\n\n\nAtkins spent her early years in , moving to  at the age of seven. Her father was a miner and her mother a seamstress; she grew up in a home with no running water. She graduated from  in 1984 and earned a BA in political science, focusing on community organizing. In 2004, Atkins completed Harvard University's  program for Senior Executives in State and Local Government as a David Bohnett LGBTQ Victory Institute Leadership Fellow. Atkins relocated to San Diego in 1985.\n\n\nWhen she first came to San Diego, she joined the staff of Womancare Health Center as Director of Clinic Services. She then served for a number of years as council representative and policy analyst to City Councilmember . When Kehoe was elected to the state legislature, Atkins was elected to Kehoe's City Council seat on November 7, 2000. She was , without the need for a November runoff.\n\nIn April 2005 Mayor  resigned after criticism of his handling of the city's fiscal problems. Councilmember , who was , took over, but three days later, resigned along with Councilmember  after they were convicted of wire fraud and  violations. In an emergency vote on July 19, Atkins was chosen by the other five council members to take over as mayor pro-tem for one week. On July 25 they reaffirmed their choice and designated Atkins deputy mayor to serve until  was sworn in as mayor on December 5. Atkins was the first openly  mayor of San Diego.\n\nWhile on the council, she represented the City of San Diego at the San Diego Chapter of the League of Cities as well as on the board and executive committee of the . She sat on the  (SANDAG) Regional Housing Working Group, as an alternate to the Transportation Committee and the Regional Planning Committee, and the City/County Joint Homeless Task Force. She continues to serve on the San Diego River Conservancy as an appointee of former   . She lists among her priorities affordable housing, workers' rights, neighborhood revitalization and redevelopment of San Diego's older urban neighborhoods.\n\n\n\n\nShe was elected to the State Assembly in November 2010, receiving 57.7% of the vote. She represented the 76th Assembly district. In November 2012 she ran in the 78th Assembly district due to redistricting, and won with 62% of the vote.\n\nIn 2012 she introduced AB 1522, a bill to prevent the granting of financial support and other spousal rights to abusive spouses. The bill was inspired by the case of a San Diego woman who was ordered to pay legal fees and spousal support to her ex-husband even though he was in prison for abusing her.\n\nIn 2012, she was the Majority Leader of the California State Assembly; in January 2014 she was chosen by the Democratic Caucus to take over as Speaker of the Assembly later in the year, replacing termed-out speaker . She was the first Speaker of the Assembly from San Diego, the first lesbian to hold the position, and the third woman to do so.  Atkins was reelected as Speaker by the Democratic caucus in November 2014. As Speaker she helped to write and secure passage for a $7.5-billion water bond that was approved by the legislature and the voters in 2014. Atkins faced protest over her vote for legislation that would limit . Atkins stepped down as Assembly speaker in March 2016.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nShe ran as candidate for the  in 2016, initially challenging the incumbent , also a Democrat, before Block bowed out. In the general election, she defeated  John Renison with 63% of the vote.\n\nIn 2018, Atkins succeeded  as . This made her the first woman and the first openly  person to lead the California State Senate.\n\n\nIn May 2019, Senate Appropriations Committee Chair  blocked  from leaving committee and entering the Senate for debate and voting. The bill proposed major reforms to address the  by reducing local control (such as requiring the permitting of more apartment construction near public transit and in suburbs with high-paying jobs). Atkins refused to step in and take the bill out of committee, which was within her powers. Proponents of the bill accused Portantino of abusing his powers to deny SB50 a debate and a vote in the Senate. Atkins' action stopped legislators from bringing the bill back for consideration that year. Due to this delay, the bill could not be considered by the Senate until 2020.\n\nIn January 2020, when the bill was being reconsidered, Atkins exercised her parliamentary powers to move the bill out of Portantino's committee. The bill made it to the senate floor and was subsequently defeated after multiple floor votes.\n\n\nAtkins has faced criticism for accepting donations from fossil fuel corporations and failing to pass major climate legislation. In particular, critics noted that she appointed opponents of climate action to committees on which they would have an outsized impact on climate legislation.\n\n\nAtkins is one of eight members of the . She lives in the  neighborhood with her spouse, Jennifer LeSar.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Walter William Herger Jr.''' (born May 20, 1945) is an American politician who served as the  for  from 1987 to 2013. A member of the , his district was the state's largest congressional district by area. It covered almost all of interior  including ,  and . On January 10, 2012, Herger announced he would not seek re-election in November.\n\n\nHerger was born in . He is of  descent; his paternal grandfather emigrated to the US from the  in the late 19th century. He is also of  and  descent. Herger was raised on his family's  cattle ranch and plum farm in the  town of  (between Yuba City and Sacramento). He worked in the family's oil and gas exploration business.Representative  ; retrieved February 11, 2011, from\n\nHe joined  when he was about 20 years old. He graduated from  with an Associate of Arts. He also attended  for a year. His political career started in 1976, with his election to the East Nicolaus School Board. He also served northern California in the  from 1980 to 1986.\n\n\n\n\nHerger was easily reelected to Congress due to the \"safe\" Republican voter registration advantage in this district, but his election campaigns were challenged by Democratic candidates in his last campaigns. The district often fields a candidate registered with a third party, such as the Libertarian party and, during the 1990s, the Natural Law Party.\n\nIn 2002 and 2004, Herger defeated Democrat Mike Johnson, garnering 67% of the vote in 2004. In 2006, Herger faced Arjinderpal Sekhon and received 64% of the vote. In 2008, Herger faced Trinity County Supervisor Jeff Morris, who did somewhat better, holding Herger to 57% of the vote.\n\nIn 2010, Herger faced a Republican primary challenge from retired Colonel Pete Stiglich, and ran in the general against Democrat Jim Reed, a lawyer who divides his time between the Bay Area and Fall River. Herger prevailed with 57% of the vote.\n\n\n\nHerger served on the influential  since his tenure began as a federal representative. Within Ways and Means, Representative Herger served on two subcommittees, the , and the . In the 110th Congress he was named the Ranking Member of the Republican (minority) delegation to the Trade Subcommittee. Representative Herger's participation in full committee is limited to Ways and Means, in accordance with the rules of the Committee on Ways and Means. While he chaired the Subcommittee on Income Security and Family Support (called the Subcommittee on Human Resources during his watch) beginning with the , he played a leading role in the reauthorization and expansion of the 1996 welfare reform law. He sponsored the , passed as part of the larger 1996 Welfare Reform Law. This bill gave additional financial incentives to law enforcement agencies that identified fraudulent recipients of aid.\n\nOn August 18, 2009, Herger triggered controversy when he attended a town hall meeting in Redding, California, where an audience member introduced himself as a \"proud right-wing \"  to reporters in a private interview ten days later, after the controversy had reached national attention, that he had misspoken, having intended to say \"extremist\". Herger did not immediately distance himself from the remark then and there, but, instead, after the constituent's lengthy comment, responded by saying, \"Amen. God bless you. There goes a great American.\" Many people, both inside and outside Herger's congressional district found his failure to respond immediately unacceptable. Herger's gaffe attained the apotheosis of national media attention when Keith Olbermann picked the story up for his show  on August 28, 2009.\n\n;Legislative goals\nThe 2nd congressional district is driven by agriculture. Herger supported legislation to bolster free and fair trade in an effort to support his constituency. Congressman Herger, from his position on the Trade Subcommittee, planned  to lead the consideration of trade agreements with foreign nations. He worked on the ''Herger-Feinstein Quincy Library Group Forest Recovery Act'', which instituted a framework for managing federal forest assets that will be tested on federal lands in , , and  counties, and has been negotiated by a diverse coalition that includes environmental and logging interests. The act aims to reduce vegetation density in Forest Service lands, while expanding forest biodiversity (i.e. reduction of \"monoculture\" forests).\n\nCongressmen Herger and Meek (D-FL) drafted a bill to repeal the three percent withholding tax scheduled to begin in 2011. The withholding tax would apply to governments with expenditures of greater than US$100&nbsp;million on services from for-profit companies. The law mandates that governments will only deliver 97&nbsp;percent of a contract to the contractor, and send the remaining  3% to the . Vendors and contractors are expected to increase their bid values to cover this new cost. The National Association of Counties thinks that this will give Counties a competitive disadvantage when dealing with vendors and contractors. (Counties assess costs of federal '3-percent withholding law')\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n**  (chairman)\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\nHerger is married to Pamela Sargent, with whom he has 9 children and 19 grandchildren.  He is a member of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and used to sit  on the .\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n*  \n* \n* \n*  from \n*  from the ''''\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
