    "pages": }\n|relatives =  (cousin)\n|occupation=, \n|website=\n}}\n'''Carole Ward Allen''' is an American politician, professor,  and political consultant. She is a member of the , and serves as the  of CWA Partners, LLC. As a  executive in the , Ward Allen served three four-year terms as an elected member of the  representing the  from 1998 until 2010.\n\nDuring the 1980s and early 1990s, she was often featured in '''' for making history in  and . Before entering the , Ward Allen was appointed to serve on the California Commission on the Status of Women by  in 1980. In 1983, she was elected by her colleagues to serve as the commission's first   for a one-year term. Ward Allen served on the state commission until 1985.\n\nIn 1987, Ward Allen was appointed to the Oakland Board of Port Commissioners by . In 1990, she was elected among board members to serve as ; making her the first African American female and the longest woman to achieve such stride with two one-year terms. After having served six years in  at the , her tenure ended in 1993.\n\nIn 1998, Ward Allen was elected by voters to the  board of directors. As a BART director representing the 4th district ( and ), she led efforts to secure $4 billion in capital for system rehabilitation projects, the transit system's  of the , and  programs.\n\nOn December 15, 2005, the BART board of directors elected Ward Allen to serve as its  and Lynette Sweet as its ; making  the first major  agency to be led by two African-American women in .\n\nIn 2010, she led the BART Board and  region through the process of approving the , and securing federal funds under .\n\n\n\nWard Allen was born Carole G. Allen in  to mother Nell G. Allen, and father Claude O. Allen, who was a  veteran and an  who specialized in . Her father was one of the first  lawyers in  and the first African American to run for the .\n\nAfter graduating from  in 1960, Ward Allen went off to college. She holds a Bachelor of Arts and a  from , and a  in Higher Education from  in .\n\nAlso, Ward Allen completed post-graduate studies at the , ; Fourah Bay College University, ; , Nigeria; the University of Kumasi, Ghana; and , Kenya.\n\n\n\nIn 1970, Ward Allen began her career at  serving as a professor of  at  in . Later, she was elevated to assistant  for  at the  after having served as director of community relations and marketing at Laney College.\n\nWard Allen retired from Peralta in 2005, but served as an adjunct professor until 2017. She taught students  and was a member of the  department.\n\n\n\n\n\nOn March 14, 1980, Governor  appointed Ward Allen to the California Commission on the Status of Women. In 1983, she became its first  . Her tenure ended with the state commission in 1985 under the  of Governor .\n\n\nMuch of her policy-making consisted of advancing women in  and , improving  wives' circumstances, and fighting for women to return to their jobs after . As commission chair, Ward Allen pushed for practical  policies that resulted in women receiving paid ; she worked closely on this workplace policy with then-  who introduced a  on this issue in 1984, and she advocated for women to receive equal  for equal work. Ward Allen told '''' that women should be allowed to return to the workplace after having children and be afforded maternity leave under . She saw maternity leave as a vital right for women and thought the lack of a maternity law in California perpetuated a false choice for women, stating:\n\n}}\n\nCalifornia state legislators  and Waters worked closely with commissioner Ward Allen on issues pertaining to  in society. Ward Allen served on the commission with future-California state senator , and  who would become  of the .\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1987, Ward Allen was nominated by  and appointed by the  to serve on the . From 1990 until 1992, she served as , making her the first   to lead the port in its history; during a time when Oakland's port was recognized as one of the top ten ports in the country. Also, Ward Allen was the second African American female to be appointed to the commission and the third .\n\nDuring her six-year tenure with the port, Ward Allen was responsible for , businesses, financial and  strategies for the development of the maritimes facilities, the , and  holdings. In the capacity as port commissioner, she authorized port , provided  to the  or , awarded funding for  projects, and managed a budget of $100 million, accounting for directly and indirectly more than 44,000 jobs.\n\nWard Allen led a wide range of port planning, port development, and port productivity projects working with  across the world. While president of the board of port commissioners, she expanded  and  activities.\n\nOn August 6, 1991, she hired Charles Roberts as chief executive officer of the port. In addition, she was responsible for the  board authorization to award the City of Oakland $5.2 million to ease its  crisis in 1991, whereby helping the city balance its .\n\n\n\n\n\nOn January 3, 1989, Ward Allen honored the life and legacy of  by authoring a  of condolence. George was a  of Ward Allen's father; working in his  in 1960s, and a long-time family friend.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn addition, Ward Allen along with her board members advocated and secured funds to bring  to Oakland in the early 1990s after the . This was the second time in history Amtrak had come to Oakland. The site of the Amtrak station officially re-opened in 1995 owned by the Port of Oakland. Ward Allen was involved in much of the contracting and legal work surrounding the Port of Oakland owning the facility where the  was built when she headed the Port from 1990 to 1992, working with two different city mayors; Lionel J. Wilson and .\n\n\n\n\n\nWard Allen was a critical proponent of the  during the late 1980s and early 1990s. In 1989, when Ward Allen was vice president of the Port of Oakland Board of Commissioners, the Port's headquarters relocated to Jack London Square and her name was engraved on the building.\n\n\n\nIn July 1991, then-President Ward Allen of the Board of Port Commissioners, advocated for permits to be issued to allow  to take place at the port. She pushed for dredging at the port along with labor representatives and other agencies, stating that:\n}}\n\n\n\nWard Allen was an advocate for the creation of , which was adopted by the  with the Port of Oakland serving as a partner of the charter school. While she was on the BART Board, she remained committed to serving as an advocate of this  since her days on the Board of Port Commissioners.\n\n\n\n\nWard Allen was a District 6   in 1998 challenging then-city councilman Nathan Miley. She ran a strong  having received major endorsements from local  that resulted in her earning 42% of the vote to Miley's 52%. Ward Allen's first city council campaign was effective, but unsuccessful in unseating an .\n\n\nIn 2001, Ward Allen sought her second bid to become District 6 Oakland city councilperson. Her candidacy was endorsed by Oakland city councilmen Larry Reid and Dick Spees. After having campaigned aggressively on the trail a second time, she lost to  Moses Mayne by 129 votes in a hotly contested .\n\n\n\n\nWard Allen was first elected by voters to serve on the  on November 3, 1998, which is a  body that governs the  system in the California counties of , , and . Ward Allen represented the 4th district in Alameda County, which included the cities of  and . She was re-elected in 2002 and 2006 running unopposed.\n\nDuring Ward Allen's tenure she changed policies, procedures, operations, and reformed the  with assistance from the  and members of the general public under her watch.\n\nIn addition, she advocated for the hiring of  as the first female to serve as  or  of the entire BART organization. Although, Ward Allen originally supported the hiring of an African American female, Beverly Scott of the  to become general manager, she had to .\n\nWard Allen constantly reinforced  policy-making, which resulted in  and livable communities for residents in the , , and  districts. She supported minority-and-women-owned businesses stay afloat economically, and generated employment opportunities for her constituents.\n\nWard Allen's greatest  achievements were passing  to build the controversial  project, and advocating for civilian oversight of the . She called on the  to assist the BART Board, according to the '''', stating:\n\n\nAdditionally, she served as  in 2005 and  in 2006 of the BART board of directors, managing a budget of $672 million for the transportation agency.\n\n\n, (Center) Ward Allen, James Fang, and  at the groundbreaking of the  in 2010.]]\n\n\n\nSince 1998, Ward Allen fought vigorously for the creation of contracting opportunities for small minority-and-women-owned businesses. Providing  opportunities to Oakland and Alameda residents was her main source of motivation in . Therefore, she often collaborated with the local s to facilitate the creation of job opportunities to put people back to work and provide  relief to , especially  in the wake of the . For example, the   project generated approximately 2,500 to 5,200 direct and indirect jobs. Ward Allen actively sponsored many of BART's historic measures such as its first  with zip-code-priority to disadvantaged communities in her district and formulated the first small business and bonding committee to help mitigate economic disparities disproportionately impacting minority-owned businesses.\n\nOn October 20, 2010, BART director Ward Allen had a ground breaking event on the project at the  and was joined by , , , Oakland city councilman Larry Reid,  officials, representatives of local unions and s on its announcement to the public. The high-tech and environmentally friendly 3.2-mile automated Oakland Airport Connector began operating in November 2014.\n\n\nAs chairwoman of the Oakland Airport Connector Committee, she has solicited the input from diverse communities (such as non-English speaking and low-income), in the aftermath of a civil rights complaint against the construction of the . She was the first BART director to demand that signage and documentation needed to be multi-lingual; to serve her communities, but to ensure diverse populations understand how to evacuate train stations in the circumstance of an emergency. This need was especially a priority to  and Fruitvale districts given the predominantly Asian and Latino populations. Furthermore, she made sure there were live translators available for the first time in BART's history during community and townhall meetings in 2009.\n\n\n\n\n\nOn July 15, 2010,  signed the historic BART Accountability Act AB 1586 into , which Ward Allen urged the  to adopt during a Senate hearing on June 15, 2010. She worked closely with , who authored the legislation, to enforce civilian oversight of the BART Police Department. Ward Allen thanked the governor, the community, the entire BART organization and Assemblyman Swanson for their hard work on getting AB 1586 bill implemented in the aftermath of the . The law also created the Office of the Independent Auditor at BART, which would investigate matters brought to the BART Board by the civilian oversight committee.\n\nIn addition to changing , Ward Allen supported the family of Oscar Grant by being the only BART director who attended the Oscar Grant trial on the nine-member board in  during the summer of 2010. Earlier, in the same year, she was one of the keynote speakers at the inaugural vigil; honoring the life of  and supporting his family at the . In her speech, she apologized again on the behalf of BART for his tragic death, and gave Grant's uncle Cephus Johnson a bouquet of flowers for the family. The events leading up to Grant's death were chronicled in the film '''', in which  starred as Grant. The Fruitvale station was in Ward Allen's district.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2009, the hiring of two independent organizations reviewed BART's  and procedures in the process of reforming the . The two independent firms, included the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement and Myers Nave who were responsible for investigating the matters of  and were charged with making recommendations to the board. Ward Allen acknowledged that the BART Police Department needed to be reformed and restructured. She told the public at its first board meeting after the shooting that: \n}}\n\nThereafter, Ward Allen formulated and chaired BART's first Police Department Review Committee, and as a result, BART made sweeping changes on many  measures, as well as corrected and implemented several policies and procedures. BART Police Department Review Committee has led to the re-training of all officers on ,  re-training and other issues. Ward Allen hired Kenton Rainey, the person selected to lead BART's 296-member police force, to take command as .\n\n\n\n\n\n, David Hinson, and Ward Allen (far right) finishing a business meeting with U.S. Department of Commerce.]]\nOn May 25, 2005, then-Vice President Ward Allen of the BART board of directors joined Oakland Mayor , city councilman Larry Reid, CCJPA vice chair Forrest Williams, and Caltrans Division of Rail Chief Bill Bronte at the grand opening of the Oakland Coliseum Intercity Rail Station. She was a proponent of the $6.6 million facility being built to provide other modes of public transportation to citizens of Oakland and the Bay Area. Ward Allen served on the  board of directors for several years during the early 2000s.\n\n\n\nWard Allen's efforts toward cultivating a more eco-friendly and green  for BART resulted in the largest BART bicycle station being created as a part of the Fruitvale . The Fruitvale transit village is a national model for , given Ward Allen and former BART director Margaret Pryor's leadership. The Fruitvale transit village was built in partnership with the Spanish Speaking Unity Council, and Phase I was completed in 2004. Phase I included 94 rental units, 92 of which were affordable households that were considered low income, and 2 market-rate units. This was a significant victory for 's 4th district residents in the . On July 22, 2010, Ward Allen and the BART Board approved 3.4 acres of property that remained undeveloped for Phase II of the transit village.\n\nIn addition, she worked hard on the Coliseum transit village for more than a decade and approved its construction of single-family for-sale homes  with some set aside for low- and moderate-income residents  as well as shops and restaurants. Ward Allen worked closely with Oakland city councilman Larry Reid to approve the third stage of the transit village project, which would explore building approximately 100 workforce housing units on what is now a 1.3-acre parking lot at Snell Street and 71st Avenue in their shared district.\n\n\nIn 2009, Ward Allen formulated BART's first Small/Minority/Women-Owned Business and Bonding Committee. The committee sought to address the critical problems that are preventing minority-and-women-owned construction  from receiving adequate information in a timely fashion, making plan rooms available to low-income communities, expediting the response time of all allocations and qualifying for contracts. Ward Allen advocated that the BART Board should earmark a part of the  to support   enterprises, resulting in BART injecting up to $45 million between 2009 and 2014 into the  with much of that money going to minority- and women-owned businesses.\n\n\n\nIn March 2011, Ward Allen was inducted into the  in the category of . She has taught over 100,000 students in the , according to ''''. Many students have indicated that she made  a fundamental difference in their lives and inspired them to seek out knowledge.\n\nThe ''Conference of Minority Transportation Officials'' (COMTO) presented Ward Allen with the  at its annual awards ceremony in 2011 for her dedication to  in the , and recognizing her achievement of breaking ground on the , a landmark construction project legislated by Ward Allen.\n\nIn 2008,  President Frank Chong recognized Ward Allen for her leadership in  with the President's Award.\n\nIn 2005, she received recognition for her  as a groundbreaking  of  with the  San Francisco Bay Area chapter's  Pioneer Award at the ''7th Annual  Business and Community Recognition Awards Luncheon''. At the time, Ward Allen was the  of .\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Evan Low''' (born June 5, 1983) is an American  currently serving in the . He is a  representing the , which encompasses parts of , including , ,  and portions of northern and western . He is a member of the  (and served as chair from 2017 to 2018 and 2021 to 2022), and currently serves as Chair of the California Asian American & Pacific Islander Legislative Caucus.\n\nPrior to his election in the Assembly in 2014, Low served as  and City Councilmember in . On January 15, 2020, Low was named national co-chair of 's .\n\n\nLow was born in , on June 5, 1983, to   Arthur Low. Low grew up in San Jose and attended . In 2003, Low moved to neighboring Campbell.\n\nLow earned an  from  in , and a  in political science from .\n\n\nIn 2004, Low unsuccessfully ran for a seat on the City Council, but he ran again in 2006 and won in his second attempt. Low worked as a senior district representative for California's former 28th State Assembly district Assemblymember .\n\nWhen his colleagues selected him to become Campbell mayor in 2009, Low became the youngest openly gay, Asian American mayor in the nation.\n\nIn 2013, his colleagues on the Campbell City Council selected him to serve as mayor for a second time. His term on the council expired in 2014.\n\n\nIn 2014,   appointed Low as Assistant Majority Whip. Low was kept in the same leadership role by Atkins's successor, Speaker , in 2016.\n\nLow chaired the California Assembly Business and Professions Committee from March 2016 until November 2021, when he was removed without explanation by Speaker Anthony Rendon. Low was replaced by .\n\nLow is a co-founder and co-chair of the California Legislative Tech Caucus. There are 24 members of the Tech Caucus.\n\nIn 2014, Low supported , an initiative that would have asked voters to consider eliminating 's ban on the use of , , , , or  in recruitment, admissions, and retention programs at  and colleges. Proposition 209 also effectively banned affirmative action in the public contracting and employment. Low supported a similar effort to repeal Prop 209 in its entirety with  in 2020. In 2023, Low also supported , a narrower effort \"that would allow state agencies to consider race if academic research shows evidence those race-based programs could work.\"\n\nIn 2016, Low introduced AB 1887 that would ban all California state-funded travel to states that enacted laws to discriminate against individuals based upon , , and , that was supported by   . The  was replaced in 2023 with an advertising campaign.\n\nIn 2016, '''' identified Low as a potential United States presidential candidate in 2024 along with nine other young Democrats who, like Obama, have unusual ambition.\n\nIn the 2017–2018 session, '''' identified Low as California's most prolific lawmaker, where he had the most bills signed by any member of the state legislature by Governor Jerry Brown. He has also been credited with driving the future of Uber and Lyft in the California State Legislature.\n\nIn 2019, Low introduced AB-57, which would allow candidates with birth names in character-based languagessuch as Chinese, Japanese, and Koreanto use those names in voter requested translated ballots. Previously, candidates such as  have had  versions of their name (e.g. Fei O Na Ma) appear on translated ballots. The bill also required candidates without character based birth names to phonetically translate their names on translated ballots, unless they prove that they are known under a different name within the target community. AB-57 was signed into law by Governor Gavin Newsom in July 2019 and went into effect in 2020.\n\nIn 2023 in SB 815, language added by Low in AB 2098, was removed from California Law due to concerns it was unconstitutional being tested in Court.  Judge  prevented any doctors from being punished during the one year the \"anti-misinformation\" language was on the books.\n\nIn 2023, Low announced that he would be running for Congress in . It is currently represented by Representative , who announced that she would be retiring after the 2024 election.\n\n\n\nIn December 2023, Low announced his intention to run for , which was held by retiring incumbent . After the primary in March 2024, Low and   repeatedly traded the second-place position multiple times during the vote count. By April 3, 2024, both Low and Simitian tied with 30,249 votes each and were expected to advance to the general election under a stipulation by California elections code regarding a second-place tie in primary elections. Both campaigns released statements indicating that they intended to compete in the general election.\n\nHowever, after a poll believed to be conducted on behalf of supporters of first-placed  testing two-way match-ups was fielded, two residents of the district, including former Liccardo campaign finance director and current donor Jonathan Padilla, requested a recount; Liccardo himself was ineligible to do so because he does not live in the district. Liccardo's campaign denied responsibility, though they agreed the recount was necessary, saying \"every vote should be counted.\"\n\nAt the conclusion of the recount, Simitian was ultimately eliminated and Low advanced to the general election by a 5-vote margin.\n\nIn October 2024, good-government group Defend the Vote filed an FEC complaint against Low, alleging that he had spent nearly $600,000 from his state campaign account on ads that were distributed across the congressional district. Defend the Vote argued that the move violated federal campaign finance laws, as state campaigns can accept higher individual contributions than federal campaigns, and can receive political action committee and corporation donations directly.\n\nIn wake of the expenditures, an attorney for Liccardo sent cease and desist letters to five TV stations that broadcast the ads. The Mercury News Editorial Board reaffirmed their endorsement of Liccardo, criticizing Low for “putting political self-interest ahead of campaign integrity.”\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting added Campbell to Assemblymember 's district, Low announced he would run in the new  spanning , , and .\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n  issued a proclamation naming June 5, 2006, \"Evan Low Day\" in the City and County of San Francisco.\n\nAssemblymember Low has been named \"Legislator of the Year\" by the , TechNet, The Computing Technology Industry Association, California Faculty Association, Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association, California District Attorneys Association and Faculty Association of California Community Colleges.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Alan Stuart Lowenthal''' (; born March 8, 1941) is an American politician who served as the  for  from 2013 to 2023. A member of the , he served as the man for the  from 1998 to 2004 and  from the  from 2004 to 2012. In both posts, Lowenthal represented the city of  and its surrounding suburbs. On December 16, 2021, Lowenthal announced that he would not seek reelection to Congress.\n\n\nLowenthal was born and raised in , . His family is Jewish. He was graduated with a B.A. from  and earned a Ph.D. from . In 1969, Lowenthal moved to  and became a professor of  at . He went on leave to become a Long Beach City Councilman in 1992. He remained on leave for several years until retiring in 1998.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1998, Lowenthal decided to run for the  of the . He defeated Republican nominee Julie Alban 50%-47%. In 2000, he was reelected, defeating Republican nominee , a  member, 59%-39%. In 2002, he was reelected to a third term, defeating Republican nominee Cesar Castellanos, 60%-40%.\n\n\nIn the Assembly, Lowenthal authored gun control legislation that would ban gun selling in people's homes. He was also a founding member of the Assembly's Bipartisan Caucus and authored legislation for the creation of California's first ever .\n\nIn 2002, the California Firefighters Association named Lowenthal Legislator of the Year by after he passed a law that limited liability for organizations that donated firefighting equipment. The  named him Legislator of the Year in 2001 due to his advocacy on behalf of local governments. He has also received the \"Rivie\" Award from the Friends of the Los Angeles River due to his efforts to help clean up the river.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2004, Lowenthal ran for the  in the . He won the Democratic primary unopposed. In the general election, he defeated Republican nominee Cesar Navarro Castellanos 63%-37%. In 2008, he was reelected, defeating Allen Wood 67%-33%.\n\n\n\nThe 47th district includes the  communities of , , Signal Hill, , , , , , , , , , Florence-Graham and . It also extends to the western  cities of , , , , , and , and includes .\n\nLegislation that Lowenthal had signed into law include a law to reduce diesel emissions at the ports by limiting idling time for trucks conducting transactions at the ports, a bill that established a grant program to provide financial incentives for purchasing or leasing electric vehicles, and a bill to protect highways.\n\nWith Bonnie Lowenthal's election to the Assembly and Alan Lowenthal's reelection in 2008, Senator and Assemblywoman Lowenthal were the first divorced husband and wife to serve concurrently in the .\n\nLowenthal provided significant commentary throughout the documentary ''''.\n\n\n*Senate Committee Education (chair)\n*Select Committee on California Ports and Goods Movement\n*Select Committee on High-Speed Rail (chair)\n*Senate Environmental Quality Committee\n\n\n\n\n\nOn November 6, 2012, Lowenthal was elected to the  from the newly created  after defeating Republican . DeLong carried the  portion of the district with 54% of the vote, but Lowenthal swamped him in the  portion by over 38,000 votes, more than the overall margin of 30,100. He took office on January 3, 2013. Lowenthal is the first non-Hispanic Democrat to represent a significant portion of traditionally heavily Republican Orange County in Congress since , who served from 1975 to 1985. He was reelected in 2014, 2016 and 2018 by similar margins.\n\nUntil the Democrats swept every seat in Orange County at the 2018 elections, Lowenthal was the only elected white Democrat above the county level in much of the Orange County portion of the district. But the Los Angeles County portion has more than double the population of the Orange County portion; the district's share of Long Beach alone accounts for over half of its population.\n\nLowenthal is a member of the .\n\n\nLowenthal is a strong supporter of . He said that the \"historical denial about the right of Jewish people to have their own homeland\" and the  \"refusal to acknowledge Israel as a Jewish state, that is a critical issue that needs to be addressed.\"\n\nLowenthal has been critical of 's president . In March 2019 he and 29 other Democratic lawmakers wrote Secretary of State  a letter that read in part, \"Since the election of far-right candidate Jair Bolsonaro as president, we have been particularly alarmed by the threat Bolsonaro’s agenda poses to the LGBTQ+ community and other minority communities, women, labor activists, and political dissidents in Brazil.\"\n\n\n*\n**\n**\n**\n*\n**\n**\n**\n\n\n* \n*\n*\n*\n*.\n*\n*\n* House Pro-Choice Caucus\n\n\nOn December 16, 2021, Lowenthal announced that he would retire from the U.S. House at the end of his term on January 3, 2023.\n\n\n\nAs of 2020, Lowenthal has a 100% rating from  and an F rating from the  for his abortion-related voting record. He opposed the , calling it \"devastating to every American woman who has, with the stroke of a pen, had their rights curtailed and their status as free and equal citizens abridged.\"  Noted for his work on environmental issues, among other things he has supported banning the use of hydrofluoric acid (HF) at oil refineries.\n\n\nLowenthal is married to Deborah Malumed. His son, Daniel, is a judge on the Los Angeles County Superior Court. His other son, , ran for  in 2018 in the , which was being vacated by , but lost to . Josh has since been elected in the .\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Tri Ta''' (born April 10, 1973) is a  politician currently serving as a member of the . He represents Assembly District 70, which consists of much of the  area of northwestern . He previously served as Mayor of .\n\n\nTa was born in Saigon in  (now ). In 1992, he and his parents immigrated to the United States as refugees. Ta was 19 at the time.\n\n\nTa served as a city councilor in Westminster before being elected mayor. He became mayor in 2012 and was the city's first Vietnamese-American mayor. Ta was reelected in 2018. He is a Republican and has advocated for the Republican Party to take a greater interest in Vietnamese voters. Vietnamese Americans traditionally voted Republicans, but Democrats have made gains recently, especially in Orange County.\n\nIn 2019, Ta attracted publicity for clashing with other members of Westminster's city council. He and fellow council members Kimberly Ho and Chi Charlie Nguyen frequently sparred with the remaining members. Notably, they passed a controversial resolution alleging that the Vietnamese government was improperly interfering in city politics. This dispute culminated in the three voting to change the council's procedures over the objections of other members. Opponents of the three councilors filed for a recall election in response. In April 2020, Ta and his allies survived the recall attempt.\n\nIn January 2022, Ta announced his intention to run for election to the  in district 70, which was being vacated by incumbent . He placed second in the top-two primary in June and faced  woman Diedre Thu-Ha Nguyen in the November general election. That same year, a council dispute over renewing Westminster's sales tax placed the city at risk of bankruptcy. Ta was also censured for false statements he made about other councilors.\n\nIn November 2022, Ta won the election to the California State Assembly. He took office in December.\n\nHe has supported  as  in the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Andreas Borgeas''' (born March 7, 1974) is an American attorney, politician, and academic who served as a member of the  from the , which included parts of the  and the . Prior to being elected to the state Senate, he was a member of the  Board of Supervisors. He represented all or portions of Amador, Calaveras, Fresno, Inyo, Madera, Mariposa, Mono, Sacramento, Stanislaus, Tulare, and Tuolumne counties.\n\n\nBorgeas is a native of . He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science from , a  from , and a PhD in international affairs from . He conducted his PhD field research in, and published extensively on, China and the neighboring Central Asian republics.\n\n\n\nBorgeas conducted his PhD field research in, and published extensively on, China and the neighboring Central Asian Republics, receiving his graduate education at ,  and  () of Political Sciences. After graduating, Borgeas was a  for Judge  of the . Borgeas then practiced law at Luce Forward. For over a decade he has been a professor in the fields of international law and security affairs at the  in  and is an adjunct professor at the .\n\nAs an educator, he has worked in numerous international professional and academic capacities; including, as a Fulbright Scholar, Contributing Fellow for the Woodrow Wilson Center, Policy Specialist Fellow at the U.S. Embassy in  and was appointed by House Minority Leader  as commissioner on the .\n\n\nIn 2008, Borgeas started his political career by running successfully for the . In 2012, Borgeas was elected to the  Board of Supervisors; he was re-elected in 2016.\n\n\n\nIn November 2018, Borgeas was elected as a Republican to the , representing the 8th district. Borgeas defeated  Paulina Miranda with 59.6% of the votes.\n\nBorgeas serves as chair of the Senate Agriculture Committee and vice chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee.\n\nOn January 11, 2022, Borgeas announced he would not seek a second term in the state Senate.\n\n\nIn October 2019, Borgeas was invited by President  to witness the signing of two executive orders at the .\n\n\n\nAfter incumbent Congressman  announced that he would resign from  to become CEO of the , Borgeas formed an exploratory committee to consider a campaign for the seat.\n\nOn January 6, 2022, Borgeas announced that he was suspending his campaign for the .\n\n\n\nBorgeas has been lauded for his bipartisan leadership when it comes to addressing regional issues on numerous occasions. The Fresno Bee has acknowledged Borgeas' objective and deft handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. Borgeas also successfully spearheaded, with his Democratic colleague, , a bipartisan effort to deliver $2.6&nbsp;billion to small businesses impacted by COVID-19.\n\nBorgeas has been praised by ''The Modesto Bee'', ''The Fresno Bee'', and ''The Sacramento Bee'' for being one of the few Republicans to condemn the . The Sacramento Bee noted: \"...state Sen. Andreas Borgeas, R-Fresno, who is apparently the only one of California’s nine Republican state senators willing to directly say the truth.\"\n\n\nBorgeas has been a staunch advocate for California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) reform. In an op-ed Borgeas stated \"...CEQA has morphed into a legal weapon for lawyers and activist groups to stall essential projects...\" and narrowly passed Senate Bill 659 through the Senate Judiciary Committee.\n\n\n\nBorgeas has been an opponent of , passed by Assemblywoman  in 2019. In a tweet, Borgeas claimed AB 5 \"...limit[s] an individual's ability for flexible employment and destroys entire industries across California. Independent contractors and small businesses are the backbone of a thriving California economy.\" He organized a town hall at Clovis Community College to discuss the bill's impact on freelancers and independent contractors.\n\n\nBorgeas has advocated for state and federal support to improve the , which is critical for water delivery to the agricultural industry in the San Joaquin Valley. Senate Bill 559 introduced by state Senator  would have allocated $400&nbsp;million in state funding to make necessary repairs to the canal as a result of subsidence from groundwater overdraft.\n\nBorgeas has also vocalized support for the federal government's plan to increase water deliveries to California farmers. During then-President Donald Trump's visit to the San Joaquin Valley in February 2020, Borgeas stated,\"The ball is now in Governor Newsom's court to provide clean, reliable and ample water supplies to Valley farmers and communities. The state must ensure that infrastructure and storage are a top priority. It's simple: no water, no farms, and no food.\"\n\n\nBorgeas has received high marks from the  and the .\n\n\nBorgeas and his wife, Anna, have two sons. Borgeas and his family live in . Borgeas has said growing up in  helped shape his political views at an early age. Borgeas is known to be heavily involved in Fresno's Greek and Armenian communities. He is also known for his involvement with the Fresno Greek Fest and as an advocate for the recognition of the .\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kansen Chu''' ( born October 27, 1952) is a Taiwanese-born American politician. A , Chu was a member of the  from 2014 to 2020, for the , which encompasses parts of the  and  regions of the .\n\nIn 2019, Chu announced that he would not seek reelection for State Assembly in 2020, instead running for the . He lost to Otto Lee in the general election.\n\nOn February 10, 2021, Chu was appointed to the  Board of Trustees to fill a vacant seat. His current term ends in 2022.\n\nChu ran for the  seat in the redrawn , but was defeated in the primary by incumbent .\n\nIn the 2024 election, Chu is running for 4th district of the San Jose City Council on which he previously served as councilmember from 2007 to 2014.\n\n\nIn 1952, Chu was born in , Taiwan.\n\n\nChu earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering from . Chu earned a master's degree in Electrical Engineering from .\n\n\nIn 1978, Chu became a microdiagnostics microprogrammer at IBM, where he worked for 18 years. In 1989, Chu became an owner of a Chinese restaurant, until 2007.\n\nIn 2002, Chu began his political career as a member of  board of education.\n\nPrior to being elected to the Assembly in 2014, Chu was a  City Councilmember representing District 4. He is a member of the California Asian & Pacific Islander Legislative Caucus. He was the first  elected to the San Jose City Council.\n\n\nIn 2000, Chu was defeated by  for the District 4 council seat.\n\nIn his first year on the council (2007), Chu initiated landmark legislation to require citywide green building standards, ban the use of plastic bags, and mandate the installation of automatic heart defibrillators across San Jose.\n\n\nIn 2002, Chu was elected to the  Union School Board.  As a school board member, he championed stronger curricula, better education materials, and improved public access to school board meetings.\n\nChu has served on the Berryessa Union School Board for 5 years, Santa Clara Valley Metro YMCA, Vietnamese Voluntary Foundation, Shin Shin Education Foundation, and Advisory Board of Californians for Justice.  Kansen has also served on the Santa Clara County Mental Health Board, Private Industry Council under Job Training Partnership Act, Neighborhood Accountability Board of Berryessa, the KNTV Channel 11 Community Board, Asian Law Alliance, and many other advisory commissions and boards.   He continues to serve on the board of Vision New America, dedicated to advancing youth involvement in civics and government.\n\n\nOn May 13, 2019, Chu announced that he would be a candidate for the  Board of Supervisors in 2020.  He will not be seeking reelection to the Assembly.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1976, Chu moved to the United States. \nChu's wife is Daisy Chu. They have two children. Chu and his family live in San Jose, California.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''William Wheeler Monning''' (born April 2, 1951) is an American politician who was elected to the  in 2012. A , he served in the  which encompasses the . Monning was reelected to the Senate in 2016 for a second and final term ending in November, 2020. Education, the environment and public health are areas of particular interest to Monning.\n\nBefore his election to the State Senate in 2012, Monning served in the , representing the .\n\n\n\nBill Monning was born and raised in Southern California. He attended  from fifth to twelfth grade and participated in athletics including football, basketball, baseball and swimming. His college years were spent in the San Francisco Bay Area where he attended the  from 1969 to 1972 and the  from 1973 to 1976. During this time he also did volunteer work for the  legal department and participated in marches and other activities with farm workers' movements in ,  and , meeting other activists including Jerry Cohen,  and . These experiences with the UFW were influential, \"working with the legal department as a volunteer . . . really solidified my interest and purpose in attending law school.\"\n\nMonning received a  at the University of California, Berkeley and a  degree from the University of San Francisco School of Law. He served as a Senior Fulbright Specialist, receiving  scholarships to teach and research in Peru and Chile. Additionally, he was a member of the  Court-directed mediation panel and served for four years as executive director of the  winning organization, .\n\n\n\nAfter entering the , Monning first worked as a staff attorney for the ,  (1976–1978). He then became Directing Attorney for , Migrant Farm Worker Project (1978–1982). From 1982 through 1987 Monning was the Director of the Salvadoran Medical Relief Fund, and from 1987 through 1991 he was executive director for the International Physicians for the Prevention of Nuclear War (IPPNW). From 1993 until his election to the State Assembly in 2008 he worked in private practice (Labor and Employment law) and taught at both the  (currently Middlebury Institute of International Studies) as professor of International Negotiation and Conflict Resolution and as a professor at the . Monning is also the former president and co-founder of Global Majority, Inc.\n\n\n\n}}\n\nIn 2008 Bill Monning ran for and won the California State District 27 Assembly seat being vacated by termed out . When asked in an interview with the  about why he decided to run for the Assembly in 2008, Monning cited California's structural budget limitations saying California was, \"only one of three states in the union that require a 2/3 vote in both houses to pass a budget.\" This limitation made it difficult to secure adequate funding for such needs as healthcare and education. Monning hoped to work with community groups and other legislators to effect reform in this and other areas including electoral, campaign finance and economic justice.\n\nIn 2012 Monning was elected to the California State Senate after the incumbent, , R-San Luis Obispo, chose not to run in the newly drawn 17th Senate district. Monning became Senate Majority leader in 2014 when he was appointed by then State Senate  , D-Los Angeles. Monning was reelected to the Senate in 2016 for a second and final term.\n\nIn 2016 Monning seriously considered running to fill the seat being vacated by retiring Congressmen  but felt he could be more effective in working on climate policy and other important issues as a leader in Sacramento as opposed to being a member of the minority party in Washington.\n\nMonning served as Majority Leader of the California State Senate from 2015 to 2019. In 2019 California Senate President pro tempore  appointed Monning to the  and designated him as California State Senate Majority Leader Emeritus.\n\nHe termed-out at the end of his eight years in the State Senate on November 30, 2020. He remains an active member of the  and does work as a mediator, trainer, and consultant.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMonning, Hsla-Coron, Cohen and Mason 2017.jpg|Bill Monning, Mary Hsla-Coron, Jerry Cohen and  - panel discussion  \"What can we learn from 1960's activism to inform today's resistance movements?\"\nMonning with Book.jpg|Monning with book - ''Vision for a Healthy California''\nBill Monning March for Science 2017.webm|Bill Monning  2017 Monterey, CA\nBill Monning on Climate Change.webm|Recorded at a peace rally in Carmel, CA 2017\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn February 22, 2013, he introduced SB 622, which would impose a 12 cent tax on each can of soda, as well as create the Children's Health Promotion Fund, which would direct the money the tax raised to childhood obesity-preventing measures such as improving the quality of school lunches. About three months later, the bill died in committee.\n\n\n\nMonning authored a bill to protect California farm workers from sexual harassment and violence. Signed by Governor  on September 28, 2014, SB 1087 followed a 2013 investigation by , UC Berkeley's Investigative Reporting Program FRONTLINE, and the . The investigation found that hundreds of female agriculture workers said they had been harassed and assaulted in the fields with minimal response from their supervisors or from law enforcement. The law took effect on January 1, 2015. \"Female farmworkers are among the most vulnerable and invisible of the state's farm worker population,\" said Monning. \"[SB 1087] will require sexual harassment prevention training for farm labor contractors, supervisors, and employees, and is the first step to help protect these workers from unwanted sexual advances and sexual violence.\"\n\nSenator Monning successfully authored another bill, SB 168 in 2013, to help agricultural workers get back wages and penalties owed by state-licensed farm labor contractors. According to Monning, some California contractors had fraudulently dissolved and moved their assets to new corporations, leaving farm workers without anyone to file a claim against. \"This measure is modeled after previous legislation in the garment manufacturing and car wash industries to address fraudulent successor business scams,\"  said Monning  \"The workers most affected and victimized by such unscrupulous practices are farm workers.\"\n\n\n\nIn 2015 Monning co-sponsored, with  (D-Davis), SB 128, the . The bill was modeled after Oregon's . The law authorizes adults with six months or less to live to request a doctor's prescription for life-ending medication.  It passed the California Senate easily, but stalled in the Assembly. In a legislative session in September dedicated to healthcare, several amendments were introduced, and eventually the bill passed in the Assembly 42–33, and the Senate 23-14 It was co-authored by Assembly Member  (D-Stockton). California governor  signed the California End of Life Option Act on October 5, 2015, and it went into effect on June 9, 2016. California thus became the fifth state to pass a Death With Dignity law. In a 2018 interview with the ''Monterey County Weekly'' Monning claimed that the End of Life Option Act was \"one of his greatest legislative achievements\". He was very moved by the testimony of terminally ill people in Sacramento, \"They knew that they weren't going to be able to benefit from it (the Act), and yet they still came, facing their terminal conditions, making sure that those who followed them would have options that they didn't have\".\n\n\n\nSenator Monning believes climate change is the largest long-term threat to humanity and that it will also negatively affect public health and coastal communities. In the 2015–2016 legislative session Senator Monning co-authored Senate Bill 350, the Clean Energy and Pollution Reduction Act of 2015. This complex bill was intended to increase the state's energy efficiency, reduce petroleum use in vehicles and set new standards for California's  (RPS). Under this bill the state of California would be required to generate half of its electricity from renewable sources by 2030. The bill was signed by Governor Jerry Brown October 7, 2015. Other sponsors of the bill were primary sponsor Senator Kevin de León, Senator , Senator , Assemblyman  and Assemblyman .\n\n\n\nMonning authored the Safe, Clean, Affordable Drinking Water Act of 2019 (SB 200) making available $1.3 billion over ten years in funding for community projects though . The bill was signed into law in July 2019, making some 300 community with limited access to clean water eligible for funding to help them build or maintain new wells and water treatment facilities.\n\n\n\nHe and his wife, Dana T. Kent, a family physician, reside in Carmel, California. They have two daughters and three grandchildren.\n\n\n* ''Vision for a Healthy California'', Foreword by , Gui Mundo Publishing Company, 2010, \n* ''Voices of Change: The People's Oral History Project Interviews with Monterey County Activists and Organizers 1934–2015'', Author Gary Karnes, foreword by Senator Bill Monning, Co-authors Karen Araujo and Juan Martinez, Park Place Publications, January 15, 2016, \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Steven Seokho Choi''' (; born January 15, 1944) is an American  who served as a member of the  representing the  from 2016 to 2022. A  from , he previously served two terms as  of .  In 1998, he became the first Asian-American elected to the Irvine Unified School Board and served two consecutive terms there before becoming the first  to have been elected to a four-year term on the  and one of two s on the council.\n\n\nSteven Choi was born in 1944 in , ,  (now in South Korea). Choi earned his  from  in 1966. In August 1968, Choi moved from South Korea to the United States as a  language instructor for the . He then continued his post-graduate education, earning his  in  from  in 1971 and  in library and information science at the  in 1976.\n\n\n\nChoi has taught at several universities and colleges including the ; ; ; ; ; and most recently . He founded and serves as director of Dr. Choi's Academy, a tutoring and academic enrichment business.\n\n\nChoi was elected to the   in 1998 and reelected in 2002.  He was elected to the   in 2004, becoming the first  elected to a four-year term on the council. He and  (elected to a two-year term on the same day) became the first two s and Koreans elected to the Irvine City Council.  Choi served on the Irvine City Council until 2012, when he defeated councilman  in  and was elected to a two-year term as Irvine's mayor. He was later reelected as mayor .\n\nThe Irvine City Council is composed of 5 people, including the mayor.  The council has 4  members (Choi, Christina Shea, Lynn Schott, and Jeff Lalloway) and 1  member (Beth Krom).  Choi is a part of the  council majority, and has been able to promote programs he supports and stop policies he opposes from being enacted. During the course of new sister city negotiations, he successfully opposed the  demanded by 's  government in the , which would have required Irvine to abandon its existing long-term sister city relationship with , .\n\nChoi serves as Chairman of the   Advisory Board, which consists of Mayors and Council members from 27 Orange County cities, and is also Chairman of the Irvine Library Advisory Committee. He serves on the  Corporation Board, the Irvine Redevelopment Agency, the Orange County Sanitation District Board and other countywide committees. His vision is to build a large Orange County/City Metropolitan Library at the Great Park.\n\nIn addition, Choi is a member of the  President's Advisory Council and is Irvine's representative to Growth Management Areas 4 and 9 and the Newport Bay Watershed Executive Committee. He formerly represented the 71st Assembly District on the Orange County  Central Committee. On June 3, 2008, he became the only incumbent to not be re-elected to the Orange County  Central Committee, coming in seventh with only 6.5% of the available vote.  He is also a member of the Local Elected Officials Association and the 400 Club.\n\nIn 2010, Choi sought election to the , but narrowly lost the Republican primary to , who went on to win the general election.\n\nIn 2016, Choi won election to the California State Assembly, narrowly defeating    in the primary and winning the general election with 60% of the vote.\n\n\nWith his wife, Janie, and their two children, Choi has lived in  since 1993. He previously lived in  from 1981 until 1993. Both of their children attended public schools in the . His son, Daniel, is a physician at  in Orange County. His daughter, Michelle, is an attorney working in Irvine.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  – Official campaign web site\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Imelda G. Padilla''' (born 1987) is an American politician who is currently a member of the  representing the  since 2023. She had previously ran for the 's Board of Education for the 6th district, losing to  in the runoff election.\n\nElected in the  to replace , Padilla previously worked as a community relations manager.\n\n\nPadilla was born in 1987 in  and raised in , a first-generation  with her father being a gardener and her mother working at an airplane factory. One of several children, Padilla has stated that she had followed her older sisters towards doing community service. She attended , with her sisters introducing her to the L.A. City Youth Council when she was in ninth grade. While attending public schools, she had  and was bullied by other kids. She then attended and graduated from  with a , later graduating from  with a . She worked on engagement for the L.A. County’s Women and Girls Initiative, , and Pacoima Beautiful, as well as being a field deputy for councilmember .\n\n\n\nIn 2016, Padilla announced that she would be running for LAUSD's Board of Education for the 6th district, which was being vacated by Monica Ratliff's run for City Council, stating that various people had come to her asking her to run. She was backed by  and other unions. In the primary election, she was behind , a schoolteacher who was backed by the California Charter School Association, and they went into a runoff.     "pages": }\n'''Juan Carlos Vargas''' (born March 7, 1961) is an American businessman and politician who has been a  for  since 2013. His district includes the southernmost portions of .\n\nVargas previously served as a  member in the  representing the 40th district, the  representing the 79th district, and the .\n\n\nVargas was born on a chicken ranch in , where he grew up very poor. He is the third of ten children of Tomas and Celina Vargas, who immigrated to the United States from  in the late 1940s as part of the . Vargas graduated  with a BA from the  and earned an MA in humanities from .\n\nAfter college, Vargas joined the  Novitiate in . In the Jesuits, Vargas served in an orphanage in El Salvador's civil-war-torn jungles. After leaving the Jesuits, he attended law school, graduating in 1991 with a  from .\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1992, Vargas ran in the newly created , based in . He lost the  primary, ranking fourth with 19% of the vote.  won the primary with a plurality of 26% and went on to win the election.\n\n\nVargas served on the  from 1993 to 2000. While on the council, he created \"Operation Restore\" to employ homeless people to remove graffiti and to rehabilitate homes.\n\n\nIn 1996, Vargas challenged Filner in the Democratic primary. Vargas wouldn't debate Filner, so the incumbent instead sparred with a life-sized Vargas cardboard cutout. Vargas said he agreed with Filner on \"99 percent\" of issues. Filner defeated him 55%–45%.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2000, Vargas ran in . He defeated Republican Jon Parungao 77%–19%. In 2002, he defeated Republican Mark Fast 66%–30%. In 2004, he defeated Libertarian Eli Wallace Conroe 85%–15%.\n\n\nIn his first year in the Assembly, Vargas was appointed Assistant Majority Leader. He authored AB 188, legislation that bans smoking in children's playgrounds. He also introduced legislation aimed at protecting children from arcade video games, and authored legislation to mandate life sentences for people who commit violent sex crimes against children, which served as a model for Chelsea's Law.\n\n\n*Business and Professions\n*Insurance (chair)\n\n\n\nIn 2006, Vargas challenged Filner a third time, this time in . He accused Filner of being a part of the  of Washington, pointing out that Filner had paid his wife more than $500,000 in campaign funds for consulting services performed from their condominium in Washington. Filner argued that Vargas had controversial payments to his brother-in-law, who was a lobbyist for realtors. Filner defeated Vargas 51%–43%, with Danny Ramirez getting 6% of the vote.\n\n\nAfter leaving the State Assembly in 2006 due to term limits, Vargas took a job with a home, auto and small business insurance company, where he was tasked with creating jobs and outreach in diverse San Diego communities as part of the company's diversity initiative. He left that job at the end of 2009 to run as a Democratic candidate for the California State Senate.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2010, Vargas narrowly won a seat in the California's 40th State Senate district, defeating Assemblywoman  by 22 votes after recounts in San Diego and Riverside counties. He resigned from the Senate effective January 2, 2013, to take his seat in Congress. A special election to fill his seat was held in March 2013.\n\n\n;Standing committees\n*Banking & Financial Institutions (chair)\n*Agriculture\n*Business, Professions, and Economic Development\n*Education\n*Public Employment and Retirement\n\n;Subcommittee\n*Education: Sustainable School Facilities\n\n;Joint Committee\n*Rules\n\n;Select Committee\n*Recovery, Reform, and Re-Alignment\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2012, when Filner announced he would retire from Congress to run for , Vargas endorsed him despite their history of bitter rivalry. Vargas then ran for Filner's seat in the . In the open primary, he ranked first with 46% of the vote. Republican Michael Crimmins ranked second with 20%, Democratic state senator  third with 15%, and four other candidates received single-digit percentages. In November, he defeated Crimmins 71%–29%.\n\n\n\nIn 2019, Vargas spent $124,200 of campaign money on photography, printing, postage, mailing and shipping of holiday cards that he sent to constituents.\n\n\nVargas was sworn in on January 3, 2013. In 2015, he and his wife, Adrienne, spent five days in Berlin and , Germany. The trip was paid for by  and the  and cost $18,200. Part of Vargas's congressional work, the trip was to help him develop \"a greater understanding of the key legislative topics of the 114th Congress through our [Germany and the United States] transatlantic relationship.\" San Diego Reader |url=https://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2015/apr/30/ticker-juan-and-adriennes-bavarian-spring-break/ |access-date=22 November 2020 |work=San Diego Reader |date=30 April 2015 |language=en}}\n\nIn 2022, Vargas was one of 16 Democrats to vote against the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act of 2022, an antitrust package that would crack down on corporations for anti-competitive behavior.\n in , March 28, 2024]]\nHe voted in favor of a bill that provided an additional  to support  in the .\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n** \n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\nVargas has a 100% rating from  and an F rating from the  for his abortion-related voting record. He opposed the , calling it \"fundamentally wrong and extremely disappointing, impacting millions of women across the country.\"\n\nIn 2023, Vargas was among 56 Democrats to vote in favor of H.Con.Res. 21 which directed President  to remove U.S. troops from  within 180 days.\n\nVargas was among the 46 Democrats who voted against final passage of the  in the House.\n\n\n\nVargas and his wife, Adrienne, have two daughters.\n\nDuring the 1999  in , Vargas welcomed a Kosovar refugee family into his family's home for nearly two years.\n\nHe had a cameo in the 2023 movie ''''.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n* campaign website\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Burton received her  (J.D.) degree from the  in 1990.\n\n\nIn the 1990s, Burton worked in the .     "pages": }\n'''Michael Bonin''' (born March 19, 1967) is an American politician, who served as a member of the  for the  from 2013 to 2022. A  member of the , he was previously a reporter and a council staffer.\n\n\nBonin graduated from  in , , in 1985. His grandfather  was a state representative and a judge in the town of Clinton. His uncle  also served as a state representative.  He had a sister, Maureen, who died of cancer in 2010.\n\n\n in 2012.]]\nFrom 1989 to 1996 Bonin worked as a reporter at Springfield Newspapers in , and Wave Newspapers in .\n\n\nBonin began his political career in Los Angeles city politics in 1996, joining the staff of L.A. City Councilmember . During his seven years with Galanter he worked as a legislative deputy, district director, and deputy chief of staff. From 2003 to 2004 Bonin worked in the Office of Congresswoman  as deputy chief of staff and district director. In 2005 Bonin managed 's successful campaign for L.A. city council. Rosendahl subsequently appointed Bonin as his chief of staff.\n\nDuring the summer of 2012, Rosendahl announced he had been diagnosed with cancer, and in October announced he would not seek reelection. He endorsed Bonin. Bonin won the subsequent election with 61% of the vote. Bonin was re-elected on March 7, 2017, defeating Mark Ryavec and Robin Rudisill. Bonin won with 71% of votes cast supporting him.\n\n\nBonin was appointed Chair of the City Council's Transportation Committee, and serves as a member of the  Board of Directors\n\nOn September 4, 2013, Bonin and his colleague  introduced the Los Angeles Fracking Moratorium to the City Council. The motion, which instructed the City Attorney to draft an ordinance that would temporarily ban \" and gas drilling\" techniques like fracking in Los Angeles until they can be proven safe, was approved by the City Council on February 28, 2014. \n\nOn February 18, 2014, Bonin and his colleagues  and  introduced legislation to establish a living wage of $15.37 per hour for employees at large hotels in Los Angeles. The bill was approved by the Council by a 12-3 vote, setting one of the highest minimum wages in the country.\n\nIn the fall of 2014, Bonin was one of four co-authors of legislation that would raise the minimum wage in Los Angeles. While supportive of Mayor 's initial proposal to incrementally increase the minimum wage to $13.25 per hour by 2017, Bonin called for extending the proposed increase to reach $15.25 by 2019.\n\nOn September 15, 2017, a campaign for a recall election to remove Councilman Bonin from office was launched. The recall campaign failed to receive support from the required five individuals and was abandoned before it ever formally began.\n\nA second recall campaign was launched in 2021. In November 2021, the group sponsoring the recall claimed that it had submitted sufficient signatures to trigger a recall election. On January 18, 2022, the Los Angeles City Clerk announced that although the recall group received 25,965 valid signatures, it fell 1,350 short of the number needed to trigger a recall election.\n\nOn January 26, 2022, Bonin announced that he would not seek reelection for a third term, citing  and health issues. On October 9, 2022,  that records fellow council members Nury Martinez and  making racist remarks about Bonin and his son.\n\n\nIn 2019, Bonin opposed , a zoning reform bill which would allow for dense housing near rail stations, major bus routes and areas with high concentrations of jobs. Bonin said that more housing supply would \"ravage\" the Del Rey neighborhood and cause the displacement of low-income Latino renters.\n\nIn 2018, Bonin supported the construction of a Bridge Home facility in a residential area of . Amid resistance from residents, the facility was constructed at a cost of $8.5 million dollars. It provides 100 beds for homeless adults and 54 beds for transitional age youth.\n\nIn May 2021, Bonin sponsored a motion to study situating temporary homeless housing in parking lots near . This prompted criticism by some residents.\n\n\n\n\nBonin lives in Mar Vista with his husband, Sean Arian, whom he married in 2014. Mayor Eric Garcetti performed the wedding ceremony. Arian is founder and President of EOS Consulting and also serves as the Founder and Chief Strategist for Bixel Exchange, a technology startup incubator created by the  and .  The couple has an adopted son who is . Bonin is , a member of  in .\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert Timothy Leslie''' (born February 4, 1942) is an American politician from  and a member of the  in United States.\n\n\nBorn in , Leslie moved to California with his family as a two-year-old.  He earned his  degree in  at  where he was a member of  fraternity.  He then earned his  from the .\n\n\nA one-time lobbyist, Leslie first ran for the  in 1984, losing to Democratic incumbent  by just 1 percent.  With Moorhead Duffy not seeking re-election in 1986, Leslie comfortably won election to the Sacramento area 5th District over Jack Dugan, an assistant state Attorney General.  He won re-election in 1988 and 1990 without serious opposition.  In 1991, Leslie ran for the  in a special election for the 1st district left vacant when GOP incumbent  was elected to Congress.  He easily won re-election in 1992 and 1996.\n\nIn 2000, when  prevented him from seeking re-election to the State Senate, Leslie ran successfully for the 4th District in the State Assembly again and won re-election in 2002 and 2004.\n\n\nIn 1998, Leslie was the Republican nominee for , but lost to Democrat  52.7% to 38.8%.California Journal Vol. XXIX, No.12 (December 1998) \"Complete Primary Results\".  StateNet Publications, December 1998.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|birth_place         = , \n|death_date          = \n|death_place         = \n|party               = \n|spouse              = Phil Hwang\n|education           =  () ()\n|website             = \n}}\n'''David Campos''' (born September 28, 1970), is a politician who is Vice Chair of the California Democratic Party. In  he was elected to the , where he represented 's  (, , and the Inner ) until 2016 when he termed out. During his tenure, Campos sought to prohibit the construction of market-rate housing in his district.\n\n\nDavid Campos was born in .\"Supervisor Campos - About\". San Francisco Board of Supervisors. Retrieved December 24, 2010. His father was a . His family first tried to  when David was 11, but they were caught and deported. Around 1983, his father made it across the border and went to , where he became a . In 1985, at age 14, with his mother and two sisters, he fled  and emigrated illegally to the United States. Campos graduated from  in . In 1993, he graduated from  with a degree in . While attending  from 1993 to 1996, Campos became a  of the United States and met his partner, Phil Hwang. They married in 2014.\n\nCampos became Deputy  in 1999. According to his biography on the Santa Clara County government website, Campos was Deputy City Attorney 1999–2004. Campos was  for the  from 2004 to 2007. While general counsel, Campos was on the  2005–2008.\n\n\nIn 2008, David Campos was elected to the , representing  (, , and the Inner ), succeeding newly-elected State Assemblymember . Mayor  appointed Campos to the vacant supervisorial seat on December 4, 2008, one month before the other freshman supervisors were elected in November 2008. His predecessor, Ammiano, had resigned from the  in early December to start his tenure at the .\n\nCampos introduced legislation in August 2009 that sought to protect undocumented immigrant youths from deportation and separation from their families by the San Francisco police. The legislation would have required local authorities to wait for a criminal conviction before turning youth over to ICE.\n\nIn May 2013, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors unanimously passed Campos’s Health Care Access Buffer Zone legislation. The legislation created a 25-foot harassment free buffer zone around all free-standing health clinics in the city. The penalty for encroaching the buffer zone is up to a $1,000 fine or three months in jail. The ordinance also expands the federal , which makes it a federal offense to use physical force or intimidation to prevent a person from entering a reproductive health care facility.\n\nIn September 2012, San Francisco's supervisors voted 8-3 to approve Campos’s  legislation. CleanPowerSF is a publicly owned clean energy program that allow residents to choose to buy electricity generated from renewable source rather than from , the dominant utility in the city. Ultimately, the plan will use the program’s revenue stream to help construct the city’s own renewable energy infrastructure, including wind and solar generators.\n\n\nDuring his tenure on the Board of Supervisors, an average of 157 residences (32 of which were subsidized units) were built in the Mission per year. According to one estimate, Campos opposed the construction of units capable of housing 6,058 people, including subsidized housing for 3,930 lower-income people. Among the developments that Campos opposed was a 2016 proposal to develop a lot containing an abandoned warehouse into housing for 227 people, including 45 low-income residents. Campos argued that the development would harm the vibrancy of his district. The proposal was blocked; by 2022, the lot still contained only an abandoned warehouse.\n\nIn 2015 and 2016, while he was on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, Campos introduced proposals to prohibit the construction of market-rate housing in his district in San Francisco. While running for office in 2022, Campos said he had changed his view on banning market-rate housing. In 2016, Campos held rallies opposing a \"density bonus\" proposal whereby developers in San Francisco would be allowed to build taller buildings in exchange for increasing the number of affordable housing units in the buildings.\n\nIn April 2016, Campos introduced legislation that would fine  companies such as  $1000 a day for each listing that wasn't registered with the City of San Francisco. After the Board of Supervisors approved the legislation, Airbnb sued the City, claiming that the law violated the Communications Decency Act, which prohibits the government from holding websites accountable for the content published by users. Campos then introduced new amendments to the legislation to attempt to address the challenges in the lawsuit.\n\nIn 2021, Campos expressed opposition to a proposal to build 495 apartment units (25% of which would have been affordable housing) on a  valet parking lot. Campos said that his position was not \"anti-housing\" – rather, he said that the apartments would cause displacement: \"there is a very real fear of displacement of the people who live around [the parking lot].\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn August 1, 2013, Campos filed papers at  to run for the California State Assembly seat in the  (eastern half of San Francisco). Campos advanced to the general election with   in the primary on Tuesday, June 3, 2014, with 43 percent of the vote. Chiu won 48 percent of the vote and Republican candidate David Salaverry won 8.5 percent. Chiu beat Campos in the general election with 51 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBy September 2021, Campos had announced his intention to run for the 17th Assembly District seat that would be vacated by David Chiu when he would become . In the special election held on February 15, 2022, Campos ended up in second place with 33,448 votes (35.67%). Since no candidate received 50% of the votes, the top two candidates, Campos and , moved onto the  on April 19, 2022.\n\nWhen filing his papers for candidacy for the special election, Campos listed his occupation as a \"civil rights attorney\". In a letter to the California Secretary of State, Matt Haney challenged the accuracy of that statement, arguing that the role of a DA’s chief of staff is to oversee operations and administration, not practice law. When the  rejected Haney's challenge, Haney filed a lawsuit against the office. In February 2022, Judge Shelleyanne Chang of the Sacramento Superior Court ruled in favor of Haney citing that the civil rights attorney designation was “misleading voters.” Judge Chang ordered that Campos could no longer list his occupation as a civil rights attorney or criminal justice attorney and must list his occupation as criminal justice administrator in the run off election ballot.\n\n\n\nIn March 2017, Campos was named one of seven deputy executives for  to lead the Division of Equity & Social Justice focused on , immigration, , labor, and  issues. During the , Campos coordinated government communications in non-English languages.\n\nIn September 2020, he became chief of staff for  . In an interview, Campos cited the long commute to Santa Clara, and the opportunity to work on meaningful  as motivation to take the new job. In November 2021, Campos took a leave of absence from the Chief of Staff role. In December 2021, Campos was named in a lawsuit filed by a former investigator in the District Attorney's office. The plaintiff claimed that he was wrongfully terminated for reporting and punishing the office's violations of the .\n\nCampos is one of two Vice Chairs of the . Previously, he was a member of the San Francisco Democratic County Central Committee 2016–2021, and elected from within that body to be Chair of the San Francisco Democratic Party 2017–2021.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
