    "pages": }\n| module2             = \n}}\n'''Judy May Chu''' (born July 7, 1953) is an American politician serving as the  for . A member of the , she has held a seat in Congress since 2009, representing  until redistricting. Chu is the first  woman elected to Congress. – See  ()\n\nChu was elected to the  in 2007, representing the 4th district. She previously served on the  , on the   (with three terms as mayor) and in the . Chu ran in the  for the seat vacated by  after Solis was confirmed as President Obama's  in 2009. She defeated  candidate  and  candidate Christopher Agrella in a runoff election on July 14, 2009.Blood, Michael P. , ''Huffington Post'', 15 July 2009. Chu was redistricted to the 27th district in 2012, but still reelected to a third term, defeating Republican challenger Jack Orswell.\n\n\nChu was born in 1953 in . Her father, Judson Chu, was a  World War II veteran born in California, and her mother, May, was a  originally from , . Chu grew up in , near 62nd Street and , until her early teen years, when the family moved to the .\n\n\nIn 1974, Chu earned a  degree in mathematics from the . In 1979, she earned a  degree in psychology from the  of 's  campus.\n\n\n\nChu taught psychology in the  for 20 years, including 13 years at .\n\n\n\nChu's first elected position was as a member of the  in  in 1985.\n\nIn 1988, Chu was elected to the  City Council. In 1989, she became Mayor of Monterey Park and served until 1994. Chu was mayor for three terms.\n\nChu ran for the  in 1994, but lost the Democratic primary to ; in 1998, she lost the primary to .\n\nChu was elected to the State Assembly on May 15, 2001, following a special election after Romero was elected to the . She was elected to a full term in 2002 and reelected in 2004. The district includes , , , , , , , and , within .\n\nBarred by term limits from running for a third term in 2006, Chu was elected to the  from the 4th district, representing most of Los Angeles County.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChu decided to run for the 2009 special election for the  after U.S. Representative  was appointed to become President 's . Chu led the field in the May 19 special election, but due to the crowded field (eight Democrats and four Republicans) she only got 32% of the vote, well short of the 50% needed to win outright. In the runoff election, she defeated  Betty Chu (her cousin-in-law and a Monterey Park City Councilwoman) 62%–33%.\n\n\n\n\nChu was heavily favored due to the district's heavy Democrat tilt. With a  of D+15, it is one of the safest Democratic districts in the nation. She was reelected to her first full term with 71% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\nIn August 2011, Chu decided to run in the newly redrawn . The district has the second highest percentage of s in the state with 37%, behind the newly redrawn  which is 50% Asian. Registered Democrats make up 42% of the district. Obama won the district with 63% in the 2008 presidential election.  won with 55% in the 2010 gubernatorial election. Chu was reelected, defeating Republican Jack Orswell 64% to 36%.\n\n\n\n\nChu was reelected over Orswell, 59.4% to 40.6%.\n\n\n\n\nChu was reelected over Orswell, 67.4% to 32.6%.\n\n\n\n\nChu won reelection over fellow Democrat Bryan Witt by a 79.2% to 20.8% margin, in one of a handful of districts in California that featured only Democrats on its midterm ballot.\n\n\n\n\nChu won reelection to her seventh term over Republican Johnny J. Nalbandian by a 69.8% to 30.2% margin. Nalbandian never conceded the race, citing unproven voter fraud.\n\n\n, at Chu's Swearing In ceremony for the U.S. House of Representatives]]\nIn 2009, Chu voted to increase the debt ceiling to $12.394 trillion. In 2010, she voted to increase the debt ceiling to $14.294 trillion. In January 2011, she voted against a bill to reduce spending on non-security items to fiscal year 2008 levels. In 2011, Chu voted against the Budget Control Act of 2011, which incrementally raised the debt ceiling.\n\nIn 2010, she voted against measures proposed by the House to strip government funding to , and opposed restricting federal funding of abortions.\n\nChu opposed the \"See Something, Say Something Act of 2011\", which provides \"immunity for reports of suspected terrorist activity or suspicious behavior and response.\" She said, \"if a person contacts law enforcement about something based solely on someone's race, religion, ethnicity, or national origin, they would not receive immunity from civil lawsuits.\"\n\nIn June 2011, the House Ethics Committee began an investigation after receiving information suggesting that two of Chu's top aides had directed staffers to do campaign tasks during regular work hours. The investigation found that Chu had sent two emails to her staff on how to respond to aspects of the Ethics Committee's inquiry. The Committee found no evidence that Chu was aware of her staff's actions, it did find that the emails represented actions that interfered with the committee's investigation of the matter, and on December 11, 2014, it formally reprimanded Chu for interfering with its investigation of her office.\n\nIn 2012, a Chinese spy, Christine \"Fang Fang\" Fang, volunteered for Chu's campaign and is suspected to have used political connections to spy for the . Chu was one of several Democratic politicians who were targeted. She is an advocate of the  (MEK). Chu later voted against a resolution \"denouncing the horrors of socialism,\" and published an op-ed in the '''' explaining it.\n\nOn December 6, 2017, Chu was arrested during a protest outside of the . In 2019, Chu was named \"honorary chairwoman\" of the Forums for Peaceful Reunification of China, an organization advocating for .\n\nChu accused , a  member, of inciting the conflict between  and  over the  of . On October 1, 2020, she co-signed a letter to Secretary of State  that condemned Azerbaijan's offensive operations against the -populated enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, denounced Turkey's role in the  and called for an immediate ceasefire.\n\nAs of October 2022, Chu had voted in line with 's stated position 100% of the time.\n\nIn February 2024, Congresswoman Judy Chu was recorded as 'not voting' on HR 2766, the Uyghur Policy Act of 2023, a bill intended to address human rights concerns regarding the Uyghur population in China. The bill had broad bipartisan support.\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n** \n* \n** \n** \n** \n\n\n* (co-chair)\n* (vice-chair)\n* (chair) \n* (vice-chair) \n*\n*Creative Rights Caucus (co-founder and co-chair)\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\nDuring the , Chu voted with President 's stated position 99.1% of the time according to a '''' analysis.\n\n\nChu claims that abortion access is \"not just health care - it is a fundamental human right.\" She opposed the .\n\n\nChu was among the 46 Democrats who voted against final passage of the  in the House.\n\n\nChu voted to provide Israel with support following . However, as of April 20, 2024, she voted against sending aid via H.R. 8034 to Israel,  \"Israel has demonstrated that it can prosecute its war against Hamas without this offensive military assistance from the United States, and the way in which it has done so has resulted in more than 33,000 deaths in Gaza and a worsening humanitarian crisis.\"\n\n\nChu married  in 1978. They live in Monterey Park. Eng took Chu's seat on the Monterey Park City Council in 2001, when Chu left the council after being elected to the , and in 2006, he took Chu's seat on the Assembly when Chu left the Assembly.\n\nChu's nephew, , a , died by suicide while serving in  on April 3, 2011, allegedly as a result of  from fellow Marines after Lew allegedly repeatedly fell asleep during his watch. Chu described her nephew as a patriotic American and said that those responsible must be brought to justice.\n\nIn December 2019, Chu and her brother Dean Chu donated $375,000 to the  in , California.\n\nChu is one of three  in Congress.\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n* campaign website\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Devon John Mathis''' (born September 21, 1982) is an American politician serving as a member of the  from the newly drawn , which is located in , western , and a small part of southern . He serves as the Caucus Operations Chair for the California State Assembly Republican Caucus.\n\n\nMathis was born in . He earned an  degree in  from  and  in  from . Mathis graduated from  earning a  in Strategic Public Relations in 2021.\n\n\nBefore joining the Assembly, Mathis served for 10 years as a Sergeant in the , including two tours in . During his second tour in Iraq, Mathis was severely injured in a roadside bomb attack, for which he was awarded a .\n\nIn 2014, he unexpectedly defeated  Mayor Rudy Mendoza, a fellow Republican who was better known and had more support from established Republicans. Mendoza sought a rematch in 2016, but Mathis defeated him again in the primary. Mathis, who had no previous political experience, ran on his status as a former Army National Guard sergeant and veterans advocate.\n\nIn July 2017 Mathis, along with four other Republican assemblymen, voted \"Yes\" on AB 398 to extend California's  program.\n\nIn 2018, Mathis faced a serious primary challenge, winning only 30% of the vote and narrowly eliminating Republican  Mayor Warren Gubler. But in the November general election, he rallied and defeated Democratic  man Jose Sigala with 58% of the vote.\n\nMathis was not seriously challenged in 2020 or in 2022.\n\nHe currently serves as the Vice Chair of the Assembly Committee on Agriculture  and the Vice Chair of the Assembly Committee on Water, Parks, and Wildlife. Mathis also serves on the Assembly Committee on Appropriations, the Committee on Government Organization, the Committee on Military and Veteran Affairs, the Committee on Natural Resources, and the Utilities and Energy Committee.\n\nTo date, Mathis has successfully authored 17 bills and 15 resolutions that have been chaptered into state law; he is also listed as a joint author to 46 other measures and 9 other resolutions. Spanning his legislative career, Mathis has coauthored 139 bills and 954 resolutions that have been chaptered into law.\n\nOn November 27, 2023, Mathis announced that he would not be a candidate for reelection.\n\n\nDevon lives in Porterville with his five children. He married Mistie Davis on October 6, 2023.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Charles Suren \"Chuck\" \"Pooch\" Poochigian''' (born May 19, 1949) is an American jurist serving as Associate Justice of the . A member of the , he is also a former .\n\nHe campaigned unsuccessfully in 2006 for , losing to former Governor  in the November general election.\n\n\nPoochigian is a third generation  resident of the .  His family has farmed there since 1912.\n\nHe received his undergraduate degree in business administration from California State University, Fresno, in 1972 and his  (J.D.) from  in 1975. From 1975 until November 1988, he practiced general civil and business law.\n\nHe served six years in the .\n\nHe and his wife, Debbie, married since 1977, have three grown children.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1978, Poochigian worked on the campaign of then-State Senator , who was running for Attorney General.\n\nFrom 1985 to 1987, Poochigian served on the California Fair Employment and Housing Commission as an appointee of Governor Deukmejian. In 1988, he was chosen to serve on the senior staff of Governor Deukmejian. Poochigian served as the Chief Deputy Appointments Secretary, assisting the Governor in the selection of key administration officials and members of over 375 state boards and commissions.\n\n\nIn 1991, Governor  named him the Appointments Secretary.  While serving on the Governor's senior staff and overseeing the appointments unit, he assisted the Governor in the evaluation and selection of candidates for judicial appointments.\n\n\nIn 1994, Poochigian was elected to the  to represent the 29th Assembly District with 67.7% of the vote and was reelected in 1996 with 67.8% of the vote.\n\nIn his first Assembly term, he served as the chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee, as a member of the Republican Caucus Leadership (1995–1997), and as a member of the Budget Conference Committee (1995 and 1996).  Additionally, he served as the Assembly's representative on California's Little Hoover Commission, having been appointed by both Republican and Democratic Speakers of the Assembly.\n\nIn 1996, the ''California Journal'' named him the Republican \"Rookie of the Year\" (out of a class of 22).  The ''Journal'' also rated him among the top 5 legislators in the 80-member State Assembly in the following separate categories: Effectiveness, Integrity, Intelligence, Problem-solving, Potential, and Overall.  In 1998, the ''California Journal'' also recognized him as one of the top 5 Assembly members in the categories of Integrity and Hardwork.\n\n\n]]\nIn 1998, Poochigian was unopposed in seeking election to represent , which included portions of , , and  Counties.\n\nIn November 2002, he was again re-elected without opposition to the reapportioned 14th Senate District which now includes all or portions of , , , , , and  Counties.\n\nOn April 8, 2005, as a California State Senator and assistant Republican leader, Poochigian published an article in the San Diego Union-Tribune, entitled \"Using the ADA to abuse the legal system\" where he ridiculed the ADA requirements for basic accommodations for disability, such as grab bars around toilets and levers on doors and faucets, and referred to those requirements as \"payday for shakedown artists\".\n\nIn 2006, ''Capitol Weekly'' named Poochigian the most effective Senator (excluding the Pro-Tem). However, Poochigian earned a zero rating from  (EQCA) for his opposition to  legislation. EQCA noted that Poochigian opposed every major LGBT bill, including: AB 1001 (prohibited discrimination based on sexual orientation); AB 537 (protected LGBT children from harassment and violence in public schools); and AB 25 (established the most basic rights for same-sex domestic partners).\n\n\n\nIn the  , Poochigian was defeated by Democrat , the former governor of California and at the time, mayor of , for , receiving 38.2% of the vote, to Brown's 56.4%.\n\nPoochigian's campaign was characterized as one of the most aggressive and creative down-ballot races in 2006. The campaign was featured by ''The Wall Street Journal'' and others for its use of emerging technology, such as MySpace, YouTube, and other online mediums, to reach out to voters and mobilize activists. One notable attack ad released by the Brown campaign voiced over by  stated that Poochigian had a 0% rating on the environment. The ad also made the claim that Poochigian flatly rejects \"\" which caused confusion about what exactly \"\" means.  ''The National Journal'''s \"Hotline\" named the campaign one of the country's top 15 down-ballot races to watch.\n\nA post-election ''Los Angeles Times'' article stated: \"[T]he famously collegial Poochigian, 57, proved reliably feisty, hitting Brown hard for Oakland's skyrocketing murder rate and a past littered with Moonbeam moments during his long-ago stint in Sacramento and lefty pronouncements while he was a talk radio host in the 1990s.\"\n\n\nOn August 20, 2009, Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger nominated Poochigian to become a justice of the , Fifth Appellate District.  On September 24, 2009, Poochigian was unanimously confirmed to the court by California's Commission on Judicial Appointments, consisting in this case of Chief Justice , Fifth District Presiding Justice , and Attorney General Brown.  At the confirmation hearing, Chief Justice George \"ripped into the commission that rated [Poochigian] \"not qualified\" for the post,\" noting that there was a \"real problem in the process\" used by the Commission on Judicial Nominees Evaluation, and strongly urging that there be \"some revisions in the procedure.\"  Chief Justice George and Justice Ardaiz criticized the JNE commission for disregarding its own standards and the statutory standards that are supposed to govern its processes.\n\nStill, Poochigian's appointment was not without controversy.  JNE Commission Chair Jonathan Wolf of San Francisco wrote to the Chief Justice that Poochigian “is intelligent, diligent, and articulate...and is committed to public service” but continued that in the Commission's view \"Poochigian’s legal background [did] not qualify him for the appellate bench.\"  In explaining the Commission's findings, Wolf continued, \"he [Poochigian] had not practiced law for approximately 21 years and had not litigated a case in approximately the same amount of time. Moreover, he has no jury trials and no criminal law experience.\"\n\nAmong other groups, Poochigian's appointment was strongly opposed by the  and    In a circulated letter opposing Mr. Poochigian's appointment, California  President Patricia Bellasalma wrote,\"Mr. Poochigian’s long political history of being vehemently opposed to the rights of women, the LGBT community, workers and people of color in addition to having no credible legal experience qualifying him for the bench, as determined by the California State Bar, amplifies this travesty.”\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Joseph Garcia''' (born April 24, 1976) is an American politician and former  pilot serving as the  for . A , he was first elected in a  and went on to win a full term in the .\n\nGarcia was educated at the , and . He served in the  from 1998 to 2012, participating in multiple combat missions during the . Following his active duty in the Navy he worked at .\n\nGarcia has faced and defeated  nominee  in all three of his successful elections: the 2020 special election held to fill the vacancy caused by Representative 's resignation; the , when he won his first full term; and the , when he won his second term. Garcia had initially represented , but the district was renumbered as the  following the .\n\n\nMike Garcia was born on April 24, 1976, in , a suburb of Los Angeles, to parents who had immigrated from  in 1959. In 1994, he graduated from  and earned a  in political science, graduating in the top 3% of his class, from the  after being nominated by Representative . In 1998, he earned a  in  from .\n\n\nGarcia joined the  in May 1998, and was sent to flight school at . He was deployed as an  aviator from the . During the , he participated in over 30 combat missions.\n\nFrom 2009 to 2018, Garcia worked as a  at , one of four business segments of .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn the  in , Democrat  defeated incumbent Representative . In April 2019, Garcia announced that he would challenge Hill in the 2020 election. On November 3, 2019, Hill resigned from Congress due to a scandal involving her relationship with a campaign staffer. Governor  ordered a special election to fill the vacancy caused by Hill's resignation.\n\nGarcia placed second in the  on March 3, 2020, ahead of former Representative  and behind , a member of the . Garcia was endorsed by the  and the .\n\nGarcia campaigned on strengthening the United States  and  to improve the , specifically in response to the . He also campaigned against the Democratic leadership in the . His platform included promises to \"defeat socialism\" and \"build the wall.\" Garcia said he was in favor of \"securing and better surveillance of our borders.\" Will GOP Hopefuls Enforce Border?|url=https://signalscv.com/2019/11/allan-favish-will-gop-hopefuls-enforce-border/|access-date=2020-07-16|website=signalscv.com|language=en-US}}\n\nOn May 12, 2020, Garcia defeated Smith in the special election in an upset. She officially conceded the race the next day, but affirmed her intention to run against Garcia in the November general election for a full term in Congress. Garcia's victory marked the first time since 1998 that a Republican flipped a California congressional district held by a ; in 1998,  won in the . He is also the first Hispanic Republican representative to serve from California since  left office in 1883, after representing the .\n\n\n\n\nIn the November general election, Garcia faced Smith in a rematch. In August, Garcia was listed as one of the 10 most vulnerable House members by ''''. Votes were still being counted a week after the election, though Smith held a lead. Smith conceded to Garcia on November 30, 2020. Garcia raised $3 million more than Smith. Garcia won by only 333 votes.\n\n\n\nGarcia ran for reelection in what is now . He defeated Christy Smith again in the November 8, 2022, general election.\n\n\nGarcia was sworn into office on May 19, 2020. \n\nIn January 2021, he  to Congress's .\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n** \n* \n** \n* \n** \n** \n\n\n* \n* \n\n\nGarcia has been described by  as a \"relatively moderate lawmaker\".\n\n\nOn January4, 2021, Garcia announced his intention to reject some states' electoral votes based on claims of fraud. On January 6, he objected to Congress's . He later acknowledged 's win and said the \"election process has run its course\".\n\nGarcia voted against  after the .\n\n\nAccording to ''California Catholic Daily'', Garcia opposes abortion and does not support federal funding of . After winning the special election, he signed a petition to bring the  to the House floor for a vote. Garcia has cosponsored proposed legislation that would effectively ban abortion and some forms of birth control.\n\n\nDuring a virtual debate with Smith before the special election, Garcia said that financial aid to small businesses should be administered through cities and local chambers of commerce.\n\nGarcia has called on the  to investigate Governor 's policy on nursing homes during the pandemic. Along with other Republican representatives, Garcia claimed that Newsom had ignored guidance provided by the .\n\nGarcia voted against the .\n\n\nIn 2023, Garcia criticized members of his own party for blocking an $826billion defense appropriations bill for the . In his criticism, Garcia said that the far-right Republicans stalling the bill on procedural grounds were \"enabling the failed defense policies\" of the Biden administration \"and accelerating the downward trajectory of our nation's security.\"\n\nDuring the debate on the 2024 defense appropriations bill, which included a fifth round of aid to , Garcia said \"I'm not necessarily opposed to supporting the Ukrainians further, but I am opposed to doing it at this point without some sort of explanation from the executive branch, Secretary of Defense [Lloyd Austin] telling us what we are doing with this money and where it's going and what the end state is.\"\n\n\nGarcia has advocated for repealing the . During his campaign, he said he \"was not a big fan of .\"\n\n\nGarcia supports the construction of a wall along the . He is in favor of increasing surveillance at the border. Garcia has voiced opposition to the  and giving  to  who entered the United States as children.\n\n\nIn June 2021, Garcia was one of 49 House Republicans to vote to repeal the  against Iraq.\n\n\nGarcia voted to support Israel following the .\n\n\nIn 2021, Garcia voted against the , calling it \"contrary to American ideals\".\n\nOn July19, 2022, Garcia and 46 other Republican U.S. representatives voted for the , which codified the right to same-sex marriage in federal law.\n\n\nIn May 2020, Garcia said that he supports congressional term limits.\n\n\nIn January 2021, Garcia introduced the State and Local Tax (SALT) Fairness Act, a bill to eliminate the SALT deduction cap created in the . Compared to residents of other states, Californians are disproportionately impacted by the SALT deduction cap.\n\n\nIn 2022, Garcia was one of 39 Republicans to vote for the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act of 2022, an antitrust package that would crack down on corporations for anti-competitive behavior.\n\n\nGarcia opposes . In April 2021, Garcia voted against the .\n\n\nGarcia's wife Rebecca is an interior designer. They have two sons. Garcia and his family live in .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n, 2020}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* official U.S. House website\n* \n* \n \n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ken William Cooley''' (born March 18, 1953) is an American , who served in the .     "pages": } after defeating Marjan Philhour, who ran for the seat in 2016, in a narrow race. Chan is a . District 1 includes the , , , and  neighborhoods, and parts of .\n\n\nChan was born in Hong Kong and migrated to  at the age of thirteen with her family, who settled in . She attended high school at the  and earned her  at the .\n\nChan was a spokesperson for the  and . She also worked for the . At various points, Chan was an aide to Supervisor ,  , and Supervisor .\n\n\n\nTwo days after incumbent Supervisor  announced she would not seek re-election in 2020, Chan (a resident of the Richmond District) announced her candidacy for the open District 1 seat. Fewer endorsed Chan to be her successor. She also received the endorsement of two former supervisors who held the seat,  and .\n\nIn the November 2020 general election, Chan won by 134 votes against challenger Marjan Philhour, a senior adviser to Mayor . Philhour, a centrist candidate,St. John Barned-Smith, , ''San Francisco Chronicle'' (February 5, 2024). had previously run for the seat in 2016, but was defeated by Fewer.\n\n\nChan was sworn into office on January 8, 2021.\n\nChan supported legislation by Supervisor  to create a city-run . In February 2021, Chan supported a plan to provide free Summer Activities for San Francisco's elementary school students.\n\nIn February 2021, Chan and Peskin called upon the city controller and Budget Analyst's Office to investigate the San Francisco Parks Alliance, amid a debate on whether to renew the city's contract with the Alliance to operate the , a  at . Chan and fellow Supervisor  blocked a decision by the San Francisco Historic Preservation Commission to extend the wheel's stay through 2025, referring it to a vote in the Board of Supervisors. Instead of the Commission's proposal for a four-year extension, Chan and Peskin proposed a one-year extension, citing complaints from Ferris wheel opponents regarding the wheel's bright lights and electric generator, which they said might injure wildlife, as well as the San Francisco Parks Alliance's linkage to a corruption investigation. The Board of Supervisors rejected the Chan/Peskin proposal on a 6–5 vote.\n\nPeskin, as chairman of the Board of Supervisors, appointed Chan as chair of the Budget Committee, whose other members were Supervisors  and .Mike Ege, , ''San Francisco Standard'' (June 29, 2023). As Budget Committee chair, Chan supported extension of the  -era  emergency benefits and called for eventually making the  system .\n\nChan disagreed with several of Mayor Breed's key priorities.  Chan and other supervisors, along with the mayor, ultimately negotiated a $14.6 billion budget, which ended a $780 million deficit that had emerged in the two years of the pandemic, and largely preserved Breed's major proposals on public safety and economic policy. The budget included close to $63 million in additional funding for , representing an 8.5% increase in the department's budget. Chan opposed Breed's separate proposal for an additional $27 million supplemental appropriation to SFPD. The budget also adopted a compromise negotiated between Breed and supervisors regarding funding of the San Francisco emergency  network. The budget adopted a limited version of Breed's proposal to offer s to firms opening new offices in downtown San Francisco.\n\n\nIn 2020, while running for the Board of Supervisors, Chan expressed support for building more  along  and other major thoroughfares, but only if the new developments were ; Chan also argued that building more market-rate housing does not increase .\n\nIn 2021, Chan voted to block the development of 495-unit apartment complex (one-quarter of which were designated as affordable housing) on a   lot next to a  station. The 8&ndash;3 vote in the Board of Supervisors was highly controversial.\n\nIn 2021, Chan supported the reopening of the  (a two-mile stretch of road bypassing the ) to cars. Auto access to the Great Highway had been closed during the  and .\n\nIn a 2022 vote in the Board of Supervisors' Rules Committee, Chan and Peskin voted down a proposal (supported by Supervisor  and Mayor ) to place a referendum on the city ballot to streamline the permitting process for certain housing developments; San Francisco takes substantially longer to approve housing permits than other California municipalities. Breed described the vote as \"obstructionism.\"\n\nIn 2022, Chan authored a bill that would have streamlined the development of 100% affordable housing that met the requirements laid out in the bill. Chan and the owners of the long vacant Alexandria Theatre announced the City and the building owner were exploring a development agreement to convert the former movie theatre into 76 housing units, with affordable housing units on-site.\n\nIn December 2023, Chan and Peskin asked the city attorney to sue the State of California to challenge the implementation of SB 423, a new California law (sponsored by state Senator  of San Francisco) that allowed streamlined approval for housing development projects. In their letter, Chan and Peskin asserted that the law unfairly discriminated against San Francisco, and that San Francisco had sufficiently produced market-rate housing. Weiner criticized Chan's and Peskin's letter as an attempt to encourage the filing of a \"frivolous lawsuit\" and criticized city authorities for creating \"extreme impediments\" to resolving the .\n\nIn response to SB 423, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors passed a package to reform San Francisco’s byzantine housing permitting and review process, by a 9-2 vote, with Peskin and Chan opposing.\n\n\nChan is seeking reelection in 2024, running again against Philhour in a rematch of the 2020 race. The race is hotly contested.Aldo Toledo, , ''San Francisco Chronicle'' (March 10, 2024). As was the case in the campaign four years earlier, Chan ran as a progressive while Philhour has run as a centrist/moderate.\n\n\nChan's long time partner, Ed, is a member of the . The couple has a son. Like many Asian women of her generation, she is named after American news anchor .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Deborah V. Ortiz''' (born March 19, 1957, in Sacramento) is an  from . A , she served in both chambers of the . A then-member of Sacramento City Council, Ortiz was elected to the  in 1996 and served a single two-year term representing the . In 1998, she was elected to the  from the  with 55% of the vote and won re-election in 2002 with 70.8% of the vote. s prevented her from seeking a third Senate term in 2006; she instead ran unsuccessfully for Secretary of State.\n\n\n\n\nOrtiz was first elected to public office in a special election in March 1993 when she was elected to the Sacramento City Council. In a field of six candidates, Ortiz received 36% of the vote and was elected to  the seat of  who had been elected Mayor of Sacramento in November 1992. Prior to that she had served as Chief of Staff to then State Assemblyman  and as a leader at the Latino Coalition for Fair Sacramento Redistricting.\n\nOrtiz had also served on the Sacramento County Planning Commission, the Oak Park Project Area Committee and the UC Davis Medical Center Community Advisory Board.\n\n\nOrtiz was known as a major advocate for Oak Park, the neighborhood where she lived and was raised. Oak Park had a long history as one of the most blighted and crime ridden neighborhoods in the City of Sacramento. Ortiz authored ordinances to hold absentee landlords accountable by imposing penalties on neglected vacant properties and she established a cash reward program for reporting of illegal dumping in neighborhoods. Ortiz also authored an ordinance that required gun dealers to register with the police department and precluded them from locating near schools and day care centers. In 1995, Ortiz managed to have  open the first new bank in Oak Park in thirty years.\n\n\nAfter nearly four years on the city council, Ortiz decided to run for the Assembly seat that , a former Mayor of Sacramento was vacating due to term limits. In the Democratic primary, she faced County Supervisor Roger Dickinson and Bill Camp. In a three-way race, Ortiz defeated Dickinson and Camp by over 50%. Ortiz was easily elected in the November general election against token opposition.\n\n\nOrtiz focused on health  and passed the first law in the nation protecting embryonic stem cell research. She was the first legislator to ban sodas from primary and middle schools when she passed SB 677 in 2003. Ortiz passed laws that created the California Biomonitoring Program, established the California Lead  Abatement standards program, established the standards for Chromium 6 in drinking water, and created the California Department of Public Health.  Ortiz also authored the historic Cal Grant Scholarship Program that guarantees college grants for poor and working class students who attend California schools.\n\nOrtiz is well known for authoring the California Freedom of Access to Clinic and Church Entrances Act (or California FACE Act) and the Reproductive Rights Law Enforcement Act in 2001. Passed by the Legislature and signed into law by Governor Davis, the law protects reproductive health care clients, providers and assistants and also worshipers and places of worship. Motivated by attacks on abortion patients, providers, clinics, and clinic escorts, it targets crimes, not First Amendment-protected speech.\n\nShe also authored laws that required criminal background checks for school employees after the death of Michelle Montoya at . Michelle Montoya was brutally raped and murdered on a school campus by a janitor that had been released from prison for manslaughter.  Montoya was the daughter of a friend of Ortiz.\n\nOrtiz also passed laws to create funding for ovarian cancer research and laws to ensure access to emergency contraception.\n\nOrtiz also authored SB 400 that allowed public employees to receive more generous pensions and provided local government the authority to vote to increase public employee pensions.  Many argue that changes enacted by the bill have contributed to fiscal crisis in the State of California.\n\n\nOrtiz was termed out of office  in 2006 having served two terms in the Senate. Thus, she decided to run  for Secretary of State against incumbent . However, Ortiz lost the June 6, 2006 Democratic primary to fellow State Senator  (D-Marina del Rey) who ended up defeating McPherson in November.\n\n\nOrtiz was born and raised in the Oak Park neighborhood of the City of Sacramento. Ortiz attended  for her undergraduate studies and received her  degree from . Ortiz was elected to the Los Rios Community College Board of Trustees in 2010 and reelected in 2014.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\nLos Rios Community College Board of Trustees, Area 6, elected in 2010 and reelected in 2014\n\n\n\n\n\n#\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Connie Marie Conway''' (born September 25, 1950) is an American retired politician who served as the  for  from 2022 to 2023. She was a member of the  from 2008 to 2014. Before that, Conway was a member of the  for  from 2001 until 2008. She is a member of the .\n\n\nConway was born in . She attended the  and . Her father, John Conway, served on the   from 1981 until his death in 1991.\n\nFrom 1988 to 1991, Conway worked as a wellness coordinator at the . From 1991 to 1994, she worked at Sweet's Home Medical. From 1994 to 2000, Conway worked as a district manager at .\n\n\nConway served on the Tulare County Board of Supervisors for eight years. She also chaired the board in 2005 and 2008. Conway also chaired the California Partnership for the San Joaquin Valley, an appointment she received from the governor. The partnership works to improve the economy and quality of life in the San Joaquin Valley by making policy recommendations to the governor. In 2006, Conway served as president of the , representing California's 58 counties at the state and federal levels. She later became a director of the , chaired its membership committee, and worked on its economic development committee.\n\n\nConway entered the 2008 election to succeed termed-out  in the . In the primary, she faced two candidates, Rebecca Maze (the incumbent's wife) and Bob Smith, a retired sheriff's deputy, and won.\n\nAfter her reelection to the Assembly on November 2, 2010, Conway was elected by her Republican colleagues as the Assembly Republican Leader after a closed-door meeting of Assembly Republicans on November 4. She said that outgoing Minority Leader  had voluntarily stepped down, and she had been elected unanimously. Conway was the first woman to serve as GOP assembly leader since 1981.\n\nUnder the term limits law in effect in California at the time, Conway was limited to three terms in the Assembly; she stepped down at the end of her third term in 2014.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nConway was a candidate in the  in  to replace , who stepped down in January 2022. In the April , she advanced to a runoff against Democrat Lourin Hubbard. On June 7, 2022, Conway defeated Hubbard in the runoff election.\n\n\nConway was sworn in on June 14, 2022. On July 19, Conway voted against the , which would protect the right to same-sex marriage at a federal level. On August 12, Conway voted against the \n\nConway did not seek a .\n\n\n\n* \n** \n** \n* \n** \nSource:\n\n\nConway is a .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n  \n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Steven Craig Bradford''' (born January 12, 1960) is an American politician currently serving in the . He is a  representing the , encompassing parts of . Prior to his election to the state senate, he was an assemblymember for the  of the . Bradford was elected to represent the 51st district in a special election held on September 1, 2009, after  resigned his seat to take a seat in the . He was re-elected in 2010 and, with 72% of the vote, was elected once more to represent the brand new 62nd District, comprising the communities of , , , , , , , , , , ,  and .\n\nBefore his election to the assembly, Bradford served on the  City Council.\n\n\nBradford moved to Gardena with his family at age nine. He attended Purche Avenue Elementary School, Henry Clay Junior High School and . Following high school, he attended  and , where he earned a  in  and certificate in .\n\nBradford was the first African American elected to the Gardena City Council, a post he held for over 12 years. He served one year as Mayor Pro Tem of the city.\n\nHe also worked twelve years as a public affairs executive at , seven years at , and four years as a program director at the Los Angeles Conservation Corps.\n\n\n\nBradford's time in the assembly has been marked by his chairmanship of the Assembly Committee on Utilities and Commerce, which has legislative jurisdiction over electricity, natural gas, telecommunications, private water corporations and other issues related to commerce. Actions taken in this committee affect California homeowners and businesses, the economy, jobs, and the environment.\n\nIn his role as chair, Bradford has garnered national attention presiding over important hearings investigating major power outages, and how federal, state, and local authorities might better respond to such events and prevent them from happening in the future. In October 2011, Bradford convened a joint legislative hearing with Assemblymember , chair of the Joint Legislative Committee on Emergency Management, in San Diego to discuss the massive power outage that struck the Pacific Southwest region in September of that year.\n\nIn February 2012 Bradford and Lowenthal convened another hearing in  to investigate another major power outage that struck the Los Angeles area as a result of a massive windstorm.\n\nEarly in 2013, Assembly Speaker  named Bradford the Chair of the Assembly Select Committee on the Status of Boys and Men of Color. The Select Committee is a bipartisan panel of legislators from around the state tasked with fact finding and making recommendations for addressing the issues facing young men in California, particularly black and Latino boys.\n\nIn February Bradford accepted an invitation to the White House to attend President 's announcement of \"My Brother's Keeper,\" a federal investment in the lives of boys and men of color. The program follows the work Bradford's Select Committee on the Status of Boys and Men of Color has done to give young men of color the tools they need to succeed, while dismantling systemic injustices that stand in the way of their success.\n\n\n\nIn addition to his management of the Assembly Committee on Utilities and Commerce, Bradford has also authored several pieces of legislation on energy and utilities.\n\nIn 2012 Governor  signed into law AB 1511, which requires property sellers to inform buyers of important information about natural gas pipelines near their homes. The law was authored in response to the deadly explosion of an underground pipeline in .\n\nBradford also authored AB 2201, which increases civil penalties on pipeline operators for safety violations. Bradford's bill brings the cap on penalties under California law into line with those under federal law: $200,000 per day, and a maximum of $2,000,000.\n\nBradford drew national attention for AB 2514, a bill requiring the California Public Utilities Commission to conduct a study examining the costs and benefits of California's net-energy metering (NEM) program. While NEM programs have helped develop solar power industries in countries around the world, Bradford believes they may shift costs unfairly onto homes without solar panels.\n\nBradford closed the 2013 legislative year having 11 bills signed into law by Governor  Among these were bills focused on public safety, solar energy, and criminal justice reform:\n\n* AB 128: Following a recommendation made by the California Commission on Peace Officer Standards and Training (POST), AB 128 reclassifies the Los Angeles World Airports police department under Penal Code 830.1. Officers with 830.1 status are considered full peace officers, equivalent to municipal police departments. Without 830.1 status, airport officers are prohibited from removing vehicles, seizing drugs or weapons, or other functions for which they may need to wait for backup to arrive. Bradford, whose district includes , introduced the bill ten years after the POST recommendation. Earlier versions of the bill died in the legislature.\n* AB 170: For purposes of obtaining an assault weapons permit, under current law a \"person\" is defined as an \"individual, partnership, corporation, limited liability company, association, or any other group or entity.\" AB 170 limits the definition of a person to an individual. \n* AB 217: Extends existing financial support for solar installations on low-income households. The California Solar Initiative (CSI) directs 10 percent of its funding to solar subsidies for low and very-low income households. AB 217 extends this component for another six years after the CSI sunsets. \n* AB 651: Gives judges more discretion to grant an expungement of a low-level offense when the offender has completed supervision, paid restitution, and demonstrated a commitment to reentry. \n* AB 721: Clarifies the existing drug trafficking statute, which allows prosecutors to add a felony transportation charge to a person found physically moving any amount of illegal drugs. AB 721 adds the words \"with the intent to sell\" to clarify the Legislature's intent to punish drug dealers. An individual may still be eligible for a drug possession charge, but prosecutors will now have to show an individual had the intent to sell in order to qualify for an additional trafficking charge. \n* AB 1371: The Three Feet for Safety Act establishes a minimum three-foot buffer around bicyclists on public roads in California. Motorists wishing to pass a cyclist must keep a distance of at least three feet, or slow to a safe and prudent speed if there is not enough room to give three feet. Bradford's version of the bill was the fifth attempt at a safe passing distance in California. Earlier versions died in the Legislature twice, and were twice vetoed by the Governor. The safe passing distance took effect September 16, 2014.\n\nBy the close of the 2014 legislative year, Bradford had sent 15 bills to the governor's desk. As of September 21, he had already signed AB 2634, which gives courts \"greater authority to issue injunctions against police departments that have a history of civil rights violations.\"\nStill awaiting gubernatorial action are bills including:\n* AB 2673: Sponsored by City Attorney Mike Feuer and endorsed by the '''', this bill eliminates \"the use of civil compromise in misdemeanor hit-and-run collisions that result in injury or death.\" Under current law, a hit-and-run driver may reach a civil compromiseusually a financial settlementand have criminal charges dropped. This bill ensures that hit-and-run drivers face criminal responsibility for their actions.\n*AB 1327: Jointly authored with Assembly Members Jeff Gorell and Bill Quirk, this bill establishes regulations for public agencies wishing to deploy unmanned aerial vehicles. Among those, agencies would need a warrant and to give public notice before deploying a drone; would be required to destroy any data and images collected from a drone within one year, unless part of an ongoing investigation; and would be expressly prohibited from arming a drone with weapons. This bill has been endorsed by Los Angeles Mayor  and the ''''.\n\n\nSteven Bradford was elected in a 2009 special election, following the resignation of , who had recently won election to the . He was elected to his first outright term in 2010.\n\nFollowing the , California's legislative districts were redrawn. Bradford ran for the newly drawn 62nd district, which maintained many of the cities from the previous 51st district. Bradford was endorsed for election to the 62nd Assembly district by the local newspaper of the , the ''''.\n\nHis electoral results are shown below.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  - campaign website\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ivy Baker Priest''' (September 7, 1905 – June 23, 1975) was an American politician who served as  from 1953 to 1961 and  from 1967 to 1975.\n\n\nPriest was born in , on September 7, 1905, to Clara Fearnley and Orange D. Baker. Her father worked as a gold miner in Kimberly and later as a copper miner in the town of , while her mother ran a boarding house. She was active in politics from high school, when she worked to register voters in a mayoral campaign.\n\n\nPriest was a delegate to the GOP state convention in 1932 and ran unsuccessfully for Congress in Utah on the Republican ticket in 1934. From 1934 to 1936, Priest was elected as Regional Co-Chair of the Young Republican National Federation.\n\nBeginning in 1944, she served for several years as Utah's woman and, in 1950, ran for Congress in Utah again and lost for a second time. During 's campaign for , Priest took charge of the women's division of the Republican National Committee and was credited with the successful drive to get out the women's vote, which totaled 52 percent of Eisenhower's victory margin.\n\nShe served as  under President Eisenhower from January 28, 1953, to January 29, 1961, during which time her signature appeared on all U.S. currency.\n\nIn 1967, she became national chair of the .\n\nIn 1966 she was elected as a  to the office of , narrowly unseating Democrat .  She was reelected to a second term in 1970 by a comfortable margin, but did not seek a third term due to declining health.  \n\nDuring her first term she was sued in her role as California State Treasury by John Serrano, a parent of a Los Angeles public school student, for California's inequitable system of funding public education.  This case, , together with voter-approved  in 1976 led to a permanent change in California's education finance system; greatly reducing per-student spending disparities among California K-12 school districts.\n\nIn 1968 she became the first woman to nominate a candidate for U.S. president for a major political party when she offered  's name in a speech before the Republican National Convention. (The convention chose Richard M. Nixon.)\n\n\nShe was a member of .\n\nOn December 7, 1935, she married Roy Fletcher Priest in .  He died on June 11, 1959, in . On June 20, 1961, she married Sidney William Stevens.\n\nShe died of cancer in  on June 23, 1975. She was buried in the Wasatch Lawn Memorial Park Cemetery, Salt Lake City, Utah.\nIvy Baker Priest was the mother of Hollywood actress Pat Priest, best known for her portrayal of 'Marilyn Munster' on the 1960's television comedy:  'The Munster's'.\n\n\nOn August 29, 1954, Priest was the featured guest on ''''. The recording is available on YouTube. On March 17, 1960 she was also featured on '''' with Ernie Kovacs.\n\nPriest was the mother of , an actress best known for playing  in the 1960s television show '''' and appearing in the 1967 Paramount motion picture '''' with .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* - Salt Lake Tribune Negative Collection\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n}}\n\n'''Philip Yu-Li Ting''' (born February 9, 1969) is an American politician currently serving in the . He is a Democrat representing the , which encompasses western  and northwestern . Prior to being elected to the Assembly in 2012, he was the Assessor-Recorder of San Francisco.\n\n\nTing began his career as a real estate  at  and . He also previously served as the executive director of the , as the president of the Bay Area Assessors Association, and on the board of .\n\n\nIn 2005, Ting was appointed San Francisco Assessor-Recorder by Mayor , becoming San Francisco’s highest-ranking  official at the time. He was then elected to the post in November 2005, garnering 58 percent of the vote.\n\nAs Assessor-Recorder, Ting cleared a five-year assessment backlog, which resulted in the collection of more than $200 million in unpaid property taxes. In February 2012, Ting commissioned the country’s first real study of mortgage fraud that spurred national action, uncovering \"widespread mortgage industry irregularity\" in San Francisco foreclosures.\n\nSpecifically, Ting commissioned an audit of nearly 400 homes in the city that had been foreclosed upon in 2009-2011. The results of the audit, which demonstrated that more than 80% of the sampled foreclosures contained at least one clear legal violation, provided documented support for the state legislature to push for increased oversight of the mortgage industry.\n\nTing was re-elected Assessor-Recorder in 2006 and 2010.\n\n\nA Democrat, Ting represents the state's 19th District, which includes the west side of San Francisco, in addition to , , , and . Ting was chair of the Assembly Committee on Budget and was the first Asian-American to hold the position. He is the chair of Assembly Budget Subcommittee No. 6 on Budget Process, Oversight and Program Evaluation, chair of the Select Committee on Asia/California Trade and Investment Promotion, and is a member of the Committee on Business and Professions, the Committee on Utilities and Energy. He previously served as chair of the Assembly Committee on Revenue and Taxation and Chair of the Assembly Democratic Caucus.\n\nTing is a member of the .\n\n\nOn his first day in office Ting was appointed to the Assembly Leadership, being named the Democratic Caucus chair by Speaker .\n\nDuring his first term in the Assembly, Ting authored a law that helped set into motion the transformation of Piers 30-32 into what would become  the home of the . He also helped protect seniors by enabling local governments access to state funds to make pedestrian crossing safer near senior centers.\n\nIn 2014 Speaker  appointed Ting to chair the Revenue and Taxation Committee. In 2014, Ting announced his support for a $100 million property tax-break for large corporations in San Francisco's Mid-Market District.\n\n\n\nIn 2015 Ting authored legislation that was signed into law which ensured free pedestrian and bicycle crossing of the , and a created an incentive program to double the amount of food assistance benefits Californians receive if they purchase  fresh fruits, nuts, and vegetables.\n\nIn 2016 Ting was appointed Chair of the Assembly Budget Committee by Speaker Rendon. Ting’s appointment was historic as he was the first Asian Pacific Islander to chair the Assembly’s Budget Committee.\n\nHe also successfully authored a number of new laws including; requiring single occupancy restrooms to be designated as gender neutral restrooms. This received praise and condemnation from around the country as transgender individuals' use of public facilities including restrooms and locker rooms became a partisan issue.\n\nTing also authored a bill to expand the list of individuals who could petition for a , to help increase their use, however it was vetoed by Governor Brown.\n\n\n\nIn 2017 Ting helped secure $10 million in the State Budget to create an additional Homeless Navigation Center in San Francisco.\n\nIn 2018 Ting passed legislation to protect minority communities by setting minimum standards for law enforcement hate crime policies, protected renters by requiring landlords to accept payments by third-parties, gave hope to inmates serving long sentences by allowing prosecutors an avenue to recommend the re-sentencing of inmates who have been rehabilitated, increased accountability of law enforcement by requiring public disclosure of body camera footage, and supported California’s transition to EV’s by requiring the  to study EV infrastructure needs.\n\nTing also reintroduced his bill to expand the list of individuals who could petition for a Gun Violence Restraining Order, however it was again vetoed by Governor Brown.\n\t\n\n\nIn 2019 Ting also took action when the  (CRV) program virtually shuttered around the state, first by securing $5 million in the State Budget to support 400 low-volume recycling centers, and then by creating a mobile recycling pilot program to replace the hundreds of closed redemption sites around the state.\n\nTing also responded to the  college admissions scandal by authoring a law to require colleges to disclose preferential admissions practices to the State.\n\nIn 2020 Ting wrote laws which increased housing across California. One law prevents Homeowner’s Association from prohibiting rentals, while another allows cities and counties to declare “shelter crisis” to suspend regulatory hurdles to building emergency housing and safe parking programs.\n\nHe also authored a law directed at creating green jobs in the state, by redirecting state budget funds to help public schools replace HVAC and plumbing, and requiring the  to act on pending electronic vehicle infrastructure applications.\n\n\n\nIn 2021, Ting as the Assembly Budget Chair partnered with legislators and the Governor to take early budget action in February designed to help renters/small businesses and send qualified Californians $600 in relief checks to respond to the impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nTing and the AAPI Legislative Caucus successfully got the $166.5 million API Equity Budget included in the state spending plan, bolstering resources and services for victims of , while also investing in cultural institutions that promote greater understanding.\n\nTing was able to get numerous pieces of legislation enacted include banning harmful  chemicals from food packaging and authorizing a pilot program for San Francisco to pay jurors more to see if that resulted in more diverse juries.\n\nIn 2022, Ting led the Assembly Budget Committee through another budget surplus, crafting a historic state budget; with the centerpiece of the spending plan was tax rebates to fight inflation.\nBecause of the mass shootings in ,  and , the Legislature acted early to pass Ting’s AB 1594, which holds the gun industry accountable for the harm their products cause, allowing private citizens, the state Attorney General and local governments to sue firearms manufacturers and retailers when break California’s strict gun laws.\nUnder Ting and  Budget Chair , lawmakers also took quick action when faced with an enrollment freeze at UC Berkeley, after neighbors sued under  to stop enrollment growth authorized and funded under the state budget. Phil Ting's \"Freedom to Walk\" bill to decriminalize jaywalking was signed into law by Governor Newsom.\n\nIn 2023, Ting spearheaded the effort in the California Senate to pass AB 1633, which prevents  abuse of the California Environmental Quality Act to block new housing developments that already comply with local and state land use and environmental regulations.\n\n\n\n\nTing ran in the  but was defeated by incumbent . Ting set a California record for highest campaign expenditures per vote after spending $500,000 on his 2011 campaign for  only to finish in 12th place. The majority of the money came from the city's public campaign financing system which provided Ting's campaign with over $300,000.\n\n\n\nIn 2012, he was elected to the California State Assembly, comfortably defeating fellow Democrat Michael Breyer, son of  Justice .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTing lives in San Francisco's  with his wife and their two daughters. His parents are .\n\nOn June 20, 2020, Ting admitted to having a \"years-long\" affair with Carmel Foster, a domestic worker whom he had met through a dating website. Foster had previously testified before the California State Assembly in favor of AB-5, a bill which Ting supported. Ting later released a statement denying that the affair had any influence on his voting record.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Carol Jean Liu''' (born September 12, 1941) is an American  who is a former member of the . A , she represented , which includes portions of the  and s.\n\nBefore being elected to the State Senate, Liu served in the  representing the  until 2006. In 2008, Liu was elected to succeed the termed-out  in the State Senate.\n\n\nLiu was born in 1941 in . Her mother was a fourth generation Californian, and her father was a Chinese immigrant. Liu graduated from  with a B.A. in 1963. Liu taught junior high and senior high school-level history in the  cities of  and  from 1964 until 1978. She also served as executive director of the Richmond Federation of Teachers from 1975 to 1978. In 1982, Liu completed a teaching and administrative credential at the .\n\n\nBefore serving in the Senate, Liu served in the .  Prior to the Assembly, Liu served on the city council of , a small city in the  near , from 1992 until 2000, including two terms as its mayor.\n\nIn the 2008 primary election for the California Senate seat, she initially faced opposition from former Assembly Majority Leader . However, Frommer decided to drop out before the election.\n\n\nAmong her major accomplishments in the Senate has been the enactment of Senate Bill 110, the Crime Victims with Disabilities Act of 2010. Passed unanimously by the Legislature and signed into law by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, the bill assures that abuse and neglect of people with disabilities and elders are treated as crimes.\n\nSenator Liu's  bill coordinates California's Higher Education segments (U.C. and C.S.U.), but it was vetoed by Governor .\n\nSenator Liu voted in favor of . The proposed bill would have asked California voters to consider repealing provisions of , thus permitting state universities to consider an applicant's race, ethnicity or national origin in making admissions decisions.  The proposed amendment resulted in controversy. In a Facebook response, Liu indicated that  set \"outdated barriers\" to groups of \"underrepresented students eligible for U.C. and C.S.U.\" and that their enrollment \"has not kept pace with the proportion of the high school graduating class they now represent.\"  Senator Liu, along with former senators  and , who had also voted for the bill, ultimately issued a joint statement calling for the bill to be withheld pending further consultations with the \"affected communities.\"  Mar. 12, 2014\n\n\nLiu is married to , who was appointed to the  by Governor , and later was named president of the Commission by Governor , where he served until retiring in 2014.\n\nThey have three children and four grandchildren.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Curt Hagman''' (born January 2, 1965) is an American public servant representing the Fourth District in San Bernardino County California since his election to the Board of Supervisors in 2014. The Fourth District encompasses the cities of Chino Hills, Chino, Ontario, Montclair and Upland. Hagman was elected Chairman of the Board of Supervisors for two consecutive terms in recognition of his leadership during the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nHagman began his public service as a volunteer and served as a Chino Hills Parks & Recreation Commissioner. He later represented Chino Hills as a Council member and Mayor, served on the San Bernardino County Workforce Investment Board, and served six years in the California Legislature as a member of the State Assembly representing .\n\n\nHagman earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from . Hagman was a member of . He was also in the .\n\n\nIn 2004, Hagman served on the  City Council, until 2008 when he became the Mayor of .\n\nHagman was elected to the 55th district state assembly in 2008, winning 55.9% of the vote. He was re-elected in November 2010 with 65.3% of the vote.\n\nIn 2014, Hagman won the election for the  . He defeated U.S. Representative . He won re-election in 2022, easily defeating .\n\n\nHagman's wife is Rossana Hagman. They live in .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Paul Krekorian''' (born March 24, 1960) is an , who has represented the  on the  since 2010.  A member of the , he served as the  from October 18, 2022 to September 20, 2024.  He was previously a member of the , representing the . Krekorian is the first  to be elected to office in the city of .\n\n\nKrekorian was born in 's , as a third-generation San Fernando Valley resident. He is the son of JoAnn, a  native, and Erwin Krekorian, a Marine Corps WWII veteran. His father was of  descent and ran a small business on Saticoy Street in . Krekorian completed his primary education entirely within the , graduating from  in Reseda. As the first member of his family to attend college, Krekorian enrolled in the , where he first became active in political causes. He worked with then-Assemblyman Tom Bane, became the campus organizer for 's 1978 gubernatorial campaign and helped lead USC's Democratic student group. After graduating with a B.A. degree in  from USC, Krekorian went on to earn a  degree from the . Krekorian became an organizer for 's 1992 presidential campaign and co-chaired the Saxophone Club, the 's nationwide young professionals group.\n\nKrekorian practiced law, with a focus on business, entertainment, and intellectual-property litigation, at the firms Skadden Arps, Dewey Ballantine and Leopold, Petrich & Smith, and Fisher & Krekorian, where he was a name partner. He served on the board of trustees of the LA County Bar Association, the Board of Trustees of the LA County Law Library and the California State Legislature's Task Force on Court Facilities. In the aftermath of the 1992 Los Angeles riots, Krekorian was counsel to the Webster Commission and was appointed to the Los Angeles City Ethics Commission. Krekorian has been praised for his efforts in preserving women's rights for his pro-bono work in the fight against domestic violence, and a program he developed for at-risk youth, called GenerationNext.\n\n\nKrekorian lives in the San Fernando Valley with his wife Tamar and children Hrag, Andrew, and Lori.\n\n\nKrekorian has served the San Fernando Valley for more than two decades, first as a member of the Burbank School Board and then as a California State Assemblymember. He currently serves as a member of the Los Angeles City Council, representing District 2 in the southeast San Fernando Valley. Council District 2 includes the communities of North Hollywood, Studio City, Valley Glen, Valley Village, Toluca Lake, and parts of Sun Valley and Van Nuys.\n\n\nIn 2006, Krekorian was elected to the 43rd district of the California State Assembly. During his first term in office, Krekorian held one of the best records in the Assembly with the highest number of bills signed into law by any freshman legislator. He was named Assistant Majority Floor Leader of the State Assembly, the third ranking leadership position in the Assembly, by then-Speaker . Krekorian's legislative priorities included making government more accessible and responsive, saving and creating jobs, protecting the environment and increasing public safety. He created the \"Government at Your Doorstep\" program in response to complaints about speeding, graffiti, and noise pollution in his district. As the state battled to pass a balanced budget in early 2009, Krekorian authored a historic bill to ensure film and TV production in California stays local. His bill was the first successful tax incentive aimed at saving California jobs by addressing . On-location feature production increased 9.1 percent in the second quarter of 2012, generating 160 production days in Southern California. Krekorian also introduced legislation that restricted  in ocean run-off, expanded renewable energy generation for California public utilities and reduced carbon emissions. He worked closely with local police departments to reduce gang violence, along with crime in his district and throughout the state. In his first Assembly term, Krekorian's Weapons and Ammunition Nuisance Abatement Act of 2007 gave apartment owners greater latitude to evict tenants who harbor guns and ammo. That year, Krekorian also introduced and passed a bill to encourage participation with federal authorities to siphon off the state's stock of weapons.\n\n\n and , and members of the Fire Commission in 2015.]]\nOn December 8, 2009, Krekorian won a seat on the Los Angeles City Council, representing . He is the Chair of the city's powerful Budget and Finance Committee, the Vice Chair of the Housing Committee, and sits on the Energy, Climate Change and Environmental Justice Committee; Trade, Travel and Tourism Committee; Executive Employee Relations Committee; and the Board of Referred Powers. He also serves on the board of the  (Metro) and , and sits on the San Fernando Valley Council of Governments, a coalition of leaders advocating for the Valley's two million residents.\n\n and other city councilmembers during a meeting with , 2023.]]\n\nIn 2012, Krekorian was tapped to lead the Budget and Finance Committee, inheriting the responsibility of overseeing a multi-billion dollar General Fund budget. Since taking the helm, he has taken a \"difficult but responsible approach to solving a $220 million deficit and enhancing the city’s solvency.\"\n\nKrekorian has advocated for expanding rail and bus transit in the Valley, including electrifying and eventually converting the  to light rail, completing the East Valley North-South Transit Corridor and Sepulveda Pass projects, linking the Red Line to the Hollywood Burbank Airport and connecting the San Fernando and San Gabriel Valleys by rail. He has also led the efforts to connect North Hollywood to Pasadena with a Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) line.\n\nOn October 18, 2022, Krekorian was elected the president of the Los Angeles City Council following the resignation of former council president .\n\n\n\nHis campaign officially began on July 10, 2009, when Krekorian officially announced his candidacy to fill the vacant District 2 seat in a special election. The primary was held on September 22, in which Krekorian placed first with 34% of the vote. A runoff was scheduled for December 8 and, aided by support from a number of public safety, environmental, and Democratic groups, including , the United Firefighters of Los Angeles City, the Los Angeles Chapter of the Sierra Club, and the Democratic Party of the San Fernando Valley, Krekorian soundly defeated  with more than 56% of the vote, despite being outspent 2–1 in overall campaign dollars and 13–1 in third-party political committee donations.\n\nHe was overwhelmingly elected to his first full term in 2011 and again in March 2015 and June 2020. In their editorial endorsing his March 2015 campaign, the Los Angeles Times called Krekorian \"smart, knowledgeable\" and a \"voice for fiscal responsibility and responsive government.\"\n\n\n\n\n\nIn response to the 2020 , Krekorian introduced a resolution in the , stating that \"The savage invasion of Artsakh is a blow against freedom, democracy and self-determination everywhere.\"\n\nIn a joint letter regarding the , addressed to President , Krekorian and   demanded the following:\n# Providing direct U.S. humanitarian assistance to , including food and medical supplies\n# Making clear to  and  that the United States demands and will act to ensure the safe passage of flights into Artsakh to provide aid\n# Assertive U.S. diplomatic engagement to facilitate negotiations between  and  to guarantee the rights and security of the Armenian population of Artsakh\n# Insisting that  be replaced by international peacekeepers\n# Taking tangible action against the regime in Azerbaijan to hold it accountable for its crimes pursuant to  of the  and the .\n\n\nAt an October 2022 fundraiser brunch for  hosted by member , Krekorian honored the organization with a proclamation.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
