    "pages": }\n\n'''Antonio Mendoza''' (born April 22, 1971) is an American  who served in the . A , he represented the , which encompasses  and the  of .  In January 2018, the State Senate voted to suspend him for 60 days to investigate allegations of sexual harassment.  He could not vote on legislation during that period, while contesting the suspension. Before a vote for expulsion was to be taken by the State Senate due to the released findings of an investigation that determined he likely engaged in a pattern of unwanted advances and sexually suggestive behavior toward six women, including four subordinates, over the last decade, Mendoza resigned on February 22, 2018.\n\nHe was a member of the California Latino Legislative Caucus. Prior to being elected to the State Senate in 2014, Mendoza served in the  from 2006 to 2012, representing the . Before his service in the , Mendoza was a fourth grade teacher in , and served as a Mayor and City Councilmember in .\n\nAfter resigning from the State Senate, in 2019 he was appointed as the general manager of the , one of the few publicly owned and operated cemeteries in California.\n\n\nAfter receiving his bachelor's degree in Political Science: Public Administration from California State University, Long Beach and his Multiple Subject Bilingual Teaching Credential from California State University, Los Angeles, Mendoza taught elementary school for ten years in East Los Angeles.\n\nDuring his teaching years with the Los Angeles Unified School District, Mendoza served as a member of the board of directors with  (UTLA) and as a representative with the  (CTA) and the  (NEA).\n\nIn 1997, Mendoza ran a grassroots campaign in his hometown of Artesia as a candidate for city council.  His platform of securing Artesia neighborhoods from gangs resonated with the community, and Mendoza became the youngest, and first Latino member, of the Artesia city council, and the youngest to serve as mayor at the age of 26.\n\nMendoza served three terms on the Artesia city council before running for the State Assembly in 2006.  Mendoza represented the communities of Artesia, Buena Park, Cerritos, Hawaiian Gardens, Norwalk, Santa Fe Springs, Whittier, Lakewood, Los Nietos, and South Whittier.\n\n\nMendoza authored several bills that were signed and adopted into law while serving in the Assembly, including bills that dealt with health, public safety and the environment.\nAB 97 made California the first state in the nation to ban the use of s in food preparation in all California restaurants, cafeterias and bakeries.  AB 1291 helped parents take a lead role in the life of their child; the child who has been charged and convicted of a first-time gang related offense can jointly enroll with his or her parent or parents in anti-gang courses to prevent further involvement in gang activities.  AB 1488 required smog checks for lightweight diesel vehicles to ensure they are running clean.\n\nMendoza's 2018 legislation was a mix of education, consumer and employment bills.  AB 63 protects consumers by requiring retailers who issue a service contract or extended warranty to maintain a copy on file for the life of the contract, and make it available to a consumer within 10 days of request.\n\nAB 943 would end the practice of using a person's credit report as a part of the hiring process with the exception of positions that deal with large sums of cash or expensive property.\n\nAB 857 would place highly trained individuals from the Employment Development Department (EDD) in  local EDD centers to work face-to-face with individuals on their unemployment benefits.  This bill also would hire an additional 800 people to serve in call centers.  The bill used no state money to fund the program, but instead allocated federal dollars to maintain the level of service to help those transitioning.\n\n\nIn 2008, Mendoza launched the Young Legislators, a student program which put high school seniors from throughout the 56th Assembly District in real-life political scenarios.  The program's goal is to teach high school seniors about the political world.\nSeniors who qualify take part in an eight-month program that introduces them to local, regional and statewide office holders who share their perspectives on various issues, and explain their role in the political process.  Young Legislators conclude their studies by participating in a mock legislative session in Sacramento in which they deliver and deliberate on legislative bills they have designed and introduced.\n\n\n\n\nThe California Fair Political Practices Commission launched an investigation after a series of contributions was made by Tony Mendoza and Assembly Candidate Tony Bermudez. \"Latino Caucus Chairman Assembly Member Tony Mendoza, acting on his own accord and without input from Members of the Latino Caucus, provided a recommendation to transfer $50,000 from Yes We Can, an Independent Expenditure Committee (IEC), to another IEC prior to his resignation as Chair of the Caucus. The funds have since been transferred numerous times and have been used to support candidates who are not endorsed by the Latino Caucus. As the current Chair of the Latino Caucus, I do not condone or support his actions\", said , D-South Gate. Bob Stern, former president of the Center for Governmental Studies, the principal co-author of the California Political Reform Act and the Fair Political Practices Commission's first general counsel, said the transactions look \"very suspicious, but there could be explanations.\" \"Money laundering is the most serious of campaign violations,\" Stern said, noting that money laundering is used to both skirt campaign contribution limits and conceal contributors.\"\n\n\n\nIn November 2017, Mendoza was accused of inviting a young female staffer to his residence in Sacramento. In February 2018, leaders of the State Assembly publicly released the findings of an investigation that determined he likely engaged in a pattern of unwanted advances and sexually suggestive behavior toward six women, including four subordinates, over the last decade. Senate President Pro Tem Kevin de León introduced Senate Resolution 85, which cites the house's zero-tolerance sexual harassment policy and the results of the investigation as grounds to expel Mendoza. Before the Senate could take a vote for expulsion, Mendoza resigned from his position.\n\n\n\nAssemblyman Mendoza grew up in South Central Los Angeles. He is the first in his family of nine children to graduate from college. He received a bachelor's degree in Political Science from . He received his teaching credential from .\n\nMendoza and his wife Leticia live in Artesia and have two daughters and two sons.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

He is also a practicing .\n\n\nPan was born in , and raised in , , to immigrant parents from Taiwan. He earned a  from , a  from the , and a  from . He completed his pediatric residency at  also serving as Chief Resident and a fellowship at  in child advocacy and primary care research.\n\nDr. Pan was a professor at the  where he led the pediatric residency program and founded Communities and Physicians Together, a service learning curriculum that placed physicians-in-training with community settings to learn about social determinants of health.\n\n\nPrior to being elected to the State Senate in 2014, he was a member of the  representing the , and after the 2010 , the . Pan was Chair of the California Asian American & Pacific Islander Legislative Caucus.\n\nFollowing  and infected 131 people, Pan and Senator  introduced  in 2015, which eliminated philosophical and religious beliefs exemptions to vaccine requirements for California school children. The bill passed and was signed into law by  . Pan authored laws to expand  for  (AB395 in 2011),  (AB1559 in 2014) and all conditions recommended by the federal DHHS Recommended Universal Screening Panel (SB1095 in 2016). Pan authored legislation to extend the  Program managed care carve-out (AB301 in 2011) and to establish the  Children's Health Advisory Board to guide Medi-Cal policy affecting children (AB357 in 2014). In 2021 he authored a law (SB 742) that makes illegal to \"harass, intimidate, injure or obstruct\" people who are on their way to get a vaccination; the law was inspired by an incident in January when protesters targeted and briefly shut down a mass vaccination site in Los Angeles.\n\nIn 2022, together with Senator , Pan introduced Senate Bill 866 which would have allowed minors aged 15 and older to receive FDA-approved vaccinations without parental consent. The bill did not become law.\n\n\nPan and his wife, Wen Li-Wang, have two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Johannes Meindert Willem Moorlach''' (born December 21, 1955) is an American politician who served as a member of the  representing , which includes portions of , from 2015 to 2020. He was narrowly defeated for reelection by  in ; he lost a 2021 special election to return to the Orange County Board of Supervisors; he withdrew from the 2022 election for Orange County Auditor-Controller; and he lost the 2022 election for Mayor of Costa Mesa. A Republican, he previously served on the  from December 5, 2006, to January 5, 2015, and as Orange County Treasurer–Tax Collector from March 17, 1995, to December 5, 2006.\n\n\nJohannes Meindert Willem Moorlach was born in , , and came with his family to the United States when he was four years old. He grew up in , and . He earned his  degree in business administration from the  in 1977.\nHe is a certified public accountant and certified financial planner. Before entering public office, he was vice president of accounting firm Balser, Horowitz, Frank and Wakeling, and the administrative partner of its Costa Mesa office.\n\n\n\n\nMoorlach first came to public attention by predicting the largest  portfolio loss and bankruptcy in U.S. history while campaigning for the office of Orange County Treasurer–Tax Collector against incumbent   in 1994. Citron resigned later that year and was replaced on an interim basis by . On March 17, 1995, Moorlach was appointed to fill the vacancy. In 1996 he was elected by the voters to complete the unexpired term, and re-elected in 1998 and 2002, serving nearly twelve years.\n\nHe is recognized as a leading expert on municipal bankruptcies.\n\n\nIn 2006, he opted not to run for re-election as Treasurer–Tax Collector and instead ran for  , winning 70% of the vote. Moorlach was unopposed for re-election in 2010.\n\nWhile on the Board of Supervisors, he served on the , , , and Southern California Regional Airport Authority boards.\n\nHe was succeeded on the board by  and ran in the 2021 special election to succeed her following her election to the . He lost to Democrat Katrina Foley.\n\n\nIn 2013, Moorlach announced his candidacy for the  seat being vacated by , but dropped out shortly before the deadline to file candidacy. The Congressional seat was won by  . Moorlach won the special election to succeed her in the  with 50.3% of the vote, defeating  , a fellow Republican who won 44.0% of the vote.\n\nIn 2019, Moorlach introduced a bill to expand Interstate 5 and State Highway 99 with two additional lanes. The proposal also included the repeal of speed limits on those two roads. The bill mandated a report be delivered by January 1, 2021, which has not occurred.\n\nIn the fall of 2020, Moorloch lost his bid for re-election to Democrat . Moorlach later filed papers to run for his old seat on the .\n\n\nAfter losing his Senate re-election bid in 2020, Moorlach made several failed attempts to return to office:\n*Losing a  for his former seat on the \n*Withdrawing from the March 2022 election for Orange County Auditor-Controller amid charges that he did not meet the legal qualifications to hold the office\n*Losing the November 2022 election for Mayor of \n\n\nMurloch and his wife have three children.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Van Thai Tran''' (; born October 19, 1964) is a  attorney and politician in , formerly serving as a  member of the , representing portions of .  Tran and    were the highest-ranking Vietnamese American elected officials in U.S. history until  was elected to the United States House of Representatives in December 2008. Tran took office one month before Vo did, making him the first Vietnamese American to serve in a .  He served in the Assembly as Assistant Republican Leader.\n\n\nBorn in , , Tran and his family emigrated to the United States after being evacuated by the  one week before the , when he was 10 years old.  After originally settling in , they moved to Orange County when Tran was a teenager.\n\nTran worked as an intern and later as a staff aide for   and for   while a student at the , where he earned a  in  in 1990.  Tran completed a  from  and a  from .  He was admitted to the  in 1994.\n\nIn 2000, Tran was elected to the   with the highest number of votes in city history and became only the second Vietnamese American man to be elected to office in the United States ( was the first when he was elected to the city council of neighboring  in 1992).  After serving one term on the council, he was elected to the California State Assembly to replace outgoing Republican state assemblyman , who was forced to retire due to term limits. Tran was re-elected to the Assembly in 2006 and 2008.\n\n\nTran represented the 68th District. He was the Vice Chair of the Assembly Judiciary Committee. He also served on the Assembly Utilities and Commerce Committee and the Assembly Governmental Organization Committee. In June 2007, he was appointed by the Assembly Speaker as chairman of the Select Committee on International Trade.\n\n\n\n\nOn December 21, 2005, Tran announced that he would launch an  for a 2006 run against  First District Orange County Supervisor  in the race for the State Senate seat being vacated by ed Democrat .  Tran opted not to join the race, allowing Assemblywoman  to win the Republican nomination with nominal opposition, and she went on to lose the general election to Correa by a 1% margin.\n\nOn November 7, 2006, Tran was re-elected to the Assembly with 62% of the vote.\n\n\n\nTran challenged and lost to Democratic incumbent . Tran was endorsed by  .\n\n\nTran announced that he would run for State Board of Equalization representing District 4.  He ran, but lost the primary to state Assemblywoman , who went on to easily win the general election.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* \n* at \n*\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Lena Adriana Gonzalez''' (born January 26, 1981) is an American politician serving as a member of the  from the , which encompasses the  area including  and . Since February 2024, she has served as Majority Leader of the Senate.\n\n\nGonzalez was born in , the daughter of immigrants from , . Her father worked as a cargo truck driver and her mother worked in the aerospace technology industry. She holds a  in  from  and a  from .\n\n\nGonzalez previously worked for  as a corporate affairs manager in charge of the company’s philanthropy and civic engagement.\n\nShe served on the  from 2014 to 2019, representing District 1 in . Prior to this, she worked for then-Councilman .\n\n\nGonzalez was first elected to the  in a June 2019 special election to succeed , who was elected .\n\nShe chaired the Senate Transportation Committee, becoming the first Latina to ever serve in this capacity and the only woman to serve in the last 20 years. On February 12, 2021, Senator Gonzalez was appointed as Majority Whip. She was one of several California lawmakers to attend the  Summit.\n\nShe was appointed  of the Senate in 2024, succeeding  .\n\n\nGovernor  signed Gonzalez's “The Equal Insurance HIV Act” into law, which prohibits life and disability income insurance companies from denying coverage to HIV-positive individuals solely based on their  status.\n\nGonzalez has been a frequent critic of the '' lobby in California, authoring numerous bills protecting environmental standards and public health. She introduced legislation in 2022 to require  and  to engage in  to align with the state's climate action goals. Governor  signed a bill by Gonzalez that would ban new oil and gas wells near homes and schools in 2022. Gonzalez introduced Senate Joint Resolution 2 alongside Assemblyman , which upon adoption made California the largest economy endorsing the \n\n\nGonzalez lives in  with husband Adam Carillo and three sons in a .     "pages": }\n'''Mitch O'Farrell''' (born 1960) is an American politician, who served as a member of the  for the  from 2013 to 2022, during which he spent eight days as  during the . A member of the , O'Farrell was the first Native American elected to the body, and was one of its two openly gay members until the end of his second term in .\n\n\nMitch O'Farrell was born in  in 1960, and raised in the  suburb of . He grew up in a farming community. His mother was an administrative assistant and his father was a Teamster truck driver. O'Farrell is a member of the , and is the first Native American to be elected to the Los Angeles City Council.\n\n\nO'Farrell first moved to Los Angeles in 1982 for an audition. During the 1980s, he pursued a career in the arts and was a professional dancer and actor. He has lived in  since 1992.\n\nO’Farrell quickly became an active member of the Glassell Park and greater Los Angeles community. Most notably, he was elected President of the Glassell Park Improvement Association and helped form the Glassell Park Neighborhood Council. O’Farrell also served as president of the Northeast Democratic Club, and regularly volunteered at local non-profits including the Wildlife Waystation, Project Angel Food, and the Santa Cecilia Orchestra. In 2002, he was hired by then-Councilmember Garcetti to work in his office, where he remained for ten years. O'Farrell served as a field deputy, deputy director, district director, and finally as senior advisor.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2013, O'Farrell ran for the City Council seat held by Garcetti, where he faced former Public Works Commissioner and  John Choi. The contest between O'Farrell and Choi was noted for being unusually contentious. During the campaign, Choi accusing O'Farrell of  during the contest over a campaign flier that included \"a grainy picture of him above the words “not from our community.” O'Farrell responded by saying that \"I didn’t like it anymore than you did, John\" and noted it was from an independent group, but also noted that \"[t]he fact is my opponent is new to the district... “I am the local candidate.”\n\nDuring the campaign, he was endorsed by many elected officials including Councilmembers  of the  and  of the . After a tumultuous campaign, O'Farrell won in the runoff of the election, receiving 53.05% to John Choi's 46.94%.\n\n\nO'Farrell was reelected with 59.26% of the vote (17,053 votes) in a wide-open contest. During the campaign, O'Farrell was endorsed in his reelection bid by   and local , among other politicians and organizations. Coming in second place was challenger Sylvie Shane, a founding member of the LA Tenants Union, who received 15.07% of the vote. Jessica Salans, who was endorsed by the  and would later become chief of staff to Councilwoman , came in a close third place.\n\n\nIt was speculated that O'Farrell would receive a challenge from a  candidate in the 2022 election.  Albert Corado, homelessness policy advisor , and  organizer  challenged O'Farrell from the left; Sheriff's Deputy Steve Johnson also ran against O'Farrell.\n\nIn October, O'Farrell became Acting President of the City Council for eight days following 's resignation in wake of the .\n\nO'Farrell conceded the 2022 election to Soto-Martinez on November 15.\n\n\n at the .]]\nAs the first Native American to serve on the Los Angeles City Council, O'Farrell has championed indigenous issues. He proposed and successfully established the creation of  in Los Angeles, and was endorsed by Chief Billy Friend of the Wyandotte Nation nearly a decade ago, during his 2013 City Council campaign.\n\nO'Farrell has been a supporter of expanding the City's housing stock, particularly of covenanted affordable housing. During his time in office, over 4,300 units of covenanted affordable housing were built in Council District 13.\n\nO'Farrell is described as having \"spearheaded efforts to remove the camp\" of homeless people at  during a widely-publicized and controversial police-led action to sweep out the unhoused and temporarily close the historically popular city park towards the end of the COVID19 pandemic. O'Farrell has been criticized for \"not doing more to ensure the safety of those living in the encampment\". As head of the City Council's Homelessness and Poverty Committee, O'Farrell has spoken in favor of limiting which sidewalks homeless people would be allowed to sleep on.\n\nAfter removal of the encampment, O'Farrell's office significantly altered the layout and nature of Echo Park Lake, erecting an enormous security fence enclosing the previously wide-open community park, restricting access to a small number of specific discrete entrances, contracting private security to monitor the park, and adding surveillance cameras that cover \"every inch of the park\".\n\nDespite claims by O'Farrell's office that the unhoused residents would be placed into permanent supportive housing, today, out of the 200 or so residents who were swept from Echo Park Lake, only around 9 are in permanent housing. Several have since died, and many more have disappeared from official records.\n\nO'Farrell has focused on improving . O'Farrell notes that his work has led to the banning of coyote snare traps in Los Angeles, which he describes as \"one of his proud accomplishments\" in his official biography.\n\n\nO'Farrell is openly gay. He resided with his partner George Brauckman in , but moved back to Oklahoma after his defeat. Mitch O'Farrell - Los Angeles City Council 13th District|website=cd13.lacity.org|access-date=2019-06-22}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gordon Mar''' is an American politician from San Francisco. He was a member of the  from 2019 to 2023, representing District 4. He is the brother of former District 1 supervisor .\n\nDistrict 4 includes the western San Francisco neighborhoods of Central , Outer Sunset, , Outer Parkside, and Pine Lake Park.\n\n\nHe was Executive Director of  San Francisco and the . \n\n\nAfter incumbent District 4 Supervisor  declined to run for re-election in 2018, Mar filed papers to run for the District 4 seat in the . In the months leading up to the race, the campaigns of both Mar and his primary opponent, Jessica Ho, were criticized for \"mudslinging\" tactics. A Mar campaign staffer was caught tearing down a poster for Ho. \n\nMar was elected supervisor for District 4 on November 6, 2018, receiving 10,314 first preference votes (36.29 percent of all valid votes). After allocation of preferences from eliminated candidates in San Francisco's  system, Mar received 56.84 percent of final-round votes, compared to 43.16 percent for runner-up Jessica Ho, an aide to the incumbent supervisor .\n\nMar led negotiations with San Francisco Mayor  to fully fund 's free tuition program for ten years beginning in 2019, and negotiated a deal to provide full reserve funding for raises for  educators.\n\nMar has called on  to release aggregated demographic data on Asian-American crime victims, following an increase in hate crimes in San Francisco and several high-profile attacks on members of the Chinese community, and announced legislation requiring this data to be released annually. \n\nMar is the author of a number of ordinances reforming San Francisco's electoral system and addressing money in politics, including 2019's Proposition F addressing pay-to-play politics, corporate contributions, and dark-money donations, and Public Financing 2.0, which tripled the impact of San Francisco's  program for elections.\n\nIn November 2022, Mar lost his bid for re-election to . With the redistricting process, Engardio was eligible to run in District 4 after running and losing three prior campaigns for Supervisor in District 7. With this loss, Mar became the first elected Supervisor in the ranked-choice era to lose their reelection bid. \n\n\nMar spearheaded multiple Board of Supervisors resolutions which denounced California State Senator 's SB 50 bill, which would have legalized higher density housing development in areas close to public transit. When asked to explain why he voted to block the construction of a 495-unit apartment complex (with 25% affordable housing) on a Nordstrom's valet parking lot in the South of Market neighborhood, Mar said there was an abundance of available \"luxury units\" in the neighborhood and families \"can check Craigslist today\" to find housing.\n\nMar opposes building a  in District 4.\n\nWhen asked to comment on legislation that would permit construction of fourplexes across the city, Mar said \"a modest density increase to  is certainly worth considering\" in San Francisco but did not specify further. Later in 2021, amid debates to allow the construction of four housing units on lots previously designated for single-family housing, Mar proposed to prohibit the construction of market-rate housing on the upzoned lots. \n\nIn November 2021, Mar proposed to scale down a 98-unit low-income apartment complex in the Sunset District so that it would only have 80 units. Mar characterized this as a compromise between supporters and opponents of the apartment complex. \n\nIn January 2022, Mar defended the delay in approval for a $18.7 million grant to repurpose a hotel into a homeless shelter for upwards of 250 people. Mar said, \"We’re all well aware of the urgency of this work. But I would echo the comments of my colleagues that we can’t use that urgency to go through a bad process.\"\n\n\nHis wife Cecilia is a realtor. Together, they are landlords.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  }}\n*  }}\n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Irma Louise Anderson''' ( Husbands; January 18, 1931 – January 28, 2024) was an American politician who was the elected mayor of the city of , serving between 2001 and 2006. She ran for re-election as the incumbent  in the  and lost to  challenger councilperson  by 192 votes.\n\nBefore serving as mayor she was a member of the city council from 1993 through 2000. She was the first black woman to serve on the ; December 18, 2006. and arguably claimed to be the first   elected mayor of a major  city (although  served as mayor of slightly smaller  in 1973)., San Francisco Chronicle via sfgate.com, November 8, 2001; retrieved December 12, 2011.\n\nAnderson, born and raised in , was her high school class . She earned both  and  degrees from . She also earned an  at the school of public health of .\n\nIn 1954, Anderson came to Richmond, California, with her husband, the late Rev. Booker T. Anderson Jr. (who served as Mayor of Richmond from 1973 to 1974). The couple had two sons, Ahmad and Wilbert. Ahmad ran for Richmond City Council in 2020. \n\nHer career changed from nursing to politics working for the  Health Department where she began as a nurse and advanced to Director of Public Health Nursing. As mayor, Anderson worked with the  developing after-school programs throughout the city of Richmond.\n\nAnderson died from pancreatic cancer at her home in Richmond, on January 28, 2024, at the age of 93.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joshua Botts Newman''' (born October 17, 1964) is an American politician who serves in the . A , he represents the , which encompasses parts of , , and  counties. He was previously recalled from the same office in June 2018.\n\nNewman was elected to the State Senate by a very narrow margin in November 2016, providing Democrats with a ⅔ supermajority of 27 seats. In June 2018, he was successfully recalled by the voters of the 29th Senate District, and replaced by his 2016 opponent, former   .  In November 2020, Newman once again defeated Chang to return to the State Senate.\n\nPrior to being elected to the State Senate, Newman was a veterans' advocate and executive director of a nonprofit for veterans.\n\nNewman graduated from  and served as an officer in the .\n\n\n\n\nIn Newman's first election, he defeated former  Mayor  in the primary, then  narrowly defeated state   to succeed term-limited Republican  in the general election.\n\n\nIn June 2018, Newman was , ostensibly for his affirmative vote on Senate Bill 1, which increased gas and diesel taxes and raised DMV registration fees in California. The recall effort was heavily pushed by influential radio personalities . He was replaced by Republican , whom he had defeated in the 2016 election.\n\n\nOn March 4, 2019, Newman announced that he would be a candidate to return to the  in the 2020 elections.\n\nHe came in second in the primary election, defeating Democratic challenger Joseph Cho. In the general election, he won office with 51.3% of the vote to retake the seat from Chang.\n\n\n\nFollowing redistricting, Newman announced that he would run for the , going up against fellow Democrat . Later, Senator Min announced that he will be retiring from the State Senate and be running as a candidate in .\n\n\nNewman is . He is married and has one child.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* l\n*\n* on \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michael J. Machado''' (born March 12, 1948) is a  politician from . He served from 2000 to 2008 in the . Machado represented the , which includes the cities of ,  and  in ; , ,  and  in ; , ,  and  in ; as well as  and a portion of  in .\n\n\nMachado was born to William John Machado and Grace Fenley Machado, and had two siblings. His paternal grandparents immigrated to California from the .\n\nMachado graduated with a degree in  from , earned his master's degree in  from the , and in 1988 attended the   Seminar. Machado served in the  during the . Prior to entering the State Legislature, he served on the board of a major California food processor and worked for the Agency for International Development in  and  assisting farmers with the transition from a closed to an open market economy.\n\nMachado owns and operates a family farm in Linden. He and his wife Diana have three children: Erahm, Melissa and Christopher (deceased).\n\n\nMachado represented the 's 17th District from 1994 to 2000. He distinguished himself as a pragmatic legislator who supports education reform, \"balanced\" environmental regulations and tax relief for all Californians. Since his election in 1994, Machado has authored legislation protecting school children from perpetrators by creating safety zones around schools, establishing drug rehabilitation programs in county jails, and providing a moratorium on gun shows illegally selling weapons. During the last legislative session, he was instrumental in crafting legislation designed to stop the unfair practice of \"predatory lending.\"\n\nMachado was the subject of a recall effort by the state GOP in the summer of 1995, which failed.\n\n\nMachado chaired the Senate Banking Committee and the Sub-Committee on  Resources. He also served on the Senate Committees on Budget and Fiscal Review, Local Government, Natural Resources and Water, and Transportation and Housing. Additionally, he was a member of the Select Committees on the California Correctional System. Two of Machado's most notable accomplishments were Proposition 13 (Safe Drinking Water, Clean Water, Watershed Protection, and Flood Protection Bond Act) which Machado authored, and the passage of Proposition 50, the Water Security, Clean Drinking Water, Coastal and Beach Protection Act of 2002.\n\nMachado was supported by Handgun Control, the California , California Nurses' Association, , Building and Construction Trades, and many other labor groups. Machado also received the support of the California Abortion and Reproductive Rights Action League (CARAL) and Planned Parenthood.\n\n\nMachado was appointed to the State Fund's board of directors in 2009. In 2010, Machado was named the Director of the Delta Protection Commission.\n\nMachado has served on the board of directors of PICO Holdings, Inc. since 2013. Since that time, the company's stock price has fallen by over 65% from over $25 to under $9 per share. Machado was criticized by shareholders for approving an executive compensation plan that is widely perceived as excessive.\n\n\n\n\n\n*https://web.archive.org/web/20041030121618/http://www.ucop.edu/state/advocacy/biographies/SDMachado05.pdf\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert \"Bob\" Epple''' (November 18, 1948 in Los Angeles, California - April 13, 2011 in Norwalk, California) was an American attorney and politician from California and a member of the .\n\nEpple first ran for elective office in 1980, when he challenged entrenched GOP state senator  in what was then a safe Republican district.\n\nHe then served as an elected member of the Cerritos College Board of Trustees from 1981 until 1988, when he ran for the .https://www.joincalifornia.com/candidate/2677 \n\nEpple challenged incumbent assemblyman  (R-La Mirada) in the 1988 election. Democrats considered Grisham vulnerable after he lost a special state senate election the year before against then Norwalk councilman  within roughly the same geographic area.California Journal Vol. XIX, No.5 (May 1988) \"Campaign '88\".  StateNet Publications, May 1988. With help from Sacramento Democrats and Speaker , Epple narrowly defeated Grisham. \n\nReelected easily in 1990, Epple had a much tougher time in 1992, when he opted to run in the newly drawn , based around Cerritos, Bellflower, Downey and part of Long Beach. Although he represented a portion of the new district before reapportionment, he had to move there to seek reelection, mainly to open up a his old Norwalk-based  (which had been redrawn as a majority-Latino district) for a Latino candidate. He faced conservative businessman Phil Hawkins, in what became one of the most expensive California legislative races that year. Epple managed to only barely beat Hawkins  by 542 votes. When they faced off in a rematch two years later, Hawkins beat Epple by more than 10 points in a strong year for Republicans nationally.https://www.joincalifornia.com/election/1994-11-08\n\nIn 2004 Epple's wife Cheryl, then an elected member of the  Board of Trustees, died suddenly of a heart attack.  He replaced her on the board and was reelected in 2005 and 2010. \n\nOn April 13, 2011 Epple died after a long battle with leukemia.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| children             = 2\n| alma_mater           = ()\n| party                = \n}}\n'''Anthony A. Strickland''' (born February 17, 1970) is an American politician who is a member of the City Council of . He was mayor of Huntington Beach from 2022 to 2023. During his tenure as mayor, he was involved in conflicts with the state of California due to his opposition to new housing. \n\nA member of the , he was a   (elected from the ) from 2008 to 2012 and a  (elected from the ) from 1998 to 2004. He owns a political and business consulting firm. He is the president and CEO of Strong America, an  and .John Scheibe, , ''Ventura County Star'' (January 12, 2016).\n\n\nStrickland was born at , when his father was stationed there as a soldier in the . Don Strickland met his wife, Antonie, when he was stationed in Germany. The family moved to  in 1973. Strickland earned his  in political science at , where he earned the Leadership and Service Award and was a  Scholar.\n\nFrom 1996 to 1997, Strickland served on the staff of man .\n\n\n\n\nStrickland was first elected to the Assembly in 1998 with 49% of the vote in a three-way race. \n\nIn 1998, Strickland distributed flyers in his campaign claiming Camarillo Mayor Charlotte Craven endorsed him. Strickland was not endorsed by Craven and the mayor requested that Strickland remove her name from the flyer. With Craven's name removed, only one elected official, Mike Markey, had endorsed Strickland.\n\nIn 1998, the Strickland campaign had a complaint filed against it alleging that a mailer sent out by an independent group attacking Strickland's opponent coordinated with the campaign. The complaint was made by the President of the West Valley Republican Club, Michael Chulak. He claimed that the mailer was illegal because it was sent out \"at the behest\" of the Strickland campaign. The mailer was sent out by a Sacramento-based gun owner's group on Strickland's behalf.\n\nHe was re-elected in 2000 with 51% of the vote, again in a three-way race. He was re-elected to a third term with 63.1% of the vote in 2002. s prevented Strickland from seeking a fourth term in 2004. , his then-wife, decided to run for the seat and won (she was re-elected in 2006 and 2008).\n\n\n\nIn 2006 Strickland ran for . He won 41% of the vote in a four-way primary, besting State Senator , his nearest opponent, who received 37.0% of the vote. Strickland was defeated by  in the general election by a 50.7%-40.2% margin.\n\n\n in 2014.]]\nStrickland ran in California's 19th district against the Democratic nominee, former state Assemblywoman . Senate District 19 includes areas of , ,  and  counties. The race was highly competitive and the closest state Senate race in California that year.\n\nThe race was also contentious, with critics of Strickland upset at the alleged misrepresentations of his business background.  On various campaign literature, the Strickland campaign portrayed Strickland as a vice president of Green Wave Energy Solutions, LLCeven though Strickland has worked in politics his entire adult life, and Green Wave Energy Solutions LLC has not done any business in California.\n\nJackson conceded just five days before Strickland was sworn into the Senate. He had won the election by 900 votes. With Strickland's 2008 election to the State Senate and his wife, Audra, simultaneously winning re-election to the State Assembly, the Stricklands became the second husband and wife to serve concurrently in the  (after Senator  and Assemblywoman ).\n\n\n\nIn the June 2010 primary, Strickland won 60% of the vote to gain the Republican nomination for State Controller, setting up a rematch of the  between Strickland and Chiang, who was unopposed in his bid for the Democratic nomination for re-election as State Controller.  In the general election, Strickland lost again to Chiang, this time by a wider margin: Chiang received 55% of the vote, while Strickland received 36%.\n\n\n\nIn January 2012, Strickland announced his candidacy in the newly redrawn , based in . Strickland was defeated by Democrat  on November 6, 2012.\n\n\n\nCongressman , who represented  since 1993, retired and endorsed Strickland. He was also endorsed by former Republican candidate for president, , and vice presidential candidate . He ran against then California State Senator  on November 4, 2014, and was defeated.  covers northern parts of  and parts of . It includes the cities of , , , and , and the northern part of the .\n\n\nIn December 1999, the  sued Strickland for failing to report $116,140 in late contributions, in violation of the California Political Reform Act of 1974. He was fined $6,000.\n\nIn April 2010, the  (FPPC) decided that Strickland and Strickland for State Senate, a member of the California State Senate, and his candidate-controlled committee sent out a mass mailing without the name of the committee on the outside of the mailing. The Commission levied a $3,000 fine.\n\nIn May 2016, Strickland agreed to pay a $40,000 fine to settle a FPPC investigation that determined that he laundered campaign donations during his 2010 run for state controller. The Commission  found that Strickland had routed campaign contributions through the Ventura County Republican Party and Stanislaus County Republican Central Committee, in an effort to evade state limits on campaign contributions. The Commission said that Strickland did not cooperate with the investigation. Strickland accepted responsibility for eight violations, but said that he did not personally solicit the donations to the party organizations.Taryn Luna, , ''Sacramento Bee'' (May 19, 2016). \n\n\nDuring the , Strickland supported ,Nicholas Riccardi & Michael R. Blood, , Associated Press (May 1, 2016). and he was a Trump delegate at the . In May 2016, Strickland was also named the California chairman of the \"Committee for American Sovereignty,\" a pro-Trump .Mike Harris, , ''Ventura County Star'' (May 13, 2016).\n\n\nStrickland was elected to the Huntington Beach city council in November 2022.Magnolia Lafleur, , ''Orange County Register'' (December 17, 2022). Strickland and three other conservative candidates (Grace Van Der Mark, Casey McKeon and Pat Burns) campaigned as a , and all four won election to the council, forming a new conservative majority.Hannah Fry, , ''Los Angeles Times'' (December 13, 2023).\n\n\nStrickland spent a one-year term as mayor of Huntington Beach. He was sworn in on December 7, 2022.Matt Szabo, , ''Los Angeles Times'' (December 7, 2022). In its December 2022 vote, the new conservative-majority council chose Strickland as mayor on a 4&ndash;3 vote, with Van Der Mark being elected mayor ''pro tempore '' on a 4&ndash;3 vote. On December 6, 2023, on a 4&ndash;3 vote, Strickland was succeeded by Van Der Mark, and the ''pro tem'' position went to Burns.Matt Szabo, , ''Los Angeles Times'' (November 30, 2023).Sara Cardine, , ''Los Angeles Times'' (December 6, 2023). In both 2022 and 2023, the council voted 4&ndash;3 to set aside previous council resolutions under which the ''pro tem'' post was granted to the longest-serving councilmember who had not served as mayor in the past four years. During the 2023 vote, Strickland made the motion to set aside this previous custom of selecting the ''pro tem'' based on seniority.\n\nStrickland remains a member of the city council.\n\n\nAs a city councilmember and as mayor, Strickland staunchly opposed increasing housing supply. During his tenure, the city stopped accepting applications for s, which prompted   to sue the city, alleging that the city was violating the  (SB 9), a state law requiring municipalities to allow greater housing supply. The city also sued the state of California, alleging that the state's  infringed on the city's authority; a federal judge denied the city's request for a temporary restraining order blocking the application of state housing law. Bonta said that Huntington Beach's suit was a \"baseless and obstructionist attempt by the city to defy state housing laws.\"\n\nStrickland says that he supports affordable housing but Huntington Beach is \"95% built out\" and he will not support \"anything that guts our suburban coastal community.\" In 2023, he claimed that \"high rise high density urbanization\" was being \"forced\" on the city.\n\nIn 2024, Strickland supported a ballot initiative to allow California cities to impose  on new apartments. Strickland said he did not support rent control as a policy, but would support the initiative because it would enable local governments to impose steep requirements on new housing which would block new housing construction.\n\n\nIn October 2015, Strickland announced the formation of Strong America, a  of which he is president and CEO.\n\n\nStrickland has one daughter and one son with his first wife, , who he married in 1998, though they eventually divorced.  He married his second wife, Carla Dispalatro Strickland, on February 17, 2019. \n\n\nStrickland and his wife live in a four-bedroom 1,800 square-feet condominium on the west side of Huntington Beach that she purchased for $319,000 in 2000. The unit is publicly listed as a state mandated affordable housing unit. Given that Strickland lives in affordable housing, his staunch opposition to affordable housing mandates prompted accusations of hypocrisy.\n\nStrickland also owns a home in  in Ventura County.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jay Phillip Obernolte''' ( ; born August 18, 1970) is an American politician and businessman serving as the U.S. representative for  since 2021, when it was numbered as the 8th district. A , he was previously a member of the  representing the . Before serving in the Assembly, Obernolte served on the city council and was the mayor of . He is the owner, president, and technical director of , an American .\n\n\nObernolte was born in , , and raised in . He graduated as valedictorian of  in 1988. In 1992, he obtained his Bachelor of Science degree in engineering and applied science from the  and in 1997, he received his Master of Science in  from the . In 2020, he was awarded a  from the  with a dissertation on \"Managing Budgetary Conflict Between the Executive and Legislative Branches of Government\".\n\n\n\n\nIn 1990, Obernolte launched FarSight Studios, an independent developer and publisher of  s. The company originally produced games for the , and as of 2023 develops for , , , , , ,  and . Notable games the studio has developed include '''', '''', ''Hotel for Dogs'', '''', and the  version of ''''. FarSight Studios claims , , , and Apple among its clients and employs 25 workers.\n\n\nIn 2005, Obernolte was elected to the  Airport Board, where he served for five years. He then served as president of the board for three years and as vice president for one year.\n\nIn 2010, Obernolte was elected to Big Bear City Council, where he served as mayor. He also served on the Big Bear Lake Fire Protection Board, as director of the Mojave Desert and on the Mountain Integrated Waste JPA Board, the Mountain Area Regional Transit Authority Board, and the League of California Cities Desert-Mountain Division.\n\nObernolte served as state assemblyman for , which encompasses a wide expanse of the  (areas of the ), from the eastern fringes of the  to the  and  borders, from 2014 to 2020. He was elected to Congress in 2020 to replace retiring  as representative for , which includes , , and the majority of land mass in .\n\n\nIn January 2016, Obernolte was elected to serve on the California Legislative Technology and Innovation Caucus, which is co-chaired by Assembly members  and . He also sat on the following committees: Arts, Entertainment, Sports, Tourism, and Internet Media as vice chair; Budget as vice chair; Appropriations; Budget Subcommittee 6 on Budget Process, Oversight and Program Evaluation; Budget Subcommittee 6 on Budget Process, Oversight and Program Evaluation; Utilities and Commerce; Joint Committee on Arts; and Joint Legislative Budget.\n\nIn 2016, Obernolte expressed concern over 's acquisition of 's voice, video, data, and FiOS network, saying that the takeover \"negatively affected\" his constituents through poor landline telephone service.\n\nIn 2016, Obernolte introduced Assembly Bill 2341, which would provide San Bernardino and other rural counties with additional judges to resolve backlogged court systems. The bill would have shifted seats from Santa Clara and Alameda counties to the rural counties including San Bernardino, but died in the Senate Appropriations Committee without a hearing.\n\nIn 2017, Obernolte opposed 's nomination as .\n\nObernolte said that Governor 's $179.45 billion budget proposal was \"responsible\", but expressed a preference for fixing existing programs over creating new ones. He also stated an interest in funding job skills training, improving the state's  program, repairing infrastructure, and working on the housing crisis. Obernolte pushed for lawmakers to limit long-term funding commitments and said the budget proposal did nothing to address the \"state's out-of-control pension debts and retiree health care liabilities.\"\n\nObernolte co-authored Assembly Bill 1103, which would have allowed California bicyclists to roll through stop signs if it was safe to do so (the \"\"). The bill died in committee.\n\nObernolte authored Assembly Bill 1642, which would extend the deadlines to either pay the fire tax, which is a state fire prevention fee, or file a petition for redetermination from 30 days to 60 days. In July 2017, the fire fee was suspended as part of Assembly Bill 398. Obernolte opposed raising  costs, which is calculated by factors in the risk of wildfire, fuels, slope and road access for emergency vehicles.\n\nObernolte opposed increases in the minimum wage.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn September 2019, after  announced his retirement from , Obernolte announced his candidacy. The district covers most of the  of  and  and  counties.Ryan Hagen, , ''San Bernardino Sun'' (November 10, 2021).\n\nIn February 2020, President  endorsed Obernolte on Twitter.\n\nIn the November 2020 election, Obernolte defeated Democratic nominee Chris Bubser with 56.1% of the vote to Bubser's 43.9%. Obernolte was sworn in to Congress on January 3, 2021, and appointed Freshman Class Representative to the House Republican Policy Committee.\n\n\n\n, 2020}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn January 6, 2021, Obernolte voted  in the , citing unilateral changes to election law made in those states by the judiciary or executive branch rather than the state legislature. He also voted against  for inciting his supporters to . Obernolte voted against the creation of the .\n\nObernolte's first pieces of legislation to pass the House concerned the enabling of technological advancement. His Fellowship and Traineeship for Early Career AI Researchers Act and Next Generation Computing Research and Development Act were included in the bipartisan H.R. 2225, the National Science Foundation (NSF) For the Future Act, and H.R. 3593, the Department of Energy Science for the Future Act respectively. His first standalone legislation, H.R. 3533, passed the House in September 2021. It establishes occupational series for federal positions in software development, software engineering, data science, and data management.\n\nIn February 2021, Obernolte voted against the resolution that stripped  of her committee assignments for her incendiary and violent statements. In November 2021, he voted against censuring Representative , who posted an edited video of himself violently attacking Representative  and .\n\nIn March 2021, he voted against the .\n\nIn June 2021, Obernolte voted to repeal the .\n\nAs of October 2021, Obernolte had voted in line with 's stated position 20% of the time.\n\nAlong with , Obernolte began chairing a bipartisan taskforce on  in 2024. The taskforce was established to \"to explore how Congress can ensure America continues to lead the world in AI innovation while considering guardrails that may be appropriate to safeguard the nation against current and \".\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n** \n* \n**  (Chair)\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\nObernolte supported the  and believes that because the Constitution does not mention abortion explicitly, states may outlaw it.\n\nOn July 19, 2022, Obernolte and 46 other Republican representatives voted for the , which would codify the right to same-sex marriage in federal law. He said, \"As an ardent advocate for limited government, I do not feel that government should be empowered to dictate the terms of a marriage.\"\n\nIn 2022, Obernolte was one of 39 Republicans to vote for the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act of 2022, an antitrust package that would crack down on corporations for anti-competitive behavior.\n\nIn 2023, Obernolte was among 47 Republicans to vote in favor of H.Con.Res. 21, which directed President  to remove U.S. troops from  within 180 days.\n\n\n\n\nOn February 10, 2014, Obernolte announced his candidacy for the  to succeed  in the 33rd district.\n\nObernolte was endorsed by the , the  Republican party, the California Republican Assembly, '''', the , Peace Officers Research Association of California (PORAC), San Bernardino County Safety Employee's Benefit Association (SEBA), the California Conservative Christians, and the Independent Voter Political Action Committee. He defeated Democrat John Coffey in the November general election with 65.9% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn January 25, 2016, Obernolte announced he would seek reelection as the representative for California's 33rd Assembly District.\n\nIn the June primary, Obernolte finished first with 60.7% of the vote with 43,526 votes. He defeated Democrat Scott Markovich in the November general election with 60.6% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n, 2022}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nObernolte married his wife, Heather, in 1996, and they have two sons. The family has lived in Big Bear Lake since 1997.\n\nObernolte holds an airline transport pilot's license. He is a certified flight instructor and has flown light aircraft since 2005. He worked with  as a member on its Pilot Advisory Board during the development of the . Obernolte volunteers as a pilot with the  and the .\n\nObernolte holds a fifth-degree  in Pacific Unified Martial Arts and is co-owner and instructor at PUMA Karate in Big Bear Lake.\n\nObernolte is .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n* \n*  campaign website\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
