    "pages": }\n\n'''Mervyn Malcolm Dymally''' (May 12, 1926 – October 7, 2012) was an American politician from . He served in the  (1963–1966) and the  (1967–1975) as the  (1975&ndash;1979) and in the  (1981–1993). Dymally returned to politics a decade later to serve in the  (2003–2008).\n\nDymally was the first  to serve California as  and . He was one of the first persons of  (mixed African and Indian) origin to serve in the U.S. Congress.\n\nIn , he and  became among the first  elected to statewide state office since  did so during .\n\nDymally was the second African-American to hold statewide office in California, following  who served as  starting in 1971.\n\n\nBorn in , , Dymally first received his secondary education at  before transferring to Saint Benedict's College, both in . He is of  (mixed  and ) descent.\n\n\nHe moved to the United States to study journalism at  in . After a semester there, he moved to the greater  area to attend , and completed a Bachelor of Arts in education at  in 1954. Dymally became a member of  fraternity in 1949. Dymally became a U.S. citizen in 1957.\n\nIn 1969, while serving in the , he earned a master's degree in government from . Dymally earned his doctorate in human behavior from  (later merged into ) in  .\n\n\n]]\nIn the tightly contested race for lieutenant governor in , Dymally's bid for re-election was derailed when Michael Franchetti, an aide to State Senator , floated a false rumor that Dymally was about to be . The story, coming days before the election, harmed the Dymally campaign, and Dymally lost to Republican .\n\nFranchetti later said that the source of the rumor was a '''' reporter, who called the Justice Department trying to confirm its authenticity. Franchetti could not substantiate the rumor but included it in a report. The report was passed to Curb's office with the rumor part erased, after which it moved to broadcaster  who announced it as fact on Los Angeles radio station  and its CBS affiliates. (Stout's wife worked for Curb.) Then-Attorney General  filed a letter of reprimand in Franchetti's personnel records, accusing him of a breach of responsibility.Stewart, Jocelyn Y. (February 22, 2007) , ''Los Angeles Times''. Retrieved January 12, 2009.\n\nDymally was an old friend of  founder .Flynn, Daniel (2011-11-17) , ''''. Accessed September 5, 2022. When Jones decided to move his congregation to , , Dymally \"wrote the  to reassure him that Jones was an upstanding citizen.\" The Jonestown compound would be the site of the  on November 18, 1978.\n\nIn 1983 he joined with seven other Congressional Representatives to sponsor a resolution to  over his sudden and unexpected .\n\nIn the 1990s, Dymally served as a paid lobbyist for the country of , attempting to present the country as engaged in abolishing every remnant of .\n\nDymally came out of retirement and returned to the  in 2002 when Assemblyman Carl Washington was ed. He served for six years and then ran for the State Senate in 2008. However, he was defeated in the Democratic primary for State Senate election by . He died in Los Angeles and is buried at  in .\n\nMervyn M Dymally Senior High School at 88th street and San Pedro in , part of the  is named in his honor.\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n* from the ''Washington Post''\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n\n\n\n| birth_place  = New York City, NY, U.S.\n| death_date   = \n| death_place  = , U.S.\n| occupation   = Actor, politician\n| years_active = 1939&ndash;1992\n| spouse       = \n* \n}}\n| children     = 1\n|module= \n}}\n\n'''John Augustus Kelly Jr.''' (September 16, 1927 &ndash; November 7, 1992) was an American film and television actor most noted for the role of  in the television series '''', which ran on ABC from 1957 to 1962.\n\nKelly shared the series, rotating as the lead from week to week, first with  as  (1957–1960) then with  as  (1960–1961) and  as  (1961, for two episodes), before becoming the only Maverick (alternating with reruns from the Garner era) in the .\n\nKelly later became a politician, having served from 1983 to 1986 as the mayor of Huntington Beach, California.\n\n\nJohn Augustus Kelly Jr. was born in Astoria, Queens, New York, one of four children, to Ann Mary (née Walsh) and John Augustus Kelly Sr. Jackie, as he was called as a child, came from a prominent theatrical family. His mother, Ann \"Nan\" Kelly, had been a popular stage actress and  model. Kelly Senior was a theater ticket broker, and after he moved the family to Hollywood, entered the real estate business.\n\nHis sister was actress . His other two siblings, Carole and William Clement, also tried show business. Kelly served as a weather observer in the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II, where he was on the first  to fly over the Arctic Circle.\n\n\n\nKelly made his film debut in an uncredited role in the 1939 biopic ''''. In early 1954, he appeared in the film noir '','' written by  and . On July 15, 1954, Kelly played the gunfighter, cattleman, and bandit  in the television series ''''.\n\nIn 1955-1956 television season, Kelly starred in a series based on the 1942 feature film '''' starring  and . He played Dr. Parris Mitchell, a young psychiatrist coping with the narrow-minded environment of his small town while  played the part originally performed by Reagan in the theatrical film. ''King's Row'' was one-third of the '''' , hosted by . It rotated at the scheduled hour of 7:30 Eastern on Tuesday with a similar television version of the popular movie '''' as well as the new ABC Western series ''''. After the series ended in 1956, Kelly appeared in '''' (1956) and '''' (1957), along with guest roles on '''', '''', '''', and ''''.\n\n\n as Gentleman Jack Darby]]\nThe various anti-heroic Mavericks were dapper professional poker-players roaming the  with the benefit of superb scripts (at least in the first two seasons; the show gradually declined during the last three seasons). The series had an enormous cultural impact during a time when there were only three television networks and most American cities had only three TV channels to choose from.\n\n''Maverick'''s demanding filming schedule had caused production to lag behind early on. The producers decided to give Bret Maverick () a brother so as not to run out of episodes long before the end of the season. Thus, Kelly was introduced as Bart Maverick in \"Hostage,\" the  of the series.\n\nKelly shared the lead with James Garner in one of the show's famous episodes, \"\", on which the first half of the 1973 movie '''' appears to be based. The pair also co-starred in the famous \"Pappy\" episode in which Garner played the brothers' much-quoted father Beauregard \"Pappy\" Maverick, in addition to his regular role of Bret. Aided by trick photography, Bret and Pappy play cards together in one scene (Kelly had a dual role in the episode as well, playing Bart and elderly Uncle Bentley \"Bent\" Maverick). Bart rescued Bret at the climax of \"\", in which Garner fought guest star .\n\nGarner had first choice of which part he would play in the two-brother episodes, which delineated the brothers as \"Maverick 1\" and \"Maverick 2\" in the scripts, giving him an enormous advantage. All but one script during the show's first two years were written with Garner in mind regardless of which actor was being cast. Series creator  insisted that the writers visualize Garner as Maverick while writing the scripts, according to his  interview. The second-season episode in which Maverick was written with Kelly in mind instead of Garner was titled \"Passage to Fort Doom.\"\n\nAlthough the \"solo\" episodes in which Bart appeared tended to be somewhat more dramatic than the often more humorous Bret episodes, Kelly displayed his comedic skills in lighter ''Maverick'' outings such as \"Hadley's Hunters\" and \"The People's Friend.\" Kelly actually appeared in more episodes of ''Maverick'' than James Garner, who left the show following a contract dispute in 1960 to successfully accelerate his . Kelly appeared in approximately 75 episodes due to his remaining for the entire run of the series; Garner is in 52 episodes altogether not counting introducing Kelly's earlier solo episodes in a separate frontispiece to ease audiences into the presence of a second Maverick during much of the first season.\n\nIn the wake of Garner's departure,  played Bart's cousin  in 14 episodes, sharing the screen with Kelly in three of them, while Garner look-alike  appeared in two installments as a third brother wearing Bret's costume and named Brent, one of which briefly featured Kelly. The series was canceled after the fifth season, which consisted of Kelly appearing as the only Maverick in new episodes alternating with reruns of Garner shows from earlier seasons. The billing at the beginning of the show was reversed in the fifth season, with Kelly being billed above Garner. Kelly maintained that he was never notified of the cancellation by the studio but instead wound up learning about it in a newspaper article.\n\nFile:James Garner Bret Maverick Jack Kelly Bart Maverick.JPG| and Jack Kelly\nFile:James Garner Jack Kelly Maverick 1959.JPG|James Garner and Kelly\nFile:Jack Kelly Julie Adams Bart Maverick 1960.JPG| and Kelly \nFile:Jack Kelly Kathleen Crowley Mike Road Maverick 1962.JPG|Kelly,  and \nFile:Jack Kelly Paula Raymond Maverick 1961.JPG|Kelly and \nFile:Jack Kelly-Jackie Searl in Maverick.jpg|Kelly and \n\n\n\nWhen ''Maverick'' ended in 1962, Kelly continued acting with roles in a number of films and television shows. In 1962, he played the lead in ''Red Nightmare'' (also known as '''' in its derisive 1985 video re-release incarnation) a  film narrated by  in which Kelly's character wakes up one morning to discover that America has been taken over by . \n, , Kelly and ]]\n\nOn December 30, 1963, Kelly appeared in \"The Fenton Canaby Story\" on ABC's ''''. Canaby, played by Kelly, is a former trailmaster with a dark secret he refuses to discuss. He is attracted to Lucy Garrison, a young woman with her own questionable past portrayed by .\n\nKelly co-starred in '''' (1968) and as a villain dressed quite similarly to Bart Maverick who beats  with his belt in his hotel room in '''' (1969). From 1969 to 1971, Kelly hosted the daytime game show '''', but he was replaced by . He was also briefly a series regular in '''' (1974) and '''' (1978), and performed many lucrative television commercial .\n\nIn 1977 Kelly appeared as obstreperous villains for a few moments in two episodes of 's series ''''. The first appearance was in the season 3 episode \"The Becker Connection,\" and the second was the first show of season 4, \"Beamer's Last Case\" as a jealous husband. In 1978, he briefly appeared as Bart Maverick and was again paired with Garner in the TV movie '''' and in Garner's TV series '''' (1981; Kelly appeared momentarily at the end of the final episode of the show and would have become a regular had it been renewed). He showed up on a 1983 episode of '''', costumed as Bart Maverick but playing himself in a story that rounded up many classic TV cowboys. In 1991, he reprised the role of Bart Maverick one last time in the  vehicle ''''. Kelly died the following year.\n\n\nKelly's acting roles became less frequent in the late 1970s as he became more involved in real estate and local politics. He started buying real estate in Huntington Beach in the mid-1960s and moved there permanently in 1971.\n\nHe formed August II, Inc. to hold the real estate assets in June 1965 in Huntington Beach.\n\nHis wife Jo became a real estate broker and did much of the business management of the real estate business, especially while Kelly was involved with Huntington Beach city government.\n\nDuring the 1980s and early 1990s, he served as Huntington Beach city councilman and mayor] campaigning with the slogan \"Let Maverick Solve Your Problems.\"\n\n\n series leads  (''''),  (''''), Jack Kelly (''''),  (''''),  (''''),  ''(''), and  ('''').]]\n\nKelly married actress  (real name: Donna Lee Hickey) on October 14, 1956. They separated in February 1964 and were divorced on October 19, 1964. She stated in court that they had been arguing frequently the last two years and he started staying out all night.\n\nFollowing the divorce, he dated  for a short time.\n\nHe married Jo Ann Smith in Las Vegas, Nevada on October 16, 1969. The following November, their daughter Nicole was born. Nicole is the founder of and executive producer at August II Productions.\n\nOn April 28, 1992, Kelly suffered a heart attack. A little over six months later he died of a stroke at Humana Hospital in Huntington Beach, California on November 7, 1992. He was age 65.\n\nJo Kelly became an extra in film and television productions, helped others learn the business, and wrote the book ''The Truth about Being an Extra'' (2006).\n\nA , Jack Kelly supported  during the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Katherine Lauren Hill''' (born August 25, 1987) is an American former politician and  administrator from . A member of the , she served as the  for  from January to November 2019. Hill is the former  of People Assisting the Homeless (PATH), a statewide non-profit organization working to end homelessness throughout . She won her seat by defeating incumbent   in the .\n\nOn October 18, 2019, , a conservative blog, published a report on an alleged affair between Hill and her Legislative Director, which they both denied. On October 23, 2019, Hill admitted that she had had an inappropriate relationship with a campaign staffer before she became a Member of Congress. On October 27, 2019, she announced that she would resign from Congress. Nude photos of Hill were published by the '''', a British . Hill blamed the release of the photos on her ex-husband, called them an  and vowed to advocate for victims of . She left office on November 3, 2019.\n\nIn June 2021, Hill was ordered to pay US$220,000 to the ''Daily Mail'' and other media, to reimburse the legal fees these companies spent defending themselves against her accusations. Hill's attorneys plan to appeal the decision.\n\n\nHill was born in , and grew up in the  section of . Her mother, Rachel (née Campbell), was a , and her father, Michael Hill, was a police lieutenant. Hill attended public schools in the  and graduated from  in 2004. She attended  where she earned a  in English and a .\n\n\nHill began her career as a policy advocate at People Assisting the Homeless (PATH), a nonprofit organization developing affordable and supportive services for the . Her husband allegedly worked there as well, and it is claimed Hill was his boss. Later as the  for PATH, she raised the organization from a local force in  to one of the largest nonprofit providers of homes for the homeless in . Hill helped pass a , , during spring of 2017 to help alleviate homelessness by providing $1.2 billion in funds for homeless services in Los Angeles County.Pramuk, Jacob (April 4, 2018).  CNBC. Hill and her husband also raised  in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn March 8, 2017, Hill announced her candidacy for the  for , her home district, challenging incumbent , a Republican who had held the office since 2014.Panzar, Javier (March 8, 2017).  ''Los Angeles Times''. Knight won re-election in 2016.\n\nIn 2018, Hill came in second place in the , allowing her to advance to the November 6, 2018, general election, where she again faced Knight. In the general election, she defeated Knight by a 54% vs. 46% tally.\n\nShe was the subject of a documentary-style series of episodes that aired on the  show ''''. The series documented the Hill campaign as the \"most  campaign ever\" for Congress. ''Vice News Tonight'' reportedly planned on doing a follow-up episode regarding Hill's advancement to the general election. In the weeks leading up to the , Hill was endorsed by former President , who also attended a campaign event in  leading up to the election.\n\n\nHill stated during her race for office that her top issues were addressing healthcare, rebuilding the middle class with policies that address  and , and getting big money out of politics. She also stated her support for .\n\nHill reportedly ran a  campaign that didn't accept money from corporate . In the first quarter of 2018, she raised over $400,000, bringing her total to $1,092,025 raised, with more than 9,800 individual contributions and more than 5,100 individual donors.\n\nHill has supported comprehensive  while working towards greater funding and security along the southern border to counter primarily illegal drug trafficking and other various crimes. She also has supported some form of physical barrier along certain areas of the southern border.\n\nAccording to an October 2018 article in '''', Hill is an unabashed gun owner: \n\n\nBefore the start of the , Hill and  freshman U.S. Representative  were chosen as the freshman class representatives for the .\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n* '''''' (Vice Chair)\n** \n** \n* ''''''\n** \n\n\n*  (Co-Chair)\n* \n* \n\n\n\nOn October 18, 2019, the conservative political blog '''' published allegations that Hill was involved in an  with her young male staffer. Hill denied such allegations, with Hill saying that her  husband, whom she described as abusive, was doing everything he could to humiliate her, and that her political opponents were exploiting a private matter for political gain. Her husband denied the allegations of abuse. Hill reached out to the   to deny the allegations.\n\nOn October 23, 2019, Hill sent an email to constituents in which she admitted to an inappropriate relationship with a campaign staffer before becoming a member of Congress. The relationship was with a 22-year-old female subordinate recently out of college. ''RedState'' also published nude photos of Hill as part of the story. Hill said that the  opened an investigation into who may have leaked the photos.\n\n\nThe  announced on October 23, 2019, that it would conduct an investigation into the allegation that Hill had an affair with her staffer, which would be in violation of House ethics reforms that were implemented in 2018 in response to the  movement. Hill promised to cooperate with the Congressional ethics investigation regarding allegations of wrongdoing as a member of Congress.\n\n\nOn October 27, 2019, Hill announced via  that she would resign from Congress: \"This is the hardest thing I have ever had to do, but I believe it is the best thing for my constituents and our country.\" Speaker of the House  said Hill made \"some errors in judgment that made her continued service as a Member untenable\". Hill vowed to combat  after photos of her were leaked.\n\nIn her last speech before Congress on October 31, 2019, Hill said there was a \"\" and \" culture\" that resulted in her decision to step down from her position: }}\n\n\nOn December 7, 2019, Hill penned an  in '''' in which she described the events that led to her decision to resign, and mentions that she was suicidal during that time period.\n\nIn the  held in the spring of 2020, Hill endorsed  , who ultimately lost the election in an . Hill, whose PAC contributed $200,000, said that Smith had been considered \"the mom of Democratic politics\" in the district for years, and that \"there's no one else that I could even think of that I would want to run for this.\" Some Democrats regretted Hill's involvement in the campaign.\n\nHill released a memoir titled ''She Will Rise: Becoming a Warrior for True Equality'' in August 2020. Hill noted that, after her resignation,  reached out and offered to talk about some of the similarities and differences in their respective experiences being the victim of .\n\nIn December 2020, Hill filed a lawsuit against her ex-husband, the ''Daily Mail'', and RedState over . On April 7, 2021, a judge ruled in favor of the ''Daily Mail'', finding that the photos are protected as \"a matter of public issue or public interest\" under the . Hill's attorneys said they plan to appeal the decision. The judge also ordered Hill to pay roughly $220,000 in fees to the ''Daily Mail'' and a couple of journalists. In July 2022, Hill declared bankruptcy, which would allow her to avoid paying the defendants' attorney fees.\n\nOn April 5, 2021, Hill called for  to resign in an opinion piece for '''', after it was reported that Gaetz had allegedly shown pictures of naked women he claimed to have slept with, including to colleagues on the House floor. Gaetz had supported Hill after the leak of her photos, and Hill called him an \"unlikely friend\" during their time in Congress.\n\n'''' published an op-ed by Hill in September 2023. In it, Hill discusses the apparent rise in individuals creating intimate content of themselves, as well as the lack of accountability of bad actors using this content as political leverage against the creators. She cites her own incident in Congress as an example.\n\n\n election, 2018\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nHill  as  after high school. The tattoo has since been covered over after photos were published in 2019.\n\nIn July 2010, Hill married Kenny Heslep, whom she began dating just after high school. They resided in , on their farm, where they fostered . Heslep filed for divorce in 2019 and the divorce was settled in October 2020. In December 2020, a judge awarded Hill a  against her ex-husband.\n\nHill also rented an apartment in , with freshman representative .\n\nOn January 19, 2020, her half-brother, Daniel Bennett, died of a drug overdose at the age of 20.\n\nHill's , ''She Will Rise: Becoming a Warrior in the Battle for True Equality'', in which she shares her experiences from her time in politics, was published in 2020.\n\nBy July 2019, Hill was in a romantic relationship with Alex Thomas, a reporter and novelist. In October of 2021, Hill said that she and Thomas were expecting a child. She contracted  during the seventh month of her pregnancy, and gave birth to her son in early January 2022, seven weeks premature. Hill and Thomas married in March 2024.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Shamann Walton''' is an American politician. He has been a member of the  since 2019, representing , and served as President of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors from January 8, 2021 to January 8, 2023. Walton earlier served on the  and was its president immediately prior to his election as supervisor.\n\n\nWalton was raised by his mother in . His teenage years were often troubled, having been expelled from the  and served in  numerous times.\n\nWalton graduated from  in 1998. He received his master's degree in public administration from  in 2010.\n\n\nWalton was elected supervisor for District 10 on , receiving 9,550 first preference votes (41.22 percent of all valid votes). After allocation of preferences from eliminated candidates in San Francisco's  system, Walton received 63.07 percent of final-round votes, compared to runner-up Tony Kelly's 36.93 percent. He was sworn in at the Board of Supervisors' January 8, 2019 meeting, replacing , who was ineligible to run for re-election after  and had been elected to the .\n\nThe Board elected Walton to Board President in 2021.\n\n\nWalton was the only San Francisco Board of Supervisors member to explicitly reject a potential plan to allow four-plexes in San Francisco in areas previously restricted to single-family housing (which had been implemented in the neighboring city of Sacramento). He stated that the Sacramento bill \"would speed up the gentrification\" and \"this policy is bad for San Francisco.\"\n\nIn 2019, Walton supported a resolution that expressed opposition to California , which mandates denser housing near “job-rich” areas and transit hubs.\n\n\nIn December 2018, Walton and supervisor  put forth legislation calling to close San Francisco's  by December 2021.\n\nIn June 2020, during the nationwide , he introduced a resolution to ban the  and  from hiring officers with a history of serious misconduct. In October, he introduced the CAREN act, which would make fraudulent s motivated by  illegal.\n\n\nIn February 2020, Walton put forth a resolution calling for  for the city's African American population. The resolution itself forms a working group that will further develop the plan.\n\nIn July 2022, Walton admitted to using a racial slur against an African American sheriff's cadet at San Francisco City Hall because he was frustrated with having to take off his belt for metal detectors. Walton was later determined by the city's human resources director to have retaliated against the cadet for filing a report, in violation of city policy.\n\nIn 2024, Walton passed an ordinance which declares Vietnamese as an official language of San Francisco. As a rationale for the change, Supervisor Walton stated, \"San Francisco is home to many diverse immigrant communities and is a national leader in providing language access services with one of the strongest and most comprehensive local language access laws.\"\n\n\nIn July 2020, Walton and supervisor  opted to not introduce a $100 million sales tax measure into the November 2020 ballots to finance , which has seen a 95% reduction in ridership due to the . Ride fares account for 70% of the service's operating budget. The supervisors cite the lack of shared authority on the Joint Powers Board over the train line's management, which was operated by the , and the  of the sales tax to fund operations for a service whose customer base has a mean income of $120,000 as pain points to supporting the measure. However, Peskin mentioned that the measure can still be introduced by the mayor or other supervisors if they wanted to. The supervisors later changed their minds when Caltrain pledged to make changes to its structure, making it more independent from SamTrans.\n\nDuring the COVID-19 pandemic, John F Kennedy Drive in  was made car-free. Walton and  opposed making the JFK Drive car-free after the pandemic. Walton argued that keeping the street car-free was segregationist and recreational . Data obtained by the  showed that no district showed a change in its proportion of overall visits to JFK Drive by more than 1.5% during the pandemic, with Walton's District 10 showing a decrease of 0.3%.\n\n\nWalton is a Christian. He is a father of two.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* }}\n* }}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Susan Talamantes Eggman''' (born March 3, 1961) is an American  who is currently serving in the . A , she represents the , which encompasses western ; since January 19, 2022, she has served as Assistant Majority Leader.\n\nPrior to being elected to the Senate in 2020, she was a member of the  representing the  as well as being a  woman and Associate Professor of social work at .\n\nEggman, a lesbian, is a member and past chair of the . She is also a member of the California Latino Legislative Caucus.\n\nLaws she has written include the law establishing the California Solar on Multifamily Affordable Housing Program, the End of Life Option Act, and the law establishing the ’s Discovery Challenge Academy in French Camp.\n\n\nSusan C. Eggman was born 3 March 1961, in , Talamantes is her mother's maiden name. Her brother Michael ran in the primary, for , on June 5, 2018.\n\nEggman grew up in  and graduated from  in 1979. After graduation, she enlisted in the , where she served four years from 1979 to 1983 as a  at the  army hospital, Maryland. After the military, she attended , where she earned both a  in psychology and a . She later earned a  in social work from .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn May 19, 2019, Eggman announced that she would be a candidate for the  in  in 2020. Incumbent state Senator  was not eligible for reelection due to term limits.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jane Jungyon Kim''' (born July 9, 1977) is an American attorney and politician, and the first  elected official in San Francisco. She represented San Francisco's  on the  between 2011 and 2019. She is a member of the San Francisco's Democratic County Central Committee. She is executive director of the California .\n\nPrior to her election to the Board of Supervisors, Kim was a member and then president of the . In 2016, she ran for the , but lost to  in a  after finishing first place in the primary. She was a candidate for mayor in the , finishing third with 24.03% of the first-round vote.\n\nShe was the California political director and national regional political director for ' 2020 presidential campaign.\n\n\nJane Kim was born in  on July 9, 1977, to South Korean parents who immigrated to the U.S. from  in 1971.\n\nKim grew up learning both the English and Korean languages. Her mother owned a store selling women's clothing. Her father joined Kiss Products, a global cosmetics company, while she was in college.  At age 14, Kim began studying , eventually earning a . She was involved with community activism, especially the issue of . While attending , a New York prep school, she stopped reciting the  in her teensshe rejected the Pledge words \"with liberty and justice for all,\" because she saw that LGBT people were not treated equally.\n\nKim graduated from  with a bachelor's degree in Political Science and Asian American Studies. She settled in San Francisco and attended the . Kim earned a J.D. degree and was admitted to the  in 2009.\n\n\n\nAfter graduating from Stanford, Kim worked as a Fellow at  in San Francisco and then as a Youth Community Organizer at the  (CCDC). Reverend Norman Fong, who interviewed her, took a risk in hiring Kim as she was not Chinese American and did not speak Chinese but “she won him over.” Kim successfully led a youth volunteer and leadership program in  for six years. Through her community organization efforts, she met power broker .\n\nIn 2005 Kim was elected president of the San Francisco People's Organization (SFPO), made up of many notable San Francisco activists and organizers. SFPO worked against several s in November 2005, and assisted with health care and affordable housing measures for San Franciscans through 2006.\n\n\n. She became the first Korean American elected official in the city's history.]]\nIn 2003 while campaigning for   , Kim observed that Asian Americans were not well represented in San Francisco politics despite the size of its population. In 2004, she decided to run for the . In a field of 12 candidates seeking four seats, Kim came in seventh place; her bid failed in part because she was a member of the minority Green Party and did not have the backing of the . In 2006, Kim mounted a stronger campaign and she came in first in a field of 15 candidates seeking three seats. Kim was the top vote getter in every district except Marina/Cow Hollow, West of Twin Peaks and Castro/Noe Valley. In 2007, she became the first Korean American elected official in San Francisco. Kim's election was part of a more liberal shift in the school board joining Fellow Green , , and Kim-Shree Maufas.\n\nIn 2006, the school board took up the issue of whether to continue the 90-year-old  (JROTC) program in San Francisco high schools. The board voted to phase out the JROTC program over two years. In December 2006, previous to taking office, Kim learned about a death threat against her that was sent from a JROTC cadet to his friend on Facebook. The cadet had also used  to threaten a high school girl who argued prominently against JROTC. Kim spoke to the cadet herself and reported that he sincerely regretted his actions. Kim took the position that the JROTC program should not be hosted by San Francisco as long as the U.S. military continued its \"\" policy. In June 2008 Kim and  submitted a proposal to accept JROTC programs as optional after-school activities, without giving students  (P.E.) credit toward graduation. In October, Kim proposed an alternative program called Student Emergency Response Volunteers (SERV) that would train students in emergency preparedness and disaster relief. The bid to remove or replace JROTC failed in a 3–4 vote held in May 2009.\n\nIn March 2008, Kim and Sanchez traveled to Israel as members of the U.S. Green Party to investigate whether the party should continue to support the  program targeting Israel for its occupation of Palestine. Kim complimented a  program near Haifa, recommending its director be brought to San Francisco to help train educators.\n\nKim re-registered with the Democratic Party in 2008 after  was elected president.\n\nIn 2010, she was elected president of the Board of Education. As board president, Kim had to negotiate statewide budget cuts that resulted in a two-year shortfall of $113&nbsp;million for San Francisco schools. She authored and led the first district-wide Restorative Justice Program to address the disproportionate suspension and expulsions of African American students and won a pilot to establish ethnic studies classes in all San Francisco public high schools. Kim stated that the program will “be a cost savings to the district if we’re able to retain more students” and that there is “flexibility to find funding” in a budget of $400&nbsp;million.\n\n\nKim had lived in various neighborhoods of San Francisco, including Polk Gulch and the Sunset. She moved to District 6 in 2009 and subsequently ran in the  election to fill the seat being vacated by Supervisor . District 6 includes , , , , , , , , , , and . Kim announced her candidacy in January 2010, then she kicked off her campaign in June, at a party attended by former mayors  and , as well as the President of the Board of Supervisors, , who knew Kim from having shared housing for more than two years. Kim ran against several candidates, including , who was endorsed by mayor , and liberal Debra Walker, who was endorsed by the Democratic Party and most labor unions. When Brown contributed $5000 to the Kim campaign, some of her progressive supporters questioned whether Kim was being supported by a . Kim's campaign was seen as having the approval of Rose Pak, but the California Democratic machine of the 1960s and '70s was \"dormant\".\n\nKim won the race for supervisor in an upset victory. When she was sworn in she became the first Korean American  in the nation. She told '''' magazine that without the backing of labor unions and the media, and with her own Democratic Party endorsing her opponent, the only strategy she had available was the \"old-fashioned\" one of visiting as many constituents as possible. This was called Kim's \"Fifty-Nine Precinct Strategy\" (referring to 's ) because of the many neighborhoods of the district that were targeted. Less support came from the Korean community, who participated little in the election, than from Chinese American supporters, especially senior citizens in Chinatown, and a broad base of San Francisco youth.\n\n\nKim stood up during the  at Board of Supervisors meetings but refused to recite it in keeping with the decision she had made in her youth. Within a few weeks of being sworn in, her silence gained the attention of local and national news media. She said in 2011 that the words \"liberty and justice for all\" were not yet a reality for many in the United States including communities of color, the LGBT community, immigrants and women. Kim said she was committed to \"helping our nation achieve those ideals.\" On July 10, 2013, following the  decision in '''', declaring unconstitutional the federal  (DOMA), Kim recited the Pledge along with the other supervisors. Kim said that, for her, DOMA had \"symbolized th[e] inequity\" of American justice.\n\n\n and Supervisor Kim pose with Jessica Robinson Love, left]]\nTwitter is an online  that was headquartered in District 6 on Folsom Street when Kim took office. In January 2011, Twitter announced it was considering moving a few miles south to the city of  because the company was expanding and needed ten times more space. Mayor  indicated that he wanted Twitter to stay, so Kim led a team made up of mayoral staffers and Supervisor  to quickly shape a proposal which she sponsored in early February: Twitter would benefit from a six-year payroll tax exemption on net new jobs if it moved into the neglected and distressed mid-Market Street neighborhood of Kim's district. Talks centered on the company moving to the old Furniture Mart, a large  office building vacant since 2008. Kim's tax break proposal would apply to any large company willing to settle in the economically depressed area. Observers felt that this, Kim's first proposal as supervisor, signaled a break with her previous progressive record, to show a pro-business aspect. Former supervisor Chris Daly was critical; he said the plan could not help the city's budget shortfall, a serious problem resulting in jobs and services being cut. Agreeing with this assessment, Local 1021 of the  (SEIU) also opposed the plan. Other businesses expressed anger that they would be unable to take advantage of the tax break. The city Controller's Office reported that the difference between Twitter leaving entirely or moving to mid-Market with the tax break was possibly worth $54&nbsp;million in added revenue spread over 20 years.\n\nIn April 2011, the Board of Supervisors voted to approve the payroll tax exemption plan. Two weeks later, Twitter signed a ten-year lease on the Furniture Mart building. The Twitter tax break remained a defining issue in the : Incumbent Lee supported the exemption while challenger  criticized it. Lee retained his seat in the election. By June 2012, Twitter had settled 800 employees into the new location renamed Market Square, and Kim was invited to visit. She posted a photo of Twitter's new \"micro health kitchen\". Other tech companies such as  and  took advantage of the payroll tax exemption plan.\n\n\n]]\nIn 2010, Supervisor  represented District 5, which shared a border with District 6. Mirkarimi, a fellow ex-Green Party member and progressive politician, accompanied Kim one day during her District 6 door-to-door campaigning in the border area.\n\nMirkarimi was elected sheriff in 2011, but he was soon embroiled in a controversy regarding violence allegations that he had restrained his wife by grabbing and bruising her arm. For this he was suspended by Mayor Lee. About two out of three San Franciscans polled said they thought Mirkarimi should not be reinstated as sheriff. Despite this popular sentiment, in October 2012, Mirkarimi was reinstated through the votes of four progressive supervisors: Kim, Avalos,  and . Kim said she voted to reinstate Mirkarimi because his wrongdoing was less than that described by the city charter as grounds for removal. On the other hand, she said she would support a  to remove Mirkarimi by popular vote. '''' columnist  criticized Kim's position as that of a \"political weathervane,\" unworthy of a leader. '''' editor Steven T. Jones was more supportive, describing how Kim was persistent in questioning Deputy City Attorney Sherri Kaiser to determine what misdemeanor might be considered too small for the mayor to dismiss any elected official. Kim explained to her supporters that her decision was based on Mirkarimi not abusing the power of his office to commit wrongdoing, a point required by the city charter. She also expressed her worry that the case would have set a  allowing the mayor too much power over elected officials. '''' columnist Joe Eskenazi suggested that Kim's support for Mirkarimi kept her out of the running for president of the board of supervisors in 2014.\n\n\nIn March 2013, after Polish labor organizer  made anti-gay remarks, Kim announced that she would seek to rename San Francisco's tiny Lech Walesa Street. The narrow one-way street was originally named Ivy Street but was changed in 1983 to honor Wałęsa. Kim suggested that  co-founder  be honored instead of Wałęsa, especially since the Tom Waddell Health Center was at that location. The San Francisco Board of Supervisors voted unanimously to change the name as Kim proposed.\n\n\n in 2010]]\nKim has tackled several issues regarding the use of bicycles in San Francisco. While serving on the Board of Education, she supported new bike racks for eight middle schools, and she promoted Bike-to-School Day. Though she never rode a bike in her childhood or at college, Kim told the  in 2010 that she had been introduced to the city's \"bike culture\" and was slowly learning how to ride, a process that heightened her awareness of  concerns. In 2011,  she rode as a passenger on the rear of an extended bike, but on May 10, 2012, she pedaled herself to . With Mayor Lee, Kim backed the Yerba Buena Street Life Plan which was announced in 2011 for the area around  in District 6. The plan included new bike paths and more bike parking. In September 2013 when the  was criticized for its investigation of a cyclist fatality that happened the previous month, Kim requested a hearing to discuss improvements for such police procedures. Along with Supervisors Yee and Avalos, in January 2014 Kim called for the city to adopt a multifaceted bicycle and pedestrian safety initiative modeled after the Swedish  program. Kim ushered the most protected bike lanes, 18.6 miles, of any San Francisco Supervisor during her time.\n\n\nSan Francisco supervisors had previously tried unsuccessfully to reform the process by which a citizen could use the 1970  (CEQA) appeals process to challenge a building project on the basis of its environmental impact. In 2012 Supervisor  proposed new rules that would restrict such challenges. Bicycling advocate Ben Christopher was supportive of Wiener's proposal, citing one instance in 2005 when a single citizen held up the city's comprehensive bicycle plan. However, critics such as the  said the proposed changes would weaken CEQA's protections. In April 2013 Kim proposed a competing set of reform rules which Eric Brooks of the Green Party reported as \"more CEQA friendly.\" Wiener and Kim hammered out a proposal combining elements of both versions; this was passed unanimously by the Board in July 2013. Kim said the reformed rules would not prevent the public from \"giving input\" to construction projects.\n\n\nIn September 2016, Kim authored the Evictions Protections 2.0 bill to protect tenants from \"no fault\" evictions, which had seen an uptick. This rise in \"no fault\" evictions coincided with a spike in market rent, causing landlords to evict tenants in rent controlled units in order to rent spaces at the higher market rate. 83% of the city's evictions were no fault evictions. \n\nThe ordinance prohibits landlords from evicting tenants for small infractions, dubbed “gotcha evictions,” such as leaving shoes or strollers in the hall, painting a bedroom, hanging laundry out to dry, etc. The bill also removed lease restrictions created by landlords on roommates that are less than the maximum number of persons permitted by applicable laws, such as the SF Housing Code.\n\nThe legislation was co-sponsored by Supervisors Campos, Mar, and Avalos and was passed on October 14, 2015.\n\n\nIn April 2015, the  and Mayor Lee announced a large community development proposal, Mission Rock, to replace the parking lots near , where the baseball team plays. The proposal required voter approval in November 2015. In May 2015, the Giants announced that 33% of the project would be devoted to affordable housing, to match Mayor Lee's goal for all new construction. Kim determined that a larger proportion of the project should be devoted to affordable housing, and she drafted a competing ballot initiative with the assistance of  (TODCO), a non-profit community housing planning group. The danger of a competing ballot initiative brought the Giants to negotiate. Kim and the Giants worked out a deal to increase the project's affordable housing to 40%, and Kim dropped her own ballot initiative.\n\nIn 2021, Kim was involved in efforts to lobby against the construction of a 495-unit apartment complex  on a parking lot next to a BART station in San Francisco which only committed to 14.5% affordable units on-site for residents who make between 50-110% AMI (individuals who earn $45,000-93,000/year, unaffordable to low-income residents in South of Market and Tenderloin). The next year, a proponent of project filed an ethics complaint against her, alleging that she worked as a lobbyist for TODCO in opposing the housing project. Kim was reported to be a paid employee for TODCO, supplying TODCO-prepared materials to the Board of Supervisors. Kim responded that she advocated against the housing project on her own time. City ethics regulations bar ex-officials from lobbying on issues that they covered while in office.\n\n\nIn April 2016, Kim proposed that tuition should be free at  (CCSF), which had seen a 30% decline in students over the previous four years, had lost $35&nbsp;million in state funding tied to attendance, and was in danger of losing its accreditation and more state funding. Some 20% of the college students had already been granted a fee waiver by the City of San Francisco; Kim said that these students should also have free books, transportation and child care. Vermont Senator , himself a proponent of free college tuition, voiced support for the idea. To pay for this idea, Kim authored a real estate tax initiative to raise taxes on real estate sales and transfers over $5&nbsp;million, with the goal of increasing city revenue by about $45&nbsp;million per year. Voters approved Kim's Proposition W at the ballot in November 2016. CCSF's accreditation was confirmed for seven more years starting in January 2017. The next month, Mayor Lee and Kim announced a deal through which the city would pay $5.4&nbsp;million per year to CCSF students who had lived in San Francisco for at least one year, so that they could pay their tuition. The deal, called Free City, also provided $250 cash per semester for each low-income student who attended CCSF full-time, as well as $100 per semester for part-time students. The cash grants were for the students to pay for books, transportation, supplies, and health care. The Free City program was described by  as the first time that a US city made  tuition free for all its residents. In September 2017 when the program began, enrollment at CCSF increased by 6,450 students, a \"huge boost\". Sanders spoke at CCSF to praise the successful program as \"a model\" for the whole country.\n\n\nKim ran for the  in 2016 against Scott Wiener. Kim received slightly more votes than Wiener in the primary election, but when the general election was held \n\nKim was a candidate in the , held in June 2018 following the sudden death of Mayor Lee in December 2017. Kim was seen as one of the top four candidates, along with ,  and . She received 24% of the vote in the election, finishing in third place. Because the election was conducted with , most of Kim's votes were apportioned to the remaining two candidates in Round 8, with two-thirds of Kim voters choosing Leno as their next alternative, and one-fifth of Kim voters choosing Breed. The larger Kim apportionment to Leno did not overturn the strong lead taken early by Breed, and Breed was elected mayor.\n\n\n\nKim plays electric bass guitar and has performed with the all-female indie rock band Strangely at small San Francisco venues including the Brainwash Cafe and Laundromat. In 2000 she co-founded Locus Arts in , a non-profit gallery and media performance space formed to support Asian American art; the gallery eventually merged with . For the  she served on the board of directors. She helped to save Bindlestiff Studio, a place for Filipino arts in SoMa. Kim occasionally serves as a judge at  competitions held by Youth Speaks. In 2004 she said her favorite musical artists included the , a collective of hip-hop musicians such as rapper  and hip-hop duo . In 2010 she said her favorite song was \"\" released in 1997 by the .\n\nKim was selected by '''' magazine as one of \"20 Hot 2010\" persons in September 2010. She was pictured on the cover of '''' in October 2010. Kim was featured on the cover of '''' magazine in February 2011. ''Nark'' magazine interviewed Kim in June 2012, asking her about her nightlife preferences. She said she appreciated the work of San Francisco Entertainment Commissioners who ease the friction between nightlife venues and local residents. Kim said wine and single-malt whiskey were drinks she enjoyed, especially .\n\nIn August 2016, Kim was reportedly dating  Associate Justice .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Willard H. Murray Jr.''' (January 1, 1931 – December 20, 2021) was an American politician who served as a member of the  from 1988 until 1996. Murray made an unsuccessful run for congress in a special election in 1996 when he lost to . After that loss, he left the Assembly due to .\n\n\nAfter working as an engineer throughout the 1950s, he became involved politically with the onset of the Civil Rights Movement in the 1960s. He served on the staffs of Los Angeles City Councilmen Robert Farrell and Billy Mills. On a state level, he served on the staffs of Lieutenant Governor  and as an advisor to the Senate Democratic Caucus. As a politician Murray focused on education, crime control, economic development, family values, homeless veterans, and pediatric and prenatal care for the poor.\n\n\nMurray established the first Institute on the Preservation of Jazz as an Artform at , and established the Center for African-American Educational Excellence and Achievement at . Murray coauthored legislation which provides for Superintendents of Education in both the CDC and the California Youth Authority to have literacy programs for inmates to preempt recidivism. In 1997, the government of California rewarded Murray with a section of the State Route 91 named after him.\n\n\nHe was married to Barbara Murray. They had two children, , a former state senator from California's 26th Senate District and Melinda, a Deputy District Attorney for Los Angeles County. He died on December 20, 2021, at the age of 90.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|children      = 2\n|education     =  ()\n}}\n'''Victor Herbert Fazio Jr.''' (October 11, 1942 &ndash; March 16, 2022) was an American politician who served as a member of the  for California from 1979 to 1999.\n\n\nFazio was born in , the son of Betty Virginia (Freeman) and V. Herbert Fazio. He was of Italian and New England  descent. After graduating from Madison High School in  in 1960, Fazio attended  in  in 1961. He earned a  from  in , in 1965, and did graduate work at , from 1969 to 1972. From 1965 to 1966 he was a  Fellow in Los Angeles.\n\n\n\n\nFazio was a congressional and legislative consultant from 1966 to 1975, during which time he co-founded ''California Journal'' magazine in 1970. He served on the  Charter Commission from 1972 to 1974, on the Sacramento County Planning Commission in 1975, and as a member of the  from 1975 to 1978.\n\nFazio was a delegate to California state Democratic conventions in 1976 and 1978, and was a delegate to s of 1976, 1980, 1984, 1988, 1992, and 1996.\n\n\nFazio was elected as a Democrat to the  and to the nine succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1979 – January 3, 1999). He represented  from 1979 to 1993 and after redistricting changed district numbers he represented  from 1993 to 1999.\n\nAs congressman, he lobbied to set aside area as a wildlife refuge below the I-80 overpass between  and . His efforts led to the establishment of the , dedicated in 1997 by President . The region is in  and is known to locals as the 'Yolo Bypass,' a seasonal wetlands generated by controlled fall, winter, and spring flooding. The refuge provides valuable winter habitat for waterfowl and shorebirds. It is additionally used as a Pacific Flyway stop-over by migrant waterfowl and shorebirds during fall and spring migrations, and can be accessed for visitation by an auto tour route.\n\nFazio won his first seven terms without serious difficulty, but his district was made measurably more rural and  after the 1990s round of redistricting.  He only won 51 percent of the vote in 1992 against former state senator .  In 1994, he was nearly defeated, winning by only three percentage points. In 1996 he was elected by a larger margin, winning 54%.  He announced he would not run for re-election in 1998, in November of the prior year.\n\n\nFazio worked as a senior advisor in the Washington office of  and sat on the board of . \nHe served as co-chair of the , a public policy . He also sat on the Council on American Politics, bringing together leaders from across the nation to address issues facing the growth and enrichment of . In addition, he served on the board of directors of the . After leaving office, he became involved in political reform efforts, including joining nine other former members of Congress to co-author a 2021 opinion editorial advocating reforms of Congress. He was also a member of the ReFormers Caucus of .\n\n\nAfter his first marriage to Joella Mason ended in divorce, Fazio was subsequently married to Judy Kern (formerly Judith G. Neidhardt) from 1983 until her death in 2015, aged 71. He then married Kathy Sawyer, a retired journalist, in 2017. He had two daughters from his first marriage to Mason, Dana and Anne; and two step-children from his second marriage to Kern, Kevin and Kristie.  Anne died from complications of leukemia in 1995.\n\nFazio died of  at his home in , on March 16, 2022, at the age of 79.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* Catalogue entry at Special Collections Dept., University Library, University of California, Davis\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kenneth Frederick Hahn''' (August 19, 1920 – October 12, 1997) was a member of the  for forty years, from 1952 to 1992.  Hahn was on the  from 1947 to 1952. He was an ardent supporter of civil rights throughout the 1960s, and met  in 1961.\n\n\nHahn was born August 19, 1920, in , the son of Hattie Louise (Wiggins) of , Canada, and John Heinrich Hahn. The couple moved from Saskatchewan to Los Angeles in , and Hahn's father died just a few months later. The couple had six other sonsHenry, John, Allan, Louis, George, and .\n\nHe went to public schools in Los Angeles, including John Muir Junior High School and , class of 1938. He graduated from  in 1942. He received a master's degree in education while he was on the City Council. He also had a  teaching credential.\n\nHahn began his working career as a partner in the Hahn Brothers'  at 6300 South Main Street, at the foot of San Pedro Street in the South Park area. Before World War II he was a messenger for the County Probation Department and the Los Angeles Police  Department.\n\n\nHahn entered the Navy as an  in 1942 and earned a commission after studying at naval schools at  and  universities. He was a ship's  in , the youngest pilot in the history of the . He served with the  in the  as the commanding officer of a  and was discharged in  as a . After the war, in 1947, he taught American government and history at .\n\n\nHahn's first try for public office was as a candidate for the State Assembly in the 66th District in June 1946. Hahn, a Democrat, won the Republican nomination in the primary election but lost the Democratic nomination, and therefore he could not compete. Instead the Republicans were able to nominate another candidate at a .\n\n\n\nHahn unseated , the incumbent in , in 1947. He was supported by students at Pepperdine College, which at that time was located in the 8th District: they circulated his nominating petitions and did house-to-house campaigning for him. At age 26 he was the youngest person elected to the City Council to that time. He was reelected in 1949 and 1951. In that era, the 8th District was bounded on the north by Vernon Avenue, on the west by , on the east by the city limits or  and on the south by about . , ''Los Angeles Times'', November 30, 1940, page A-3. Includes a map.\n\nHahn left the council on December 1, 1952, when he became a county supervisor.\n\n\n\n'''Jail, 1947.''' He urged a delay in the building of  until the council could hear from Assemblyman Vernon Kilpatrick, who declared in a letter that the proposed lockup represented \"outmoded thinking concerning jail programs\" and suggested that the money be spent for more \"sunshine and fresh air\" prison camps. His motion failed on a 6–6 vote.\n\n'''Smog, 1949.''' The council adopted Hahn's resolution asking Air Pollution Control Director Gordon P. Larson to appear before it to report on the worsening  situation in Los Angeles. \"The entire smog program seems to have bogged down,\" he said. \"Yesterday it was almost impossible to breathe in my office, and I am informed that some places had to shut down completely.\"\n\n'''Feud, 1950.''' He and Councilman  engaged in what was called a \"feud\" over various subjects, including their differences concerning the subject of continuing wartime  in Los Angeles, with Hahn favoring and Harby opposing. Harby also called a suggestion by Hahn for a pay raise for city employees \"political prostitution in its lowest form.\" Harby used the same term, calling Hahn a \"political prostitute\" in a raucous debate over the fate of a $110-million-dollar  proposal for the city (Hahn in favor and Harby opposed). At one point, Harby \"reached over\" and shoved Hahn back into his seat.\n\n'''Birds, 1951.''' Hahn proposed a special police patrol to protect birds nesting on the City Hall grounds. The idea was referred to a committee.\n\n'''Un-American, 1952.''' Hahn and Council Members ,  and  attended a dinner meeting in  to honor the .\n\n\n. It was approved and adopted in 1957, and was used until September 2004, when it was replaced by a slightly-modified version.]]\nHahn was elected to the County Board of Supervisors for the first time in 1952. He was elected to his tenth term in 1988 with 84% of the vote. He was known  for his promotion of social causes,  to Los Angeles and putting emergency call boxes along freeways. In 1970 he joined with his personal physician, cardiologist , to establish the first system of emergency paramedic care in California; Hahn is credited with winning support for the then-radical idea from the Board of Supervisors and the state legislature, and persuading then-governor  to sign the bill authorizing the provision of emergency medical care by trained personnel other than doctors and nurses.\n\nAt the Board of Supervisors, Hahn designed the County Seal adopted in 1957, which was modified in 2004 due to the  on the seal. The  had threatened a lawsuit if the county had not removed the cross. , laavenue.com\n\nIn 1961, Hahn was the only public official to greet  when he came to Los Angeles \"after confronting the police dogs and water hoses of Birmingham\". After  in April 1968, Hahn asked King’s wife,  if a new hospital could be named after him.  opened in 1972.\n\nAt the , Hahn proposed and eventually achieved consensus in favor of putting a proposition on the ballot that not only included funding for a rail network (controversial in some suburban communities), but also funding for local transit to be spent by the local communities as well as lower bus fares for three years. While the two previous rail transit ballot measures were rejected by the electorate, the compromise  was approved at the November 4, 1980 election by 54% of voters and eventually led to the creation of the  network.\n\n\nHahn died of heart failure on October 12, 1997, at the age of 77 in an Inglewood hospital.Wahlgren, Eric (1977),  , ''Los Angeles Daily News'' A funeral service was held at Faith Dome of  on Vermont Avenue, and interment followed at .\n\n\nHahn was married to Ramona Hahn. They had two children, James and Janice. They lived at 833-1/2 West 69th Street in the Vermont-Slauson district. He was a \"deeply religious man who often quoted Scripture\".\n\nHahn was reported to have suffered a stroke in 1987, from which he recovered over a lengthy period of time.  His recovery did not substantially affect his popularity or reelection.\n\nHahn belonged to an influential political dynasty, the : One brother, , replaced him on the Los Angeles City Council, while another, John, was assistant county clerk. His son, , was Los Angeles city attorney from 1985 to 2001 and mayor from 2001 to 2005. James Hahn is now a judge on the .\n\nHahn's daughter, , was on the Los Angeles City Council and was a member of the ; she is now on the County Board of Supervisors. A nephew, Dale Hahn, was a Superior Court judge (in ) until retiring in 2004.\n\n\nHahn is memorialized in the name of the main county building in  as the .\n\nHe is also remembered in the naming of a large park in , the . The  station on the  of the  is named in his honor.\n\nFor his contribution to sports in Los Angeles, he was honored with a   plaque by the Coliseum commissioners.\n\n\nAccess to the ''Los Angeles Times'' links may require the use of a library card.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Anthony Rendon''' (born March 4, 1968) is an American politician who served as the 70th  from 2016 to 2023. A member of the  he is the second-longest serving speaker in California history (and the longest-serving speaker to serve his first term after the adoption of California's term limits).  Since 2022, he has represented the , located in the southeastern part of , including the cities of , , and . He previously represented the  from 2012 to 2022.\n\nIn 2023, POLITICO reported that Rendon's speakership was \"one of California's most consequential speakerships\", and that he \"has presided over a progressive policy bonanza\", as California \"hiked the minimum wage, gave farmworkers overtime, enacted ambitious climate laws, expanded early childhood education, and delivered landmark labor wins\".\n\n\nRendon was born on March 4, 1968 in , a neighborhood in central . His grandparents  from  to the  during the 1920s. He grew up in a  family that frequently moved around the . His father, Tom Rendon, worked multiple jobs, including for a mobile home company, and his mother, Gloria Rendon, was a teacher's aide at a Catholic school.\n\nRendon attended , graduating in 1986. He has stated that he was a \"terrible student.\" At the age of 20, he enrolled in and attended , a  in , before earning a  and  from . After receiving a  fellowship, Rendon earned his  in  from the , graduating in 2000. He completed  at .\n\nPrior to becoming a member of the , Rendon was the executive director of  Child Development Services, an organization that provides child development and social and medical services throughout . He was also the interim executive director of the , a lobbying organization dedicated to environmental issues. He worked with the Mexican American Opportunity Foundation in . From 2001 to 2008, he was an  in the Department of Political Science and Criminal Justice at .\n\n\n\nDuring his first term in office, Rendon was chair of the Assembly Committee on Water, Parks, and Wildlife and authored Proposition 1, the $7.5 billion state water bond, which voters approved in the November 2014 election.\n\nIn 2013, Rendon authored Assembly Bill 711, a statewide ban on lead hunting ammunition, that was signed into law.\n\nIn 2015, Rendon was named chair of the Assembly Committee on Utilities and Commerce.\n\nOn September 3, 2015, Rendon was selected to be the next Assembly Speaker.  The formal vote electing Rendon as Speaker occurred on January 11.  The vote was unanimous, with the Republican leader seconding the motion.\n\nRendon brought back the tradition of past California Assembly speakers of carrying no legislation himself, but focusing on empowering the members of the chamber.  Despite this, he has made certain priorities of his known, including wildfire planning, and continuing to address poverty and educational deficits in California.\n\nOn February 19, 2021, '''' reported that nonprofit organizations associated with Rendon's wife, Annie Lam, had received over $500,000 in donations and event sponsorships from over a dozen companies that had business interests at stake with the legislature.  In 2023, the '''' reported that she received an unusually large income ($600,000 in 2022) from her job as a consultant, much of it from organizations with business before the legislature, and reported that others in government were concerned about ethical considerations.\n\nIn November 2022 due to a rift in the Assembly Democratic Caucus between its progressive and moderate members, the caucus voted to replace Rendon with Assemblymember  as the next speaker of the California State Assembly. With Rendon to remain as Speaker until June 30, 2023.\n\nRendon is a member of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100%\n}}\n\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100%\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\nRendon resides in . In December 2014, Rendon married Annie Lam in a ceremony officiated by former  .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

In his final term in the Assembly, Firebaugh served concurrently as Assembly  and  of the California   .\n\nAt the time of his death, Firebaugh had been seeking the Democratic nomination for the 30th district seat in the , and was removed from the ballot.\n\n\nFirebaugh was a resident of . He died from complications from a liver ailment with which he was diagnosed in 2003.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n#\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Lois Ragnhild Capps''' (née '''Grimsrud'''; January 10, 1938) is an American politician who served as the  for  from 1998 to 2017. She is a member of the . The district, numbered as the 22nd District from 1998 to 2003 and the 23rd from 2003 to 2013, includes all of  and  counties and a portion of .\n\nCapps served on the , where she was a member of the Energy and Air Quality Subcommittee and the Subcommittee on Health. She was a member of the .\n\n\nCapps was born Lois Ragnhild Grimsrud in , the daughter of Solveig Magdalene (née Gullixson) and Rev. Jurgen Milton Grimsrud, a  minister. Both of her parents' families came from . She has lived in  since 1964. She was educated at  with a bachelor's degree in . She earned a master's degree in religion at  in 1964 and a  degree in education at the  in 1990.\n\n\n\nWalter Capps was elected to Congress in 1996 in a rematch of his 1994 race against  . However, he died of a heart attack on October 28, 1997, only nine months into his term. His widow won the then- seat by defeating Republican  in a  on March 10, 1998. She was sworn into the 105th Congress on March 17. Lois Capps defended her seat against Bordonaro in a general election later that year and commenced her first full term in office.\n\nIn 2000, Capps retained the 22nd district seat, defeating Republican Mike Stoker with 53% of the vote. She was the first Democrat to hold the district for more than one term in over 50 years (the district, known as the 11th from its formation in 1943 until 1953, the 13th from 1953 to 1975, and the 19th from 1975 to 1993, had been held by Republicans from 1947 until Walter Capps was sworn in 1997).\n\nCapps' district was renumbered as the 23rd after the 2000 census and made somewhat safer, and she was reelected without serious opposition in 2002, 2004, 2006, 2008, and 2010. Her district was renumbered as the 24th District after the 2010 census. David Wasserman, House editor of '''', predicted that this would be a more difficult race, and local Republicans confirmed that Capps was one of their top targets in California. The reconfigured district still includes Santa Barbara and , but was redrawn to include most of the more Republican inland areas of Santa Barbara County. Capps eventually beat her opponent, , with 54.8% of the vote.\n\nIn 2014, Capps ran against Republican , an actor, screenwriter, and businessman. Mitchum is the son of legendary film star . This was Mitchum's second consecutive try for the 24th district, having previously lost the 2012 primary to Abel Maldonado. In the closest race of her entire congressional career, Capps ultimately won with only a 3.8% margin over Mitchum.\n\nCapps announced in April 2015 that she would not seek reelection in 2016.\n\n\nCapps has been described as a \"solid liberal\". In '''' magazine's 2006 \"Best and Worst of Congress\" poll of congressional staffers, Capps was named the nicest member of Congress.\n\nIn 2011, Capps voted for the  as part of a controversial provision that allows the government and the military to indefinitely detain American citizens and others without trial.\n\n;Health care\nCapps supported the Obama administration's economic stimulus and the . She was strongly critical of the  to the latter, which placed limits on taxpayer-funding of abortions (except in the cases of rape, incest, or threat to the mother's life). Capps had earlier sponsored the , which was defeated and replaced by the . Capps introduced the  which would, if enacted, authorize the  to support, fund, and coordinate data from research on rare pediatric diseases.\n\n;Foreign policy\nIn 2012, she was the only member of the House to vote \"no\" on Resolution 556 to condemn the government of Iran for its continued persecution, imprisonment, and sentencing of  of the charge of apostasy. The resolution passed 417–1 with 15 non-votes. Her spokeswoman later said that Capps strongly supported the resolution, but cast the no vote by mistake.\n\n;Environmental policy\nIn 2004, the House passed her legislation prohibiting \"comprehensive inventory of oil and gas resources beneath the outer continental shelf.\" She was also a vocal opponent of drilling for oil in the  and offshore drilling off the coast of California.\n\n\n*  - Capps introduced this bill, which would swap a parcel of  with the  in exchange for a parcel of their land. The White Lotus Foundation offers training in  and wants the land to build better access to their site.\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n** \n\n\n* Co-Chair of the Congressional Caucus on Women's Issues\n* Co-Chair of the National Marine Sanctuary Caucus\n* Co-Chair of the Congressional Coastal Caucus\n* Co-Chair of the Biomedical Research Caucus\n* Co-Chair of the House Cancer Caucus\n* Co-Chair of the Congressional Heart and Stroke Coalition\n* Co-Founder and Co-Chair of the Congressional Caucus on Infant Health and Safety\n* Founded the Congressional Nursing Caucus\n* Founded the School Health and Safety Caucus\n* Member of the \n\n\nIn 1960, while at Yale, she married , a divinity student who later became a prominent religious studies professor at UCSB; they eventually had three children. Walter died in 1997 and their eldest daughter Lisa died in 2000. Lois Capps worked for 20 years as a nurse and health advocate for the Santa Barbara public schools and also taught early childhood education part-time at . Capps' daughter, Laura, was married to , a political consultant who served as  in the .\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

  "query":
