    "pages": }\n| p = Zhū Jiāwén\n| mi = \n| j = Zyu1 Gaa1-man4\n| y = Jyu1 Ga1-man4\n}}\n\n'''Carmen Chu''' (; born April 8, 1978), ''San Francisco Chronicle'', Retrieved September 26, 2007. is an American politician serving as City Administrator of the City and County of . She previously served as the city's assessor-recorder, where she was the only Asian-American assessor elected to serve among the 58 counties in the State of California.  Prior to being elected assessor-recorder, Chu served as a member of the San Francisco board of supervisors, where she served two terms as the chair of the board's budget and finance committee, and was a board director of the Golden Gate Bridge, Highway and Transportation District. Before joining the board of supervisors, Chu served as deputy budget director in the mayor's office of public policy and finance. In July 2022, she was appointed to the  by Governor .\n\n\nChu is the second of three daughters to Hung Wing and Shuet Ying Chu, who immigrated from  in the 1970s with ancestry in . The Chu family settled into a number of jobs to make ends meet including initially working as a seamstress or as a restaurant worker before starting their own small family restaurant.  Chu has stated that growing up in an immigrant family and in a small business household were formative experiences in her life as she never forgot the struggles immigrants and those with limited English face nor the hardships associated with running a small business.\n\n\nIn 2000, Chu earned a bachelor's degree in public policy from  where she was a recipient of the James Irvine Foundation Scholarship – a program focused on the development of leaders and educational opportunities for city youth. She graduated from Occidental College magna cum laude and .\n\nIn 2003, Chu earned a master's degree in public policy from  as a distinguished Public Policy and International Affairs (PPIA) fellow – a fellowship program with a mission to promote underrepresented groups in public service and to advance roles in leadership positions.\n\n\nOn February 6, 2013, Chu was appointed by Mayor  to serve as assessor-recorder; the post was left vacant after  was sworn into the . In November 2013, Chu successfully ran for election and became then the only  elected female representative in a citywide position. Chu ran again in 2014 and was elected to a full term on November 4, 2014, with 98% of the vote.\n\nUnder Chu, San Francisco adopted a new electronic real estate and land use records system.\n\n\nWhen the  announced a resumption of same-sex marriages on June 28, 2013, Chu committed to keeping her office open through that first weekend of resumption so that same-sex couples did not have to wait any longer to marry.&nbsp; That weekend, 479 marriage licenses were recorded with the City and County of San Francisco. The  was the only County Recorder's Office to remain open that first weekend in the State of California. In 2013 Chu turned over public marriage licenses that were invalidated in 2004 to the San Francisco Public Library's Archival Division to ensure the historic preservation of documents filed during a pivotal and defining moment in the movement for .\n\n\nChu was nominated by Mayor  to replace departing city administrator Naomi Kelly in January 2021. After confirmation by the board of supervisors, Breed conducted Chu's swearing-in ceremony on February 2, 2021.\n\n\n\nOn September 25, 2007, she was appointed to replace the embattled San Francisco Supervisor , who was then suspended for alleged official misconduct. The District 4 seat remained vacant for five and a half hours until  appointed her to succeed Jew for the remainder of Jew's term. Chu ran for election after Jew's term expired, and on November 4, 2008, she was elected by the voters as supervisor of District 4 for the term January 2009 to January 2011. Chu was re-elected as supervisor representing the Sunset/Parkside District for a four-year term in November 2010.\n\nChu worked on legislation that incentivized local small businesses to do work for the city by streamlining the city's contracting process; provided protections to tenants who are victims of ; strengthened regulations, coordinated enforcement and expanded community review of establishments in neighborhood commercial corridors; advocated for and improved neighborhood libraries, parks and playgrounds, and directed local funding for neighborhood commercial revitalization efforts including facade improvements, free assessments for compliance with , installation of parklets and major street resurfacing efforts. Chu worked with the local Public Utilities Commission to develop the largest municipal solar project in the country at the time. Board of Supervisors|website=sfbos.org|access-date=2016-11-09}} The rooftop of the Sunset Reservoir, a project which would provide clean energy for municipal buildings.\n\n\n\nAs supervisor, Chu chaired the board's budget and finance committee for the 2011–2012 and 2012–2013 budgets and served as a member of the committee in all but one year while in office. Working with the mayor, community leaders, city departments and labor, the 2011–2012's $6.83 billion budget preserved funding for critical city services while closing a General Fund deficit of $380 million.&nbsp; In 2012–2013, Chu again chaired the budget and finance committee, where she led the development of San Francisco's first two-year budget, a good government initiative designed to recognize the ongoing long-term budget impacts of annual budget decisions.&nbsp; The 2012–2013 budget included key measures to back-fill state funding cuts to childcare subsidies for San Francisco's working families and was the first year of a multi-year plan to fund the recruitment and back-filling of critical public safety positions in the  and .\n\n\nPrior to her time on the , Chu served as the deputy director of the mayor office of public policy and finance – the division charged with balancing the city and county's annual appropriations. Chu worked on projects such as the development of the city's first  – a centralized point of access to City services available to residents 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Under Chu's direction, San Francisco was awarded the Distinguished Budget Presentation Award in 2006–2007 from the  for the annual proposed budget document.\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''John Laird''' (born March 29, 1950) is an American politician who is the  for , since December 7, 2020, and was Secretary of the  from 2011 to 2019 and a former legislator who represented the  in the  until 2008. The 27th district included parts of ,  and . \n\nLaird (along with ) was one of the first two openly gay men to serve in the California legislature.  Laird became one of the United States' first openly gay mayors in 1983 when he took over the mayoralty of the city of .\n\n\nLaird was raised in , and educated in Vallejo public schools. Laird's parents were both educators. He graduated from Adlai Stevenson College of the  in 1972 with an A.B. in . His undergraduate thesis was on the history of water development in California.\n\nLaird served for two years on the district staff of United States Representative , and worked during the summer of 1974 for Rep.  of Florida in his run for the . Laird moved to  and joined the staff of the  Administrator in 1974 and later served in the  and  departments.\n\n\nIn 1981, Laird received the most votes in a field of eight to be elected to a seat on the Santa Cruz City Council. He was re-elected as top vote-getter in 1985, serving until term limits ended his Council service in 1990. He was elected by the City Council to one-year Mayor's terms in 1983–84 and 1987–88. During his time on the Santa Cruz City Council, he worked with the environmental organization  to lead local governments in the fight against proposed offshore oil drilling and in favor of the designation of the .\n\n \n\nLaird was an elected member of the  Board of Trustees from 1994 to 2002.\n\n\n\nLaird ran unopposed in the 2002 Democratic primary and easily won election to the California Assembly.  He was re-elected to the assembly in 2004 and 2006 before being  in 2008. While serving the maximum three terms in the Assembly, Laird authored 82 bills that were signed into law.\n\nHis election campaigns have often won the backing of the .\n\n\nLaird ran for the   seat previously held by Republican , whom Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger named as Lieutenant Governor in November 2009. He lost to    in a special election primary held on June 22, 2010 and subsequently in the runoff election held on August 17, 2010. Laird lost by a 7.59% margin in the primary and a 3.93% margin in the runoff.\n\n\nLaird was appointed by  on January 5, 2011 as California's . In the Brown administration, Laird oversaw a $10 billion budget and 25 statewide departments, commissions and conservancies.\n\n\n\nIn January 2019, Laird announced his intention to run for the 17th District state Senate seat in 2020. He pledged to focus on a range of issues if elected, from managing the impact of climate change and wildfires, to protecting California's ocean policies, supporting the middle class and expanding access to health care, education and affordable housing. Laird was elected on November 3, 2020 to the State Senate after defeating Vicki Nohrden by  64.7% to 35.3%.\n\nDuring his first term (2020-2024), Laird authored 59 bills signed into law – addressing fentanyl overdose reversal drugs, survival benefits for families of fallen officers, services for foster youth who attend community college, support for older Californians living with HIV, protections against excessive rents for mobile home residents and requires propane cylinders sold in the state to be refillable or reusable by 2028.\n\nIn December 2021, the  voted in favor of a new state Assembly and Senate district maps.   spans the northern Central Coast, including the entirety of Santa Cruz, San Benito and Monterey counties and most of San Luis Obispo county. Previously, District 17 included sections of Santa Clara county and did not include San Benito County or the Salinas Valley.\n\nOn March 7, 2023 Laird announced his campaign for a second term.\n\n\nLaird has been active in the Santa Cruz community, serving as Vice Chair of the City Charter Review Committee, a founder of the Santa Cruz Community Credit Union, and a board member of the Santa Cruz Area Chamber of Commerce. He has been active on a variety of community boards.\n\nHe has been active with the lesbian and gay community, as a columnist for the Lavender Reader, a commentator on 's \"Closet Free Radio\", a founding member of the International Network of Gay and Lesbian Officialsand was an original board member of BAYMEC, the gay and lesbian political action committee for San Mateo, Santa Clara, Monterey and Santa Cruz Counties. In the Assembly, he served as chair of the .\n\nLaird was a founding member of the . He served as executive director of the Santa Cruz AIDS Project from 1991 to 1994.\n\nHe also has served on the Santa Cruz Community Foundation's Advisory Committee for the Lesbian and Gay Grants Partnership. Laird lives in Santa Cruz with his spouse John Flores. He is fluent in .\n\n\n\nLaird has been a long-time resident of Santa Cruz with his spouse John Flores.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joe Coto''' (September 4, 1939) is an American educator and politician. Coto served three terms as a member of the  from 2004 to 2010, representing the 23rd district.\n\n\nCoto was born in , one of four children, to Mexican-American parents. His father worked in copper mines for over 30 years, and encouraged Coto and his three sisters to attend college. Coto earned a bachelor's degree from . He received his administrative credential from , as well as a Masters in Business Administration from the . He has also studied at .\n\n\nCoto began his career as a  teacher in the . He worked in a variety of administrative positions and left the school district to serve as a City Councilmember for the City of Oakland. After his four-year term on the city council, he ran for Mayor of Oakland and almost beat a longtime incumbent. He returned to the school district and ultimately became Superintendent of the Oakland Public Schools in 1984. In 1988, he was recruited to serve as  of the  in San Jose, and served in that position for the next 14 years. In recognition of his contributions as superintendent of , the Association of California School Administrators named him the 2003  of the Year.\n\nAs  in San Jose, Coto supported Senate  1051, an $80&nbsp;million increase in funding promoting diversity in San Jose's school system. The legislation has since brought close to a billion dollars to school districts in East San Jose over the years. Coto was also able to bring nearly half a billion dollars in grant monies and improvement bonds to the East Side Union High School District.\n\n\nCoto was elected to the  to represent  in 2004.\n\nNew laws sponsored by Coto cover a variety of fields including educational bills providing support to underachieving schools, standards for math instruction for blind students, and over $30&nbsp;million to support English learners and flexibility in spending to support the educational program. He authored a bill to protect students from vendors trying to entice them with gifts to get them to apply for credit cards. Coto was also responsible for establishing an eminence credential for  languages to be taught in California's schools (cosponsored by Assembly member ).\n\nIn the area of health, one of his bills provides cultural and linguistic training for physicians so that they can serve their patients more effectively and another extends the  program so that children throughout the state can be eligible for health insurance. Working in collaboration with the , as well as other employer groups, such as the California Federation of Labor, he authored legislation to fix part of the workers compensation system in a way that benefits both business and labor.\n\nCoto recently completed a two-year term serving as Chair of the 26 member Latino Legislative Caucus. Prior to becoming Chair, he served for two years as the Vice Chair.\n\nDue to , Coto retired from the Assembly in 2010.\n\n\n\nIn December 2011, Coto announced that he would run for California State Senate to represent District 15, which includes the cities of , , , , , and . Coto's campaign focused on improving education to create a competitive workforce, balancing the budget, and solving the issue of income inequality. He was defeated by  by a 13% margin in the November 2012 election. The  issued a $6,000 fine for exceeding contribution limits and failing to disclose more than $117,000 in expenditures during his State Senate run.\n\n\nCoto and wife, Camille Coto, have been married for 35 years and have two daughters. Both daughters graduated from the .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n*  at SmartVoter\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Alejandra Campoverdi''' (born September 20, 1979) is an American  advocate, best-selling author, and former  aide. Under , Campoverdi was the first White House Deputy Director of Hispanic Media.\n\n\nBorn in , Campoverdi was raised by a single mother and her grandmother who immigrated to the  from . Alejandra spent her childhood sharing a cramped apartment in  with extended family. \n\nThere were periods when Campoverdi's family was on welfare, , and , California’s public health insurance program. A strong academic performer, Alejandra attended  on financial assistance and with the support of non-profits and pipeline programs.\n\nWhile paying her way through school, Alejandra graduated ''cum laude'' from the  at the . Campoverdi worked as a part-time actress and model--among other jobs--during her time at USC to pay for her education. She later received her  from the  at . Campoverdi pointed to the vote for  and the  as events that shaped her worldview and served as a political awakening.\n\n\nAfter working for the Agricultural Worker Health Initiative&nbsp;at The California Endowment, a health-focused foundation that expands access to quality and affordable healthcare to underserved communities in , and following her master's degree, Campoverdi was hired by then-Senator 's 2008 , to work in the  headquarters. She lived off her credit cards, had no health insurance, and stayed in supporter housing. Campoverdi's focus during the campaign was outreach to various constituent groups, including the Latino community.\n\nFollowing Obama's victory, Campoverdi was appointed to work in the West Wing of the  as Special Assistant to the White House Deputy Chief of Staff for Policy, . She later became the first ever White House Deputy Director of Hispanic Media. In the latter role, Campoverdi developed and implemented the White House’s communications strategy directed towards the Hispanic community and briefed  in preparation for interviews with Hispanic media. Campoverdi also worked on White House communications around a broad range of issues, including the  and its effects on the Latino community.\n\nAfter departing the White House, Campoverdi held various senior leadership roles in media, including at Univision and the ''''.  \n\nIn December 2016, Campoverdi announced that she would seek the nomination of the  in the , to replace , who had been appointed to succeed  as .She cited the election of  and the potential repeal of the  as her motivation to run. In the April 4, 2017 primary election, Campoverdi did not make the run-off, and former California Assembly member  was elected.\n\n\nAlejandra Campoverdi has served or currently serves on the Boards of Harvard’s , the , the '''', UCLA's Center for Diverse Leadership in Science, and the Friends of the National Museum of the American Latino, and she is a member of the .\n\nIn 2017, Campoverdi was appointed to serve as a Commissioner for the California Children and Families Commission, also known as . The Commission is a statewide body that is dedicated to improving the lives of California’s youngest citizens and their families through a multi-faceted approach that includes education, health services, childcare, and other vital programs.\n\nPreviously, she was a volunteer teacher for , through which she taught a weekly creative writing class to incarcerated youth in Los Angeles’ .\n\n\nIn March 2017, Campoverdi revealed in a profile by '''' that she inherited the , giving her an 85% risk of developing , and that she planned to have a preventive double mastectomy. Campoverdi lost both her great-grandmother and grandmother to breast cancer, and her mother and two aunts have also battled the disease.\n\nCampoverdi made the protection of access to affordable healthcare and the Affordable Care Act a focus of her congressional campaign, choosing to speak publicly about her personal health in an effort to bring attention to the stakes of limited access to healthcare. \n\nIn 2017, Campoverdi was awarded 's Basser Center for BRCA's inaugural YLC Distinguished Advocacy Award for her advocacy around BRCA-related cancers.\n\nThe following year, Alejandra underwent a preventive double mastectomy to lower her risk of developing breast cancer. Routine testing of the removed tissue subsequently revealed she had unknowingly had Stage 0, non-invasive breast cancer, which every previous mammogram, ultrasound, and MRI had not detected. Because of her preventive surgery, Campoverdi did not need to do any additional treatment, and went on to say, \"I beat breast cancer before I even knew I had it.\"\n\nCampoverdi speaks often about the importance of being your own best health advocate and her decision to be \"CEO of her own body.\" She is the founder of The Well Woman Coalition, an initiative aiming to empower women of color to have agency over their own health and healing through awareness, education, and advocacy. Campoverdi also founded LATINX & BRCA in partnership with Penn Medicine's Basser Center for BRCA, which is the first awareness campaign on the BRCA gene mutation that targets Latinos and offers Spanish-language educational materials. \n\nIn an op-ed for '''', Campoverdi wrote, \"Now more than ever, we must recognize and accept the complexity of real women, and celebrate them in their quest for leadership roles. Whole, multi-dimensional women. Please throw your name in the arena, whichever one you’re in  because it only gets better every time one of us tries.\"\n\n\nIn 2020, Campoverdi produced and appeared in the PBS documentary ''Inheritance''. Named one of the “Best Documentaries of 2020” by ''ELLE'', ''Inheritance'' follows three women's experience with hereditary breast cancer and the BRCA gene mutation, as they undergo life-altering medical procedures in the hope of reducing their risk and saving their own lives. A medical device company, Sientra Breast Implant Company, is the corporate sponsor of the film that had an estimated $800,000 budget.\n\n\nOn September 12, 2023, Campoverdi published a book, ''FIRST GEN: A Memoir'', about navigating her educational journey as a \"First and Only\" of many professional experiences.  Described as \"part memoir, part manifesto,\" FIRST GEN's major themes address \"generational inheritance, aspiration, and belonging\" for those who are trailblazers of all kinds. \n\nWithin a week of publication, ''FIRST GEN'' was a best-seller, and the book was chosen as the 2024 Opportunity Matters Book Club selection for the , a national book club for first-generation and low-income students at colleges and universities across the country. \n \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n\n'''John Scott Duarte''' ( ; born September 9, 1966) is an American politician, businessman, and  farmer. A member of the  , he has served as the  for  since 2023.\n\n\nDuarte was born on September 9, 1966, in , to Jim and Anita Duarte. He is of . Duarte graduated from the   with an  and a  in finance from  in 1989.\n\n\nIn 1989, Duarte began his career as a vice president of sales for Duarte Trees & Vines, which was founded by his parents in 1988. In 2007, he became the company's chief executive officer and president.\n\nIn 2017, Duarte was ordered to pay a $2.8 million government fine after the  claimed that he had violated the  by plowing a field to plant wheat on his property in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn March 9, 2022, Duarte launched a campaign to represent  after the  created a new district based in the . He and   advanced to the general election. He defeated Gray in the  by 564 votes in an . He was declared the winner on December 3, 2022, almost a month after the election.\n\n\n\n\nDuarte is running for reelection against Gray again in 2024.\n\n\nDuarte was sworn into office on January 3, 2023. He supported  for .\n\nIn October 2023, Duarte said that House Speaker Kevin McCarthy should be reinstated as Speaker due to the unrest in Israel changing the political dynamics and stakes in the U.S. House. After McCarthy's ouster, Duarte supported  as the nominee. Once Scalise dropped out, Duarte voted for  on the House floor.\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n** \n* \n** \n** \n* \n** \n** \n** \n\n\nDuarte has said \"I don't care about party politics\" and that \"I'll stand against 'the woke.' I'll stand against the ultra-conservatives.\"\n\t\nBuilding new infrastructure to secure water for the San Joaquin Valley is one of Duarte's top priorities.\n\n\nIn 2023, Duarte was one of two Republicans to vote against the  amendment to H.R. 2670: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, which would prohibit the Secretary of Defense from paying for or reimbursing expenses relating to abortion services. In 2024, Duarte said he was a pro-choice Republican. Duarte has voiced opposition to a federal ban on abortion but has stated that abortion \"should be left to the states\".\n\n\nIn 2023, Duarte was the only Republican to vote against the  amendment to H.R. 2670: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, which would prohibit TRICARE from covering and the Department of Defense from furnishing gender affirmation surgeries and gender hormone treatments for transgender individuals.\n\n\nDuarte was one of 41 Republicans to vote against the Bob Good amendment to H.R. 2670: National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2024, which would defund a congressionally mandated commission tasked with renaming Army bases and military property named in honor of Confederate leaders.\n\n\nDuarte has described himself as \"immigration fluid\", meaning that he both supports greater border security but also recognizes that agriculture depends on farmworkers who lack legal immigration status. He has said only a bipartisan approach will effectively address immigration issues.\n\nIn 2023, Duarte was one of two Republicans who voted against H.R. 2, the Secure the Border Act. He called the  program \"devastating for farmers.\"\n\nDuarte is a sponsor of the Farm Worker Modernization Act which seeks to boost foreign worker availability in the U.S., with benefits to both employers and laborers.\n\nDuarte supports  (DACA).\n\n\nDuarte voted to provide  with support following the .\n\n\n\n\n\nDuarte lives with his wife, Alexandra, on a pistachio and almond farm outside of  in rural . They have four children. Duarte is an .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  campaign website\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Prior to being elected to the state Senate, she was a  woman and a  for the . California State Senate Archive |url=https://archive.senate.ca.gov/member-archives/2017-18/ling-ling-chang-r-district-29 |access-date=2024-05-30 |website=archive.senate.ca.gov}} Chang is a . She was also the first Taiwanese-born American elected to the state Assembly, and was the only Asian American woman in the California Legislature during her terms in office.\n\nIn 2016, Chang was a candidate for , losing the general election very narrowly to Democrat . After Newman was recalled by voters in 2018, Chang won a plurality of votes  and became the state Senator for California's 29th district. Chang narrowly lost re-election to Josh Newman in the .\n\n\nBorn in , Chang and her family emigrated to the United States when she was three years old. She was raised in  and graduated from . She studied biology at  but did not graduate. She was criticized during her 2014 campaign for claims that she attended  when she was in fact taking online classes through , the university's online extension program which is open to the general public.\n\n\n\nChang worked at Strategy Insights Group. In 2005, she was elected to the  Water District Board and was then elected twice to the  .\n\n\n\nChang was elected to the  in the  in 2014 and had five bills signed into law in her first seven months in office. She also proposed bills seeking to cut business regulations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nChang was the Republican candidate for  in the 2016 election. She ran against two Democrats, former  Mayor  and veteran Josh Newman to succeed  in 2016 due to term limits.\n\nAs of October 2016, Chang had raised more than $4 million. She made public comments distancing herself from Republican presidential nominee . In November 2016, with 49.6% of the vote, Chang lost the general election to Democrat .\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn June 5, 2018, Chang won a recall election for the same State Senate seat that she had lost to Josh Newman two years earlier. Newman was targeted for recall by the Republican Party of California in an attempt to break the Democratic super majority in the Senate, though the campaign also emphasized Newman's vote to  to fund infrastructure improvements.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n| votes = 31,726\n| percentage = 21.4\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2020 Chang lost the election to serve a full term in the State Senate.     "pages": }\n'''Phillip David Wyman ''' (February 21, 1945&nbsp;– November 28, 2019) was an American politician from California. A , he was a member of the California State Assembly from 1978 to 1992 and again from 2000 to 2002; he was also a member of the California Senate from 1993 to 1994.\n\n\n\nWyman was vice president of the  Board of Trade in 1976 when he first ran for  from the - based 34th District.  He narrowly lost to Democratic incumbent  but went on to defeat him two \nyears later and served in the Assembly from 1978 until 1992, when he opted not to seek reelection and instead run for congress.\n\nIn 2000 Wyman ran again for Assembly in the 34th Assembly District, which consisted of the Mojave Desert portion of San Bernardino County (except for the Morongo valley), the eastern Kern County desert/mountains area and Inyo County. He defeated the city manager of Victorville to win the Republican nomination, and then easily won the November 2000 general election in a heavily Republican district.\n\nIn 2002, redistricting after the 2000 Census prompted Wyman to run in the new 36th Assembly District. He moved to a small apartment in  (in the rural San Bernardino County desert) to qualify to run, which caused his political opponents to accuse him of being a carpetbagger. He narrowly lost the Republican primary to  of Lancaster, the wife of then-incumbent Assemblyman .\n\nIn 2006, he ran again for Assembly in the 36th Assembly District, based in Kern County, but lost the Republican primary to Bakersfield Superintendent of Schools .\n\n\n\nThe 25th Congressional district was created after the 1991 reapportionment and was centered on the new city of  in fast growing northern Los Angeles County. Wyman moved south from  in  County to run for the new 25th.California Journal Vol. XXIII, No.7 (July 1992) \"Complete Primary Results\".  StateNet Publications, July 1992. He narrowly lost the GOP primary to  Mayor , however.\n\n\n\nWyman bounced back less than a year later when he won a special election for the -based 16th state Senate district in 1993.\n\nIn 1994, despite huge Republican gains across the country, Wyman lost his state Senate seat to then Democratic Assemblyman  (whom Wyman had defeated in the special election).  He was the only Republican west of the Mississippi to be unseated.California Journal Vol. XXVII, No.5 (May 1996) \"The 1996 Primary: The Endgame Begins\".  StateNet Publications, May 1996.   In 1996 he ran for a neighboring state Senate seat and lost the GOP primary again, this time to  area Assemblyman .\n\nIn 2010 he ran once more for the state Senate seat he had lost to Costa in 1994. He narrowly lost the primary to Tim Theissen, who then lost the general election to Democrat .\n\n\n\nThrough the years Wyman gained a reputation for moving around the area in order to run for office.  He originally served as an Assemblyman from  (in  County), moved south to run for congress in  County in 1992, then won election to a state Senate seat in 1993 in  County (north of Kern county) before losing a state Senate primary in 1996 in Los Angeles county again.California Journal Vol. XXVII, No.3 (March 1996) \"Election '96\". StateNet Publications, March 1996.\n\n\n\nIn 2000 Wyman made a comeback of sorts, winning his old 34th Assembly district.  Two years later, however, he made a tactical error and decided to run for reelection in the neighboring 36th district instead.  He was anticipating an opening in the state Senate in 2004, a district that was outside the boundaries of his 34th Assembly district, but within those of the 36th.  His plans went awry when the 36th's incumbent, fellow Republican  decided to back his wife (), who actually lived within the district.  Wyman narrowly lost the GOP primary, while his old 34th district was won by Republican , a Tulare County supervisor, who found himself unopposed after Wyman decided not to run here.California Journal Vol. XXXIII, No.10 (February 2002) \"Special Election Issue:  Complete Ballot Analysis\".  StateNet Publications, February 2002.\n\nIn 2014 Wyman was an unsuccessful candidate for California Attorney General, losing the GOP spot to former deputy state Attorney General Ronald Gold by just 1.2%.\n\nIn 2016, Wyman declared his candidacy in  being vacated by Democrat . In the June 7 primary, Wyman came in fourth in the overall field, with 247,397 total votes (4.9%), and thus was the second highest-performing Republican in the field, only behind George \"Duf\" Sundheim's 409,096 (8%).\n\n\nWyman died from cancer in Tehachapi on November 28, 2019, aged 74.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*, Election History for the State of California\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Rick Chavez Zbur''' (born March 2, 1957) is an American attorney currently serving in the .\n\nHe is also a former  candidate. He is a well-known  advocate and is active in the . Zbur is also notable as the first openly gay non-incumbent U.S. congressional primary candidate to win an election.\n\n\nZbur grew up on a farm in the  of rural  with his mother, Erlinda Chavez Zbur. He currently lives in .\"\". ''''. Retrieved 2020-03-01.\n\n\n\nZbur practiced  for about three decades before retiring in 2014. In 1996, Zbur ran for the  in California's then Long Beach-based 38th congressional district against moderate GOP incumbent . Zbur has also been a chair of the  board of directors from 2011 to 2017.  Since 2014, Zbur has led , the largest  civil rights organization in California.\n\n\n\nZbur identifies as gay and has been a vocal leader in the  for nearly four decades. In 2014, Zbur became the executive director of , the largest LGBT civil rights organization in California.\n\n\nIn the early 1980s, Zbur campaigned to fight against HIV/AIDS. He also helped found the . In 1992, together with the LGBT community in Los Angeles, Zbur organized fundraisers for , then , and , then a  who was running for the   Both were elected.\n\n\nAs an environmental lawyer, Zbur has been active in the  in California. He served as president of the  from 2011 to 2017.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1996, Zbur ran for the  in  against Republican incumbent , a two-term moderate. He became the first openly gay non-incumbent congressional primary candidate to win an election when he won the Democratic primary election on March 26, 1996.\"\" (). . Retrieved 2020-03-01.\n\nDuring his congressional campaign, Zbur's key legislative priorities included environmental protection, , and .\n\n\nIn April 2020, Zbur announced that he would be running for .\n\n\n\nIn 2021, Zbur announced a run for the California State in Assembly District 51, a newly drawn district which includes , , , and . He won the primary and then the general election in 2022.\n\nZbur is a member of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Thomas Miller McClintock II''' ( ; born July 10, 1956) is an American politician serving as the  for  since 2009 (known as the 4th congressional district until 2023). His district stretches from the  suburbs to the outer suburbs of ; it includes . A member of the , McClintock served as a  from 1982 to 1992 and from 1996 to 2000, when he became a , a position he held until 2008. He unsuccessfully ran for  in the  and for  in the .\n\n\n\n\nMcClintock was born in , and graduated in 1978 from the  (UCLA). At 23, he was elected chair of the  Republican Party, and served until 1981. He was chief of staff to State Senator  from 1980 to 1982. From 1992 to 1994, he served as director of the Center for the California Taxpayer. He was director of the  from 1995 to 1996.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1982, at age 26, McClintock ran for , then based in , after redistricting. He defeated  Harriet Kosmo Henson 56%–44%. He was reelected in 1984, defeating Tom Jolicoeur 72%–28%. In 1986, he was reelected to a third term, defeating Frank Nekimken 73%–25%. In 1988, he was reelected to a fourth term, defeating George Webb II 70%–29%. In 1990, he was reelected to a fifth term, defeating Ginny Connell 59%–36%.\n\nAfter running for Congress in 1992 and for controller in 1994, McClintock ran for the Assembly again in 1996. He ran for  and defeated Democrat Jon Lauritzen 56%–40% to win his sixth Assembly term. In 1998, McClintock was reelected to a seventh term unopposed.\n\nMcClintock authored California's  use for . He also opposed tax increases and supported spending cuts. He was a strong proponent of abolishing the car tax.\n\n\nIn 2000, McClintock retired from the California Assembly to run for . He ranked first in the March 7 open primary with 52% of the vote. In November, he defeated Democrat Daniel Gonzalez, 58%–42%. He was reelected in 2004, defeating Paul Joseph Graber, 61%–39%.\n\nIn 2008, McClintock voted against Proposition 2, which prohibits confining calves, pigs and hens in small cages in which they cannot extend their limbs. \"Farm animals are food, not friends\", he said in response to backlash to his vote. He also cited concern about increased grocery bills. In 2000, he was instrumental in proposing a two-thirds reduction in the vehicle license fee, or . In 2003, he opposed then-Governor 's attempt to rescind a rollback of a vehicle license fee. McClintock has also opposed deficit reduction efforts that would have increased taxes. He supported the Bureaucracy Reduction and Closure Commission and .\n\n\n\n\n\nMcClintock ran for  after incumbent  retired. He won the Republican primary, defeating John Morris, 61%–39%. In the general election, he lost to , former Special Assistant to   and Director of the , 48%–46%, with three other candidates receiving the other 6% of the vote.\n\n\n\nMcClintock ran for controller again in 2002, facing Democratic nominee , an  executive. Westly outspent him 5-to-1. McClintock's campaigns focused on increasing accountability for the state budget. The ads featured the character ''Angus McClintock'', a fictional cousin and fellow  extolling McClintock's thriftiness and accountability in low-budget 15-second ads. He lost by a margin of just 0.2%, or 16,811 votes, to Westly, who won with 45.3% of the vote. Three other candidates received 9.5% of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn 2003, McClintock ran in the recall election against Davis. Republican and film actor  won the election with 49% of the vote.    finished second with 31%. McClintock finished third with 14%. Together, Republicans Schwarzenegger and McClintock were supported by 5,363,778 Californians, or 62.1% of the vote. 132 other candidates received the remaining 6.4%.\n\nMcClintock performed the best in , where he received 24% of the vote. He also cracked 20% or higher in several other counties:  (23%),  (22%),  (21%),  (20%),  (20%),  (20%),  (20%),  (20%), and  (20%).\n\n\n\nMcClintock ran for  in 2006. He defeated Tony Farmer in the Republican primary, 94–6%. In the general election, he lost to Democratic  , 49%–45%.\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting, McClintock retired from the Assembly to challenge Democratic U.S. Representative  in . He won the nine-candidate Republican primary with a plurality of 34% of the vote, beating second-place finisher Sang Korman by 11 points. Beilenson defeated McClintock, 56–39%.\n\n\n\nOn March 4, 2008, McClintock announced his candidacy for the  in , about 300 miles north of the district McClintock represented in the state Senate. The district's nine-term incumbent, , was retiring. McClintock was unable to vote for himself in either the primary or the general election. Although for most of the year he lived in , a suburb of  within the  at the time, his legal residence was in Thousand Oaks, within the borders of his state senate district. The  requires state senators to maintain their legal residence in the district they represent.\n\nUpon McClintock's entry into the race, fellow Republicans  and Eric Egland withdrew from the primary and endorsed him. He was also endorsed by the , the , and U.S. Representative . McClintock faced former U.S. Representative , a moderate who represented the neighboring  from 1999 to 2005. Like McClintock, Ose lived outside the district and was painted as a  and a liberal who had voted to raise taxes and who voted for earmarks. McClintock defeated Ose, 54–39%.\n\nThe Democratic nominee was retired   Charles D. (Charlie) Brown, who had run an unexpectedly strong race against Doolittle in 2006. In March 2008, Ose's campaign commercials criticized McClintock for receiving over $300,000 in per diem living expenses during his time in the state senate even though he lived in Elk Grove for most of the year. McClintock maintained that the payments were justified because his legal residence was in Thousand Oaks, in his district. He said, \"Every legislator's [Sacramento area] residence is close to the Capitol. My residential costs up here are much greater than the average legislator because my family is here.\" Ose's campaign commercials argued McClintock did not own or rent a home in the 19th district, but claimed his mother's home in Thousand Oaks as his state senate district residence. These attacks prompted a response from McClintock's wife, Lori, who said McClintock stayed with his mother in order to care for her after she fell ill and after the death of her husband. McClintock ran ads attacking Brown's participation at a 2005 protest by , a prominent antiwar group, and argued Brown supported  but not the troops in Iraq. He also portrayed Brown as a clone of  .\n\nBy November 23, McClintock led Brown by 1,566 votes (0.4% of the vote), 184,190 to 182,624. Subsequent returns expanded the margin slightly with the last returns coming in from  shortly after . On December 1, McClintock declared victory and Brown conceded on December 3. McClintock defeated Brown by a margin of 0.5%, or 1,800 votes. He prevailed by a 3,500-vote margin in , the district's largest county. Brown won three of the district's nine counties: Sierra (49.8%), Plumas (47.9%), and Nevada (42.3%). McClintock won mainly on the coattails from , who carried the 4th with 54% of the vote, his fifth-best total in the state.\n\n\n\nMcClintock defeated Michael Babich in the Republican primary, Babich 78–22%. On November 2, he was reelected, defeating businessman Clint Curtis 61–31% and winning every county in the district.\n\n\n\nFor his first two terms, McClintock represented a district covering the northeast corner of California, from the eastern suburbs of Sacramento to the Oregon border.\n\nRedistricting after the 2010 census pushed the 4th well to the south. Only three counties remained from the old 4th: Nevada, Placer, and El Dorado. The redrawn district cut out the 4th's share of Sacramento County, including the part of Elk Grove that includes McClintock's home. Elk Grove is now entirely within the borders of the neighboring , represented by Democrat , making McClintock one of only a few members of Congress who live outside the district they represent. House members are constitutionally required only to live in the state they represent, but longstanding convention holds that they live in or reasonably close to their districts. McClintock said in 2016 that he intended to move his residence inside the redrawn 4th as soon as home prices rebounded enough for him to sell his Elk Grove home.\n\nIn 2012, California instituted its \"top two\" primary, in which candidates of all parties run against one another and the top two finishers, regardless of party, advance to the general election. McClintock and Democrat  were the only candidates in the \"top two\" primary, so the general election was a rematch. The reconfigured 4th was as strongly Republican as its predecessor, and McClintock was reelected to a third term, defeating Uppal 61%–39% in the general election. McClintock won all but two of the district's ten counties: Alpine (41%) and Nevada (37%).\n\n\n\nMcClintock was reelected, finishing first in California's \"top two\" primary and defeating moderate Republican challenger National Guard Major Art Moore in the general election, 60%–40%.\n\n\n\nMcClintock again finished first in the primary and defeated Democrat Robert W. Derlet, a physician, environmentalist and retired  professor, in the general election, 63%–37%.\n\n\n\nMcClintock defeated Democratic challenger Jessica Morse in the general election, receiving 184,401 votes to her 156,253 (54.1% to 45.9%).\n\n\nDuring the  McClintock was one of 40 members of the  who frequently voted against Republican Party leadership and vocally expressed displeasure with House bills. In 2011, he voted against the  due to a provision that would allow the government and the military to indefinitely detain American citizens and others without trial. McClintock's chief of staff, Igor Birman, was a candidate for Congress in  in 2014.\n\nIn 2009, McClintock signed a pledge sponsored by  promising to vote against any  legislation that would raise taxes.\n\nMcClintock voted in favor of the . He voted against the first version of the bill, displeased with the removal of deductions related to medical expenses, student loan interest, and . Those three items were addressed in the final version of the bill. McClintock said the bill would \"restore American workers to an internationally competitive position.\" He expressed concern about the bill's impact on the  and anticipated that it would be addressed \"by spending reforms this coming year.\"\n\nIn 2017, McClintock called for special prosecutor  to investigate President . McClintock felt that Trump's firing of  justified a special prosecutor.\n\nAfter Trump pulled 1,000 U.S. troops from -held territory on the Syrian border south of Turkey in 2019, a bipartisan resolution passed the House, 354–60, that condemned him for abandoning those U.S. allies that would allow the  (ISIL) to reestablish and regroup its forces, and allow the Turks to attack the Kurds. McClintock was one of the two members of California's congressional delegation to vote against it.\n\nIn 2020, McClintock was the sole House Republican to cosponsor the , which was proposed in response to the  and resultant . The act was introduced by  and  and cosponsored by 62 House Democrats in addition to McClintock. Because Amash was a registered  as of the act's introduction in June 2020, McClintock's support technically made the act the first tripartisan piece of federal legislation in modern U.S. history.\n\nIn the , McClintock voted against multiple motions to discipline certain Democrats in office, such as the first censure of Adam Schiff, the censure of Rashida Tlaib, and the . In each, he lambasted their actions but believed the motions were an erosion of the standards to which such motions should be held. Despite making a speech supporting holding  in  for the federal prosecution of Donald Trump, he would vote against holding him in contempt for refusing to release the audio files of the Hur interviews in the .\n\nAs of October 2021, McClintock had voted in line with 's stated position 5% of the time.\n\n\nMcClintock supported the , a bill that would prevent federal agencies from requiring certain entities to relinquish their water rights to the United States in order to use . The bill was a reaction to the 's decision to pursue a \"new regulation to demand that water rights be transferred to the federal government as a condition for obtaining permits needed to operate 121 ski resorts that cross over federal lands.\" McClintock supported the bill, saying that the Forest Service's regulation \"illustrates an increasingly hostile attitude by this agency toward those who make productive use of our vast national forests, in this case by enhancing and attracting the tourism upon which our mountain communities depend.\"\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n* \n* \n**  (Chair)\n** \n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n*\n*\n*\n* (Formerly)\n\n\n\nIn December 2020, McClintock joined 125 other Republican members of Congress in signing an  in support of a  by the attorney general of the state of Texas that sought to overturn the certified results of the  in four other U.S. states. The lawsuit was called a \"seditious abuse of the judicial process\" by the attorney general of Pennsylvania, and \"simply madness\" by 2012 Republican presidential nominee .\n\n  issued a statement that called signing the amicus brief an act of \"election subversion.\"\n\nMcClintock later became one of seven Republicans who did not support their colleagues' efforts to challenge the results of the election on January 6, 2021. These seven signed a letter that, while giving credence to election fraud allegations Trump made, said Congress did not have the authority to influence the election's outcome.\n\nMcClintock voted against impeaching Trump over his role in inciting the .\n\n\nMcClintock has said that \"farm animals are food, not friends.\"\n\n\nIn 2015, McClintock introduced an amendment to limit the enforcement of federal law in . Known as the McClintock–Polis amendment, it failed by a 206–222 vote. It was reintroduced in 2019 as the Blumenauer–McClintock–Norton amendment and passed 267–165.\n\nIn 2016, McClintock endorsed , the Adult Use of Marijuana Act. He stated: \"Our current laws have failed us, and have created a violent and criminal black market that actively and aggressively markets to young people. Legalization takes the criminal profit out of the equation, and allows us to regulate marijuana the same way we currently regulate alcohol.\"\n\nIn 2020, McClintock was one of five House Republicans to vote for the  to legalize cannabis at the federal level. In 2021, he was one of four original cosponsors of a Republican-led legalization bill named the States Reform Act.\n\n\nDuring the , McClintock expressed the view that wearing  should not be mandatory, and while wearing a mask during congressional sessions, said, \"this mask is useless\". During the , McClintock wore a mask that read \"This mask is as useless as our governor\", referring to Governor .\n\n\nIn September 2021, McClintock was among 75 House Republicans to vote against the National Defense Authorization Act of 2022, which contains a provision that would require women to be drafted.\n\n\nMcClintock questions the role that human activity plays in climate change, arguing that the \"climate has been changing for four and a half billion years.\"\n\n\nIn 2019, McClintock was one of 60 representatives to vote against condemning Trump's withdrawal from .\n\nIn 2020, McClintock voted against the National Defense Authorization Act of 2021, which would prevent the president from withdrawing soldiers from  without congressional approval.\n\nIn June 2021, McClintock was one of 49 House Republicans to vote to repeal the  against Iraq.\n\nIn July 2021, McClintock was one of five House Republicans to vote against a bill that allocates $2.1 billion for Afghan visas and Capitol Hill security.\n\nIn 2023, McClintock was among 47 Republicans to vote in favor of H.Con.Res. 21, which directed President  to remove U.S. troops from  within 180 days.\n\n\n\nMcClintock opposes . In 2008, he said, \"calling a homosexual partnership a marriage doesn't make it one.\"\n\nIn June 2021, McClintock was one of 14 House Republicans to vote against legislation to establish June 19, or , as a federal holiday.\n\n\nMcClintock voted against the Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2019 which would amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to eliminate the per-country numerical limitation for employment-based immigrants, to increase the per-country numerical limitation for family-sponsored immigrants, and for other purposes.\n\nMcClintock voted against the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2020 which authorizes DHS to nearly double the available H-2B visas for the remainder of FY 2020.\n\nMcClintock voted against Consolidated Appropriations Act (H.R. 1158) which effectively prohibits ICE from cooperating with Health and Human Services to detain or remove illegal alien sponsors of unaccompanied alien children (UACs).\n\n\nMcClintock opposes mail-in voting, saying in 2020 that it was a \"corrupted process\" that allows ballots to be sent to voters who have died or moved away.\n\n\nMcClintock lives in the Sacramento area and Thousand Oaks. He was married to Lori McClintock until her death in December 2021, from dehydration due to  caused, according to a coroner's report, by \"adverse effects of  leaf ingestion\". McClintock is a .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n Statement of Vote (Retrieved on February 1, 2010).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \"State Senator,\" (Retrieved on August 1, 2009).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \"Controller, by county,\" (Retrieved on August 1, 2009).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''For a complete list of all candidates who participated in the 2003 recall election, see .\n\n \"Governor, by county,\" (Retrieved on August 1, 2009).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \"State Senator,\" (Retrieved on August 1, 2009).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \"Lieutenant Governor, by county,\" (Retrieved on August 1, 2009).}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n, 2022}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n*\n*\n*\n*\n;Statements\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| image               = Congresswoman Michelle Steel.jpg\n| office              = Member of thefrom \n| term_start          = January 3, 2021\n| term_end            = \n| predecessor         = \n| successor           = \n| constituency        =  (20212023) (2023present)\n| office1             = Chair of the \n| term_start1         = January 1, 2020\n| term_end1           = January 1, 2021\n| predecessor1        = \n| successor1          = \n| term_start2         = January 1, 2017\n| term_end2           = January 1, 2018\n| predecessor2        = \n| successor2          = \n| office3             = Vice Chair of the \n| term_start3         = January 1, 2019\n| term_end3           = January 1, 2020\n| predecessor3        = Shawn Nelson\n| successor3          = \n| term_start4         = January 1, 2016\n| term_end4           = January 1, 2017\n| predecessor4        = \n| successor4          = \n| office5             = Member of the from the 2nd district\n| term_start5         = January 5, 2015\n| term_end5           = January 3, 2021\n| predecessor5        = \n| successor5          = \n| office6             = Member of the from the 3rd district\n| term_start6         = January 5, 2007\n| term_end6           = January 5, 2015\n| predecessor6        = Claude Parrish\n| successor6          = \n| birth_name          = Michelle Eunjoo Park\n| birth_date          = \n| birth_place         = , South Korea\n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = \n| party               = \n| spouse              = \n| children            = 2\n| education           =  () ()\n| website             = \n| module              = \n| hanja        = 朴銀珠\n| mr           = Pak Ŭnju\n| rr           = Bak Eunju}}\n| module2             = \n}}\n'''Michelle Eunjoo Steel''' ( '''Park''', born June 21, 1955) is an American politician serving as the  for  since 2023, previously representing the  from 2021 to 2023. A member of the , she concurrently served as a member of  's Whip Team for the .\n\nSteel served as the member of the   from the 2nd district from 2015 to 2021 and of the  from the 3rd district from 2007 to 2015. Steel, fellow California Republican  and Democrat  of  are the first  women to serve in Congress. Steel and Kim, along with , also became the first Republican congressional candidates since  to unseat incumbent House Democrats in California.\n\n\nSteel was born in , South Korea. Her father was born in  to  parents. Steel was educated in South Korea, , and the United States. She holds a degree in business from  and an MBA from the . She is fluent in  and .\n\n\nSteel has been active in Republican Party politics and served on various commissions in the  administration.\n\n\nSteel was elected to the  in 2006 when Republican incumbent Claude Parrish ran unsuccessfully for . Throughout her tenure, she served as the country's highest-ranking  officeholder, and California's highest-ranking Republican woman. She represented more than eight million people in the 3rd district, which then included all of , ,  and  Counties and parts of  and  Counties. In 2011, she was elected vice chair of the Board of Equalization.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2014, Steel was elected to the  representing the 2nd district, defeating  .\n\nIn March 2018, Steel was the only elected official to greet President  when he landed at  on his first official visit to California as president. In 2019, Trump appointed her to the .\n\nSteel chaired the Orange County Board of Supervisors in 2017 and again in 2020. During the , she opposed  in Orange County. She voted against requiring face coverings for retail employees and opposed mask mandates in public schools. She questioned masks' efficacy in preventing the virus spread.\n\nOn September 15, 2020, the Orange County Board of Supervisors approved plans that could lead to increased private jet traffic at . Steel was criticized by her Democratic opponent, , for taking campaign contributions from ACI Jet, the corporation that was awarded the contract.\n\nSteel and her husband  supported  against California Governor  and endorsed  to replace him.\n\nIn 2024, Steel was criticized for her management of $1.2 million allocated for food aid during the 2020 COVID-19 pandemic. With funds from the federal government , each Supervisor contracted to provide meals for needy senior citizens in their district. Steel awarded the contract to a marketing company she was using for her campaign, a company that reportedly had no prior experience with this type of government funding. An audit revealed that the meals had been considerably more costly than in other Orange County districts.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2020, Steel ran for the U.S. House of Representatives in . She received 34.9% of the vote to advance from the primary and defeated    in the November 3 general election with 51.1% of the vote. Steel raised $200,000 more than Rouda.Denkmann, Libby.  , '''', , December 3, 2020. Retrieved December 4, 2020.\n\nDuring her campaign, Steel spoke out against COVID-19 mask mandates. Her platform included opposition to , , and the creation of a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. A conservative, she aligned herself with President .\n\n\n\n\nOn December 23, 2021, Steel announced that she would run in  in 2022 due to redistricting. She was endorsed by , , , , , and the Republican Party of Orange County.\n\nSteel defeated Democratic nominee Jay Chen in the November 8, 2022, general election.\n\n\n\n\nSteel has filed paperwork to run for reelection in the district in .\n\n\n\nAlong with several other Republican U.S. House freshmen, Steel is a member of the Freedom Force, an informal group styled as a Republican counterpart to the Democratic group .\n\nSteel tested positive for  in January 2021. She referenced her own mild symptoms from her bout with COVID to advocate for opening up schools and businesses.\n\nSteel did not vote on the . She voted against the  on January 13, 2021.\n\nIn early February 2021, Steel called for the reopening of schools in California.\n\nOn February 25, 2021, Steel voted against the Equality Act, a bill that would prohibit discrimination based on  and sexual orientation by amending the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Fair Housing Act to explicitly include new protections.\n\nOn February 27, 2021, Steel voted against the , a $1.9 trillion COVID-19 relief and stimulus bill.\n\nIn March 2021, Steel introduced a bill that would block federal funding from being used to support , which she called a \"failure.\"\n\nIn June 2021, Steel was one of 49 House Republicans to vote to repeal the  against Iraq.\n\nIn 2021, Steel joined a majority of Republican representatives in signing onto an ''amicus'' brief to overturn ''''.\n\nIn July 2022, Steel voted against the , which would require the U.S. federal government to recognize the validity of s.\n\nAs of December 2022, Steel had voted in line with President 's stated position 21% of the time.\n\nIn September 2023, Steel was among a bipartisan group of eight U.S. House members who co-sponsored a mental health focused bill aimed at integrating behavioral health services for Medicare beneficiaries in primary care settings.\n\nSteel was a co-sponsor of the Life at Conception Act introduced in January 2023 during the 118th Congress. After a 2024  made clear that the bill's language could endanger the ability to administer in-vitro fertilization, Steel said \"I do not support federal restrictions on IVF.\" She added further, \"As someone who struggled to get pregnant, I believe all life is a gift. IVF allowed me, as it has so many others, to start my family. I believe there is nothing more pro-life than helping families have children.\" In March 2024, Steel rescinded her co-sponsorship of the bill due to her support for IVF. \n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n* \n** \n** \n* \n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\nIn 1981, Steel married , who became  chairman from 2001 to 2003 and man from California since 2008. They have two daughters and live in . She is a .\n\nAt a 2014  event in , Steel said she had withdrawn her younger daughter from the , and sent her to  for a one-year \"brainwash\" after her daughter voiced support for  and President .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n* \n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Juan Alanis''' (born June 17, 1978) is an American politician who is currently serving in the  for the  since 2022. Previously, he was the Sergeant for the  from 1995 to 2022.\n\n\nAlanis was born on June 17, 1978, in , growing up in the neighboring city of . As a sophomore at , he joined the . With the help of a resource officer, he was hired as a part-time employee for the Sheriff's office as part of the Sheriff's Explorers Program. He later attended  and , where he graduated with a  in 2017.\n\n\n\nIn 2017, he announced his campaign for  to succeed Adam Christianson, going against Patterson Police Chief Jeff Dirkse and Deputy Sheriff Tom Letras. Alanis lost against Dirkse in the election with 48.13%.\n\nIn 2021, Alanis again announced his campaign for sheriff against Jeff Dirkse, but after the newly redrawn  of the  placed Modesto into the district, Alanis withdrew from the sheriff election and announced his campaign for State Assembly. In the general election, he went against Democrat Jessica Self, with Alanis defeating Self to become a member of the Assembly. He was sworn in on December 5, 2022, and was placed on the Public Safety, Agriculture, and Water committees.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100.0 \n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Mitchell Englander''' (born 1970) is an American former politician who served as a member of the , representing  in the , until he resigned December 31, 2018. While serving in City Council, he was the only member of the city council who was registered as .\n\nEnglander resigned in order to take a job with . He was subsequently indicted on corruption charges, as part of a major corruption probe at . Englander pleaded guilty to one felony charge on June 7, 2020.\n\n\nEnglander was born in 1970 in  in the San Fernando Valley. According to an interview with the ''Los Angeles Daily News,'' his parents separated when he was 5 years old, and his mother, Linda, a , \"worked two jobs, but lost a home to foreclosure.\" They lived in  with his uncle Michael, whose janitorial firm Englander worked for as a teenager. Englander attended college in Arizona but returned to California without graduating allegedly in order to care for his ailing mother, who later died of a .\n\nIn 1994, his uncle Michael, who Englander said was a father figure for him, was shot and killed in a -related robbery. Englander became a Los Angeles Police Department reservist in 2005 the same day his uncle was killed, Englander's older sister Natalie suffered an asthma attack and fell into a coma. She was \"rushed to an emergency room whose doors were mistakenly locked.\"  She wasn't able to receive medical aid in time and \"awoke with brain damage.\" She lived with the Englander family for a decade before she died.\n\nPrior to elected office, Englander worked as a political consultant for another uncle, and later on his own. Englander is married to his \"high school sweetheart\". The couple appeared in the first-ever episode of ''''.\n\n\n\n\nEnglander was  to City Councilman  from 2003 to 2009, in , then in the Northwest San Fernando Valley. Like the Councilman before him, Englander joined the LAPD Reserves and used that platform to launch a run for office. In September 2009 Englander launched his campaign to succeed Smith, who had announced retirement upon his term's end.\n\nNoting that Englander was the \"consummate City Hall insider,\" the '''' endorsed him as \"the best of several good choices.\" An  noted that Englander's \"proximity\" to Greig Smith had \"clearly brought him advantages in fund-raising,\" with more than $440,000 already raised, \"which is 10 times as much as his closest rival (and more than any other candidate for city office this election).\" The ''Times'' said that Englander had been Smith's \"proxy\" and \"now claims to have played the leading role in a number of Smith's accomplishments.\" The '''' endorsed him as well, saying that Smith presented \"common-sense ideas to reform government, such as cutting general managers' base salaries but awarding bonuses to those who provide excellent service on a tight budget.\"\n\n\nEnglander was elected to represent City Council District 12 in the March 8, 2011 primary, receiving 57.74% of the total vote.  . accessed 6.21.2012\n\n\n  at the  in 2015]]\n*Arizona boycottOn October 21, 2011, Englander called for an end to the city's boycott of Arizona, which had been voted in May 2010 after that state adopted , a law requiring law-enforcement officers to ask for proof of U.S. citizenship from people in vehicles pulled over and suspected to be in the United States illegally. He said he would pay his own way to attend a  conference in Phoenix, since the city would not do so.\n*Minimum Wage-On May 19, 2015 Englander cast the lone dissenting vote when the Los Angeles City Council voted to raise the minimum wage in the city to fifteen dollars per hour in increments by 2020.\n\n\nOn October 11, 2018, Englander announced that he would resign from the council to join , a sports and entertainment advisory, development and investment company, as vice president of government affairs.\n\n\nEnglander was indicted by a  on January 16, 2020, for actions taken while still on the council.  He was charged with one count of participating in a scheme to falsify material facts, three counts of making false statements, and three counts of witness tampering. The indictment became public when Englander surrendered to the FBI on March 9, 2020.\n\nThe indictment stated that this stemmed from trips to  and  on June 1-2, 2017, and June 10-12, 2017, paid for by unnamed people. In Las Vegas, Englander and at least two city staffers were said to have attended and received hotel rooms, VIP hotel amenities, casino chips (at least some of which were returned), limo rides, escort services, a $2,400 dinner, and a $34,000 visit to a nightclub. Englander is also alleged to have accepted an envelope containing $10,000 in cash given to him in the resort and casino's bathroom. In Palm Springs, Englander is said to have accepted another $5,000 at a casino. \n\nOn January 26, 2021, Englander was sentenced to 14 months in federal prison for his conduct. He pleaded guilty in July 2020 to falsifying material facts, and as part of a plea deal admitted lying to investigators over the course of three interviews. He was also ordered to serve three years under supervised release following his prison term and pay a $15,000 fine.  Englander surrendered to the U.S. Federal Camp in Tucson, Arizona. He was released in February 2022.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Charlene Zettel''' (née '''Gonzales''') (born May 26, 1947) served in the  from 1999 until 2002. Ms. Zettel was born in . She attended Flintridge Sacred Heart Academy in La Canada-Flintridge and then earned her bachelor's degree in  from , where she was one of the original USC Song Girls.  While serving in the State Assembly, Zettel worked for the passage of \"Oliver's Law\", which provides parents with information about day care providers. She was also the first   elected to the State Assembly. She stepped down with one term to go before term limits would have claimed her in order to run for the ,  but lost that election to , who claimed 54% of the vote while Zettel claimed 46%.  She was appointed the Director of the Department of Consumer Affairs in March 2004 by Governor .\n\nCharlene Zettel was appointed University of California Regent by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger in 2009 and served until her term expired on March 1, 2021. She is also a board member of the  Regional Airport Authority and a former public interest director of the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco. Also in 2009, she was appointed director for the San Diego Office of the Governor. Ms Zettel has been married to David for 40 years; the couple has two adult sons.\n\n\n\n\n#\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Edward Vincent Jr.''' (June 23, 1934 – August 31, 2012) was elected to the  in November 2000, and represented the 25th Senatorial District until 2008, which included , , , , , , , , , and the . Vincent and his wife Marilyn lived in Inglewood from 1968. Together they had two daughters and three grandchildren. Vincent died on August 31, 2012.\n\n\nBorn in , Vincent showed a love for sports and a desire to succeed. This helped him to gain an athletic scholarship to the  in 1952. There, he majored in  and . Moreover, Vincent excelled on the football field, receiving All  and  honors. As the third draft choice of the 1956 , Vincent played in several games before being sidelined by injuries.\n\nWhile serving in the military, Vincent received all Army and all Service Football Team honors. After an honorable discharge from the U.S. Army in 1959, Vincent continued his education, earning a  degree in  from . He then embarked upon a 35-year career with the .\n\n\nVincent was elected to the Inglewood Unified School District's Board of Trustees, where he served as president from 1978 to 1979. Moreover, he represented the residents of District No. 4 on the Inglewood City Council from 1979 to 1983. In 1983, Vincent began his term as the first African-American  and was re-elected for three additional terms. He was also commissioner of the State of California World Trade Commission.\n\n\nVincent served as a member of the   from 1996 to 2000, representing the 51st Assembly District. In the Assembly, he chaired the Elections, Reapportionment, and Constitutional Amendments Committee as well as the California Horse Racing Industry Committee. On October 24, 2000, Vincent received the  for outstanding public service on behalf of farm workers. The award was presented by La Cooperativa.\n\n\nBetween 2000 and 2008 Vincent served in the State Senate. He was a member of the Senate Committees on Agriculture, Governmental Organization, and Health. He also chaired the Select Committee on the Horseracing Industry. In this function, he authored legislation on gambling licenses, state teacher retirement benefits, horse racing, and community care facilities. He was forced to leave the Senate in 2008 due to term limits.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Calvin M. Dooley''' (born January 11, 1954),  politician, was a  member of the  from 1991 to 2005, representing the 17th and 20th districts of .\n\n\nBorn in , he grew up on his parents' farm several miles east of  and graduated from  in 1972. Dooley earned his bachelor's degree in agricultural economics from the  in 1977 and a master's degree in Management from  in 1987.\n\n\nDooley worked as a rancher and then as an administrative assistant for California State Senator  from 1987 to 1990.\n\n\nIn 1990, Dooley won the Democratic primary for what was then the 17th District and faced six-term   in November. Although Pashayan had been reelected with 71 percent of the vote in 1988, he was bogged down by the , and Dooley defeated him by just over 9 points. In 1992, his district was renumbered as the 20th District and drawn as a Latino-majority district. He was easily reelected that year and five more times after that. He faced only one truly serious contest, when Republican Rich Rodriguez managed to hold him to 53 percent of the vote. A \",\" his voting record was considered moderate, as is typical for Democrats from the .\n\nDooley announced his retirement in 2004 and endorsed his chief of staff, Lisa Quigley, as his successor. However, most of the rest of the state Democratic establishment endorsed , a former state legislator from the Fresno area. This touched off a contentious primary battle which was won by Costa, all but assuring him of victory in November. \nOn October 10, 2002, Cal Dooley was among the 81 House Democrats who voted in favor of authorizing the . He has later said that he regrets this vote.\n\n\nHaving served as the president and CEO of the  (FPA), Dooley assumed the same roles at the  (GMA), following a merger with the FPA. GMA is a Washington-based trade association representing food manufacturers.\n\nIn September 2008, Dooley assumed the position of CEO of the , the trade association for American chemical companies. He announced his retirement in 2018.\n\n\nDooley is married to the former Linda Phillips, who heads the  in Washington DC. The couple have two daughters, one of whom is on the Charlottesville City School Board.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Konstantine Anthony''' (born 1981) is an American politician and former actor, serving as a member of the  since 2020. He previously served as Mayor of Burbank from 2022 to 2023.\n\nIn 2020, Anthony was elected to the Burbank City Council. In March 2023, Anthony announced his campaign for the , challenging  incumbent . He came third, winning 11% of the vote to Barger's 56%.\n\n\n\n.]]\nDuring the , Anthony came out in favor of the  and appeared multiple times on their picket lines, alongside other elected officials. Konstantine has been a  member since 2006 and a member of  since 2019.\n\n\nIn September 2023, Konstantine Anthony was involved in an incident that attracted media coverage and public discussion. During a fundraising event hosted by the Santa Clarita Valley Democrats called Drag Queen Bingo, a video was taken that showed Anthony being spanked by a drag performer. Fox News reported the incident on September 11, 2023. The Los Angeles Times, in an article dated September 14, 2023, discussed the subsequent online debates.\n\n\nAnthony is a proponent of a policeless state, advocating for the  as well as the . He identifies himself as a futurist, abolitionist, and a , stating that he believes in the restructuring of societal systems and ideologies within the framework of . \n\n\nOutside of elected office, Anthony is involved with a number of social justice organizations. He has been part of the Burbank Advisory Council on Disabilities since 2018, and is a member of the Domestic Violence Task Force. He previously served on the Burbank Transportation Commission from 2017 to 2020. He is a member of and was endorsed by , in his run for Burbank City Council.\n\n\nIn the , Anthony endorsed twenty year old activist . According to , he endorsed her in the , and according to California State Assemblywoman , he co-endorsed her for that seat. In , Anthony had previously endorsed fellow Burbank resident and U.S. representative .  However, in late October 2023, after Schiff had released a statement in support of 's \"right to defend itself\" during the , Anthony withdrew his endorsement of Schiff and declined to endorse any other candidate until Schiff would endorse peace in the region. On December 11, 2023, Anthony endorsed Schiff’s opponent in the race, Rep. .\n\n\nAnthony has publicly identified as , a factor he cites as a driving force behind his advocacy for . In a Twitter post, the Burbank Republican Party highlighted this statement from Margo Rowder: \"You chose to drag someone who doesn't have the money for a formal autism diagnosis and whose former schoolmates called him in his late 20s to ask if he thinks he might be autistic.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
