    "pages": }\n'''Elizabeth Beckman Schaaf''' (born November 12, 1965) is an American politician who served as the  from 2015 to 2023. A member of the , she previously served on the .\n\nSchaaf won the  in the 14th round in  with 62.79% of the vote. Schaaf won re-election  with a 27% margin.\n\n\nSchaaf was born in , on November 12, 1965. Her mother was a flight attendant. Growing up in Oakland's District 4, Schaaf attended  and , both in Oakland. She holds a B.A. in political science from  and a  from .\n\n\nBefore starting her political career, Schaaf was an attorney in Oakland at the law firm of . She then became the program director for the Marcus A. Foster Educational Institute in 1995, creating and running a new volunteer program for the .\n\nSchaaf's first roles in local government were as legislative aide to  president  and special assistant to Oakland mayor .\n\nIn 2006, Schaaf joined the  as the Director of Public Affairs, helping to secure state and federal funding for the city of Oakland, as well as directing all strategic communications for the port. In 2009, Schaaf graduated from , a training program for women who aspire to elected office.\n\nBefore joining the Oakland City Council in 2010, Schaaf served as the Economic Policy Advisor for the council for a year.\n\n\nIn 2010, Schaaf was elected to represent her home district, District 4, on the .\n\nDuring her tenure on the city council, Schaaf fought to raise the minimum wage, voicing her support for Measure FF, also known as Lift Up Oakland, a $12.25 minimum wage ballot initiative which passed in a landslide on November 4, 2014. Schaaf also strove to increase government transparency and efficiency, build a safer city, and strengthen Oakland neighborhoods in her time on city council. She worked extensively on Oakland Police Department reform, hiring more civilian staff and pushing through a plan to coordinate the  with the , to increase the number of officers patrolling Oakland.\n\n\n at Schaaf's inaugural celebration (pictured with the art car, the Golden Mean).]]\nIn the race for Oakland mayor, Schaaf was endorsed by   and  .\n\nDuring her mayoral term, the city lost two major league sports teams, the  and the , in 2019. Additionally, the  began during her tenure.\n\n\nIn June 2015, Mayor Schaaf announced the formation of Oakland's first Department of Transportation. The Department of Transportation assumed some responsibilities formerly held by Oakland Public Works, such as road design, resurfacing and maintenance. In her announcement, Mayor Schaaf said that the focus will be on, \"sustainable strategies that can bring needed change quickly to city streets.\"\n\nThe Department of Transportation consists of 300 employees, previously working in the Department of Public Works and Oakland Police Department's Parking Enforcement operations.\n\nFunding for the Department of Transportation came from many public resources, including Measure BB, a sales tax approved in November 2014 to fund transportation projects in Alameda County. Schaaf hired Matt Nichols as her Policy Director for Transportation and Infrastructure in March 2015. Jeff Tumlin was named Interim Director of the department in June 2016.\n\n\nIn May 2015, Mayor Schaaf instituted a ban on un-permitted nighttime marches on public roadways in Oakland, citing existing city policies. The first enforcement of this ban was on May 21, during a  #SayHerName march, a nationwide coordinated march focused on ending state violence against black women and girls in the US. Demonstrators met at  before sunset for a rally. After the rally, demonstrators began to march onto the street. Police officers told them to keep to the sidewalks, and cited , making it an arrestable offense not to comply with the police order.\n in 2020]]\nEnactment of this policy brought harsh criticism and allegations of illegality from some , including civil rights attorney and one of the co-authors of Oakland Police Department's Crowd Control and Crowd Management Policy, Rachel Lederman: \"My general impression is the police took an unduly aggressive approach that not only violated their own crowd control policy, but also the First Amendment... This was an unreasonable interference with the demonstration given that there had been no serious crimes committed.\" Other legal experts pointed to similar policies in cities like New York, which have been ruled constitutional.\n\n\nSchaaf alerted city residents to imminent  (ICE) raids in February 2018, earning criticism from some federal authorities. She responded, \"I was sharing information in a way that was legal and was not obstructing justice, and it was an opportunity to ensure that people were aware of their rights.\" ICE’s acting director  stated that ICE failed to arrest around 800 people because of the alert.\n\n\nIn March 2021, Schaaf announced that 600 selected , low-income families of Oakland would receive $500 per month \"guaranteed income\" for 18 months. According to the project's website, the income is funded by private  donations.\n\n\nSchaaf is . She lives in  with her husband Salvatore Fahey. They have two children, Dominic and Lena.\n\n\nSchaaf co-founded the nonprofit Oakland Cares, which organized and implemented hundreds of volunteer community improvement projects across the city. She also built and ran the first centralized volunteer program for Oakland public schools at the Marcus Foster Institute. She serves on the Leadership Council at , a non-profit organization that allows people to lend money via the Internet to low-income entrepreneurs and students in over 80 countries.\n\n\nSince 2010, Oakland elections have used .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}} \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  at SmartVoter\n* Articles about Schaaf at , , , and \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Brian Nestande''' (January 10, 1964 – March 6, 2024) was an American consultant and politician who was a  man representing the .\n\n\nBrian Nestande was born in , on January 10, 1964. He grew up in a political family. His father, , was a state legislator and Orange County Supervisor during the 1970s and 1980's. Nestande graduated from  in  in 1982. Nestande earned his  in  from  in 1991.\n\nImmediately after graduating from college, Nestande obtained a job as Deputy Campaign Manager of the successful congressional campaign of  in . In 1994, Nestande managed the successful congressional campaign of then- Mayor . Nestande went to work in Bono's office as Chief of Staff until Bono's death in early 1998. Bono's widow, , was elected to succeed Sonny, and Nestande served as her chief of staff from 1998 until 2000.\n\nIn 2000, Nestande built a government affairs consulting business named Nestande and Associates which was headquartered in . He represented a variety of clients working on issues involving alternative energy, health care, telecommunications as well as on other projects and issues in Riverside County.\n\n\n\n;2008\nIn 2008, Nestande ran for the  . He defeated businesswoman Kelly McCarty in the Republican primary 68%-32%. He won the general election unopposed.\n;2010\nIn 2010, he won the Republican primary, defeating Jeffrey Lemasters Tahir 76%-24%. He won re-election to a second term defeating  57%-43%.\n;2012\nAfter redistricting, he decided to run in the newly redrawn . He won re-election to a third term, defeating Democrat Mark Orozco 55%-45%.\n\n\nThe first bill Nestande introduced in Sacramento was to limit the number of bills a legislator could introduce. Nestande later led a bipartisan coalition that closed a loophole on out-of-state businesses.\n\nIn January 2011, Nestande criticized a proposal to cut in-home supportive services. He sponsored legislation to aid the Salton Sea restoration. He proposed legislation that would create online education standards, increasing college access to those unable to participate in traditional classroom instruction. In June 2014, Nestande expressed concern about the potential for money in the Governor's budget to be diverted from tech education programs.\n\nNestande argued that the state government should include unfunded liabilities when making spending decisions.\n\nIn January 2014, Nestande called for a hearing about the 43 employees with a criminal record hired by , the California state health exchange administering the  in that state. In October 2013, he sponsored legislation requiring lawmakers who want legislative health care coverage to enroll through the Covered California exchange, saying \"If we truly want to understand how the ACA is working and being implemented, there is no better way than to enroll in the exchange along with the people.\"\n\n\n;2013\n*Budget\n*Governmental Organization, Vice-chair\n*Health\n*Insurance\n*Revenue and Taxation\n\n\n\nNestande announced in May 2013 that he would challenge first-term representative , D-Palm Desert, to represent  in the . Ruiz defeated longtime incumbent Republican  in 2012.\n\nNestande, described by the ''Press Enterprise'' as the moderate candidate, received more votes than the conservative Ray Haynes, a former state assemblyman, in the . Nestande won 34% of the vote to Haynes' 16%.\n\nIn September 2014, '''' wrote that Nestande \"has proved to be one of the cycle’s more disappointing candidates\" in terms of fundraising, but a campaign spokesperson in October 2014 told the ''Desert Sun'' that there was a \"strong finance plan for the end game.\" The campaign also stated that opponent Ruiz is receiving financial contributions from outside forces, \"while more than 90 percent of Nestande's money is from California.\"\n\nIn October 2014, the ''Press Enterprise'' offered their endorsement to Nestande who they write is \"best-suited to protecting taxpayers’ money, tackling the federal government’s mounting spending and debt and generally keeping government from hampering job growth and interfering in individuals’ personal affairs.\"\n\n\nNestande was the son of politician , himself a former California assemblyman and .\n\nNestande resided in  with his wife Gina and their seven children.  Gina was elected to the Palm Desert City Council in November 2016 and became mayor in December 2019.\n\nNestande died in Palm Desert on March 6, 2024, at the age of 60.\n\nThe Riverside County Coroner’s Office identified the cause of death as \"multiple substance intoxication, including fentanyl and cocaine.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|children     = 2\n|education    =  ()\n}}\n'''Mary Bono''' '''Oswald''' (née '''Whitaker''' and formerly '''Mary Bono Mack''', born October 24, 1961) is an American politician, businesswoman, and lobbyist who served  and most of central and eastern , in the  from 1998 to 2013.\n\nA member of the , Bono was first elected to Congress in 1998 to replace her late husband, , who had died in office months earlier. She sat on the  and was chairwoman of the Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade. , Bono served on the  that approved  against President . Bono served in Congress until losing her 2012 reelection bid.\n\nIn March 2013, Bono became a senior vice president at the Washington, D.C.-based federal affairs firm Faegre Baker Daniels Consulting. In 2018, she founded the political affairs consulting firm Integritas by Bono.\n\n\nBono was born Mary Whitaker in , , the daughter of Karen Lee (née Taylor), a chemist, and Dr. Clay Westerfield Whitaker, a physician and World War II veteran. In 1963, the family moved to . She graduated from  in 1979, then from the  in 1984 with a Bachelor of Arts in art history. Whitaker was an accomplished  in her youth and worked as a cocktail waitress during her early twenties.\n\nIn 1986, Whitaker married singer, actor and politician . They moved to  where  Sonny Bono served as  from 1988 to 1992 before being elected to the  in 1994. The congressman died in a skiing accident on January 5, 1998, during his second term in Congress, leaving a vacant seat in the House, which Mary Bono would then pursue.\n\n\n\n during a press conference related to the ]]\nIn 1998, Mary Bono won the Republican nomination for the special election to succeed her late husband in what was then California's 44th congressional district. She was then elected to Congress on April 7, 1998. Bono won election to a full term on November 3, 1998.\n\nThat same year, Bono was added to the  by the Republican leadership in anticipation of the consideration of  against President Clinton, thus becoming the only Republican woman on the committee during the . Bono voted along party lines on all four motions for impeachment in both the committee and on the House floor, despite other moderate Republican House members voting against Articles II, III, and IV. Bono's service on the House Judiciary panel increased her national profile considerably.\n\nBono served in Congress for 15 years. In 2011, her bill, H.R. 2715, was signed into law with bipartisan support to amend and improve the  of 2008. The daughter of a veteran, Bono also played a key role in creation of VA clinics in Blythe and Palm Desert, California. In December 2010, she was one of fifteen Republican House members to vote in favor of repealing the 's \"\" ban on  service members.Chris Geidner,  , '''' (December 15, 2010). , '''' (December 15, 2010).\n\n\nAfter the , Bono's district was renumbered as the 36th district and made somewhat more Democratic and Hispanic than its predecessor. In a significant upset, Democratic challenger , a physician, defeated her with 53 percent of the vote to Bono's 47.1 percent.\n\nIn 2013, Bono was a signatory to an amicus curiae brief submitted to the Supreme Court in support of same-sex marriage during the '''' case.\n\n\n* \n**  (Chairwoman)\n** \n** \n* \n* \n* \n\nBono was chairwoman of the House Energy Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade. This committee debates legislation related to intellectual property, telecommunications, energy and healthcare. She was the first Republican woman to chair this subcommittee.\nShe was co-chair of the Congressional Caucus on Prescription Drug Abuse. In 2012, she formed and chaired the House Women's Policy Committee, which included 24 female Republican lawmakers from 17 states.\n\n\n* America Supports You Caucus\n* Intellectual Property Promotion and Piracy Prevention Caucus (Co-chair)\n* \n* Recording Arts and Sciences Caucus (Co-chair)\n*  (associate member)\n* \n\n\nIn March 2013, Bono became a senior vice president at the Washington, D.C.-based federal affairs firm .\n\nIn June 2013, a group of leading telecommunications firms announced formation of the 21st Century Privacy Coalition, which focuses on updating U.S. privacy and data security laws. Mary Bono and Jon Leibowitz, former Federal Trade Commission chairman, were named co-chairs of the coalition. Also in June 2013, Bono helped lead expansion of  and Faegre Baker Daniels Consulting into Silicon Valley, in her home state of California.\n\nIn August 2013, Bono was a panelist at the ''National Journal'''s Women 2020 event. At that event, she discussed gender inequality and her experiences as a woman in Congress.\n\nIn October 2018, following the  sex abuse scandal, Bono was named interim president and chief executive officer of . However, she resigned four days later following criticism over her previous role as a lobbyist for USA Gymnastics amid public concern that she had marked out the  logo on her sneakers in protest of Nike's support for NFL quarterback .\n\n\nAfter attending a lecture by mountaineer-turned-humanitarian , Bono worked with him to aid his efforts to build schools for girls in the mountainous regions of Pakistan. Bono is quoted in Mortenson's book '''' as saying \"I've learned more from Greg Mortenson about the causes of terrorism than during all our briefings on Capitol Hill.\"\n\n\nOn March 1, 1986, she married actor/singer Sonny Bono. The Bonos moved to Palm Springs, where they owned and operated a restaurant. Sonny Bono served as Mayor of Palm Springs from 1988 to 1992 before being elected to Congress in 1994. The Bonos had two children: Chesare (b. April 25, 1988) and Chianna (b. February 2, 1991). Sonny Bono died on January 5, 1998, in a skiing accident.\n\nAfter Sonny Bono's death in 1998, Bono began dating Brian Prout, drummer of the country music band . The two became engaged in 2001 but did not marry.\n\nOn November 24, 2001, Bono married Wyoming businessman Glenn Baxley about 18 months after they met in Mexico. They filed for divorce in 2005.\n\nOn December 15, 2007, Bono married Congressman  (-) in . In May 2013, the couple announced they had separated on amicable terms. They divorced later that year.\n\nOn September 27, 2015, Bono married former astronaut and retired Navy rear admiral .\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  ''official campaign site''\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Alex Tianming Lee''' (; born July 11, 1995) is an American politician who has served as a member of the  since 2020, having represented the  since 2022 and the  from 2020 to 2022. A member of the , Lee's district includes , , , , and parts of western .\n\nA Democratic Socialist, Lee is one of the most progressive members of the California legislature. During his tenure, he has been a strong supporter of legislation to increase housing, in particular social housing.\n\n\nLee was born on July 11, 1995, in . His parents immigrated to the United States from . His father is an engineer and his mother is a nurse. After his parents divorced, Lee lived alternately with his father in  and his mother in .\n\nLee graduated from  in 2013. He became interested in filmmaking and eventually decided to pursue a dual degree in political science and communications at the . Lee ran for a seat on the student senate at UC Davis in 2014 and served as student body president in 2016. He graduated with a  in 2017.\n\nWhile attending college, Lee was an  for several politicians including , , , , and . He began working for  as a full-time legislative aide after graduating college. Prior to running for office, Lee delivered food, and lived with his mother due to the high cost of living in his district.\n\n\n\n\nIn June 2019, Lee announced he would run to succeed Chu in the  upon Chu's retirement from the State Assembly. He ran as a  and was endorsed by the . In March 2020, Lee finished second in a field of nine candidates in the nonpartisan blanket primary; he split the vote with seven other Democrats and finished behind Republican Bob Brunton. Lee defeated Brunton in the .\n\nLee was sworn into the State Assembly on December 7, 2020. Taking office at age 25, he was the Assembly's youngest member, the first born in the 1990s, and the first openly  member.\n\nOn his first day in office, Lee introduced a bill that would ban corporate donations to political candidates. Lee has since introduced legislation in favor of increasing  in California. Lee has expressed support for a land-value tax as a potential way to increase housing supply and reduce inequality. YIMBY Action, a pro-housing advocacy group, described Lee \"as a strong supporter of every major pro-housing bill.\" He has also secured $2.5 million in funding for  and services for  in Milpitas.\n\nIn , Lee was redrawn into the . He placed first in the nonpartisan blanket primary ahead of Brunton, Chu, and two other Democrats, and defeated Brunton in a rematch in the general election. He was sworn into his second term on December 5, 2022.\n\nLee is the chair of the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* at \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Samuel Sharon Farr''' (born July 4, 1941) is an American politician who was the  for  (1993–2013) and  (2013–17). He is a member of the . He was elected to Congress in a 1993 special election when longtime Democratic Rep.  resigned to become Director of the . On November 12, 2015, he announced his retirement from Congress after the 2016 elections.\n\n\nFarr was born in San Francisco, the son of Janet Emerson (née Haskins) and . One of his maternal great-grandfathers was acting mayor of Los Angeles , and one of his paternal great-great-grandfathers was the brother of Nevada Senator . He grew up in , where he still lives. His father was a California state senator from 1955 to 1967.\n\nHe was educated at ,  and the . Farr is a member of the  fraternity at Willamette University.\n\n\n\n\nFarr joined the  in 1964 and served for two years as a volunteer in . He spent his time in a poor barrio near , teaching community development skills.\n\nWhile Farr was serving in Colombia, his mother died from cancer. Following her death, his father visited with Farr's sisters. While riding horses, his sister Nancy was thrown and hit her head. She died on the operating table in a Colombian hospital.\n\nSince his Peace Corps service ended, Farr has visited Colombia often. He went there for his honeymoon and has returned several other times for both personal and official business. During a trip in 2007, Farr spoke before the Colombian Congress and was awarded the Orden del Congreso de Colombia.\n\n\nFarr's public service career began in the , where he worked as a staffer on budget issues for a decade. In 1975, he ran for and won a seat on the  .\n\nIn 1980 he was elected to a seat in the Assembly, where he became a champion for the organics industry and wrote one of the country's strictest oil-spill liability laws. He served in the Assembly until his election to Congress in 1993. \n\n\n\n during his swearing in ceremony]]\nFarr was elected to the House of Representatives in a 1993 special election. He succeeded Leon Panetta, who resigned to become President 's budget director. Farr defeated Republican Bill McCampbell with 52 percent of the vote, and then was elected to his first full term in 1994, defeating McCampbell again with 52 percent of the vote. Both contests were the closest in the district since Panetta claimed the seat for the Democrats in 1977, and to date are the only times since then that a Republican has crossed the 40 percent mark. The district quickly reverted to form, and Farr was re-elected ten more times with no substantive opposition, never dropping below 64 percent of the vote.\n\n\n*Farr introduced the \"Oceans Conservation, Education, and National Strategy for the 21st Century Act\" ( ) in January 2007. The bill would consolidate national management of oceans, creating a system of regional governance; make the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration the chief oceans agency; create an ocean advisor in the president's Cabinet; create regional and national ocean advisory committees; and create an Oceans and Great Lakes Conservation Trust Fund. It received a subcommittee markup in April 2008 and passed by a vote of 11–3.\n*Farr's \"Reconstruction and Stabilization Civilian Management Act of 2008\" ( ) was approved by the House but stalled in the Senate. The bill would create capacity within the State Department to quickly deploy civilian expertise and coordinate the government response to crises abroad. President [George W. Bush] supported the program and approved initial creation of the group. Farr participated in a rollout of the group with Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice in July 2008.\n\n\n]] Farr was active in several congressional caucuses, including the House Oceans Caucus, the Congressional Travel and Tourism Caucus, the Congressional Bike Caucus, the Congressional Organic Caucus, the , and the Unexploded Ordnance Caucus.\n\nHe served as co-chair of the Congressional Travel and Tourism Caucus with Rep.  (R-Florida). Farr actively supported the travel industry, boosting membership in the caucus to more than 100 and hosting caucus events, including a June 2008 gathering of travel executives and congressional leaders--The Economic Roundtable: Travel's Significance to the U.S. Economy.\n\nFarr also was active as co-chair of the House Oceans Caucus, which he co-chaired with four other members. Each year the caucus helps sponsor Capitol Hill Oceans Week, known as CHOW, which draws hundreds of ocean experts from across the country. Farr also co-chaired the Congressional Organic Caucus and the Unexploded Ordnance Caucus.\n\n\nFarr served on the , a group established by the House and mandated to work with emerging democracies throughout the world. The group engages in \"peer-to-peer cooperation to build technical expertise in partner legislatures that will enhance accountability, transparency, legislative independence, access to information, and government oversight.\"\n\nHe also is the former chairman of the California Democratic congressional delegation, the largest state delegation in Congress.\n\n\n*''''''\n** (Ranking Member)\n**\n\n\n*Farr was one of 31 House members who voted to not count the s from  in the .\n*He opposed the  and is . He received a 91% progressive rating by Progressive Punch, ranking him the 42nd most progressive member of congress.\n*Farr took a leadership role for the House Democrats in opposing the  because he did not think it had good environmental and worker protections.\n*He voted against the invasion of  and was actively against the .\n*Farr voted for the $700 billion Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008.\n*He received a perfect 100% rating for the 110th, 111th, and 112th United States Congresses from the .\n\n\n]]\n*Farr is a proponent of ocean protection and conservation. In addition to H.R. 21, Farr introduced the Southern Sea Otter Recovery and Research Act () and the Clean Cruise Ship Act ( ).\n*He opposes opening new areas to offshore drilling, instead supporting the drilling of  of federally owned land already under lease, including  on the Outer Continental Shelf. Farr also supports ending subsidies to oil companies.\n*Farr has worked closely with Central Coast cities and the Army on the re-use of the former . He was integral in securing $29 million for the creation of . He also played a role in making sure land on the former installation included significant amounts of affordable housing.\n*He supports comprehensive immigration reform that includes a guest worker program for farm workers, allowing  to remain in the country (known as the ), and deporting undocumented felons in U.S. jails.\n\n\n*Farr consistently opposed the war in Iraq. He voted against the \"Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution of 2002\" that started the war. Farr cosponsored several bills including  , which supported a timetable for troop withdrawal, and   and  , which called for congressional approval for any long-term agreements with Iraq.\n*He was vocal in efforts to prevent military action against Iran, cosponsoring H. Con. Res 33, which would require congressional approval before any incursion into Iran, and  , a bill to prohibit the use of funds for military operations in Iran.\n*Farr parlayed his experience in Colombia to become a congressional leader on Colombian affairs. He was an active supporter of rebalancing funds dedicated to Plan Colombia, the U.S. anti-drug effort, to include more support for economic redevelopment efforts. He hosted a wide range of Colombian political leaders in his Washington office including then-President  and former President .\n\n\nOn February 26, 2008, at the  hearing, Farr said \"the public image of (the ICE agents)\" has become \"not (a) compassionate law enforcement agency but essentially a -type agency that is knocking down doors\" when conducting raids on illegal immigrants. , assistant secretary of  for , responded to Farr's comments by saying, \"We are not the Gestapo. The men and women of this agency have a very difficult job...and I think they do that with distinction and great honor.\". Farr replied that he knew and appreciated this, but reiterated that there is \"there is a very ill will public opinion in the counties (he) represent(s), about ICE\".\n\n\n at the  in 2015]]\nOn July 12, 2007, Farr joined 11 cosponsors of H.Res. 333, which laid out three articles of impeachment against Vice President . The bill maintained that the vice president purposely manipulated the intelligence process to deceive the citizens and Congress of the United States (1) by fabricating a threat of Iraqi weapons of mass destruction and (2) about an alleged relationship between Iraq and  in order to justify the use of the United States Armed Forces against the nation of Iraq in a manner damaging to our national security interests, and (3) that Cheney had openly threatened aggression against the Republic of Iran absent any real threat to the United States.\n\n\"Many residents in the Central Coast support the removal of Cheney from office, and I am proud to represent their values in Congress,\" Farr said in a brief statement.\n\n\nOn July 30, 2007, Farr received the Senator David Pryor Special Achievement Award for his ongoing advocacy for communities with military bases presented by the Association of Defense Communities. The award is given to an individual who advocates for communities with active or closed military bases. \"Communities with active or closed military bases face many special concerns, from land use to economic development to ordnance disposal,\" said Farr. \"I have been lucky enough to assist in the transition efforts at Fort Ord, and that experience has helped me push those issues locally and nationwide.\" As vice-chair of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Military Construction, Farr successfully increased clean-up funds from $221 million to $271 million for military bases closed prior to 2005.\n\n\nFarr is married to the former Shary Baldwin and has one daughter, Jessica. He is an .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n (retrieved on January 26, 2014).]}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* at \n* from the \n* from the ''Havana Times''\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|birth_place     = , U.S.\n|death_date      = \n|death_place     = \n|spouse          = Dan (m. 1983)\n|children        = 1\n|education       =  ()\n|party           = \n|website         = \n}}\n'''Diane Lynn Harkey''' (born June 20, 1951) is an American politician who served as a member of the , representing its fourth district from 2015 to 2019. A member of the , she was previously elected to the   (2004–2008), including a stint as Mayor of Dana Point (2007–2008), as well as the  (2008–2014). She was a Republican candidate for  seat in the , losing to  .\n\n\nBorn in , Harkey moved to California with her family as a young girl. Harkey graduated cum laude from the , with a  in economics.\n\n\nHarkey has served as a vice-president in the banking industry and has had a 30-year career in corporate banking and finance.\n\n\n\nHarkey's involvement in politics began in 1989, when she actively campaigned for the incorporation of the City of . Harkey has served as a board member of the Ocean Institute and Dana Point Fifth Marine Regiment Support Group, a trustee for the Capistrano Valley Symphony, and a member of the . She served on the  City Council from 2004 to 2008, and during that period, in 2007, she served as the city's mayor.\n\n\nIn 2006, Harkey ran against then-  for the 35th State Senate District in one of the closest  races in the state's history. Harman defeated Harkey for the Republican nomination by 225 votes or roughly 0.2% of the vote and went on to win the general election by 44,000 votes.\n\n\nIn , she ran as the Republican nominee for the 73rd State Assembly district against  nominee Judy Jones. Harkey received the endorsements of the Republican Congressional delegation in the district, Assemblywoman  (who vacated the seat to run for state senate), former opponent State Senator , over 80 elected officials in Orange and San Diego Counties, and the Republican Assembly Women's Caucus. Harkey won the election with 53.4% of the vote, while Jones received 40.6% of the vote. She served in the Assembly from November 2008 to November 2014.\n\n\nIn 2014, Harkey became term-limited in the State Assembly and ran for a seat on the California State Board of Equalization representing the 4th district, which encompasses , , , and  counties, as well as small portions of  and  counties. She came in second place in the June 3  with 34.0% of the vote, and subsequently won the November general election by a margin of 61.6% to 38.4%. In 2017 she was selected by her colleagues on the board to serve as board chair.\n\nShe chose not to seek reelection in 2018, choosing instead to run for Congress to represent . Her term on the board ended in January 2019.\n\n\nHarkey represents the communities of , , , , , , , , , , and .\n\nHarkey has been an outspoken opponent of , introducing several pieces of legislation to defund the project.\n\nIn 2017, the  audited the Board of Equalization and found a conference in Harkey's district had brought in 98 board employees to perform duties including \"registration, parking lot duty, and break area facilitation\". Harkey denied that she was involved in redirecting staff to these activities.\n\nIn 2017, a  audit of the  recommended the dismissal of one of Harkey's aides. The audit found that the aide was allowed to work from the agency's New York office, and that Harkey's staff \"used their positions of authority to improperly influence, and arguably pressure, BOE executives to ensure placement\" of the aide to a permanent civil service position.\n\n\nAs of 2008, Harkey had received an \"A\" lifetime rating from the  (NRA).\n\nAs of 2013, Harkey had a 100% rating from the Capitol Resource Institute, a  interest group in California.\n\nIn a March 2016 opinion piece, Harkey noted that while gas prices around the U.S. had recently dropped dramatically, California prices had stayed high. She pointed out that even though the  had approved decreases in the state gas tax, prices had not gone down accordingly. The reason for this, she explained, was \"overreaching regulatory policies\", such as \"the  and low-carbon fuel fees\".\n\nHarkey has a 100% rating from the , and an \"A−\" grade from the anti-tax  for the six years she served in the California State Assembly.\n\n\n*Business Tax Committee – Chair\n*Franchise Tax Board – Member\n*Member of the State Assembly, she served as Vice Chair for the Assembly Committees on Revenue and Taxation and Appropriations.\n\n\n\nShe would like to strengthen border security, and believes that California should pay more attention to that issue. She supports President Trump's desire to build a wall on the southern border of the United States.\n\n\nHarkey supports taking care of the environment but has stated America is damaging its economy with unnecessary climate change laws. She believes America shouldn't be leading the global fight against climate change when other countries like India and China are releasing higher levels of greenhouse gases. She doesn't support the federal plan to increase offshore drilling in California by the Trump administration, and believes California should get an exemption like the one given to Florida.\n\n\nHarkey supports the Trump administration's , especially as it affects employers, but has criticized how it got rid of state and local tax deductions for many California residents.\n\nHarkey supports  and has found some of the Trump administration's trade pacts \"frightening\" but believes the issues will resolve themselves.\n\n\nHarkey said she's not a supporter of gun control laws \"because the bad guys will always have guns\". She has stated that school shootings are actually the result of drugs and mental health issues, as well as children spending too much time with games and cell phones during their formative years. She has stated children should not have access to cell phones in schools, and that schools should be doing more to identify and address children with mental health issues. She has stated support for locking down schools and  with guns if they're comfortable with it, but believes that isn't a country-wide solution.\n\n\nHarkey has stated that the  has caused healthcare costs to rise in California. She has stated that  is a failing program and does not support its expansion. She believes the federal government should be doing more to instill healthy habits in children and focus on improving healthcare technology to bring down healthcare costs. She has stated the  should be doing more to treat mental illness.\n\n\nHarkey has been endorsed by  and supports some of his policies, though has said he lacks \"charisma\" and his mannerisms are \"not attractive\", often making women uncomfortable. She wishes he would post on  less often.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn June 5, 2018, in the California \"jungle primary\", Harkey advanced to the November 2018 general election for , finishing with the most votes in a crowded primary field. She advanced to the general election alongside Democratic environmental activist  of nearby , assuring that this north San Diego County-based district would be represented by someone from the Orange County portion.\n\nIn May 2018, the '''' endorsed Harkey for the U.S. House. In July, the , America's largest tea party , endorsed Harkey. In late August, President  tweeted what the '''' described as \"a glowing endorsement\" of Harkey.\n\nHarkey was defeated in the November 2018 general election by Levin, who received 55% of the vote to Harkey's 45%.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter the , Diane’s husband, Dan Harkey and his company, were sued by investors for real-estate related losses.  Initially, the litigation filed in 2009 included Diane Harkey, who was dismissed with  in 2013 by the plaintiffs and the court of all erroneous charges during the course of a public Jury trial.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  (Board of Equalization)\n*  (Campaign)\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Adrin Nazarian''' (; born March 19, 1973) is an   of  descent who served in the  from 2012 to 2022. A member of the , he represented the  which encompasses the central-southern .\n\nHe is of  descent and Chair of the California Armenian Legislative Caucus and a member of the California Legislative Jewish Caucus.\n\n\nAdrin Nazarian was born in . As a child, he immigrated with his family to the  in . He grew up there and received his BA degree in Economics from  in 1996.\n\nAfter graduating UCLA, Nazarian participated in the . From 1997 to 1999, he served as an aide to Congressman  (D-CA), assisting him with business and labor community issues. In 1999, then-Governor  appointed Nazarian as Special Assistant to the California Trade and Commerce Agency. During his tenure at the agency, Nazarian helped establish the Division of Science, Technology and Innovation, which focused on creating and maintaining technology-based jobs in California.\n\nNazarian served as chief of staff to then-Assemblymember  from 2006 until Krekorian was elected to the  in 2010. Nazrian then served as Krekorian's chief of staff at City Hall until 2012.\n\nIn February 2022, Nazarian announced that he would not seek reelection in the , and also announced that he intends to run in 2024 to replace Los Angeles City Councilmember , who cannot seek another term due to term limits.\n\nNazarian has served on the boards of several community-based organizations including the East Valley  and the YWCA. He was one of the founding members of Generation Next Mentorship program which worked with local public schools to give young people alternatives to a life of gangs and drugs.\n\nNazarian and his wife, Diana, reside in  with their children Alex, David and Maggie.\n\n\n\n\nAssembly Bill 979, enacted as law in 2020, requires publicly held domestic or foreign corporations whose principal executive office is in California to have a certain minimum numbers of directors from “underrepresented communities” in order to increase diversity on their boards. The term \"underrepresented community\" is defined as \"an individual who self‑identifies as Black, , , , , , , , or , or who self‑identifies as , , , or .\" In 2022, Nazarian attempted, through Assembly Bill 1840, to add , , , , ,  and individuals with , to the list of underrepresented groups.\n\n\nIn response to the , Nazarian stated \"The United States and other world powers cannot continue to ignore . While western global leaders ask for “peace” Turkey has provided arms and even transported  to Azerbaijan to fight with Aliyev’s army. Armenia is a thriving democracy, growing stronger each year. We know who the aggressors are and it is time that the international community acknowledges their complicity in these attacks. It's time the Western powers stopped prioritizing a few cheap barrels of oil over human life and peace.\"\n\nIn response to news coverage of the war, Nazarian called upon journalists to present the facts truthfully and in their entirety, stating \"It’s your responsibility to make sure that people have a  and understand what is going on.\"\n\nIn response to the ongoing destruction of Armenian cultural and historical sites, Nazarian introduced a cultural heritage preservation bill (Assembly Bill 1815), which \"would prohibit a museum in California that receives public funding from displaying any country-funded item or artifact, or sending to a country or receiving from a country any item or artifact, if that country has received an adverse judgment by the  regarding its destruction of cultural heritage artifacts or sites.\"\n\n\nIn 2021, Nazarian introduced Assembly Bill 465, which requires that professional  receive LGBTQ+  during their education and licensing process.\n\nNazarian hosted an October 2022 fundraiser brunch for , where the organization and its members received awards and recognition from local elected officials, including Los Angeles County Supervisors  and  and Los Angeles City Councilmember .\n\n\n\n\n\nThe primary election was held on June 5, 2012, where Nazarian placed in first with 27.5% of the vote defeating a crowded field of 6 candidates; Andrew Lachman (D), Adriano Lecaros (D), Brian Johnson (D), Laurette Healey (D), and Jay Stern (R).\n\nOn November 6, 2012, Nazarian handily won over his opponent Jay Stern (R) with the support of 71% of the voting electorate.\n\n\n\n\nOn December 3, 2012, Adrin Nazarian was inaugurated into the California State Assembly, representing the , encompassing the central-southern  in . He is a member of the Assembly Committees on Budget, Education, Health, Rules, and Transportation. Assemblymember Nazarian also sits on the State Allocation Board.\n\n\n\nIn June 2021, Nazarian announced $11 million in state funding for three arts and educational institutions: $1 million to the , $1 million to the , and $9 million to establish a  location in the southeast .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*   ''California's 46th State Assembly district: Adrin Nazarian''\n* \n*  then-candidate Adrin Nazarian\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Luz Maria Rivas''' (born February 6, 1974) is an American politician from the state of . A member of the , she is the member-elect to the  for . Rivas has served in the  since 2018, representing .\n\n\nRivas is from Los Angeles. She earned a  in  from the , worked for , and then earned a  from the . She founded a non-profit organization based in , to encourage school age girls to pursue careers in . She also served on Los Angeles' City Public Works Commission.\n\n\nFollowing 's resignation from the California Assembly, Rivas declared her candidacy in the  to succeed him. Rivas won the special election on June 5, 2018, and was sworn into office on June 11.\n\nRivas has opposed legislative proposals that would reduce the stringent regulations on affordable housing construction along California's coast (which includes many of the state's most affluent and segregated areas). She has sought to limit the ability of religious institutions to build more housing. Rivas is a member of the .\n\n, the incumbent  for , announced that he would not run for reelection in the . Rivas announced her candidacy for the seat, with Cárdenas' endorsement. She won the election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100%\n}}\n\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100% \n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n|term_start1  = January 3, 1993\n|term_end1    = January 3, 2007\n|predecessor1 = \n|successor1   = \n|birth_name=Richard William Pombo\n|birth_date   = \n|birth_place  = , U.S.\n|death_date   = \n|death_place  = \n|party        = \n|spouse       = Annette Cole\n|alma_mater   = \n|module       = \n}}\n'''Richard William Pombo''',  (born January 8, 1961) is an American lobbyist for mining and water-management companies and former  member of the , having represented  from 1993 to 2007. Pombo lost a  bid to Democratic challenger  on November 7, 2006.\n\nOn January 4, 2010, Pombo announced his candidacy for Congress in  to succeed retiring fellow Republican , although he did not live in the district.Paul Rogers, , ''San Jose Mercury News'', May 31, 2010, retrieved June 1, 2010 Pombo came in third in that four-way GOP race, with 20.8 percent of the votes.\n\n\nPombo was born in , 18 miles south of . He attended , for three years before dropping out to work for his family's cattle and dairy business. He is a descendant of  immigrants. Pombo is married to the former Annette Cole and has three children. Even after being elected to Congress, he returned to his 500-acre (2&nbsp;km2) ranch near Tracy every week. Pombo is a .\n\nFrom 1990 to 1992, Pombo served on the  City Council.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1992, Pombo won the Republican primary by defeating several candidates in a race for an open seat in a district newly created by . California had added seven seats in the House after the 1990 . Pombo's strongest opponent in the Republican primary was  Republican Sandra Smoley, a  Supervisor.\n\nIn November, although the district had a Democratic majority and was carried by , Pombo nonetheless defeated Democrat Patti Garamendi (wife of current California Congressman ).\n\n\nPombo was reelected from this district in , , , and .\n\n\nFor his first five terms, Pombo represented a district covering almost all of  and a large slice of . However, Pombo's district was significantly altered as a result of the 2000 round of redistricting. He lost his share of Sacramento County to the 3rd district, and lost most of  to the 18th District. The district was pushed westward into the  when it picked up some of the more Republican-leaning portions of  and  counties, which had previously been part of the East Bay–based 10th district. Pombo was reelected in  and  after the redistricting.\n\n\nIn Congress, Pombo had a  track record. In 1994, during the , he was one of the signatories of the . He was a member of the conservative . He was given the nickname \"The Marlboro Man\" by President .\n\n\n\n\n}}\nPombo co-wrote a book in 1996 with  of  about private property issues, entitled ''This Land is Our Land: How to End the War on Private Property''. The San Joaquin County Citizen's Land Alliance, founded in July 1997, has been described as a group, co-founded by Pombo, that included farmers and other landowners advocating for private property rights and opposing government encroachment on these rights. As of March 2018 it was being led by Gary Barton as   Michael Petz as , with Nanette Martin serving as corporation secretary, and as of that date it was listed as terminated (its registration having expired).\n\nPombo's association with the defense of  was spurred by the 's abandonment of the  route through Tracy. Pombo owned land adjacent to the abandoned railroad line, and argued that the abandoned  should legally revert to the adjacent property owners (such as himself) rather than to the local park district. He further argued that as the easement was granted based on a promise that the land would be used for railroad purposes only, that the easements ended entirely when they were abandoned.\n\nPombo's case resulted in Congress passing the  Act. In a '''' editorial, Pombo was called \"an outspoken product of the extreme property rights movement.\" In 2005, he proposed legislation that would allow mining companies to buy lands on which they have staked claims, even if there is no evidence of valuable minerals on that land; according to the editorial, \"This has nothing to do with mining, and everything to do with stealing land that is owned by the American people.\"\n\n\nPombo supported the . In August 2006,  activists criticized him, citing an estimate that taxpayers in the 11th congressional district paid $974 million for the war by that time.\n\n\nIn a 2006 debate, Pombo said that \"intelligence agents should obtain   before monitoring phone calls\", but \"less than five months later, he voted to allow .\" He told the '''' that his vote was consistent with his statement, and that although the bill allows a delay in obtaining a warrant, it requires that Congressional Intelligence Committees and the  be notified, this maintaining  among the branches of government. An advocate for the  said the bill went further than Pombo acknowledged insofar as it allowed for the warrantless collection of large amounts of data as long as no specific individual was being targeted (and that the bill in fact defined \"electronic surveillance\" as excluding such activity). Pombo's opponent in 2006, , who went on to defeat Pombo, opposed the bill.\n\n\n\n\n\nFrom 2003 to 2007, a member of the , and was the Chairman of the , which has oversight and sets policy on matters involving ,  and . Pombo was also a co-chair of the  (HEAT), whose stated goal was to find alternative energy solutions.\n\n\nPombo was an early member of the , a Republican caucus that promotes the interest of Hispanic and Portuguese Americans. He was also a member and former Chairman of the Congressional , which is made up of Western State members of Congress concerned about  reform, , private property rights, and other issues affecting the western states. He was also, as of 2007, co-chair of the Portuguese Caucus, a coalition of Members of Congress who promote positive Portuguese-American relations, and a group he is said to have founded. In that role, he hosted prominent visitors from  to the United States, and the Portuguese government bestowed Pombo with the Grand Order of Infante D. Henrique, Portugal's highest civilian honor, in recognition of his efforts to improve Portuguese-American relations.\n\n\n as he signs the Partners for Fish and Wildlife Act into law]]\nPombo proposed legislation to sell roughly a quarter of the land managed by the . In November 2005, Pombo and  (R-) co-authored an amendment to the Federal Budget Reconciliation Bill easing restrictions of sale of federal lands to mining companies. This amendment was opposed by , anti-growth advocates, and even some Republican Senators concerned about the measure's effects on hunting and fishing. The amendment narrowly passed the House, but was defeated in the Senate. The legislation was later described by his chief of staff as a \"bureaucratic exercise\" designed to evaluate the costs of not drilling in the  (ANWR).\n\nPombo supported oil drilling in the ANWR, despite concerns about the  and opposition from moderate Republicans.\n\nIn September 2005, Pombo helped write a revision of the 1973 . The proposed revision \"was widely denounced by environmentalists as a disturbing retreat from habitat protection and a paperwork nightmare for agencies seeking to revive the 1,268 threatened and endangered plants and animals in the country, 186 of which are in California.\" The bill did not pass.\n\nBy March 2006, ''Environmental Science & Technology'' reported that Pombo was coordinating efforts with Pac/West Communications to weaken the Endangered Species Act (ESA). Pac/West created the , an anti-environmental front group that campaigned for Pombo's bill to change the ESA.\n\nThe , a nonpartisan , assigned Pombo a lifetime average rating of 7 on a scale of 0 to 100. In 2005, he scored a 6. Subsequently, the organization named Pombo as one of the \"Dirty Dozen\" in 2006. LCV released an ad on October 31, 2006, citing Pombo's acceptance of $120,000 from oil companies and his ties to indicted lobbyist .\n\n'''' ranked him one of the worst congressmen and called him \"Enemy of the Earth\". The  called him an \"eco-thug\".\n\nAs the chairman of the , Pombo blocked legislation that would have created the  area in  state, despite broad support for the bill.\n\nHis political revival was characterized as giving environmentalists \"fits\" by the '''' in addition to describing his perception by that community as similar to that of Exxon-Valdez  or the hunter that shot 's mother.\n\nThe  added him to their Dirty Dozen list in 2010, even though this list is typically reserved for sitting members of Congress; and Warner Chabor, the organization's CEO, stated, \"Having Pombo represent a district that includes  is like electing  as mayor of \".\n\n\nIn 2006, , a nonpartisan watchgroup founded in 2005 by  and Democratic Party activists released a report naming Pombo as one of the 13 most corrupt members of Congress. Pombo issued a statement where he denied the allegations and described the group as \"a liberal-activist organization masquerading as a government watchdog group.\"\n\n\n\n\nPombo and his  ''RICH PAC'' was among a dozen leaders in the House of Representatives reportedly under investigation as part of the corruption and influence-peddling scandal centered around disgraced Washington lobbyist , and his policy issues, including . Pombo had accepted more money from Abramoff than had any other member of Congress ($500,000). Fundraisers organized by Indian gaming interests and tied to the 2005 MLB All-Star Game are among those activities under scrutiny.Erica Werner, , ''San Diego Union Tribune'', Associated Press, July 13, 2005\n\nOn January 8, 2006, the '''' alleged that Pombo helped one of Abramoff's clients, the  Indians in , gain federal recognition as a tribe. In return, Pombo received campaign contributions from both the tribe and Abramoff.Richard A. Serrano and Stephen Braun, , ''Los Angeles Times'', January 8, 2006\n\nIn the 2006 cycle, Abramoff was one of the top donors to Pombo's political action committee. Several of Pombo's top five donors are political influence brokers from , who hosted several $5,000-per-person fundraisers for Pombo in their  at  during the 2005 MLB All-Star Game. News reports indicated contributions from the two-day fundraising event would go to RICH Political Action Committee. However,  reports filed by RICH PAC show only one such contribution. Apparently contributions were diverted to some other entity making it difficult to track who attended and contributed.\n\nThe , owners of the MLB  and Detroit's , are also financial backers of various Indian tribes, including the , which is seeking to build a gaming casino on its reservation near . Various issues and tribal disputes involving the Shinnecock were before the House Resources Committee chaired by Pombo just days after the fundraiser.\n\nOn October 11, 2006, it was reported that Pombo \"says he never worked with disgraced lobbyist Jack Abramoff in his fourteen years in Congress, but billing records suggest at least two interactions between the two in 1996\".\n\n\nVarious members of the Pombo family individually own more than  undeveloped near two proposed freeways. If even one of the proposed freeways is eventually built, the value of the property owned by Pombo's relatives and located near the proposed freeway will be worth far more than its currently assessed value.\n\nPombo led an effort to build a multilane  () through the mostly uninhabited  to facilitate -bound commuting from the greater Tracy area.\n\n\nPombo's home town of Tracy is close to a large  on . In 2004, Pombo's office sent a letter to then-Secretary of the Department of the Interior , urging the suspension of environmental guidelines opposed by the wind power industry. Pombo's parents have received hundreds of thousands of dollars in royalties from wind-powered turbines on their  ranch. Pombo owns an interest in his parents' ranch.\n\n\nBetween 2000 and 2004, Pombo used his campaign and PAC funds to pay his brother Randall $272,000, and his wife (between 2003 and 2004) $85,000. In that 2003–04 campaign cycle, Pombo paid more to his family members$217,000than his opponent, , spent on his entire campaign. The two were paid for duties listed as bookkeeping, fundraising, consulting and other unspecified services.\n\nAfter publicity about the payments to his family, Randall was taken off Pombo's payroll (total payments between January 2005 and mid-2006 were less than $7,000). Pombo's wife continued to be paid at the rate of $3,000 per month.\n\n\nIn October 2004, Pombo used the franking privileges afforded members of Congress to mail approximately 175,000 copies of a two-page leaflet that openly praised the House Resources Committee and the  for overturning  limits on snowmobiling in national parks. The leaflets were sent to snowmobile owners in the s of  and . Pombo authorized the expenditure of $68,081 from House Resources Committee funds for the mailing of the leaflets as \"official business.\" House members are required to seek prior approval and obtain advisory opinions before sending out franked mail; no such approval was obtained prior to the October mailing.\n\n\nIn August 2003, Pombo and his family rented an RV and \"spent two weeks on vacation, stopping along the way to enjoy ... our national parks\". The  trip included stops in the , , , ,  and , , and other parks. The $4,935 cost of the rental was charged to the federal government, but was determined to be a more cost effective alternative to flying, renting a car, and staying in a hotel.\n\nWhen asked in February 2006 about the triprules forbid government-funded travel for personal vacations, but allow lawmakers to bring family members on official tripsPombo said that he had looked into flying into the parks by commercial air or charters, but found the costs to be excessive. After choosing to travel instead by RV, he invited his family along with him.\n\nAt , Pombo had a lengthy meeting with the park superintendent, which a spokesman charactizered as official. Pombo's visit to the  is in dispute: the secretary to the superintendent said he did not show; a spokesman for Pombo said that Pombo was certain he was there and met with a group of Native American tribal leaders nearby. Reports concerning Pombo's visit to  are also contradictory. The '''' was told that Pombo had shown up for his meeting but \"they were not there\". The '''' was told that Pombo met with the park's acting superintendent.\n\nOfficials from  and  national parks did not return calls seeking comment.Richard A. Serrano, , ''Los Angeles Times'', February 15, 2006\n\n\nOne January 8, 2006, the '''' reported that Pombo and Representative  had joined with then-House Majority Leader  of  to oppose an investigation by federal banking regulators into the affairs of  millionaire . The ''Times'' reported that \"When the  persisted, Doolittle and Pomboboth considered protegés of DeLayused their power as members of the House Resources Committee to  the agency's confidential records on the case, including details of the evidence FDIC investigators had compiled on Hurwitz.\" The investigation was ultimately dropped.\n\nAccording to the ''Times'', \"Although Washington politicians frequently try to help important constituents and contributors, it is unusual for members of Congress to take direct steps to stymie an ongoing investigation by an agency such as the FDIC.\" The article concluded, \"in the Hurwitz case, Doolittle and Pombo were in a position to pressure the FDIC and did so.\"\n\n\nOn September 23, 2006, the Central Valley ''Record'' reported that East Bay Representative  and six other House Democrats had requested that Pombo hold \"immediate\" congressional hearings concerning oil lease payments to the . The article noted that \"Miller and his alliesincluding Pombo's challenger,  consultant want oil companies such as  to renegotiate contracts they inked with Clinton administration officials that failed to include language requiring the firms to pay taxes when oil prices pass $36 a barrel.\" Pombo \"had a provision written into the House's offshore drilling legislation, which passed earlier this year, that would instead levy a fee on those firms that refuse to renegotiate their contracts.\"\n\n\nAn n oil services company under federal investigation in connection with allegations of influence peddling has contributed nearly $18,000 to Pombo. The investigation sparked a Washington state candidate for the Senate to return his contributions from -based  the day after the  raided offices of several Alaskan state legislators.\n\n\n\n\nAmid these growing scandals, Pombo faced serious primary opposition for the first time since his initial race in 1992. His leading opponent was former congressman , a leading moderate Republican. Earlier, McCloskey had led an effort to find a viable primary challenger to Pombo. Pombo defeated McCloskey in the primary with 61 percent of the vote. McCloskey had been endorsed by '''', the '''', and the . Seven weeks later, McCloskey endorsed Pombo's Democratic opponent, , who had won the Democratic primary over  and Steve Thomas. McNerney received just over half of the Democratic vote and faced Pombo in the 2006 general election in November. McNerney had been Pombo's opponent in 2004.\n\nOn October 3, 2006, a Democratic-commissioned poll was released with McNerney leading Pombo 48 percent to 46 percent. There were two polls commissioned by the NRCC, but results weren't released. Based on these events, in early October, '''' changed their rating of this race from ''Republican Favored'' to ''Leans Republican''. This was a significant development; Pombo had soundly defeated McNerney in 2004, taking 61 percent of the vote.\n\nOn November 7, 2006, Pombo was defeated by McNerney. McNerney got 53.1 percent of the vote to Pombo's 46.9 percent. Apart from prevailing national Democratic trends and the corruption allegations dogging him, Pombo was also the number one national target of environmental groups. Washington, D.C.-based  spent more than $1 million on the race and commissioned the first poll in 2005 that showed Pombo to be vulnerable in his re-election bid. The  sent over 300 volunteers and organizers to work for McNerney in the final weeks of the campaign. The group, allied with the League of Conservation Voters, also aired issue ads attacking Pombo. Pombo and  were the two Representatives targeted by the , which spent over $100,000 in Pombo's district, including organizers. Since Pombo left office, no other Republican has represented a significant part of the Bay Area in Congress.\n\nIn a letter dated November 29, 2006 from , Pombo states, \"I have accepted a position as Senior Partner at Pac/West, a full service political public relations firm with offices from California to Washington, D.C.\"\n\n\nOn January 4, 2010, Pombo announced his candidacy for Congress in  after Congressman , a fellow Republican, announced he wouldn't run for reelection. The 19th neighbors Pombo's former 11th district and leans more Republican than the 11th. Pombo said he \"didn't think [he] would ever run again, but when George Radanovich announced he wasn't running, my phone rang off the hook\". Pombo faced Radanovich-backed state Senator  and former  mayor  in the primary, which Jeff Denham won.\n\nPombo followed up his candidacy for Congress announcement by signing the Taxpayer Protection Pledge sponsored by  on January 5, 2010. This marks the second time that Pombo signed the Pledge. He previously signed it as Representative of . According to ATR, Pombo has a lifetime rating of 91% from their annual Congressional Scorecards.\n\nPrimary opponent Jeff Denham stated that Pombo was a liability to the Republican Party who has \"given them a lot of material over the years\", a reference to his various scandals and notoriety among environmentalists.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* Grand Officer of the ,  (8 June 1996)\n\n\n tags-->\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  ''official 2010 campaign site''\n\n\n*  ''San Diego Union Tribune''\n* , \n* \n* \n\n\n* \n*  by ''Indianz.com''\n\n\n*  m ''''\n* , ''''\n* , profile of Pombo by ''''\n* .     "pages": }\n\n'''Joel Wachs''' (, ; born March 1, 1939) is an American former politician and lawyer. He is the president of the  in New York City. He was a member of the  for 30 years, where he was known for his promotion of the arts, support of gay causes, advocacy of rent control and other economic measures.\n\nThe unmarried Wachs was a  man until he was preparing to run for mayor in 1999 at the age of 60. He was asked by , the  moderator of a public affairs television show, \"Are you a gay man?\" Wachs responded: \"I am and I'm very proud of what I've done for the community, and I'm also very proud of the fact that what I've done for the community is what I've done for all communities.\"\n\n\nWachs was born on March 1, 1939, in , the son of Hannah (Stahler) and Archie Wachs, a teacher. His father was a Jewish immigrant from Poland who ran a grocery and butcher shop. The younger of two sons, Joel \"suffered from  so severe that at the height of the  season, his parents sat him in the shop's  room, in a fur coat, to help him breathe\". They moved to Los Angeles when Wachs was ten, where his family became wealthy with a chain of inexpensive ladies' clothing stores. He grew up in , between 79th and 83rd streets and  and . |last1=Clayton |first1=Janet |title=Council's New President Might Have Been Song and Dance Man |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=4 July 1981 |page=b1 }}\n\nHe attended Horace Mann Junior High School and , followed by the , where the \"gregarious\" Wachs was president of his  and  classes, and of the . He earned a degree at  and a Master of Laws in taxation from . When in Los Angeles, he lived in .\n\n\nAfter completing his education, Wachs was an attorney with the Los Angeles firm of Gray, Binkley & Pfaelzer (later became Kadison, Pfaelzer, Woodard & Quinn) and practiced law for five years. He told a reporter in 1991, \"I didn't love practicing tax law&nbsp;... the result of my efforts was finding ways to save rich people money. And I didn't find that satisfying.\"\n\n\n\nWachs served on the  from July 1, 1971, to September 28, 2001, when his resignation took effect. His 30 years on the council were surpassed only by 's 35 years, 's 32 years and 's 31.\n\n\n\nIn May 1971, Wachs, \"a young political newcomer,\" \"overwhelmed\" veteran  in , which included portions of the  and the . The vote was 24,704 for Wachs and 14,898 for Potter. His victory was attributed in part to his opposing a multimillion-dollar development in the mountains just north of .\n\nAt 33, he became the City Council's youngest member. |last1=Bryant |first1=Pat |title=Wachs 'Working Hard, Enjoying It': Wachs Says His Work Hard but Enjoyable |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=17 October 1971 |page=sf_c1 }}\n\nIn 1986, a redistricting move stripped Wachs of more than 90% of his old district, and put him into a new one that ran from his home in Studio City to  in the far northeast San Fernando Valley. He was nevertheless easily reelected in April 1987 in the realigned, more conservative district, despite the opposition of the Los Angeles Apartment Owners Association, which attacked him because of his fight for . Wachs was reelected in every vote thereafter.\n\n\nAfter ten years on the City Council, two of them as president pro-tem, Wachs was suddenly and unexpectedly elected  in July 1981 when outgoing President  decided to drop out of the contest against Councilwoman  and, with Councilwoman  as a partner, put up Wachs as a candidate instead. Wachs was elected to a two-year term in an 8–7 vote, with Wachs breaking a pledge to Russell to vote for her and casting a vote for himself instead. He later described the turn of events as akin to a \"Hollywood movie\" and, inasmuch as Mayor  was soon to become a candidate for governor, he had plenty of opportunity to act as mayor when Bradley was out of town. |title=WACHS: Right Place, Right Time |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=31 January 1982 |page=b1 }} He served for two years.\n\n\nWachs resigned from the City Council 2001 to accept the presidency of the  Foundation for the Visual Arts. His last day on the City Council was September 28 of that year.\n\n\n\nWachs thrice ran for mayor of Los Angeles. In 1973, as a relatively unknown new city council member, he finished a distant fifth in a crowded primary in an election in which  eventually won his first term as Los Angeles mayor.\n\nIn 1993, he finished third behind  and .\n\nHe ran again in  and finished fourth with 11% of the vote, behind ,  and .\n\n\nIn 1977, Wachs was appointed vice chairman of a new National Task Force on the Arts, whose goal, he said, was \"to put the arts and culture on the agenda of every city government as a mainstream economic and social concern\". In a 1981 interview, he said he spent one-third of his $43,923 annual salary (equivalent to between $ and $ in ) on works of art for himself and that, when the time came to leave the City Council, he could be happy practicing law, \"being a  in a nice restaurant,\" or \"heading an arts foundation\". In 1987 he flew to  to be a part of a seven-member panel that tried to determine what to do with a 12-foot-high, 112-foot-long outdoor steel sculpture by  titled \",\" which had drawn complaints and was eventually disassembled, removed, and put in storage.\n\nHe was the author of an ordinance that requires  to set aside 1% of the value of all projects over $500,000 for cultural and artistic projectseither spending the money on their own, or depositing it with the city for such use.\n\nWachs was active in strengthening Los Angeles' ordinance on  but was equally active when the city's Building and Safety Commission at first attempted to classify a proposed work by  as a sign that fell under its jurisdiction. It later reversed itself and Wachs specifically compared the commission's initial decision to the prosecution of a Cincinnati museum over a show by photographer .\n\n\n\nIn 2001, Wachs resigned his council seat and moved to  in order to serve as president of the  Foundation for the Visual Arts. Wachs is nominally the chairman of the . Wachs's salary at the charity is over $350,000 per year, which does not include generous expenses and a pension plan of approximately 20%. Although this is nearly four times the average salary for such a position, some have argued that the Warhol Foundation is unusually complex as well as being more influential than most similar organizations.\n\nIn 2010, Wachsin his Warhol Foundation roleprotested the removal of a  piece from the \"Hide/Seek\" exhibit at the . The foundation had supported the exhibition with a $100,000 grant. Wachs wrote to the head of the  (NPG's parent organization), , on behalf of the foundation's unanimous board with the \"demand that the Smithsonian restore the work ... to the exhibition or the foundation would reject any future grant requests\". Wachs' letter said in part, \"For the arts to flourish, the arts must be free, and the decision to censor this important work is in stark opposition to our mission to defend freedom of expression wherever and whenever it is under attack.\" There were no signs of reinstatement of the Wojnarowicz piece by the NPG.\n\n\n\"Wachs defied easy categorization on the council, emerging as a populist who railed against what he saw as insider dealing in City Hall and misuse of taxpayer funds. He also was a staunch advocate for the arts and for civil rights.\" He was known as a \"moderate to liberal Republican\" but reregistered as an independent before running for mayor in 1993. He backed efforts that resulted in public financing of city elections and creation of an ethics commission.\n\n\nWachs is sometimes cited as the originator of  in Los Angeles. He organized the first onesin , , - and the hill area south of  in November 1971, choosing the first members himself from a range of backgrounds. He launched numerous studies of such councils in other cities and produced a booklet to help guide the new representative community groups in Los Angeles.\n\n\nIn 1971, he proposed a ban on oil drilling on the city's coastline one-half mile inland from the shore \"for both esthetic and geographical safety reasons\".\n\n\nHe was a supporter of levying a city income tax in order to relieve property owners of a tax burden.\n\n\nHe was a decided advocate for  in an effort to keep housing affordable for the elderly and the poor.\n\n\nWachs and Councilwoman  sponsored what Wachs called \"the strongest  ordinance in the U.S.,\" prohibiting job and housing discrimination based on sexual orientation. His measure outlawing employment discrimination against  was passed unanimously by the City Council, despite the fact that his mail on the subject was running heavily against it.\n\n\nIn 1981, Wachs called for mandatory separation of  from regular trash before collection to cope with the city's \"growing refuse-disposal crisis\".\n\n\nWachs successfully advocated for an ordinance change that would allow artists to live and work in commercially zoned districts. He also worked to create a city Cultural Affairs Department. |last1=Simon |first1=Richard |title=Wachs Heavy Favorite in 6-Way City Council Race: 2nd District Challengers Have Scant Funds, Hope |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=7 April 1983 |page=v1 }}\n\n\nWachs cast the only vote against a city ordinance prohibiting minors from purchasing , saying in 1983 he did not think police officers should spend their time raiding .\n\n\nHe proposed an eventually successful idea for the city to provide a number of , where Los Angeles' nearly 200,000 licensed dogs could run free.\n\n\nWachs emerged as the sole City Council member who helped broker an agreement that enabled Police Chief  to resign his post in June 1992 and retire \"in an orderly fashion\" after a crisis occasioned by the March 1991 beating of  and as well as the issuance of a final, critical report of the police department by the . Wachs and Gates forged a bond of trust, it was said, when the councilman leaped to the chief's defense after the city Police Commission briefly removed Gates in the wake of the riots.\n\n\nWachs went to Sacramento in January 1984 to unsuccessfully argue with state prison authorities that , the  who had killed gay leader  and Mayor , should be moved out of , where he had been d after serving five years in prison for the killings.\n\n\nWachs was credited with forging a 1997 deal with the developers of a  that lifted some of the onerous provisions that would have worked to the financial disadvantage of the city. In return for the concessions, he agreed to exempt the arena from a ballot measure he was preparing to require voter approval for any subsidized sports stadiums.\n\n\nWachs was an advocate for slow-growth development and was one of the cowriters of , along with  and .\n\n\n\n\nWachs was known for his boisterous personality. When he was newly elected to the , he distributed a mock ordinance that would supposedly have taxed all male residents on the size of their genitals. Occasionally he exclaimed \"This is fun!\" in the middle of a committee meeting. His colleagues described him as \"a human guy, a lot of heart\".\n\nIn recognition of Wachs' involvement in promoting the arts, the City Council in 2002 named the intersection of Grand Avenue and Second Street as \"Joel Wachs Square\". It lies between the  and the .\n\n\nWachs is portrayed by  in the film '''' set in 1970s . In the film, Wachs's first mayoral campaign is a plot point.\n\n\n\nAccess to some of the ''Los Angeles Times'' links may require the use of a library card.\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''David E. Cox''' (February 20, 1938 – July 13, 2010) was an American  from . A , he served as a , representing the  from December 2004 until his death in July 2010, and also served as a man for the six years immediately before his Senate tenure, including three years as Assembly Republican .\n\n\nCox was first elected to the  Board of Supervisors in 1992 and served until 1998. Cox also served on the  board as well as the  board. In 1994 Cox made an unsuccessful run for the then-6th Senate district in 1994 against veteran State Senator . \n\nCox was then elected to the , representing the  from December 1998 to December 2004, and served as the Assembly  Leader from March 2000 through January 2004. \n\nIn 2004, Cox successfully ran again for the , this time in the . His district included all or portions of , , , , , , , , , ,  and  Counties. He served on the following Senate committees:\n\n*Local Government (Chair)\n*Appropriations (Vice Chair)\n*Banking, Finance and Insurance\n*Energy, Utilities and Communications\n*Health\n\nCox was named as the \"Outstanding Senator for 2007\" by the California State Sheriffs' Association.\n\nCox earned his bachelor's degree in business administration from the  in 1961 and a master's degree from  in 1983. He was married with three children, and lived in .\n\nCox was re-elected to his second and last Senate term in 2008 with over 60% of the vote.\n\nCox died in office on July 13, 2010, following a thirteen-year-long battle with .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n* profile\n*''Follow the Money'' - Dave Cox\n**     campaign contributions\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n#\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Dawn Junea Addis''' (born July 12, 1972) is an American educator, activist, and politician serving as a member of the  for the  district. Elected in November 2022, she assumed office on December 5, 2022.\n\n\nAddis earned a  degree in  and  and a  in  from .\n\n\nAddis worked as an educator in the  20 years. In 2016, she founded the  chapter of the . She served as a member of the  City Council from 2019 to 2022 and as mayor pro tempore from 2019 to 2021.\n\nIn 2018, Addis ran for the  against incumbent Republican  in a district including all of .  Although Addis was well-funded, Cunningham won by 55% to 45%.\n\nIn 2022, redistricting moved the district north and split San Luis Obispo County, leading Cunningham to retire.  Addis was elected to the  in November 2022. She is a member of the Rules Committee.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100% \n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
