    "pages": }\n\n'''Kenneth Mejia''' (born November 7, 1990) is an American activist, , and politician, serving as the  since 2022. A member of the  and a former  member, Mejia was a three-time candidate for the  in , prior to his candidacy and  as City Controller in 2022.\n\nElected to succeed , Mejia is the first Filipino American elected official in the city of , the first Asian American elected to a citywide office, the youngest, and the first person of color to hold the position of City Controller in over a century.\n\n\nMejia is  and was born and grew up in Los Angeles. Mejia graduated from  in two and a half years, finishing in 2010 with a  in .\n\nMejia has held his  (CPA) designation since around 2013, although the status of his CPA license was \"expired\" or \"inactive\" from November 2018 until January 2022.  He worked at  but left in 2014.  He then worked for a hedge fund according to his Twitter account, which he left May 6, 2016, to focus on his campaign. In 2016, he co-founded We Can Make a Difference, a community volunteer organization that provided food and hygiene items to low-income and homeless people in Los Angeles. He then worked at  but left in late 2021 to focus on campaigning. Mejia is a member of the LA Tenants' Union.\n\n\n\n\n\nMejia was inspired by the  to engage more in politics, leading him to become a candidate to the California delegation to the Democratic National Convention. Mejia was a write-in  candidate in .\n\nHaving grown disenchanted with the Democratic Party, Mejia ran as a  candidate in the same district in 2017 and 2018. His 2017 bid was noted for its reliance on small-dollar donations. Mejia's 2018 bid advanced to the general election and yielded more than 40,000 votes, setting the record for the highest vote percentage cast for any Green candidate against a Democrat for Congress. Mejia continued to work as an accountant while campaigning in 2018.\n\n\n\n\nMejia announced his candidacy for City Controller, a nonpartisan office, in the . It has been historically uncommon for the city controller to have extensive accounting experience; Mejia claims the office has never been held by a CPA. He was the only city candidate in 2022 to receive ballot access through signatures alone. During his candidacy, Mejia drew attention to  employees receiving more than half a million dollars a year, the use of about half of the city's funds from the  on the , and the amount of police funding in the budget proposed in 2022 by .\n\nOn June 7, 2022, Mejia took first place in the primary for LA City Controller, with over 230,163 votes. He obtained 42.75% of the vote, while opponents Paul Koretz and Stephanie Clements obtained 23.83% and 16.01%. On November 8, 2022, Mejia won the general election in a landslide with 62% of the vote, defeating Koretz.\n\n\nMejia appointed  to serve as his Chief Deputy Controller and Sergio Perez to serve as Chief of Accountability and Oversight. Cole is an Urban Studies Professor and was the former mayor of  and deputy mayor for Los Angeles. Sergio Perez left his position as the 's Inspector General to serve.\n\n\n\n\n\n election, 2016\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n election, 2018\n}}\n|- class=\"vcard\"\n| style=\"background-color: #3333FF; width: 2px;\" |\n| class=\"org\" style=\"width: 130px\" | \n| class=\"fn\"    |  ()\n| style=\"text-align:right;\" | 54,661\n| style=\"text-align:right;\" | 78.7\n|-\n|- class=\"vcard\"\n| style=\"background-color: #17aa5c; width: 2px;\" |\n| class=\"org\" style=\"width: 130px\" | \n| class=\"fn\"    | Kenneth Mejia\n| style=\"text-align:right;\" | 8,987\n| style=\"text-align:right;\" | 12.9\n|-\n|- class=\"vcard\"\n| style=\"background-color: #FED105; width: 2px;\" |\n| class=\"org\" style=\"width: 130px\" | \n| class=\"fn\"    | \n| style=\"text-align:right;\" | 5,804\n| style=\"text-align:right;\" | 8.4\n|-\n\n\n|- class=\"vcard\"\n| style=\"background-color: #3333FF; width: 5px;\" |\n| class=\"org\" style=\"width: 130px\" | ''' '''\n| class=\"fn\" | ''' () '''\n| style=\"text-align: right; margin-right: 0.5em\" | ''' '''\n| style=\"text-align: right; margin-right: 0.5em\" | '''72.5 '''\n|-\n|- class=\"vcard\"\n| style=\"background-color: #17aa5c; width: 2px;\" |\n| class=\"org\" style=\"width: 130px\" | \n| class=\"fn\"    | Kenneth Mejia\n| style=\"text-align:right;\" | 41,711\n| style=\"text-align:right;\" | 27.5\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

She is a  representing the , which encompasses the Northern  and Southern  region.\n\n\nBlakespear was born on February 29, 1976, in .     "pages": }\n\n'''Sharon Yvonne Runner''' (née '''Oden'''; May 17, 1954 – July 14, 2016) was an American politician. She was a  , who represented the  at the time of her death, and previously represented the  from 2011 to 2012. She was also a member of the  from 2002 to 2008, representing the .   She was the wife of  . From 2004 to 2008, then-Senator George Runner and then-Assemblywoman Sharon Runner were the first husband and wife in California history to serve concurrently in the .\n\n\nBorn Sharon Yvonne Oden in Los Angeles, California and raised in the , Runner graduated from  and attended .\n\n\nRunner was an officer for the Antelope Valley Republican Assembly and remained active in many Republican groups in the Antelope Valley, including the Palmdale and High Desert Republican Women's Clubs, until her death. She served on the board of California Women Lead, a bi-partisan organization that encourages and empowers women running for public office. She served as President of the board of California's Women's Leadership Association for 2011–12.\n\nDuring the 2004 Presidential election, Runner served as the California Women's Coalition Chair for the Bush/Cheney Campaign. She was chosen as a delegate to the 2000 and 2004 Republican National Conventions. She worked on several statewide campaigns including Governor , , Governor , and  for Governor 2010.\n\nIn 2009, Runner was appointed by Governor  to the California Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board. She served on the board until December 22, 2010. In 2013 Runner began working part-time for the California State Senate Republican Caucus conducting community outreach events. She also ran \"The Runner Group,\" a public relations/marketing company she founded in 1994.\n\n\nIn 2002, Runner was elected to represent the 36th Assembly District and served in the State Assembly for three terms, from 2002 to 2008.\n\nWhile in the Assembly she served on the Veteran's Committee; Housing Committee; Select Committees dealing with Foster Care; the Committee on Drug and Alcohol Abuse; as well as the Task Force on the Environment, Energy, and the Economy.  \nShe also held key fiscal leadership positions, serving as the Vice-Chair of the Appropriations Committee and as a member of the Budget Committee and Budget Subcommittee on Education.\n\nDuring her first term in office, Runner was appointed as Assistant Republican Leader by former Assembly Republican Leader .\n\n\nIn 2006, along with her husband, Senator , Sharon Runner authored , California's version of . The measure passed with the support of 71% of California voters, and passed in 57 of California's 58 counties.\n\nJessica's Law ensures that all sexual offenders who are convicted of activity with children under the age of 14 are put into prison with a mandatory minimum sentence of 15 years or 25 years to life. It eliminates all \"first-offense\" sexual offense provisions from California law.\n\nIt also eliminates all \"good-time\" credits for sexual offenders serving prison terms; under the authored provisions they are required to serve their entire sentence and will not be released for good behavior. The law requires that sex offenders who are released from prison wear a GPS bracelet for life.\n\nIt also creates a 2,000-foot (615-meter) zone around schools and parks in which registered sex offenders are prohibited from residing.\n\n\nRunner ran for election to the California State Senate, representing the 17th District.  The seat was left vacant by her husband, , who was elected to the  in November 2010. The primary election took place on February 15, 2011, she defeated Democrat Darren Parker 66%–34% to avoid a runoff.\n\nTo focus on her recovery from a double lung transplant necessitated by her limited scleroderma, she chose to not seek re-election in 2012 and was succeeded by  in the renumbered 21st Senate District.\n\nA special election for the 21st Senate District, vacated by  who was elected to Congress in November 2014, was held on March 17, 2015. After a successful recruitment effort, Runner decided to enter the race. She was the only candidate on the ballot, and easily won reelection to the Senate with 100% of the vote. Runner was sworn into the State Senate on March 19, 2015, where she would serve until her death the following year.\n\n\nIn 1977, Runner co-founded  with her husband, . It has since grown to become one of the largest private schools in California with nearly 1,700 students on three separate campuses. She served on the Board until her death. Prior to Desert Christian Schools, Runner worked as a licensed realtor with Red Carpet Real Estate Company where she was named \"Realtor of the Year.\"\n\nShe volunteered her time on several boards and committees including the United Way, Antelope Valley Hospital Gift Foundation, Antelope Valley Crime Task Force, Healthy Homes Advisory Council, and , a pregnancy resource center. She also spent five years on the board of directors for the Lancaster Chamber of Commerce. In 1998,   appointed Runner to serve on the Antelope Valley Fair board of directors, where she oversaw the operations of the 50th Agriculture District and managed its multimillion-dollar budget. She held this position until 2002.\n\nShe was involved with her church, Grace Chapel Church in , for over 30 years.\n\n\nIn 2013, Runner was awarded the Marian Bergeson Lifetime Achievement Award for her work helping women run for office.\n\nIn November 2014 Runner received the Spirit of Leadership Award by the Scleroderma Foundation of Southern California for her advocacy in increasing funding to find a cure for Scleroderma.\n\n\nShe married  in 1973. They had a son, Micah, daughter-in-law, Sandy, daughter, Rebekah (who serves in the ), son-in-law, James, and four grandchildren. Through her marriage, Runner was an aunt to  player .\n\n\nRunner was diagnosed with the limited systemic form of , an  affecting her lungs, in 1984 at the age of 30. On February 24, 2012, Runner underwent a successful double- at the . She was released from the hospital ten days later. To focus on her recovery, Runner decided not to seek re-election in the 2012 race for the California Senate.\n\nRunner was a member of the Scleroderma Foundation's Legislative Committee, where she worked to obtain  for scleroderma research. She also sat on the Advisory Committee for Sierra Donor Services, a donor procurement organization in .\n\nRunner worked and connected regularly with lung transplant patients. In 2014, she was selected as a rider on the 11th annual Donate Life  Float along with 29 other donor recipients.\n\nRunner died at her home on July 14, 2016, due to \"respiratory complications.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''George Wilmarth''' \"'''Wiley'''\" '''Nickel III''' (born November 23, 1975) is an American attorney and Democratic politician serving as the  for  since 2023.\n\nNickel served as a member of the  from the 16th district from 2019 to 2023. He was elected to the  in 2022. On December 16, 2023, Nickel made the decision to not seek re-election after his seat was redrawn to heavily favor the Republican party.\n\n\nNickel was born in the . After graduating from  in , he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science and government from  and a  from .\n\n\n\nNickel worked for Vice President  from 1996 to 2001 as a member of his national advance staff. He is also a member of Gore's  Leadership Corps.\n\nNickel later worked on  and served on the White House national advance staff from 2008 until 2012. He is a member of the Obama Alumni Association and was part of Obama's first wave of political endorsements in 2018. Obama endorsed six candidates in North Carolina, including Nickel, in August 2018.\n\n\n\nNickel ran in  in 2006 against incumbent Republican . He was called \"a moderate Democrat\" and the race was seen as potentially competitive. During the primary election, he spent $250,000 on advertisements, mainly funded by personal loans. The ads, which mainly ran in the  media market, did not mention what district he was running in or his party affiliation. He lost the general election to Denham, receiving 40.2% of the vote to Denham's 59.8%.\n\n\nNickel was a criminal defense attorney, having opened his law practice in Cary in 2011.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNickel was first elected to represent the 16th senate district with over 65% of the vote on November 6, 2018. NCSBE|url=https://www.ncsbe.gov/results-data/election-results/historical-election-results-data|access-date=November 21, 2021|website=www.ncsbe.gov}} His seat was one of six seats Democrats picked up to break the Republican supermajority in the .\n\n\nNickel ran for reelection in 2020. He spoke about SB 209 during a candlelight vigil at the Islamic Center of Cary to remember the  victims.\n\n\nNickel served on the Redistricting and Elections Committee, the Judiciary Committee, the Pensions/Retirement/Aging Committee, and the Appropriations on General Government/Information Technology Committee in the state senate.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nNickel ran for Congress in North Carolina's newly drawn . The district covers southern Wake County, all of Johnston County, and parts of Wayne and Harnett Counties. Nickel won the Democratic nomination.\n\nThe ''Carolina Journal'' wrote that Nickel ran \"as a moderate despite a fairly  voting record\".\n\nNickel was endorsed by The Network for Public Education Fund, the , , , the , the , , , the , the Voter Protection Project, the , , the , North Carolina Asian Americans Together in Action, and Professional Fire Fighters and Paramedics of North Carolina.\n\nNickel defeated , the Republican nominee, in the November 8 general election.\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n* \n\n\n in 2023]]\nNickel supports abortion rights and codifying '''' into federal law.\n\nNickel voted against a resolution to condemn  against s, , and .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBorn in , Nickel moved to  in 2009.     "pages": }\n\n'''Everet William Maze''' (born April 9, 1946) is an American politician from  and a member of the . Maze is the president of Citizens for Saving California Farming Industries, a non-profit dedicated to .\n\n\nA  veteran, Maze graduated from  in San Luis Obispo in 1968.\n\n\nBorn in , Maze is a former Chairman and member of the Economic Development Corporation and Business Incentive Zone Council. He has also served as Director of , and has headed the Visalia Chamber of Commerce, Pro Youth Visalia, Inc., and the Boys & Girls Club. Maze is a past member of the Central California Resource Advisory Council for the Federal Bureau of Land Management, California Farm Bureau and Woodlake Rotary Club. He was a member and chairman of the Tulare County Board of Supervisors, where he served for one decade before being elected to the legislature in 2002.\n\n\nIn 1998 Maze lost the Republican primary for the  against then Fresno mayor pro tem . He lost the general election as well, although he collected about 8000 write-in votes.\n\nIn 2002, then 34th district incumbent Republican  decided to seek reelection in the neighboring 36th district instead, leaving Maze as the sole GOP candidate in the heavily Republican district. Maze won election to the 34th district, which covers , , , and  and won easy reelection in 2004 and 2006.\n\n\nAs an Assemblyman, Maze served on the Assembly Budget Committee and the Health Committees, served as Vice Chair of the Agriculture Committee, the Committee on Water, Parks, and Wildlife, and the Business and Professions Committee. The Assembly Speaker also appointed Maze to numerous Select Committees, including the Select Committee on Foster Care, where he served as Vice Chair. Term limits prevented Maze from seeking reelection in 2008. His wife Rebecca tried to succeed him, but she lost in the Republican primary.\n\n\n\n\n\n*, Election History for the State of California\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gerald A. \"Jerry\" Hill''' (born April 18, 1947) is an American  who served in the  as a member for the . He represented the  during his time in the California State Senate.\n\nBefore being elected to the State Senate in 2012, Hill served in the  representing the . Before serving in the Legislature, he was a member of the  , where he served one term as . He also served on the  .\n\n\nHill was born in , , in 1947. He graduated from  in San Francisco. Hill attended the , where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts. He later received a secondary  from .\n\nIn the 1980s, Hill became president of his local homeowner's association.\n\n\nIn 1991, Hill led a successful campaign for a seat on the San Mateo City Council. During his tenure on the San Mateo City Council, he authored a City of San Mateo ordinance that regulated the sale of tobacco and restricted smoking in public places. While a member of the city council and as Mayor of San Mateo, Hill served as a board member for San Mateo Transit District (SamTrans) and the Peninsula Corridor Joint Powers Authority (Caltrain). Hill served one term as mayor in 1994.\n\n\nElected to the San Mateo County Board of Supervisors in 1998, Hill worked with stakeholders to establish a new homeless shelter for a county which was located far away from local neighborhoods. Hill also pushed to expand the Children’s Health Initiative to help 17,000 children. Hill also served on the California Air Resources Board and as chair of the Bay Area Air Quality Management District.\n\n\nHill won the Democratic primary for  in June 2008 against contenders,  Mayor Gina Papan and Richard Holober.\n\nIn the , Hill received 73 percent of the vote against Republican Catherine Brinkman's 23 percent. Hill succeeded   who was  of office. Hill was re-elected to the California's 19th State Assembly district in 2010 with a similar percent of the vote.\n\n\nIn 2012, Jerry Hill announced his campaign for the  after the  released the new map of the  In the , Hill finished first among four competitors, with 51% of the vote. He served in the  from 2012 to 2020.\n\n\nHill has been recognized by the California Healthcare Institute which named him its Legislator of the Year. Hill also received recognition from the San Mateo County Association of REALTORS, TechNet, TechAmerica, California State Sheriffs Association, and California Small Business Association. He has received positive voting records from the LGBT community, California Labor Federation, Sierra Club, League of Conservation Voters, Consumer Federation of California, Congress of California Seniors, Equality California, and Planned Parenthood.\n\nThe California Clean Money Action Fund named Jerry Hill \"Clean Money Champion\" for \"his leadership in pushing for real reform\".\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jeffrey Frederick Gorell''' (born November 6, 1970), a  politician from , is currently a member of the  , having been elected to the County Board, 2nd District, in 2022. In 2010, Gorell was elected to the State Legislature to serve as  for the 37th Assembly District in California, representing most of Ventura County.  After the decennial redistricting in 2011, Gorell was re-elected to represent the new  and served as Vice-Chairman of the Assembly Budget Committee. In 2014, Gorell was a candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives in . Gorell is also the former Deputy Mayor of the City of Los Angeles for Homeland Security and Public Safety. Gorell, a Navy Reserve officer, is notable for being the first California legislator called to active duty since World War II. During his deployment, fourteen bills were sponsored in his name.\n\n\nGorell earned his  degree in  from the  in 1992. He obtained his  from the 's  in 1998, and earned a certificate in international legal studies at  studying under Associate Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court .\n\nA third-generation member of the U.S. Navy, Gorell serves as a  in the . In 2023, Gorell was selected to command NR  Joint Intelligence Operations Center Headquarters, Pearl Harbor, HI, a joint unit of 150 reserve personnel.\n\nWithin days of the  in 2001, he was recalled to active duty to support . He spent a one-year deployment in the  and . He was decorated for leadership and meritorious actions in a combat zone. He led multiple combat cameramen teams into the mountains of Afghanistan to embed with small Special Forces teams as they captured enemy weapons caches and fought the Taliban and Al Qaeda terrorists. Gorell is the grandson of a  who served in Guam during World War II and the son of a career naval officer and Vietnam veteran. Biography |access-date=2012-12-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140927184853/http://arc.asm.ca.gov/member/AD44/?p=bio |archive-date=2014-09-27 |url-status=dead }}\n\nGorell was mobilized for his second tour in support of Operation Enduring Freedom in Afghanistan in March 2011. He was embedded with U.S. Marines as an intelligence officer at  in Helmand, Afghanistan. He returned home and to his work in the California State Legislature in March 2012.\n\n\nBefore his election to the California State Assembly, Gorell was a regional public affairs firm co-owner, Paladin Principle LLC, based in . He advised clients and served as the company's legal counsel. He was also a member of the  faculty, teaching undergraduate and graduate-level politics and public policy as an adjunct professor.\n\n\nFrom 1993 to 1996, Gorell served as an advisor, writer, and deputy press secretary to former  , working to develop the administration's message on such state policy changes as \",\" state welfare reform, manufacturers' investment tax credits, \",\" and class size reduction.\n\nGorell left the Wilson Administration to serve as a spokesperson for various California businesses, including as Director of Communications for the California Manufacturers and Technology Association (CMTA) from 1996 to 1999. He advocated before the legislature and Capitol press corps for pro-business legislation in the areas of taxes, regulations, workers compensation, tort reform, and trade law.\n\n\nAs a Deputy District Attorney for the County of Ventura from 1999–2006, Gorell gained experience in preventing youth violence. He served as a trial prosecutor in the major narcotics, violent felony units, and juvenile crime units.\n\n\n\n\n;2010\n\nGorell defeated Robert Howell in the June 8, 2010, primary election, earning 89% of the vote. He then defeated Democrat Ferial Masry in the November 2 general election.\n\nGorell was the only Republican running for Assembly in 2010 to receive an endorsement from the California Federation of Labor, one of the state's prominent labor unions. He also received the endorsement of the Chamber of Commerce. On October 9, 2010, Gorell was endorsed by the ''Ventura County Star'' newspaper.\n\nJust before the November 2 general election, Gorell announced that he was being mobilized for duty by the United States Navy Reserve and deployed to Afghanistan on March 18, 2011. He noted that he would still be able to sponsor legislation and would not be drawing an assembly salary while serving overseas. Once elected, he became the first California legislator called to active duty since World War II. The ''Camarillo Acorn'' reports that \"Fourteen bills were introduced in Gorell's name while he was away, and six of those bills were co-authored by Democrats.\"\n\n;2012\n\nIn the state's first primary election under the new top-two open primary on June 5, 2012, Gorell received 58.1% of the vote, beating Eileen MacEnery, who received 23.3% of the vote, and Thomas Mullens, who received 18.6% of the vote. In the November 6, 2012, general election, Gorell went on to defeat MacEnery after receiving 52.9% of the vote.\n\n\nGorell is considered a moderate to conservative Republican. In early 2014, he introduced paperwork to begin a ballot measure that would end the  in California, arguing that \"California cannot afford to pay for a high-speed train system that will cost more than $100 billion at a time when prisoners are being released from prisons and taxpayers are being asked to dig deeper into their own pockets to pay for basic service.\"\n\nIn 2014, Gorell introduced the Drone Privacy Protection Bill, which would ban warrant-less spying by police drones in many cases. The bill passed both houses of the California legislature, but was vetoed by Governor Jerry Brown.\n\n\n;2013\n*Accountability and Administrative Review\n*Budget (Vice-chair)\n*Judiciary\n*Labor and Employment\n*Utilities and Commerce\n*Legislative Budget\n\n\n\nIn November 2013, Gorell announced he would challenge Democratic U.S. Congresswoman  for , based in . He and Brownley advanced past the June 3 blanket primary and faced each other in the general election. The ''Cook Political Report'' rated the race a \"Toss-up.\"\n\nAccording to Stuart Rothenberg of ''Roll Call'', Gorell is a \"self-described moderate Republican\": pro-choice, believes the  was unconstitutional, and supports immigration reform, including paths to citizenship for those already here.\n\nHe was endorsed by former State Senator .\n\nIn the November 4 election, he lost to Brownley by a narrow margin.\n\n\nIn 2019, Fox Network put in development ''City Hall'', an hour-long Los Angeles-set drama from writer Bruce Romans (''Deputy'', ''The Punisher''), The Nacelle Company, and Fox Entertainment-owned SideCar Content Accelerator. Gorell will serve as an executive producer.\n\n\nGorell resides in , and has two young sons, Jack and Steven. He is divorced.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Debra Lynn Bowen''' (born October 27, 1955) is an American attorney and politician who served as the  from 2007 to 2015. Previously, she was a member of the  from 1992 to 2006. In March 2008, she was given the Profile in Courage Award by the .\n\n\nBowen was born and raised in , where she graduated from  in 1973. She received her bachelor's degree in 1976 from , and her  in 1979 from the . In 1984, she started her own California law firm.\n\nMotivated by the death of  a few weeks earlier, in September 2014, her last year serving as Secretary of State, Bowen revealed that she has been battling depression since she had been in college. She vowed to continue to serve out the four months remaining in her term as Secretary of State.\n\n\nBowen began her career in politics on the Neighborhood Watch and .  Her first elected office was to the , where she represented the 53rd Assembly District in the  area from 1992 to 1998. Bowen was first elected to the , representing the 28th State Senate District, in 1998. Her district included all or portions of the cities of , , , , , , , , , , and . Bowen chaired the California Senate's Committee on Elections, Reapportionment and Constitutional Amendments. She also sat on the Energy, Utilities & Communications and Rules committees. Due to , her service in the Senate ended in December 2006.\n\nOn June 6, 2006, Bowen faced , another state senator, in the Democratic primary to run against    for the position of . Bowen won the primary by a 61-39 margin. On the November 2, 2006 general election, she defeated McPherson by a margin of 3% popular vote.\n\nBowen was re-elected on November 2, 2010 over Republican .\n\n\n state convention]]\nAfter incumbent  announced she was vacating the seat, Bowen was widely discussed as a possible candidate for the  to replace her. On February 15, 2011, Bowen announced in an email to her supporters that she was entering the race. Her candidacy was endorsed by former  governor and  chairman , , the California League of Conservation Voters, and the California Nurses Association. She came in third, not qualifying for the general election for the seat.\n\n\nBowen is known for her support of opening government to the . In 1993, her first year in elected office, she helped to pass Assembly Bill (AB) 1624, which made all of California's bill information available on the Internet.\n\nIn May 2007, Bowen commissioned a  of California's electronic voting systems, to determine their security.  On August 3, 2007, Bowen withdrew approval and certification and conditionally re-approved three  (, Hart InterCivic, ), and rescinded approval of a fourth system, (), after the top-to-bottom review of the voting machines found the machines to be highly insecure.  For these efforts she was awarded the Profile in Courage Award by the .\n\nBowen was interviewed for the January 16, 2008 broadcast of '''' and was the keynote speaker for the 2008 Usenix Security Symposium.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*  July 2008\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Johan M. Klehs''' is a  state politician from . He was born in  on June 27, 1952. He is a . Klehs served as a member of the San Leandro, California City Council from 1978 to 1982. He represented  from 1982 until 1992 and the 18th District from 1992 to 1994. He served as a member of the  from 1994 until 2002 when he was termed out and lost the Democratic primary for . He served in the Assembly again from 2004 to 2006, representing the 18th District.\n\nKlehs served as a lecturer of political science and strategic advisor to the Chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Terra Eve Lawson-Remer''' (born July 1978) is an American educator and politician serving as vice chair of the ; she has held the position since 2023. A member of the , she has represented District 3 since 2021.\n\nBorn in , Lawson-Remer grew up in the  neighborhood and attended . She graduated from  with a bachelor's degree in ethics, politics, and economics in 2000, later attending , where she received a  and . After graduation, Lawson-Remer worked for the  and the  during the . She then served as a professor at  and the , teaching .\n\nIn 2020, Lawson-Remer ran for the San Diego County Board of Supervisors, defeating  incumbent Kristin Gaspar. Her victory shifted control of the Board of Supervisors from Republican to  for the first time in decades.\n\n\nTerra Eve Lawson-Remer was born in July 1978 in . Her father, Larry Remer, was born in , to a Jewish family and worked as an investigative journalist who would become a political consultant later in his career. Lawson-Remer's mother, Shari Lawson, worked as a lawyer. Her parents met each other while organizing protests in opposition to the  and eventually married in July 1977 with , a San Diego County Superior Court judge, officiating their marriage. Lawson-Remer's paternal grandparents were Herbert and Beverly Remer. Herbert owned a company that imported goods mostly from  and  and served in the  as part of the . Meanwhile, Beverly was a schoolteacher in  who worked toward  the city's schools. Lawson-Remer's maternal grandfather, Frank Lawson, served in the  and was stationed at  and killed in action during the  in 1950. Lawson-Remer has a sister named Alexa.\n\nLawson-Remer grew up in  and graduated from  in 1996. In 2000, Lawson-Remer graduated from  with a bachelor's degree in ethics, politics, and economics. She later attended , where she received a  in 2006 and a  in political economy in 2010.\n\n\n in a  against the , August 26, 2004]]\nWhile president of her high school class in 1994, Lawson-Remer participated in a student  in opposition to , a ballot measure related to  in California. Her involvement in the walkout prompted the school administrators to strip Lawson-Remer of her class presidency. In 1999, Lawson-Remer  against a  meeting in Seattle, resulting in police arresting her. Lawson-Remer was one of nearly 14,000 law students in 2003 who submitted an '''' in '''', voicing support for  in .\n\nOn August 26, 2004, Lawson-Remer participated in Operation Sybil, a  against the upcoming , rappelling the  to place a sign in opposition to president . New York police arrested her and several other co-organizers, charging them with felony and misdemeanor charges of assault, reckless endangerment, and criminal trespass. Lawson-Remer said Bush and vice president  were \"taking [the country] in the wrong direction\" and accused them of deception on the , healthcare, and the economy.\n\nLawson-Remer worked for , PlaNet Finance on behalf of the , and as a senior advisor in the  during the . She also taught  as a professor at  and the . In 2014, Lawson-Remer appeared in an episode of '''' to discuss the effects of the  in . Along with fifteen other applicants, Lawson-Remer applied to the  City Council in 2017, hoping to fill a seat left vacant after  became the city's mayor. In 2017–2018, Lawson-Remer was a fellow at 's  and the . She led the Flip the 49th campaign to defeat Republican U.S. representative  in  in 2018.\n\nIn 2019, Lawson-Remer received the  from the  alongside  and Susan Randolph for their book entitled ''Fulfilling Social and Economic Rights'', which made a \"significant contribution to world order\" by \"inform[ing] domestic and international policies, aid[ing] in the work of non-governmental organizations and provid[ing] a way to evaluate performance in a truly comparative perspective.\"\n\n\n\n\nOn January 28, 2019, Lawson-Remer announced her candidacy in the third district of the , contending for a seat held by conservative Republican . In June 2019, Lawson-Remer received the endorsement of  Local 221, the largest  in San Diego County.  Mayor  withdrew his endorsement of  City Councilwoman Olga Diaz, a fellow Democrat, on December 3, 2019, to support Lawson-Remer's campaign. On December 24, 2019, San Diego County Superior Court Judge  required Lawson-Remer to revise her title in her ballot description, in which she indicated she was an attorney. However, because the  did not license her, Lawson-Remer cannot refer to herself as an attorney without indicating the state where she has a license, which was New York in her case.\n\nDemocratic U.S. representative , a friend of Lawson-Remer's father, endorsed her campaign to become a county supervisor in January 2020. In the March 2020 primary election, Lawson-Remer defeated Diaz to move on to the general election against Gaspar. After the election,  executive director Hasan Ikhrata made the highest possible campaign donation to Lawson-Remer. Between February 16 through June 30, 2020, Lawson-Remer received more campaign contributions than Gaspar.\n\nSeveral months before the November election, Lawson-Remer received a deluge of endorsements from California Democratic politicians hoping to flip the Republican-held seat, including governor , State Senate president pro tempore , and San Diego county supervisor . In October, Lawson-Remer received the endorsement of '''' editorial board, who endorsed her Republican opponent in 2016. An October 2020 '''' poll showed that 42% of likely voters would vote or leaned in favor of voting for Lawson-Remer, as opposed to 31% for Gaspar, whose support for  undermined her chances of reelection.\n\nOn October 12, 2020, Lawson-Remer challenged Gaspar in a  debate, and she went on to defeat her Republican opponent on November 3 to shift the balance of power of the San Diego County Board of Supervisors in favor of the Democrats. Heading into the election, the Republicans held a 4–1 majority in the Board of Supervisors, ending up as a 3–2 Democratic majority afterward, establishing Democratic control for the \"first time in at least a generation,\" according to the ''Voice of San Diego''. Lawson-Remer's victory ensured simultaneous Democratic control of the 's office, the , and the San Diego County Board of Supervisors.\n\n\nAfter winning the election, Lawson-Remer became a member of the Board of Supervisors after being sworn in on January 4, 2021. The swearing-in ceremony occurred between 10 and 11 a.m., with Lawson-Remer sworn in after  and . Lawson-Remer recited the  with   and Judge  of the , which was done so virtually due to the ongoing .\n\n\n\nLawson-Remer supported lifting San Diego County's ban on businesses selling  in , favoring  instead of prohibitive policy. On , she wanted to put together a plan that involved adopting a  program setting a timeline for 90% , support for , and other initiatives. Lawson-Remer suggested providing incentives for developers building  as a means to resolve San Diego's .  She supported the implementation of  to curb . Lawson-Remer said that  continued to be a problem locally and nationally. She opposed outsourcing the jail medical and mental health services of the . Lawson-Remer criticized San Diego County's response to the , seeing the county as unready to handle outbreaks.\n\nOn the United States' investment in , Lawson-Remer supported continued investment in these financial institutions on the basis that such investment develops and maintains national security. She argued that the  lacked legitimacy as an international actor because of issues surrounding the institution's transparency and accountability, believing that the G20 needed greater involvement of the people whose policies they affect.\n\n\nLawson-Remer resides in , where she raises her daughter Eeva Kai as a . Lawson-Remer is  and . Explaining why she became a politician, Lawson-Remer cited 's loss in the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* Column archives at '''' and ''''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Matt Dorsey''' (born 1964 or 1965) is an American politician and communications professional. Dorsey has served on the  representing District 6 since his appointment by Mayor  on May 9, 2022. He was elected to a full term in the . He previously served as the Head of Communications for the .\n\n\nDorsey worked s for   for 14 years.\n\nDorsey worked for the  from 2020–2022, where he served as Head of Strategic Communications. He defended the police department for its decision to withdraw from a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the District Attorney's Office, which assigned the office as lead investigator in police use-of-force incidents.\n\n\nDorsey was appointed to the  on May 9, 2022, by Mayor  to replace outgoing District 6 Supervisor  for the rest of his term. Unlike his predecessor, Dorsey will not represent , which was moved to District 5 after  in 2022. District 6 has 76,000 San Francisco residents and consists of , , , , , The Hub (near Market and Octavia) and Showplace Square (Southwestern SoMa).\n\nDorsey ran for election in November 2022. He defeated , a former aide to Matt Haney. Dorsey was supported by GrowSF, among many other moderate Democratic organizations.\n\nDorsey and London Breed decided to not march in  2022 after the organizers banned police officers from marching in uniform. After Pride reached a compromise with the police, Dorsey and Breed agreed to march.\n\nDorsey faced criticism for his support for a documentary on San Francisco's police department, which he began promoting during his time working for the police department and supported as a supervisor. Critics view the documentary as a waste of limited police resources.\n\n\nDorsey is gay. He is  and is in recovery from drug and alcohol addiction.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Abel O. Maldonado Jr.''' (born August 21, 1967) is an American politician who served as the  from April 27, 2010 to January 10, 2011. As of 2024, Maldonado is the last member of the  to serve as Lieutenant Governor of California.\n\nElected to the  City Council in 1994, Maldonado then served as mayor of Santa Maria from 1996 to 1998, when he was elected to the . He served in that body from 1998 to 2004 and then in the  from 2004 to 2010, running unsuccessfully for the Republican nomination for  in . Maldonado was the first Republican in the State Senate to vote for the budget during the budget deadlock in 2007. He represented a swing district in the Senate and is considered a moderate.\n\nOn November 23, 2009, then-Governor  announced Maldonado as his nominee for lieutenant governor to fill the vacancy created by Democrat 's election to the . Maldonado was sworn into office on April 27, 2010 and was defeated in the  by Democratic San Francisco Mayor .\n\nMaldonado ran for  in the , but was defeated by incumbent Democrat . In May 2013, he announced that he was running for governor in the , but dropped out in January 2014 after unsuccessful fundraising efforts and campaign missteps. In 2017, Maldonado was considered for the role of  by , but was ultimately not nominated.\n\n\nMaldonado was born in , the eldest son of immigrant Mexican farm workers. His family eventually acquired a small , where they grew . After Maldonado graduated from , his family used their earnings from the farm to send him to  in , where he studied , but dropped out before completing his degree. Maldonado then returned to his family's farm and helped his family grow the half-acre strawberry farm into a 6,000-acre (24&nbsp;km²) farm, employing 250 people, with produce shipped around the world.\n\n\n\n\nAfter months of attempting to obtain a building permit from the city of Santa Maria to construct a cooling facility on the farm, Maldonado grew disillusioned with the city bureaucracy and decided to run for the Santa Maria  in 1994 at the age of 26. In 1996, at the age of 28, Councilman Maldonado successfully ran for , defeating the incumbent Mayor Robert Gordon Bunch and retiree George Hobbs 40%-39%-21%, a margin of 70 votes.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1998, at the age of 31, Mayor Maldonado was elected to the  with 60% of the vote in the 33rd District, representing  and western . Maldonado was re-elected in 2000 with 65% of the vote and in 2002 with 63% of the vote.\n\n\nDuring his Assembly tenure, Maldonado was named \"Hero of the Taxpayer\" by the . He led issues such as seat belts in school buses and California Workers Compensation Reform.\n\n\nHe was on the Business and Professions committee.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2004, Maldonado was elected to the  by a margin of 53% to 43% over his Democratic opponent,  Supervisor Peg Pinard, in a district evenly divided between  and Republicans. The 15th District included , most of , eastern , portions of northwestern Santa Barbara County, and portions of southwestern .\n\n\nIn March 2005, a San Luis Obispo weekly newspaper revealed that Maldonado had received $30,987 in gifts from an organization representing California's power industry. Those gifts included multiple trips to ,  and . The story suggested that the gifts might have motivated Maldonado to object to a seismic safety bill that could potentially have threatened 's license to operate. According to the story, Maldonado snapped at the reporter, \"“I have never, ever, ever connected monetary resources with a bill or a special company in my area. For somebody to even suggest that is disappointing.\"\n\nMaldonado signed a \"No New Taxes\" pledge before his election which he later claimed to regret as he cast a vote for higher taxes.\n\nIn February 2009, Maldonado was initially among the Republican senators rejecting a series of bills designed to close the $41 billion state budget deficit, but he later joined the Democrats in supporting the measures.\n\nA committee indicated that it might pursue a  against Maldonado because of his vote on the budget. The same threat was made against other Republicans in the \"Sacramento Six\", but none of the recall campaigns came to anything. (Most of the recall energy was directed against .)\n\nIn response to his critics, including , Maldonado said, \"Since the budget was passed, you have gone around the state criticizing it and the role six Republicans played in its passage. Your recent statements condemning  are very frustrating. During the budget debate, which lasted over 100 days, I heard from thousands of Californians who took the time to give me their input on the state budget. But I never heard from you.\"\n\n\nIn December 2006, he was named Chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee.\n\n*Budget and Fiscal Review\n*Education\n*Health\n*Veterans Affairs\n*Food and Agriculture (Vice Chair)\n*Human Services (Vice Chair)\n\n\n\nIn 2005, Maldonado declared his candidacy for the office of California State Controller after Controller  decided to run for . Maldonado was defeated in the June 6, 2006 Republican primary by .\n\nFollowing his loss, Maldonado publicly criticized Governor  for not supporting his campaign more forcefully, suggesting that Schwarzenegger did not care about , when he told the '''' that \"[w]hen [Schwarzenegger] needs Latinos, Latinos are always there for him. When Latinos need him, the answer's been no.\" Maldonado issued a public apology for the comment. He also maintained that he would not run for any further political office after his state Senate service; he was re-elected to the Senate in 2008 with 63% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn November 3, 2009, Lieutenant Governor  resigned to take a seat in Congress. On the November 23, 2009, episode of '''', Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger announced that he was nominating Maldonado as lieutenant governor. Schwarzenegger cited Maldonado's \"bipartisanship and postpartisanship...He makes decisions based on what's best for the people rather than what's best for the party. He has helped us, many times, pass a budget, which was very important. And he comes from an immigrant family...\"\n\nMaldonado needed to be confirmed by a majority vote of the State Senate and a majority vote of the State Assembly within 90 days of the nomination in order to take office as lieutenant governor. In a statement released by the Governor's office, Schwarzenegger called Maldonado a \"true partner\" and cited his willingness \"to reach across the partisan divide\" and \"commitment to creating a transparent, accountable government\" in California.\n\n\nOn February 11, 2010, Maldonado was confirmed as lieutenant governor by the state Senate by a 26-7 vote. However, his nomination was not approved by the State Assembly. Needing 41 votes (in the 80-seat Assembly) for confirmation in the lower chamber, he received 37 votes in favor, with 35 votes against.\n\nBased upon the vote in the Legislature, Governor Schwarzenegger considered having Maldonado sworn into office, which may have set up a legal battle with Democrats. Instead, Schwarzenegger resubmitted the nomination of Maldonado on February 17. Maldonado received confirmation from the Assembly on April 22, 2010 by a 53-21 vote and from the Senate on April 26, 2010 by a 25-7 vote. He was sworn in as Lieutenant Governor on April 27, 2010.\n\n\n\nMaldonado ran for the Republican nomination for the office in June and won with 43.4% of the vote. Maldonado was defeated on November 2, 2010 by   Mayor .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2011, Maldonado announced his intention to challenge U.S. Representative , a , for her seat in the  in the .\n\nMaldonado was defeated by Capps in the election by a 55.2% to 44.8% margin.\n\n\n\nOn May 20, 2013, Maldonado announced he would seek the Republican nomination for the .\n\nOn June 28, 2013, Maldonado came out in support of the Supreme Court's ruling that cleared the way for same-sex marriage in California, and said that same-sex couples should be afforded the same rights and protections as heterosexual couples. Although Maldonado had supported  in 2008, he reversed his position in 2011 when a cousin revealed that he was gay. He also said his four children helped change his position.\n\nMaldonado withdrew from the race on January 16, 2014. His campaign was beset by problems: he accused Governor Brown of things that occurred years before he was elected, he struggled to raise money, his campaign's senior staff left in September 2013, and his campaign failed to gain traction after the entry of fellow Republicans  and  into the race. In announcing his withdrawal, Maldonado said: \"Now is not my time... I know it's cliché to say I am not running so I can spend more time with my family. Everybody says that. But the truth is, that is, a major factor in my decision today. I have missed some birthdays, family holidays and even anniversaries. From this day forward [my wife] now controls my schedule.\"\n\n\nIn January 2017, it was reported by CNN that Maldonado was an early frontrunner to serve as  in the cabinet of then-President-elect . CNN Politics|url=https://www.cnn.com/2017/01/03/politics/abel-maldonado-agriculture-secretary-front-runner-donald-trump/index.html|access-date=2022-02-26|website=CNN|language=en|archive-date=February 26, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220226024224/https://www.cnn.com/2017/01/03/politics/abel-maldonado-agriculture-secretary-front-runner-donald-trump/index.html|url-status=live}} His potential nomination was supported by the . However,  was ultimately chosen for the role instead, a move that was criticized by former Governor Schwarzenegger.\n\n\nHe is married to Laura Maldonado and has four children.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Bonnie Lowenthal''' (born February 19, 1940) is an American politician who represented . Lowenthal also served on the   prior to her service in the .  Lowenthal unsuccessfully ran for Mayor of Long Beach , failing to get past the primary nominating election, earning 19% of the vote.\n\n\nLowenthal is the daughter of Jewish immigrants from the  who immigrated to the United States to escape increasing anti-Semitism.\n\nLowenthal received her Bachelor of Science degree from the  (class of 1961) and a Master's of Science in community and clinical psychology from  (class of 1974). Since 1975, Lowenthal has been a licensed family counselor and mental health consultant. She has also served as a bilingual mental health consultant for the League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC), HeadStart, and the Centro de la Raza,\n\n\nPrior to her service in the Assembly, Lowenthal was elected to represent the First Council District of the City of Long Beach, in 2001, and was selected to serve as Vice Mayor in 2006. Lowenthal also served on the Long Beach Unified School District Board of Education for seven years and was a member of the  (MTA), as well as many community boards and committees.\n\n\nLowenthal was previously married to California State Senator who was also one of her predecessors in her assembly seat. They were the first divorced couple to serve concurrently in the legislature. They have two sons. Daniel is a judge on a , and  is a member of the California State Assembly.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Holly J. Mitchell''' (born September 7, 1964) is an American politician currently serving as a member of the .\n\nA , Mitchell served as a  for California's  from 2013 to 2020, which is also part of Supervisorial District 2 and encompasses , , , and parts of the Westmont, Florence, , , , Downtown Los Angeles. She previously represented the  after replacing then-Senator  in a 2013 . Prior to being elected to the State Senate, she served in the  representing the .\n\nMitchell is a member of the . In 2016 Mitchell became the first African American to chair the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, where she has overseen the passage and adoption of two consecutive state budgets.\n\n\nBefore working in the , she served for seven years as CEO of the nonprofit Crystal Stairs. She also served as a Consultant to the Senate Health Committee, and as a legislative advocate for the Western Center on Law and Poverty.\n\n\n\nIn 2018, Mitchell was named vice chair of the Joint Legislative Subcommittee on  Prevention and Response, formed in response to the  and several instances where accusations had forced some lawmakers to resign. Mitchell was the first African-American to serve as Chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, overseeing the passage of state budgets totaling over $200 billion.\n\nIn 2019, Mitchell drafted and sponsored the , a California law which prohibits  by extending protection under the  and the . It is the first legislation passed at the state level in the United States to prohibit such discrimination.  The Act passed unanimously in both chambers of the  by June 27, 2019, and was signed into law on July 3, 2019.  The law has since inspired similar laws across the country.\n\n\nMitchell faced member  in the 2020 race for District 2 of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors. She defeated Wesson by a wide margin. Her election to the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors in 2020 marks the first time the board is composed entirely of women.  Mitchell generated controversy when she said, \"Law enforcement and the District Attorneys Association and the Sheriffs’ Association, who just when you look at who represents them in Sacramento, is clearly such White supremacist organizations.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jacqui Irwin''' (born January 3, 1962) is an American  currently serving in the . She is a  representing the , having previously represented the 44th. Before being elected to the Assembly in 2014, Irwin worked as a  at  and , then served as a two-term mayor and three-term city councilmember in .\n\n\nIrwin was born in the  neighborhood of Los Angeles to Dutch immigrants John and Barbara Van Egmond, and grew up in the  neighborhood. She graduated with a systems engineering degree from the , where she was an  swimmer.\n\n\nAfter graduating from UC San Diego, Irwin worked as an engineer for three years at the , then for five years at . In 2003, Irwin was appointed to the Thousand Oaks Planning Commission, ran for City Council the following year, and became mayor of Thousand Oaks in 2008.\n\nIn 2014, Irwin successfully ran as a Democrat in the race to represent , defeating Republican opponent Rob McCoy.  Irwin has been reelected four times in 2016, 2018, 2020, and most recently 2022 in the new  after redistricting occurred.\n\n\nIrwin is the chair of the Assembly Committee on Revenue and Taxation, and the Assembly Select Committee on Cybersecurity, and the Assembly Select Committee on Gasoline Supply and Pricing. She also serves on the Committees on Agriculture, Business & Professions, Higher Education, and Privacy and Consumer Protection. She previously served as chair of the Assembly Committee on Military and Veterans Affairs from 2014-2021.\n\nIrwin has also been appointed to other significant roles including the Governor's Military Council, and as co-chair of the ’s Task Force on Cybersecurity.\n\n\nDuring her first term in office, Irwin passed significant legislation. Irwin improved the cybersecurity of the state by mandating state agencies undergo independent security assessments, she banned , expanded the ability of  research to be turned into real-world applications, and worked with Attorney General  to create the OpenJustice Web portal to provide better access to criminal justice data.\n\n\nDuring her second term in office, Irwin helped secure critical funding for infrastructure projects in Ventura County, including $68.6 million for a grade separation project at Rice Avenue in , and $9.5 million for emergency wastewater treatment facility repairs in Oxnard, California.\n\nShe continued her work passing significant cybersecurity legislation, enacting into law the first ever security requirement for Internet of Things devices. Irwin also significantly changed how  approached  in an effort to get students into transfer level courses.\n\n\nIn 2019 Irwin focused heavily on gun violence prevention legislation in response to the  in Thousand Oaks, California. Her legislation strengthened , in part by allowing them to extend up to five years. She also required law enforcement agencies to have policies about using GVROs. Irwin also secured $3 million to support local law enforcement efforts to recover firearms from individuals listed in the Armed and Prohibited Possessors System.\n\nIn October 2019, Irwin pulled out of attending a fundraising event for the family of an officer killed in the Borderline shooting. After the Ventura County Sheriff's Office also withdrew from the fundraiser, citing a policy of non-participation in political events, the event was postponed indefinitely. An organizer of the event was later arrested in Florida for felony violations of charitable solicitation law and misusing charitable funds.\n\nIrwin also authored ACR-17, which renamed a portion of  in Thousand Oaks after Sgt. Ron Helus, from the Ventura County Sheriff's Office, who died in the line of duty during the Borderline Shooting.\n\nIn 2020, Irwin shifted the majority of her efforts towards assisting her district's response to the . Irwin spearheaded efforts to collect  (PPE) for front line health care workers and organized  during a local shortage.\n\nIrwin also brought together local governments, academics, private businesses, and non-profits to conduct a  testing study in Ventura County. Irwin worked with the group to acquire reliable and available  to be used for the study. She also helped identify and secure locations that would be utilized as testing sites for the countywide study which offered free COVID-19 antibody testing to residents.  The antibody testing study was developed to not only understand the prevalence of COVID-19 in Ventura County, but was also modeled to understand the prevalence in targeted groups including first responders, low-income households, and those experiencing homelessness.\n\nIrwin also set the highest level for recycled materials in plastic bottles, authoring a bill with Assemblyman  to require plastic beverage containers to contain at least 50% postconsumer recycled plastic content by 2030.\n\n\n\nDuring Irwin’s fourth term in the Assembly, she continued to author landmark legislation into law. With support from Attorney General , Irwin created new rules for online charitable giving providing protections for donors and nonprofits using website like , PayPal Giving Fund, and other online platforms.\n\nIrwin also worked to protect the elderly from hospice fraud by prohibiting incentive payments, a problem highlighted by investigative journalism by the .  She partnered with County Clerks to make permanent Californian’s ability to request vital records (e.g. birth, marriage, death certificates) online, rather than visit offices in person.\n\n\nIrwin, who has a background in the tech industry, has pushed for legislature to require  companies to disclose .\n\n\nIrwin married Jon Irwin, a corporate executive, in 1986, and has three children. After her efforts to amend provisions of the  in 2019, which passed unanimously through the legislature and were signed by the governor, she received criticism for possible conflicts of interest based on her husband's position as  of . Irwin claimed that she consults with the Assembly's ethics officer on any potential conflicts of interest.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
