    "pages": }\n'''Blanca Estela Rubio''' (born September 15, 1969) is an American politician serving in the  since 2016. She is a  representing the , encompassing parts of the eastern , including , , and . Prior to being elected to the assembly, she was a board trustee for the , and a schoolteacher for 16 years. Rubio is a board member of the , a  trade group.\n\n\nBlanca Rubio was born in , Mexico, and first came to the United States with family to , where she lived as an . She was deported back to Juárez, returned to Los Angeles illegally in 1977 with her family, and eventually became a citizen in 1994. Her younger sister, , is a member of the .\n\nAssemblywoman Blanca Rubio received her bachelor's degree in Business Administration and master's degree in Education with a Multiple Subject Teaching Credential from . Rubio taught elementary school in . In 2003, she was elected to . She served for two terms as both President and Vice President.\n\n\nAssemblywoman Blanca Rubio is the Chair of Governmental Organization. The first Latina to ever serve as Chair of this Committee. She is also on the following Standing Committees, Banking and Finance, Insurance, Aging and Long-Term Care and Joint legislative Audit Committee. She serves as the Chair of the Select Committee on Domestic Violence. A subject that she is passionate about. Assemblywoman Rubio has authored and co-authored numerous bills that support victims of domestic violence, create opportunities for children within the foster care system, ensure our youngest students are given proper support to succeed in school, and support for immigrant communities. She co-sponsored SB 273 with her sister , which would extend the statute of limitations for victims of domestic violence to 10 years from 3 years in certain cases, and require more training for police dealing with abuse victims.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Terrence Doyle Schrunk''' (March 10, 1913 &ndash; March 4, 1975) was an American politician who served as the mayor for the , , 1957–1973, a length tying with , who also served 16 years (1917–1933).\n\nSchrunk was appointed sheriff of  in 1949 by the county commissioners, succeeding M. L. Elliott, who was removed from office in a . Schrunk was subsequently outright elected to the office,\n\nIn his 1956 campaign for mayor, Schrunk advocated for . Schrunk beat incumbent  by 17,000 votes in a nine-person primary, but did not get an absolute majority, and then beat Peterson in the fall run-off election. He took office at midnight on January 1, 1957.\"Schrunk Sworn In As Mayor\" (January 1, 1957). ''The Oregonian'', p. 1.\n\nIn 1968 and 1969, he served as president of the .\n\nTerry's son, , was elected  of  in 1981, and is thought to be the longest-serving district attorney in Oregon history.\n\n\n\n in Portland, Oregon.]]\nIn mid-twentieth-century Portland, gambling dens, brothels, and unlicensed bars operated virtually uninhibited by police as long as vice racketeers paid scheduled kickbacks to key city law enforcement officials.\n\nSchrunk was elected mayor with Teamsters union support, allegedly in part because the incumbent Republican mayor, Fred Peterson, offended the union when he wouldn't oust Police chief . The Teamsters felt that Purcell impeded their drive to open a wider vice business in Portland.\n\nIn 1957 he appeared as himself in the CBS documentary film ''''  and on September 2 of that year, as reported by the ''Oregonian'' on its September 4, 1957, edition, was seen in the front seat of a Lincoln convertible as he and the then biggest star in the world of music, the 22-year-old  saluted the 14,600 fans waiting for his concert to start at  (known at that time as Multnomah Stadium). \n\nAn allegation against Mayor Schrunk soon landed him before the  headed by Arkansas Democrat  investigating  U.S. labor racketeering in March 1957. While still sheriff in September 1955, Schrunk and his deputies had raided the 8212 Club, a gambling and after-hours drinking joint financed by Portland Racketeer . Elkins testified that the manager, Clifford Bennett, told him he had paid Schrunk $500, and the sheriff had gone away without causing any more troubleexcept for arresting a few drunks. Although Bennett refused to testify, several others confirmed pieces of the story. Schrunk flatly denied having taken bribes from Bennett. But he did admit that his deputies had raided the 8212 Club, seen liquor being illegally served after hours, spotted gambling equipment all over the placeand that he had gone away without taking further action.\n\n, then the lead attorney for the Senate committee, came to Portland to testify against him. Jurors acquitted Schrunk in less than two hours.\n\nThree years later, Kennedy was managing his brother, Senator 's, presidential campaign, with Oregon one of seven primaries that JFK entered. Kennedy's pursuit of Schrunk had angered enough Oregon Democrats that some of JFK's key supporters persuaded Kennedy operative Joseph S. Miller to ask Senator Kennedy to keep his younger brother out of Oregon. Although JFK largely accepted the advice, Miller's bluntness angered both brothers.  Continued resentment by Schrunk and his supporters was seen as a contributing factor to Robert Kennedy losing the Oregon Democratic Primary to Eugene McCarthy in May 1968.\n\nIn 1968 and 1969, he served as the president of the .\n\nSchrunk was initiated as a member of  Fraternity at .\n\nSchrunk suffered a heart attack in October 1972 while at City Hall and was taken to the hospital where he survived.\n\nSchrunk died after suffering another heart attack in 1975, at age 61.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gloria J. Romero''' (born July 10, 1955) is a former California State Senator from 2001 until 2010 and was the   of the  from 2005 until 2008. She was the first woman to hold that leadership position. In 2024, she joined the Republican Party.\n\n\nRomero grew up in , one of six children. Her father worked in the railroad yards and her mother, who left school after sixth grade, stayed home and raised the kids. Romero received her  from  before going on to earn a  and an  from  and a  in  from the .\n\nShe taught as a  at state universities and served as a trustee and vice president of the board of trustees of .\n\n\nShe was elected to the  in 1998 and to the Senate in 2001.  Romero represented the , which included , portions of the city of Los Angeles, as well as a major part of the , including the cities of , , , , , , , , , ,  and .\n\nIn 2008, Romero stepped down as Majority Leader and became chairman of the Education Committee. In that position she authored and guided to passage a fiercely contested ‘parent trigger’ law which allows a majority of parents in a \"failing school\" to vote on a method to restructure the school.\n\nRomero was term-limited in 2010.\n\n\nFollowing U.S. Representative 's December 2008 selection to become  by President-elect  (and expected subsequent confirmation), Romero indicated strong interest in running in the  to replace her, but later chose to run for the nonpartisan  instead. Romero was supported by advocates of , while her two major opponents were supported by teachers unions and school administrators, respectively. Eventually, Romero finished third, receiving 17.0% of the vote in a crowded 12-person field.\n\n\nRomero led the California chapter of , a reform wing of the Democratic Party supporting privatization of public schools. In the 2012 election, she supported California's  that would bar workers from donating to their unions' Political Action Committees (PACs) using payroll deductions.Finley, Allysia, , ''Wall Street Journal'', August 31, 2012. Retrieved 2012-09-03. She founded Scholarship Prep Charter School, which enrolls TK-8th grade students in low income communities.\n\nIn the unsuccessful , she endorsed Republican  as a replacement candidate for Democratic governor  in spite of saying that she \"disagrees with just about everything that Larry Elder stands for\".\n\nAs a public university professor in California, she is a member of the .\n\nOn September 4, 2024, Romero left the Democratic Party and joined the Republican Party. She gave many reasons for her switch in parties including the Democratic Party's positions on crime, gender identity, COVID-19 lockdowns, gas stoves and school choice which she disagrees with. In a press conference, Romero endorsed  in the 2024 election and offered praise for , calling him a \"personal hero\".\n\n\n\n\n\n* (official website)\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Marian Elaine''' \"'''Mimi'''\" '''Walters''' (née '''Krogius'''; born May 14, 1962) is an American businesswoman and politician. A member of the , she served from 2015 to 2019 as the  for .\n\nBefore running for office, Walters was an  from 1988 to 1995, and served as chairwoman of the  Investment and Banking Committee. She then served two terms on the  from 1996 to 2004, serving as Mayor in 2000, before representing the  in the  from 2004 to 2008. She was subsequently elected to the , representing the  from 2008 to 2012 and the  from 2012 to 2015.\n\nWalters was elected to represent  in the  in 2014, and was re-elected in 2016. She ran for a third term in the , but was defeated by  .\n\n\nIn 1962, Walters was born as Marian Elaine Krogius in . Walters' father is Tristan Krogius. Walters graduated from  (1980) before earning a  in  from the  in 1984.\n\n\nWalters was an investment banker from 1988 to 1995. She was an investment executive at the firm of , and later joined the firm of \n\n\nAfter serving as chair of 's Investment and Banking Committee, Walters was appointed to the  in 1996, after the recently re-elected incumbent Thomas W. Wilson resigned to be appointed to the . Walters served as mayor in 2000, and was elected to a second term that same year.\n\nDuring her time on the City Council, Walters also served on the El Toro Reuse Planning Authority, and opposed efforts to convert  into a commercial airport.\n\n\nIn 2004, Walters was elected to represent the 73rd Assembly District, which includes the coastal  and  county communities of , , , , , , and . Her term ran from January 2005 to January 2007. In November 2006, she was re-elected to a second term in the Assembly.\n\n\nWalters was elected to the State Senate in November 2008.\n\nIn 2013, the California Fair Political Practices Commission cleared Walters of wrongdoing in a conflict of interest investigation \"into phone calls made by her office on behalf of a company once co-owned by her husband\".\n\n\n\nIn January 2010, Walters announced that she would run for  against Democratic incumbent . Walters became the  nominee for State Treasurer, but lost to Lockyer in the general election.\n\n\nDemocratic candidate and trial lawyer Steve Young filed an unsuccessful civil lawsuit in an attempt to keep Walters' name off of the 2012 ballot. Young's lawsuit challenged Walters' residency in the 37th District; after the California Citizens Redistricting Commission re-drew the state's legislative districts in 2011, Walters announced that she had moved from Laguna Nigel to Irvine, in order to be eligible to run in the 37th Senate District.\n\n\n]]\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn July 2, 2013, Walters formally announced her candidacy for Congress, to replace Congressman , who announced he would not be seeking another term.\n\nShe was endorsed by a number of Republican members of Congress from California, including Campbell, , , and . Prior to the 2014 election, she set up the Blessings of Liberty Leadership PAC.\n\nWalters was placed in the 's (NRCC) \"Contender\" category of their \"Young Guns\" program. In September 2014, the NRCC named Walters along with 13 other candidates to their \"Vanguard\" program. In the non-partisan blanket primary, she came in first place in a field of three candidates, with 45% of the vote. In the general election, she defeated  candidate Drew Leavens with 65% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\nIn November 2016, Walters won re-election by 17 points over her Democratic opponent, Ron Varasteh. For the campaign, Walters raised over $2 million.\n\n\n\n\nWalters ran for re-election in 2018. She and Democrat  advanced out of the top-two primary in June 2018. Walters and Porter, a consumer lawyer and  law professor, faced off in the general election on November 6, 2018.\n\t \nIn May 2018, '''' reported that Democrats were confident they would oust Walters, given that in 2016,  had carried the 45th district, writing that Walters had \"backed some of the most polarizing planks of President Donald Trump's agenda\", and that Walters was \"upbeat about surviving the much-predicted Democratic wave\". ''Politico'' noted her support for a popular November ballot referendum. \"The only reason I'm a target is because Hillary Clinton won my district\", said Walters. \"I got 37,000 more votes than President Trump did.\"\n\nIn September 2018, the Congressional Leadership Fund (CLF), the largest Republican super PAC active in U.S. House races, announced a $400,000 ad buy in support of Walters' campaign. In October 2018, the '''' reported that the CLF had not purchased advertisements for Walters in its opening round of broadcast television advertising buys in Southern California. The CLF pushed back on the ''Los Angeles Times'' report, saying they had reserved over $3 million in Walters' district and had begun advertising there in August.\n\nAt the end of election night, Walters was in the lead, but over the following days, Porter gained votes and eventually overtook Walters as more ballots were counted. In fund-raising e-mails sent to supporters, Walters made unsubstantiated claims of fraud, alleging that Democrats were seeking to \"steal\" her seat by tampering with votes.\n\nOn November 15, 2018, the  called the race for Porter.\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n**\n*''''''\n*\n**\n**\n**\n* ''''''\n* ''''''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n election, 2016\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n election, 2018\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nThe  gave Walters an 89% evaluation in 2017.\n\n\nWalters opposed abortion, but had de-emphasized the issue during her political campaigns. In 2015, during her freshman term, she served on the Select Panel to Investigate .\n\n\n\nWalters had a \"D\" rating from the , an advocacy group supporting the legalization of marijuana.\n\n\nIn July 2016, '''' labeled Walters an \"Eager Unifier\", for having endorsed Trump wholeheartedly, but not until after the Indiana primary.\n\nIn February 2017, Walters voted against a resolution that would have directed the House to request 10 years of Trump's tax returns, which would then have been reviewed by the  in a closed session.\n\n had found that Walters voted with President Trump 99% of the time, and was the eighth-most partisan Trump supporter in the House, when compared to her district's voting patterns., accessed September 25, 2018\n\n\nIn November 2017, Walters voted in favor of the , the house version of the Republican Party's tax reform bill. The House bill removed state and local tax breaks that many Californians used, such as the mortgage interest deduction. Several House Republicans representing Californian districts voted against the legislation because it raised taxes on Californians. Walters said after the vote that she had received assurances from House Speaker Paul Ryan that a  would restore the lost tax breaks that had been removed in the House version. According to the '''', immediately after the vote, the Senate version of the bill \"contains even deeper cuts to state and local tax breaks that are popular with California's, but maintains the mortgage interest deduction at its current level, instead of cutting it in half, as the House plan does. It also repeals Obamacare's individual mandate, a move that could further complicate the situation for California members who represent districts with a lot of Obamacare enrollees.\"\n\n\nIn 2015, Walters sponsored and voted for H.R. 1732, a bill that opposed the , which expands the federal government's jurisdiction to regulate waters and certain adjacent lands.\n\nAlso in 2015, Walters voted to repeal the limits on carbon dioxide emissions from power plants set by the . \"Forcing a shift away from traditional energy resources\", she explained, \"would ultimately stifle the economy for years to come and harm consumers' pocketbooks.\" Walters also co-sponsored the Stopping EPA Overreach Act of 2017, which became law, and which declares that there is no legal requirement to regulate global warming.\n\nWalters was originally a , but she began to shift her views after meeting with the Orange County Central chapter of the Citizens' Climate Lobby in 2014. After they explained to her how the market-based approach of  could have a positive impact on the climate, without expanding government, Walters replied, \"You guys are doing it the right way\". In July 2017, Walters voted to veto the Perry Amendment, which would have de-funded Defense Department efforts to track climate change and its threats to military bases.\n\nIn October 2017, after President Trump pulled out of the , \"Walters officially changed from a climate-change  to a believer ... and joined the Congressional \".\n\n\nWalters supported the repeal of Obamacare, and voted in 2015 for H.R. 596, the House bill to repeal Obamacare. She also voted for H.R. 3762, the Restoring Americans' Healthcare Freedom Reconciliation Act, which would have repealed Obamacare.\n\nWalters supported repealing and replacing the  (known as ) with the , the GOP's replacement plan for Obamacare, which did not come to a vote initially. She said that passing the American Health Care Act \"is a critical step\" towards the goal of rescuing \"this failing health-care system\".\n\nOn May 4, 2017, Walters voted to repeal the  (Obamacare) and pass the . In early 2017, Walters tweeted that she was \"committed to protecting patients w/ pre-existing conditions to ensure their access to quality, affordable health care\". However, '''' noted that the version of the  that she voted in favor of allows insurance companies to charge higher premiums to individuals with pre-existing conditions (such as cancer, epilepsy, diabetes, and pregnancy). Walters was an original co-sponsor of H.R. 4684, the Access to Quality Sober Living Act, which would require the Department of Health and Human Services to establish best practices for sober living facilities for opioid addicts. This legislation was written after a subcommittee hearing exposed scams at such facilities.\n\n\nA May 2018 profile of Walters referred to her long-time \"reputation as a gun-rights advocate\". In the State Assembly, \"she twice voted against bills requiring the micro-stamping of bullets from automatic firearms\", against \"background checks for ammunition buyers\", against a ban on \"large-capacity conversion kits\", and against \"prohibiting people under domestic violence restraining orders from obtaining firearms\". But during her years in the House, \"California voters' concerns about school shootings had risen dramatically, with 73 percent of respondents admitting they were worried about a mass shooting at their public school\", with high-school students in Walters's district holding .\n\n\nWalters voted in support of the  Act (H.R. 3) in 2015.\n\n\nAs an Assemblywoman, Walters endorsed , which declared same-sex marriage illegal in the state of California. Then-Minority Whip  (D-MD) named Walters as one of seven Republican representatives who switched their votes regarding a bill upholding an executive order prohibiting defense contractors from discriminating against people based on their sexual orientation. The identities of the seven vote-switchers were not publicly recorded, and none of those named by Hoyer confirmed his claims.  reported that, under shouts of \"shame\", Walters voted against this protection, which ended up narrowly failing.\n\n\nIn January 2018, Walters voted for H.R. 695, the 2018 , saying that she had acted to \"fully fund the Department of Defense to ensure our men and women in uniform have the tools and resources they need to keep our country safe... It is imperative our armed forces are properly equipped and ready to meet current and future challenges.\"\n\n\nIn March 2018, Walters signed a bi-partisan letter in support of funding to re-start the licensing process for the . \"Just south of California's 45th district\", she stated, \"1,800 tons of spent nuclear fuel sits at the inactive  (SONGS). Unfortunately, our Nation's nuclear waste management system is broken, and spent fuel sits at nuclear sites like Songs, with nowhere to go. By law, the Federal government is obligated to take ownership of, and safely store, spent fuel at a permanent repository.\"\n\n\nIn 2014, Walters voted for a bill in committee that banned public transit workers from going on strike.\n\n\nIn February 2018, the House passed H.R. 1865, the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act (FOSTA), introduced by Walters,  (R-Missouri), and  (D-New York). It included an amendment written by Walters that would permit enforcement of criminal and civil sex trafficking laws against websites that facilitate online sex trafficking. The amended legislation passed with bi-partisan support.\n\n\nWalters is married, and has four children. In 2010, financial disclosure forms showed that Mimi Walters' holdings include between $100,000 and $1 million in . A 2017 congressional financial disclosure form showed Walters' had holdings in Boustead Securities, Laguna Advisory Services, and an  in . Walters is a .\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n \n| birth_name          = Charles Michael Calderon\n| birth_date          = \n| birth_place         = , , U.S.\n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = \n| party               = \n| spouse              = \n| children            = 3, including \n| relatives           =  (brother) (brother)\n| education           =  () ()\n| occupation          = \n| profession          = \n| religion            = \n| signature           = \n| website             = \n| footnotes           = \n}}\n\n'''Charles Michael Calderon''' (born March 12, 1950) is an American attorney and politician who served in both chambers of the .\n\n\nCalderon was born on March 12, 1950, in . He graduated from  and earned a J.D. degree from the .\n\n\nPrior to his 1982 election to the assembly, Calderon was a prosecutor and also served on the Montebello School Board.\n\nCalderon was first elected to the assembly in 1982. In 1988–89, he became leader of a power struggle for control of the assembly. The \"Gang of Five\", included Calderon, ,  of Chula Vista,  of Rialto, and  of Los Banos. Self-identified conservative Democrats, the group attempted to wrest power from , then Speaker of the assembly. Calderon was nominated for the office of Speaker, but Brown prevailed by a vote of 40–34. Brown stripped all five members of committee leadership positions and staff.\n\nIn 1990, Calderon left the assembly, and he was elected to the . From September 1996 until the end of his term, Calderon served as the first Hispanic Senate Majority leader in California history. He ran unsuccessfully for  in 1998, losing the primary to . Prior to his 2006 election to the assembly, he served as California Health Care Commissioner and was a partner with the  of Nossaman. During his second term in the Assembly he served as Majority Leader between  2010 and 2012.\n\n\nHis brothers  and  have both served in the state assembly. Ronald held Charles's former Senate seat until 2014; Thomas has been out of the legislature since an unsuccessful run for insurance commissioner in 2002.\n\nCalderon and his wife, , have three children. Calderon's son, , served in the state assembly from 2012 to 2020, representing the . Lisa won Ian's assembly seat in 2020.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
