    "pages": }\n| order4              = 38th\n| office4             = Mayor of San Francisco\n| term_start4         = November 27, 1978\n| term_end4           = January 8, 1988\n| predecessor4        = \n| successor4          = \n| office5             = \n| term_start5         = January 9, 1978\n| term_end5           = December 4, 1978\n| predecessor5        = \n| successor5          = John Molinari\n| term_start6         = January 8, 1974\n| term_end6           = January 8, 1975\n| predecessor6        = \n| successor6          = Quentin L. Kopp\n| term_start7         = January 8, 1970\n| term_end7           = January 8, 1971\n| predecessor7        = John A. Ertola\n| successor7          = Ron Pelosi\n| office8             = \n| term_start8         = January 8, 1970\n| term_end8           = December 4, 1978\n| predecessor8        = William Blake\n| successor8          = \n| constituency8       = \n| birth_name          = Dianne Emiel Goldman\n| birth_date          = \n| birth_place         = San Francisco, California, U.S.\n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = Washington, D.C., U.S.\n| resting_place       = , \n| party               = \n| spouse              = |}\n| children            = \n| father              = \n| education           =  ()\n| signature           = Dianne Feinstein Signature.svg\n| module              = \n}}\n'''Dianne Emiel Feinstein'''}} (; June 22, 1933&nbsp;– September 29, 2023) was an American politician who served as a  from 1992 until her death in 2023. A member of the , she served as  from 1978 to 1988.\n\nA San Francisco native, Feinstein graduated from  in 1955. She was elected to the  in 1969 and immediately became the board's first female president upon her appointment in 1970. In 1978, during a third stint as the board's president,  of Mayor  and City Supervisor  drew national attention. Feinstein succeeded Moscone as mayor and became the first woman to serve in that position. During , she led the renovation of  and oversaw the . Despite a , Feinstein was a popular mayor and was named the most effective mayor in the country by '''' in 1987.\n\nAfter losing a , Feinstein was elected to the  in a . In November 1992, she became California's first female U.S. senator; shortly afterward, she became the state's  when  retired in January 1993. Feinstein was reelected five times. In the , she received 7.86&nbsp;million votes, the most  received by any U.S. Senate candidate in history.\n\nAs a senator, Feinstein authored the 1994 , was the first woman to chair the  and the , and was the first woman to preside over . She chaired the Senate Intelligence Committee from 2009 to 2015 and was the  of the  from 2017 to 2021.\n\nFeinstein's last years in office were marred by poor health and concerns about her mental acuity to serve. In February 2023, Feinstein announced she would not seek reelection . Seven months later, she died in office at the age of 90. By the time of her death, Feinstein was the oldest sitting U.S. senator and member of Congress. She was also the longest-serving U.S. senator from California and the longest-tenured female senator in history.\n\n\n\nFeinstein was born Dianne Emiel Goldman on June 22, 1933, in San Francisco to , a prominent surgeon, and his wife, Betty (née Rosenburg), a former model. Her paternal grandparents were . Her maternal grandparents, the Rosenburgs, were from , Russia. (The  policy restricted Jews to living in specifically designated parts of . They were excluded from living in the main Russian cities.) Although they were of German-Jewish ancestry, they practiced the  faith, as  of . Christianity was passed down to Feinstein's mother, who insisted on her transfer from a  to a prestigious local Catholic school, but Feinstein listed her religion as Judaism.\n\nShe graduated from  in 1951 and from  in 1955 with a Bachelor of Arts in history. According to multiple sources, Feinstein's mother was abusive. Feinstein's sister, Yvonne Banks, said their mother had unpredictable moods. Later, Feinstein's mother received a brain scan that found that the part of her brain responsible for judgment had , \"possibly because of complications from a severe illness as a child\".\n\n\n is standing behind her.)|left|thumb|upright=0.68]]\nFrom 1955 to 1956, Feinstein was a fellow at the  in San Francisco, an organization that provides young people with political experience. Governor  appointed her to the California Women's Parole Board in 1960. She served on the board until 1966.\n\n\nFeinstein was elected to the  in 1969. She remained on the board for nine years, serving as its first female president from 1970 to 1971, with additional tenures from 1974 to 1975 and January to December 1978.\n\nDuring her tenure on the Board of Supervisors, she unsuccessfully ran for mayor of San Francisco twice, in  against Mayor , and in , when she lost the contest for a runoff slot (against ) to Supervisor .\n\nBecause of her position, Feinstein became a target of the , an  terrorist group that carried out bombings in California in the 1970s. In 1976, the NWLF placed a bomb on the windowsill of her home that failed to explode. The group later shot out the windows of a beach house she owned.\n\n\n\n\nAfter San Francisco Mayor  and Supervisor  were  by former Supervisor  on November 27, 1978, Feinstein became acting mayor, as she was president of the . Supervisors John Molinari, , , Robert Gonzales, and  endorsed her for an appointment as mayor by the Board of Supervisors. Gonzales initially ran to be appointed by the Board of Supervisors as mayor, but dropped out. The Board of Supervisors voted six to two to appoint Feinstein as mayor. She was inaugurated by Chief Justice  of the  on December 4, 1978, becoming San Francisco's first female mayor. Molinari was selected to replace Feinstein as president of the Board of Supervisors by a vote of eight to two.\n in San Francisco during her tenure as mayor, 1978–1988]]\nOne of Feinstein's first challenges as mayor was the state of the , which was shut down for emergency repairs in 1979; an engineering study concluded that it needed comprehensive rebuilding at a cost of $60&nbsp;million. Feinstein helped win federal funding for the bulk of the work. The system closed for rebuilding in 1982 and was completed in time for the . Feinstein also oversaw policies to increase the number of San Francisco's high-rise buildings.\n\nFeinstein was seen as a relatively moderate Democrat in one of the country's most liberal cities. As a supervisor, she was considered part of the centrist bloc that included White and generally opposed Moscone. As mayor, Feinstein angered the city's large gay community in 1982 by vetoing legislation which would have extended city-employee benefits to . In the , while a majority of  Democrats continued to support Senator 's  to President  even after it was clear Kennedy could not win, Feinstein strongly supported the Carter– ticket. She was given a high-profile speaking role on the opening night of the August , urging delegates to reject the Kennedy s' proposal to \"open\" the convention, thereby allowing delegates to ignore their states' popular vote, a proposal that was soundly defeated.\n\nIn the run-up to the 1984 Democratic National Convention, there was considerable media and public speculation that Mondale might pick Feinstein as his running mate. He chose  instead. In 1982, Feinstein proposed banning handguns in San Francisco, and became subject to a  attempt organized by the . She won  and finished her second term as mayor on January 8, 1988.\n\nFeinstein revealed sensitive details about the hunt for   at a 1985 press conference, antagonizing detectives by publicizing details of his crimes known only to law enforcement, and thus jeopardizing their investigation.\n\n'''' magazine named Feinstein the nation's \"Most Effective Mayor\" in 1987. She was a member of the  in 1988.\n\n\nFeinstein made an  for  in 1990. She won the Democratic nomination, but lost the general election to U.S. Senator , who resigned from the Senate to assume the governorship. In 1992, Feinstein was fined $190,000 for failure to properly report campaign contributions and expenditures in that campaign.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1991, Wilson resigned from the Senate to take office as governor of California. Feinstein ran for U.S. Senate in a 1992 special election to complete Wilson's term. In the Democratic primary, she defeated Joseph Alioto and  . In November, she faced Republican , whom Wilson had appointed to the Senate the previous year. Feinstein won the November 3 special election, 54.3%–38%.\n\nLike Feinstein,  was first elected to the Senate on November 3, 1992. Because Feinstein was elected to complete an unexpired term, she was sworn in as a senator in November 1992, while Boxer did not take office until January 1993; therefore, Feinstein became California's . She also became the first female Jewish U.S. senator. Feinstein and Boxer were the first female pair of U.S. senators to represent any state at the same time.\n\nFeinstein was reelected in , , , , and .\n\nIn October 2017, Feinstein declared her intention to run for reelection in 2018. She lost the endorsement of the 's executive board, which opted to support  . Nevertheless, Feinstein finished first in the state's \"\" and was reelected in the , defeating de Leon, 54.2–45.8%.\n\n\nFeinstein has been described as \"a titan of US political history who notched countless legislative achievements\" in her Senate career. She was known for her work on gun control issues. In 1994, she spearheaded the passage of a federal assault weapons ban. In the 2000s and 2010s, she investigated \"the Central Intelligence Agency's program of detention and interrogation after the Sept. 11 attacks\".\n\nIn 2009, Feinstein chaired the first inaugural ceremony of President . She was the first woman to chair the  (2007–2009) and the first to chair the  (2009–2015). Feinstein became the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee in 2017, and was the first woman to hold that position. On March 28, 2021, she became the longest-serving U.S. senator from California ever, surpassing . On November 5, 2022, Feinstein became the longest-serving female senator in U.S. history.\n\nIn the fall of 2020, media reports indicated that Feinstein was experiencing cognitive decline and short-term memory loss. She responded that there was no cause for concern and that she had no plans to leave the Senate. After her performance at 's October 2020 Supreme Court nomination hearings was criticized, Feinstein did not seek to chair the Senate Judiciary Committee or serve as its ranking member in 2021. Articles in '''' and '''' cited unnamed Democratic senators and aides expressing concern over her age and ability to lead the committee. In mid-2022,  and other outlets ran stories questioning Feinstein's cognition. On October 22, 2022, Feinstein said that due to family matters, she was not interested in serving as  in 2023; the position is traditionally held by the senior member of the Senate's majority party.\n\nIn February 2023, Feinstein said she would not seek reelection in 2024 and that she intended to retire upon the completion of her term.\n\nFeinstein's two-month hospitalization for  in early 2023 effectively stalled many of the 's judicial and executive nominees. Feinstein served on the , which was evenly split between Democrats and Republicans without her. Representatives , , and , along with a group of California progressive organizations and the '''' editorial board, publicly urged Feinstein to resign. She resisted calls to resign. However, she requested temporary removal from the Judiciary Committee; Senate Republicans declined this request.\n\nFeinstein returned to the Senate on May 10, 2023, amid continuing concern about her capacity to serve.\n\n\nFeinstein was the first woman to chair the  (2007–2009) and the first to chair the  (2009–2015). She became the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee in 2017, and was the first woman to hold that position. Her committee assignments for the 118th Congress were as follows:\n* \n** \n** \n** \n**  (Chair)\n** \n** \n* }}\n**  (Chair)\n** \n** \n** \n* \n* \nShe previously sat on the  (104th Congress) and  (107th–109th Congress)\n\n\n* \n* \n*  (defunct)\n\n\n\n and California Governor , October 25, 2007]]\nIn 2018, the '''' wrote that Feinstein had emphasized her centrism when she first ran for statewide offices in the 1990s (when California was more conservative than it became during Feinstein's later career). Over time, she moved leftward as California became one of the most Democratic states in the nation. In 2013, ''The New York Times'' called her a \"liberal lioness\". Feinstein was known for her advocacy of gun control, abortion access, environmental protection, and a strong national defense.\n\n\nFeinstein supported  during her Senate career. In 2003, she voted against the , a proposal to ban , although the proposal eventually became law. After the Supreme Court overturned '''' in 2022, Feinstein called for congressional action to protect abortion rights and stated her support for lifting the Senate filibuster rule to allow such legislation to pass with a simple majority.\n\n\n]]When Feinstein first ran for statewide office in 1990, she supported . In 2004, she called for the death penalty in the case of San Francisco police officer Isaac Espinoza, who was killed while on duty. By 2018, she opposed capital punishment.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2007, Feinstein led a bipartisan effort as part of the wider  to significantly reduce automotive greenhouse gas emissions, which accounted for 26 percent of total U.S. emissions at the time. Her legislation, the Ten-in-Ten Fuel Economy Act, raised  standards for America's fleet of vehicles by at least 10 miles per gallon between 2010 and 2020 - the largest increase in fuel efficiency in almost three decades. Thereafter, said CAFE standards became subject to periodic adjustments by the  under the . As a result of Feinstein's legislation, average fleet fuel economy for new automobiles will climb to approximately 60 miles per gallon by 2032, cutting greenhouse gas emissions from passenger and commercial vehicles in half without impeding automotive performance or degrading traffic safety.\n\nDuring the , Feinstein authored an amendment to the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2008, mandating all major sources of greenhouse gasses to annually report their emissions to the .}} These emissions disclosures in turn inform EPA's nationwide, multi-sector inventory of greenhouse gas emissions and sinks, which is submitted to the United Nations in accordance with the .\n\nFeinstein co-sponsored (with  Republican ) an amendment through the Senate to the Economic Development Revitalization Act of 2011 that eliminated the Volumetric Ethanol Excise Tax Credit. The Senate passed the amendment on June 16, 2011. Introduced in 2004, the subsidy provided a 45-cent-per-gallon credit on pure ethanol, and a 54-cent-per-gallon tariff on imported ethanol. These subsidies had resulted in an annual expenditure of $6&nbsp;billion.\n\nIn February 2019, when youth associated with the  confronted Feinstein about why she did not support the , she told them, \"there's no way to pay for it\", and that it could not pass a Republican-controlled Senate. In a tweet after the confrontation, she said that she remained committed \"to enact real, meaningful climate change legislation\". Conversely, the Sunrise Movement tweeted that Feinstein had reacted with \"smugness and disrespect\", and that \"her reaction is why young people desperately want new leadership in Congress.\"\n\nLater in the  and es, Feinstein authored the Addressing Climate Financial Risk Act, to prepare U.S.  for risks posed by climate change. While Feinstein's bill ultimately died in the Senate,  issued an executive order containing several of its provisions, including directing the  to study climate-related financial risks. In addition, Feinstein co-sponsored with  the Climate Action Rebate Act of 2019 - legislation that would create a nationwide  program to decarbonize the American economy and transition it to . As with the Addressing Climate Financial Risk Act, the Climate Action Rebate Act also failed to make it out of committee. However, a separate battery storage tax credit bill co-sponsored by Feinstein was ultimately incorporated into the , legislation she also supported.\n\n\nFeinstein, who spent her childhood visiting the lake, regarded  as \"a national treasure\" and \"the Jewel of the High Sierra\". She founded the Lake Tahoe Summit in 1997 and successfully authored the landmark Lake Tahoe Restoration Act of 2000. This act of Congress formally created the  within the  and authorized $900&nbsp;million in federal spending over ten years for invasive species control, stormwater management, environmental protection, and fire risk mitigation projects throughout the Lake Tahoe watershed. Later in 2016, Feinstein co-sponsored with senators , , and  a bipartisan seven-year extension of the Lake Tahoe Restoration Act, authorizing another $415&nbsp;million to combat invasive species, improve water quality and forest health, restore habitat for fish and wildlife, and reduce the threat of catastrophic wildfires. She co-sponsored a second bipartisan, bicameral reauthorization of the Lake Tahoe Restoration Act's activities with senators , , and  on March 1, 2023 – six months before her death.\n\n\nFeinstein co-sponsored legislation in 2006 with  that permanently protected approximately 300,000 acres of wilderness in Northern California, namely the King Range, Yolla-Bolly Middle Eel, and Trinity Alps wilderness areas, along with 21 miles of the  in Mendocino County. The , part of the , has the longest stretch of undeveloped coastline anywhere in the lower 48 states; its  is often considered the \"crown jewel\" in the . The Yolla-Bolly Middle Eel Wilderness, which surrounds the , hosts roughly half of California's summer-run  population. The river is the largest remaining wild run of these fish in the lower 48 states. The  encompasses rugged mountains, alpine meadows, myriad pristine lakes and streams, 550 miles of maintained hiking trails, and California's third-largest swath of previously unprotected old-growth, predominantly  forest.\n\nFeinstein also helped secure $250&nbsp;million in federal matching grants to purchase the 7,500-acre Headwaters Forest, the world's last unprotected, intact, old-growth  forest. Her 1999 legislation also guaranteed the continued conservation of 12 ancient redwood groves by bringing them under federal management. Several  call the Headwaters Forest home, including , the , and the . The resulting  is managed by the  in partnership with the  as part of the National Landscape Conservation System.\n\nPerhaps Feinstein's greatest contribution to public lands conservation came through her advocacy for California's  and s. She authored landmark legislation in 1994 that established , , and , and designated another 7.6&nbsp;million acres of California desert as federal wilderness. This  was followed in 2000 by Feinstein's Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains National Monument Act, designating 272,000 acres in the Santa Rosa and San Jacinto mountain ranges as a . Later in 2016, Feinstein requested  create , , and  national monuments under the . She also authored the California Desert Protection and Recreation Act as part of the  passed in 2019, furthering landscape conservation and outdoor recreation opportunities in the California desert. The combined acreage of the 1994, 2000, and 2019 acts of Congress, in concert with the presidentially authorized national monument designations, protect the largest tract of public lands anywhere in the lower 48 states and the second-largest desert preserve on the planet.\n\n\n\nFeinstein supported a conciliatory approach between  and fostered increased dialogue between high-level Chinese representatives and U.S. senators during her first term as senator. When asked about her relation with Beijing, Feinstein said, \"I sometimes say that in my last life maybe I was Chinese.\"\n\nFeinstein criticized Beijing's missile tests near Taiwan and called for dismantlement of missiles pointed at the island. She promoted stronger business ties between China and Taiwan over confrontation, and suggested that the U.S. patiently \"use two-way trade across Taiwan Strait as a platform for more political dialogue and closer ties\".\n\nShe believed that deeper cross-strait economic integration \"will one day lead to political integration and will ultimately provide the solution\" to the .\n\nOn July 27, 2018, reports surfaced that a Chinese staff member who worked for 20 years as Feinstein's personal driver, gofer and liaison to the Asian-American community was caught reporting to China's . According to the reports, the  had contacted Feinstein five years earlier warning her about the employee. The employee was later interviewed by authorities and forced to retire by Feinstein. No criminal charges were filed against him.\n\n\nFeinstein supported the  in July 2015, saying that it would usher in \"unprecedented & intrusive inspections to verify cooperation\" by Iran.\n\nOn June 7, 2017, Feinstein and Senator  issued dual statements urging the Senate to forgo a vote for sanctions on Iran in response to the  that occurred earlier in the day.\n\n\n\nFeinstein voted for the  and later said she regretted it.\n\n\nIn September 2016in advance of  condemning s in the occupied Feinstein signed an -sponsored letter urging Obama to veto \"one-sided\" resolutions against Israel.\n\nFeinstein opposed President 's decision to , saying, \"Recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capitalor relocating our embassy to Jerusalemwill spark violence and embolden extremists on both sides of the debate.\"\n\n\nDuring a July 2017 appearance on '''' after  of an , Feinstein said the country had proven itself a danger to the U.S. She also expressed her disappointment with China's lack of response.\n\nResponding to reports that North Korea had achieved successful miniaturization of , Feinstein issued an August 8, 2017, statement insisting that isolation of North Korea had proven ineffective and that Trump's rhetoric was not helping resolve potential conflict. She also called for the U.S. to \"quickly engage North Korea in a high-level dialogue without any preconditions\".\n\nIn September 2017, after Trump's first speech to the United Nations General Assembly, in which he threatened North Korea, Feinstein released a statement disagreeing with his remarks: \"Trump's bombastic threat to destroy North Korea and his refusal to present any positive pathways forward on the many global challenges we face are severe disappointments.\"\n\n\n (left) with U.S. Senator Dianne Feinstein (middle) and San Francisco Mayor  (right) in 2007]]\nFeinstein introduced the , which became law in 1994 and expired in 2004. In January 2013, about a month after the , she and Representative  proposed a bill that would \"ban the sale, transfer, manufacturing or importation of 150 specific firearms including semiautomatic rifles or pistols that can be used with a detachable or fixed ammunition magazines that hold more than 10 rounds and have specific military-style features, including pistol grips, grenade launchers or rocket launchers\". The bill would have exempted 900 models of guns used for sport and hunting. Feinstein said of the bill, \"The common thread in each of these shootings is the gunman used a semi-automatic assault weapon or large-capacity ammunition magazines. Military assault weapons only have one purpose, and in my opinion, it's for the military.\" The bill failed on a Senate vote of 60 to 40.\n\n\nFeinstein supported the , repeatedly voting to defeat initiatives aimed against it. She voted to regulate tobacco as a drug; expand the Children's Health Insurance Program; override the president's veto of adding 2 to 4 million children to  eligibility; increase Medicaid rebate for producing s; negotiate bulk purchases for Medicare prescription drugs; allow re-importation of prescription drugs from Canada; allow patients to sue s and collect s; cover prescription drugs under Medicare, and  Medicare. She voted against the  's Medicare choice, tax and spending cuts; and allowing tribal Indians to opt out of federal healthcare. Feinstein also favored the creation of a  to achieve , co-sponsoring a bill with that aim. Feinstein's congressional voting record was rated as 88% by the  (APHA), the figure ostensibly reflecting the percentage of time the representative voted the organization's preferred position.\n\nAt an April 2017 town hall meeting in San Francisco, Feinstein was booed when she stated that she did not support a proposal for single-payer health insurance. Feinstein said, \"[i]f  health care is going to mean the complete takeover by the government of all health care, I am not there.\" During a news conference at the  in July 2017, she estimated that Democratic opposition would prove sufficient to defeat Republican attempts to repeal the ACA. Feinstein wrote in an August 2017 op-ed that Trump could secure health-care reform if he compromised with Democrats: \"We now know that such a closed process on a major issue like health care doesn't work. The only path forward is a transparent process that allows every senator to bring their ideas to the table.\"\n\n\nIn September 2017, after Attorney General  rescinded the  program, Feinstein admitted the legality of the program was questionable while citing this as a reason for why a law should be passed. In her opening remarks at a January 2018 Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, she said she was concerned the Trump administration's decision to terminate  might be racially motivated, based on comments Trump made denigrating , , and .\n\n\nIn 1996, Feinstein was one of only 14 senators to vote against the  (DOMA), which defined marriage as an  union for purposes of federal law. In 2011, she introduced a bill to repeal DOMA. In 2022, she was the lead Senate sponsor of the , which repealed DOMA and required the federal government and all state governments to recognize  and s.\n\n\nFeinstein opposed a number of reforms to  at the state and federal level. In 2016 she opposed , the Adult Use of Marijuana Act, to  in California. In 1996 she opposed  to legalize the  in California. In 2015 she was the only Democrat at a Senate hearing to vote against the , legislation that limits the enforcement of federal law in states that have legalized medical cannabis. Feinstein cited her belief that cannabis is a  in voting against the amendment.\n\nIn 2018, Feinstein softened her views on marijuana and cosponsored the , legislation that would protect states from federal interference regarding both medical and recreational use. She also supported legislation in 2015 to allow medical cannabis to be recommended to s in states where its use is legal.\n\n\n\nWhile delivering the commencement address at Stanford Stadium on June 13, 1994, Feinstein said:\n\n}}\n\nFeinstein was described during her lifetime as a  on matters of national security. She voted for the extension of the  and the  provisions in 2012. Feinstein also voted for President Trump's $675-billion  for FY 2019. Later in 2017, she criticized the banning of  enlistments in the military under the Trump administration.\n\n\nFeinstein co-sponsored  on May 12, 2011. She met with representatives of technology companies, including Google and Facebook, in January 2012. A Feinstein spokesperson said she \"is doing all she can to ensure that the bill is balanced and protects the intellectual property concerns of the content community without unfairly burdening legitimate businesses such as Internet search engines\".\n\nFollowing her 2012 vote to extend the  and the  provisions, and after the  involving the  (NSA), Feinstein promoted and supported measures to continue the information collection programs. Feinstein and  also defended the NSA's request to  for all the  about phone calls made within the U.S. and from the U.S. to other countries. They said the information gathered by intelligence on the phone communications is used to connect phone lines to terrorists and that it did not contain the content of the phone calls or messages. '''' wrote that she had a \"reputation as a staunch defender of NSA practices and [of] the White House's refusal to stand by collection activities targeting foreign leaders\".\n\nIn October 2013, Feinstein criticized the NSA for monitoring telephone calls of foreign leaders friendly to the U.S. In November 2013, she promoted the FISA Improvements Act bill, which included a \"backdoor search provision\" that allows intelligence agencies to continue certain  searches as long as they are logged and \"available for review\" to various agencies.\n\nIn June 2013, Feinstein called  a \"traitor\" after his leaks went public. In October 2013, she said she stood by that.\n\nIn 2014, Feinstein accused the  of snooping and removing files from congressional computers, saying that the \"CIA's search may well have violated the separation of powers principles embodied in the United States Constitution\". Several months later the CIA admitted to having hacked Senate Intelligence Committee computers. Feinstein's displeasure at having been spied on was contrasted with her support for government surveillance of US citizens, with public figures and privacy advocates such as  and Edward Snowden noting the apparent incongruity.\n\nAfter the 2016 , Feinstein and  sponsored a bill that would likely have criminalized all forms of  in electronic communication between citizens. The bill would have required technology companies to design their encryption so that they can provide law enforcement with user data in an \"intelligible format\" when required to do so by court order.\n\nIn 2020, Feinstein co sponsored the , which seeks to create a 19-member committee to decide a list of best practices websites must follow to be protected by section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The EARN IT Act effectively outlaws end-to-end encryption, depriving the world of secure, private communications tools.\n\n\nFeinstein served on the , her time on the committee coinciding with the  and the debates on the  of terrorists and alleged terrorists. On the Senate floor on December 9, 2014, the day parts of the  were released to the public, Feinstein called the government's detention and interrogation program a \"stain on our values and on our history\".\n\n\nDuring the , Feinstein served on President 's steering committee in California and as a Carter delegate to the . She was selected to serve as one of the four chairs of the 1980 Democratic National Convention.\n\nFeinstein endorsed former Vice President  during the . She and  chairman  signed a contract in 1983, making San Francisco the host of the .\n\nAs a  in the , Feinstein said she would support Clinton for the nomination. But after  became the presumptive nominee, she fully backed his candidacy. Days after Obama amassed enough delegates to win the nomination, Feinstein lent her Washington, D.C., home to Clinton and Obama for a private one-on-one meeting. She did not attend the  in  because she had fallen and broken her ankle earlier in the month.\n\n (center left) in 2017]]Feinstein chaired the  and acted as mistress of ceremonies, introducing each participant at the . She was the first woman to have presided over a U.S. presidential inauguration.\n\nAhead of the , Feinstein was one of 16 female Democratic senators to sign an October 20, 2013, letter endorsing  for president.\n\nAt an August 29, 2017, event in San Francisco, Feinstein expressed hope that Trump could become a good president. \"The question is whether he can learn and change\", she said. \"If so, I believe he can be a good president\". The next day, Feinstein released a clarifying statement: \"I've been strongly critical of President Trump when I disagree on policy and with his behavior... While I'm under no illusion that it's likely to happen and will continue to oppose his policies, I want President Trump to change for the good of the country\".\n\nOn January 9, 2018, Feinstein caused a stir when, as ranking member of the , she released a transcript of its August 2017 interview with  co-founder  about the  regarding connections between Trump's campaign and the Russian government. She did this unilaterally after the committee's chairman, , refused to release the transcript.\n\nAs the  approached, Feinstein indicated her support for former Vice President . This came as a surprise to many pundits, due to the potential candidacy of fellow U.S. Senator from California , of whom Feinstein said \"I'm a big fan of Sen. Harris, and I work with her. But she's brand-new here, so it takes a little bit of time to get to know somebody.\"\n\n\n signs the  in the Oval Office, February 2, 2011. Feinstein is standing fourth from right.]]\nIn September 2005, Feinstein was one of five Democratic senators on the Senate Judiciary Committee to vote against Supreme Court nominee , saying that Roberts had \"failed to state his positions on such social controversies as abortion and the right to die\".\n\nIn January 2006, Feinstein said she would vote against Supreme Court nominee , but expressed disapproval of a filibuster: \"When it comes to filibustering a Supreme Court appointment, you really have to have something out there, whether it's gross moral turpitude or something that comes to the surface. This is a man I might disagree with, [but] that doesn't mean he shouldn't be on the court.\"\n\nOn July 12, 2009, Feinstein said the Senate would confirm Supreme Court nominee , praising her for her experience and for overcoming \"adversity and disadvantage\".\n\nAfter President Obama nominated  to the Supreme Court in March 2016, Feinstein met with Garland on April 6 and later called on Republicans to do \"this institution the credit of sitting down and meeting with him\".\n\nIn February 2017, Feinstein requested that Supreme Court nominee  provide information on cases in which he had assisted with decision-making. In mid-March, she sent him a letter saying her request had not been met. Feinstein stated her opposition to Gorsuch's nomination on April 3.\n\nAfter , Feinstein received a July 30, 2018, letter from  in which Ford accused Kavanaugh of having sexually assaulted her in the 1980s. Ford requested that her allegation be kept confidential. Feinstein did not refer the allegation to the FBI until September 14, 2018, after the  had completed its hearings on Kavanaugh's nomination and \"after leaks to the media about [the Ford allegation] had reached a 'fever pitch'\". She faced \"sharp scrutiny\" for her decision to keep quiet about the Ford allegation for several weeks; she responded that she kept the letter and Ford's identity confidential because Ford had requested it. Feinstein opposed Kavanaugh's nomination. After an additional hearing and a supplemental FBI investigation, Kavanaugh was confirmed to the Supreme Court on October 6, 2018.\n\n, , and  to discuss school and community safety in the Cabinet Room at the White House, February 28, 2018]]\nIn the fall of 2020, in her capacity as ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Feinstein participated in the confirmation hearings for President Trump's nomination of  to the Supreme Court. Shortly before the 2020 presidential election, Barrett was nominated to the Court following Justice 's death, and the nomination was intensely controversial. Feinstein opposed Barrett's nomination, but at the conclusion of the hearings, she hugged Republican Senator , saying, \"this has been one of the best set of hearings that I've participated in\". Outraged progressives responded by calling for Feinstein to step down from her leadership role on the committee. Barrett was confirmed to the Court. After the hearings, Senate Minority Leader  said he had had a \"long and serious\" talk with Feinstein. After the 2020 election, Feinstein announced that she would not seek to serve as chair or as ranking member of the Judiciary Committee in 2021.\n\n\nFeinstein was awarded the honorary degree of  from  in San Francisco on June 4, 1977. She was awarded the  by France in 1984. Feinstein received with the  for public service from the  of the Smithsonian Institution on November 3, 2001, in Los Angeles. In 2002, Feinstein won the American Medical Association's  for \"the Betterment of the Public Health\". She was named as one of '''' 50 in 2015.\n\nIt was announced on January 16, 2024, that the 's International Terminal would be named in honor of Feinstein.\n\n\n\nFeinstein was married three times. She married Jack Berman (), who was then working in the , in 1956. She and Berman divorced three years later. Their daughter,  Mariano (), was the presiding judge of the  for 12 years, through 2012. In 1962, shortly after beginning her career in politics, Feinstein married her second husband,  Bertram Feinstein, who died of colon cancer in 1978. Feinstein was then married to investment banker  from 1980 until his death from cancer in 2022.\n\nIn 2003, Feinstein was ranked the fifth-wealthiest senator, with an estimated  of $26&nbsp;million. Her net worth increased to between $43 and $99&nbsp;million by 2005. Her 347-page financial-disclosure statement, characterized by the '''' as \"nearly the size of a phone book\", claimed to draw clear lines between her assets and her husband's, with many of her assets in s.\n\nFeinstein took up  as a hobby in the 1990s, primarily depicting scenes from nature and s of flowers taken from her gardens. She later made prints from her original pieces for charity auctions and as gifts to Senate colleagues, ambassadors, and other dignitaries. Despite her works being seen as collector's items, Feinstein considered herself merely \"a doodler\".}}\n\n\nFeinstein had an  inserted at  in January 2017.\n\nIn 2020, investigative journalist  reported that it had been evident to some colleagues and staffers for several years that Feinstein was experiencing . Mayer reported that among various short-term memory issues, Feinstein could not remember Chuck Schumer's repeated attempts to convince her to relinquish her leadership of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Stories of Feinstein's cognitive issues continued to circulate in the press for the last few years of her life: in 2022, ''The New York Times'' reported that she struggled to remember her colleagues' names, meetings she had attended, and phone calls she had received. When asked about her, some colleagues and staffers argued that Feinstein was following in the footsteps of , who remained in office with mental infirmity until age 100.\n\nIn March 2023, Feinstein was diagnosed with  and hospitalized. She then suffered complications, including  (which caused swelling in her brain) and  (which caused paralysis on the left side of her face and problems with her balance and eyesight). These complications delayed her return to the Senate. Feinstein, then 89, returned to the Senate floor in early May 2023 after a 10-week absence. At the time, she used a wheelchair and was described as frail and noticeably thinner. Soon after her return, when asked about her absence, Feinstein told reporters: \"I've been here. I've been voting\". This remark raised further questions about her memory.\n\nOn July 17, 2023, Feinstein ceded  to her daughter, Katherine. In August 2023, Feinstein was hospitalized after falling at her home in San Francisco. A spokesperson said it was \"a minor fall\" and Feinstein was subsequently cleared to return home.\n\n\n rotunda where Feinstein's body lay in state]]\nFeinstein died of natural causes at her home in Washington, D.C., on September 29, 2023, at the age of 90. Despite longstanding health problems that had caused her to miss Judiciary Committee meetings for several months, her death was sudden, with Feinstein having cast a vote on the Senate floor the previous day that was needed for Democrats' efforts to .\n\nFeinstein received many tributes from politicians such as  ; Senate Minority Leader ; President ; Vice President , who served with Feinstein during her time in the Senate; former presidents  and ; House Speaker ; former House Speaker ; former Secretary of State, First Lady and Senate colleague ; fellow Senators , , , , , , , , , , and ; Representatives , , and , who were running for the Democratic nomination for Feinstein's Senate seat in the ; and California Governor . \n \nFeinstein's death marked the first time  since  died in 2018 of brain cancer, and the first time in U.S. history that a female senator died in office.\n\nFeinstein  at  on October 4, 2023. A memorial service was held the next day on the front steps of the Hall, and the public was discouraged from attending. At the service, President Biden eulogized Feinstein as \"a great American hero\". Vice President Harris added, \"You helped move the ball forward, and our nation salutes you\". The service was punctuated by  of the , coinciding with San Francisco's . Feinstein was buried between the graves of her two husbands at  in .\n\nOn October 1, 2023, Governor Newsom appointed  to fill Feinstein's vacant Senate seat. He had previously promised to appoint a Black woman in the event of a Senate vacancy. Butler chose not to run for Feinstein's Senate seat in the 2024 election.\n\n\nThe 2019 film '''', about the  investigation into , extensively features Feinstein, portrayed by .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* , co-chair of Feinstein political campaigns\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''George Purdy Radanovich''' (born June 20, 1955) is an American politician and former  for , serving from 1995 to 2011. The district includes most of northern , as well as several rural areas northeast of the city. He did not seek reelection in 2010. He is a member of the .\n\n\nRadanovich was born in  to a Catholic family of  extraction.\n\nHe was educated at , . After college, he performed a variety of jobs, including work as a banker, substitute teacher, and construction worker. He began growing grapes in his native  in 1982, after observing a  in the area suitable for their growth. In 1986, he opened the Radanovich Winery, the first winery in the region. He was a member of the   from 1988 to 1992, serving as chairman in 1991. He first ran for Congress in 1992 after his home in Mariposa was shifted to the 19th District, and lost in the Republican primary to Fresno businessman Tal Cloud.\n\nRadanovich won the Republican primary in 1994. In the general election, Radanovich faced six-term incumbent   in the following November election. Lehman had only defeated Cloud by 1,100 votes in the previous election cycle, and speculation had abounded that the 19th would not stay Democratic for long. Radanovich defeated Lehman by a shocking 17-point margin (56 percent to Lehman's 39 percent). It was one of the largest margins of defeat for an incumbent in a cycle that saw many tenured Democrats lose their seats.\n\nAccording to ''Wine Spectator,'' in 2003 Congressman Radanovich closed ''Radanovich Winery'' due to “the tough economic times currently facing many California wineries, the congressman said on Friday. \"It has been a painful decision,\" said Radanovich, 47. \"The past six months have been some of the most difficult that I've been through.\" ''SFGate'' reported on this as well saying, “Radanovich cited the current wine oversupply situation facing California vintners, the economic situation and his desire to focus on his job in Washington. The winery's tasting room has closed and some winery inventory will be sold to pay outstanding debts.”\n\nIn the 2006 election, Radanovich ran against chemical engineer , who ran unopposed in the Democratic primary. Cox was arguably Radanovich's most serious and well-funded challenger since his 1994 election. However, Michael Der Manouel Jr. commented on Cox's chances for election by saying, \"Cox could spend $10 million and  could spend another $10 million and Congressman Radanovich wouldn't lose.\"  Radanovich was reelected with 60% of the vote in 2006 and was unopposed for reelection in 2008 in what is now considered one of the most Republican districts in California. Cox was later elected to Congress in the 21st district in the 2018 elections.\n\nOn December 29, 2009, Radanovich announced he would not seek reelection in 2010.\n\n\nIn 2022, Radanovich ran for . He was eliminated when he placed third in the primary.  \n\nIn 2024, Radanovich placed first in the primary election for \n\n\n\n.]]\nHe was president of the Republican freshman class of 1994, has signed the Taxpayer Protection Pledge, and is a member of the .\n\n*October 6, 2005: Voted for the Department of Homeland Security.\n*December 14, 2005: Voted to reauthorize the Patriot Act.\n*June 16, 2006: Voted to reject timetables for withdrawal from Iraq.\n*September 29, 2008: Voted for the \"Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008\" (Paulson Bailout Bill).\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n** (Ranking Member)\n**\n\n\n* Water Caucus (Co-Chair)\n* Congressional Wine Caucus (Co-Chair)\n* Congressional Croatian Caucus (Co-Chair)\n\n\nHe was married to Ethie Weaver Radanovich from November 1996 until her death from ovarian cancer on February 4, 2010. They have one son, King.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*Jim Boren, ''The Fresno Bee'', Published on May 25, 1994, p. B3, article 8\n* Jim Boren, ''The Fresno Bee'', February 18, 2006\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''John Taylor Doolittle''' (born October 30, 1950), is an attorney and an  politician. Elected to Congress in 1990, he served as a  member of the  from 1991 to 2009, representing  (numbered as  during his first term). In the , he held a leadership role as the  for the Republican party in the House. He was succeeded in the House of Representatives by . Before being elected to Congress, he had served in the California State Senate from 1984 to 1991.\n\nIn the approach to the 2008 election, Doolittle lost support from previous allies and had difficulty in fundraising. He announced that he would not run again. He had been criticized by opponents for improprieties, including using his wife's one-person firm for his political fundraising, as she based her compensation on a percentage of all funds raised, including from his PAC. She made nearly $180,000 in such commissions from 2001 to 2006. His office did not stop using her firm for fundraising until January 2007.\n\nHe was under investigation from 2006 to 2010 related to alleged financial improprieties. These included his and his wife's business relations with , a prominent   lobbyist who was found to have defrauded numerous clients, including Indian tribes. During this period,  (CREW) listed Doolittle as among the 20 most corrupt congressmen in reports from 2006 to 2009. The US Attorney closed its investigation of Doolittle in 2010 without bringing any charges against him.\n\n\nDoolittle was born in . He grew up in , attending local public schools. He graduated from  in 1968. He graduated with honors with a  in history from the . He earned a  degree from , , in , in 1978.\n\nBefore going to law school, Doolittle spent two years as a missionary in  for , to which he and his family belonged. Doolittle is married to the former Julia (Julie) Harlow. They have a son and daughter.\n\n\nDoolittle entered politics early. Soon after passing the bar, in 1979 Doolittle started work as an aide to California state senator , the conservative founder of  and the Law and Order Campaign Committee. \n\t\nThe next year Doolittle decided to run for the state senate, with encouragement from Richardson and other Republicans. Riding on the coattails of Governor 's victory in the presidential race, in 1980 the 29-year-old Doolittle narrowly defeated incumbent Democrat , dean of the state Senate and chair of the Senate Finance Committee. Doolittle won his seat in the .\n\nIn 1981, the Democratic-dominated state legislature issued a redistricting plan following the 1980 census and congressional reapportionment. It tried to squeeze out Republican lawmakers. The newly drawn district put Doolittle into a predominately Democratic district, where he lost to then-Assemblyman Leroy Greene in 1982 for the state senate. But by a quirk of redistricting rules, Doolittle was able to keep his original seat until 1984. He won another term in the state senate by beating , a Republican turned Independent from .Jeff Kearns,  , ''Sacramento News and Review'', 22 July 2004 An administrative law judge later found Doolittle guilty of violating campaign finance laws because his campaign had contributed to his Democratic opponent in order to pull votes away from Johnson.\n\nDoolittle easily won re-election in 1988. From 1987 to 1990, he was chairman of the state Senate Republican Caucus.\n\n\nIn 1990, Republican , also a Mormon, retired from Congress. In the November general election, Doolittle defeated Patty Malberg, a Democrat from , getting 51% of the vote, in what was then . The district covered much of the northeastern corner of the state, from the northern suburbs of  to the Oregon border.\n\nDoolittle's district was renumbered as  in 1992, following redistricting. He was reelected with 50 percent of the vote, again defeating Malberg. In 1994 he received 60% of the vote and did not face another close race until 2006.\n\n\nIn his first years in Congress, Doolittle was a member of the group known as the , which had a role in exposing the .\n\nDoolittle is a staunch conservative. According to the ''Associated Press'', \"Doolittle is a generally loyal supporter of the Bush administrationthough like many House Republicans he opposes Bush's support for an immigration guest worker program.\" He is in favor of partial privatization of Social Security, saying he would like to see people \"gain ownership over their own funds\". He opposes gun control and abortion rights.\n\nAfter the  had its funding removed in 1995, Doolittle helped revive it as the \"Conservative Action Team.\" He alternated the chairmanship with  of ,  of , and  of  until 1999.\n\nIn November 1997, Doolittle was one of eighteen Republicans in the House to co-sponsor  by  that sought to launch an  against President . The resolution did not specify any charges or allegations. This was an early effort to  Clinton, predating the eruption of the . The eruption of that scandal would ultimately lead to a more serious effort to impeach Clinton in 1998. On October 8, 1998, Doolitte voted in favor of legislation that was passed to open . , Doolittle voted in favor of all four proposed  against Clinton (only two of which received the needed majority of votes to be adopted).\n\nIn January 2006, an opinion piece published in ''The Union'' newspaper, of , quoted Doolittle as saying that \"A liberal front is underway to find God and all things pertaining to him unconstitutional.\"\n\nIn February 2006, Doolittle was praised by the El Dorado Irrigation District for his assistance in obtaining federal funds for  projects.\n\n\n\nDoolittle is known for support of the  project, despite environmental concerns. People who opposed construction of the dam were particularly concerned about the uncertainties of the potential effects of such a dam on  activity in the area. A mid-1990s preliminary  report cited concerns about the potential for s to be caused by that project.\n\nDoolittle's stated reason for supporting the Auburn Dam was for  of . After  in 2005, he portrayed the flooding in  as an example of why the project was needed. Critics replied that the Gulf Coast, with its hurricane season and the torrential rainfalls associated with it, is not a valid comparison to a region of the country that historically often has droughts. They said that  and  dams sufficed to control floods in an intense rainy season. Opponents of the project believe that the proposed Auburn Dam will also accelerate  east of Sacramento and downriver from the proposed dam.  already has one of the highest growth rates in the country, putting strains on local services and infrastructure, and affecting the environment. Opponents also cited other issues, such as destruction of the canyon environment and loss of habitat for wildlife.\n\nIn 1975, the construction of the dam was stopped due to environmental concerns, money issues, and the seismic instability of the proposed dam site. The construction was canceled and the project is abandoned. Much of the preliminary work on the dam can still be seen today. In 2005, Doolittle secured funding for studies to move the project forward.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2002, Doolittle defeated Republican challenger Dr. Bill Kirby of , 78%–22%. In the general election, Doolittle defeated Mark Norberg, 65%-35%, while raising $1,024,986 compared to Norberg's $8,202.\n\n\nIn 2004, Doolittle took in more than $1 million in contributions and received 65% of the vote. His Democratic opponent David Winters raised $2,300; he won 35 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\n\nIn the Republican  on June 6, 2006, Doolittle was challenged for his party's nomination by Mike Holmes, the mayor of Auburn. Doolittle raised more than $1.1 million in campaign contributions, more than 14 times the fund of Holmes. Doolittle won the primary with 67% of the vote.\n\nIn the , Doolittle's Democratic opponent was retired Air Force Lt. Colonel . Doolittle agreed to a single debate, on October 11, 2006. Doolittle defeated Brown, getting 49% of the vote to Brown's 46%. Brown defeated Doolittle in , but narrowly lost , the most populated county in the district, and lost the rest of the district.\n\nIn January 2007, Doolittle announced ten steps he said he would take to re-establish the confidence of the district in his holding office. He announced the planned changes in an op-ed piece he distributed to newspapers in his district, to attempt to gain free publicity about it.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2007, Congress took up the reauthorization of the , which provides health care for about 6 million children and 670,000 adults from families who earn too much money to qualify for Medicare but not enough to afford health insurance. Congressional Democrats and many Republicans tried to expand the coverage of the program to other needy families, but they were opposed by President George W. Bush and other Republicans. In 2006, 5.4 million children were eligible but not enrolled in SCHIP or Medicaid, and 9.4 million total children were uninsured. Such children and their families are often treated in emergency rooms of hospitals, a much more expensive alternative for taxpayers than expanding the SCHIP and similar programs.\n\nJohn Doolittle voted against the first House bill, which passed along party lines. It would have added $47 billion over five years to the $25 billion cost of the program and added about 5 million people to the program, including children, some legal immigrants, pregnant women, and adults aged 18 and 19. The bill was to be financed mainly by an increase in cigarette taxes.\n\nHouse Democrats, with 45 Republicans, later compromised and passed a bill that expanded the plan by $35 billion and would have insured about 3.5 million more children from families generally making between 250% and 300% of the federal poverty line (about $51,000 to $62,000 for a family of four). Most non-pregnant, childless adults were excluded, as were most legal immigrants and all illegal immigrants. Doolittle voted against the bill.\n\nAfter President Bush vetoed the bill, Democratic leaders attempted to override the veto with the same bill but failed. Doolittle voted against the bill.\n\nHouse Democrats attempted to override the veto with a new bill, which acceded to Republican demands for increased checks for citizenship, the quick phasing-out of adult coverage, a hard limit of 300% of the federal poverty level, and funding for families to cover their children through private insurance instead. Angry that the congressional vote was scheduled to proceed despite massive wildfires in California, Republicans blocked the veto override. Doolittle voted with fellow Republicans against the bill.\n\n\nBetween 2005 and 2006, John Doolittle raised a total of $2,354,786 for his political campaign. 65.1% of his finances came from private donors, 34.5% from PACs, and 0.3% from other various sources. 54.3% of the PAC contributions came from business organizations while the other 45.7% came from labor and ideological groups. At the end of his 2005–2006 political campaign, 98.4% of his finances were completely disclosed. According to the FEC (), John Doolittle raised a total of $278,142 in that year.\n\n\nDoolittle was investigated by the US Attorney for issues related to his campaign financing and reporting, beginning in 2006. He and his wife both had business and political relations with , a prominent lobbyist in Washington, DC. Abramoff was investigated by a Congressional committee and found to have defrauded numerous clients, especially Indian tribes which he represented on gaming issues. Doolittle's wife had a consulting firm that Abramoff used for some activities. He required his Indian tribe clients to contribute some $50,000 to Doolittle's political campaigns and personally contributed another $14,000.\n\nOn September 20, 2006, the  (CREW), a non-profit group headed by former Democratic Congressional staffer Melanie Sloan, , Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington released its second annual report on the most corrupt members of Congress. It was entitled ''Beyond DeLay: The 20 Most Corrupt Members of Congress (and Five to Watch)''. Doolittle was one of the 20 discussed in the report. The organization said, \"His ethics issues stem from his wife's relationship to his campaign and political action committees, as well as campaign contributions and personal financial benefits he accepted from those who sought his legislative assistance.\" He was also listed as among the most corrupt Congressmen in CREW's subsequent 2007 and 2008 reports.\n\nOn June 11, 2010, the U.S. Attorney announced that, after a 4-year investigation, they had closed its case against Congressman Doolittle and would not pursue charges. Doolittle, who had consistently denied wrongdoing, expressed regret that so many lives and careers had been affected by the investigation. He was forced from office by it. He said he was relieved that the investigation was ended.\n\n\n\nJohn Doolittle has been entangled in the scandal involving . On September 27, 2007, he indicated that he planned to fight a Justice Department subpoena for 11 years of records as part of that department's investigation into his conduct.\n\nDoolittle has denied any wrongdoing. In connection with the matter, he hired David Barger, a criminal defense lawyer and former prosecutor from 's office, and , a law firm that specializes in campaign finance and government ethics. Doolittle has estimated that he received about $50,000 in contributions for his campaigns from clients of Abramoff, mostly Indian tribes. His congressional campaigns from 1999 to 2004 received $14,000 in personal donations from Abramoff over the period 1999–2004 to Doolittle's congressional campaigns. After Doolittle's Chief of Staff  left to work for Abramoff, Ring helped arrange for Abramoff to hire a consulting firm owned by Doolittle's wife. Doolittle used Abramoff's luxury sports box for a political fundraiser and failed to report this as part of his campaign finances. Doolittle was investigated by a federal probe into his relationship with Abramoff. On April 13, 2007, Doolittle's former aide, Kevin Ring, resigned from his lobby firm. On the same day, the  raided Doolittle's Virginia home. On September 4, 2007, the House announced that Doolittle's Chief of Staff Ron Rogers and Deputy Chief of Staff Dan Blankenburg were subpoenaed to testify before a grand jury.\n\n\nDan Landon, a Republican and the executive director of the Nevada County Transportation Commission, said that he was told recently by Doolittle's staff that \"it also doesn't hurt to have a lobbyist\". Sharon Atteberry, city administrator for the city of , said she had also been urged to hire a lobbyist by Doolittle's staff. \"They encouraged us that a lobbyist is very important to any city or county government\" she said.\n\n\nDuring the 2001–2005 period, Julie Doolittle had at least three different occupations: she worked for Jack Abramoff doing event planning (see above); she worked as a bookkeeper for a lobbying firm; and she worked on commission as a fundraiser for her husband. Payments to Julie Doolittle during the period were done via a company called Sierra Dominion Financial Solutions. It was founded in March 2001, just after Congressman Doolittle gained a seat on the Appropriations Committee. It is based at the couple's home in ; Julie is the only employee. The company (that is, Julie) has continued to do fundraising, but no event planning or other work, since the Abramoff scandal first became public in early 2005.\n\n\nFrom 2002 until mid-2005, the , a  lobbying firm with close ties to Congressman , paid Sierra Dominion for bookkeeping work for a nonprofit group called the  (KORUSEC). The latter was created by , a partner in the firm, and was located at the ASG headquarters. KORUSEC is also connected to , one of Doolittle's former assistants. ASG closed due to the financial scandals caused by  and his associates. Julie Doolittle's records regarding her work there were subpoenaed by the US Department of Justice.\n\n\nSierra Dominion charged Doolittle's campaign and his Superior California Political Action Committee a 15 percent commission on any contribution that Julie Doolittle helped bring in. Federal and state campaign records show that, since late 2001, she had received nearly $180,000 in commissions from for such fundraising. This meant that Doolittle and his family had personally made money off his political fundraising. Doolittle aides said even though the PAC had made payments to other fundraisers, Julie Doolittle was entitled to 15 percent of all money the PAC brought in because those donations were raised at events she helped organize.\n\nIn December 2005, Richard Robinson, Doolittle's Chief of Staff, defended the commission structure. \"Sierra Dominion's compensation is based entirely on performance in that it receives a percentage in what it is directly involved in raising. This arrangement is not only consistent with that of other fund raisers but is designed to avoid the appearance that Sierra Dominion is compensated for anything other than its tireless and effective work. Any suggestion otherwise is completely without merit.\"\n\nBut in 2006, the 27,000-member Association of Fundraising Professionals published a letter it had sent to Doolittle, stating emphatically that his wife's activities and form of compensation violated the Association's ethics code. Their code \"explicitly prohibits percentage-based compensation\".\n\nIn January 2007, Doolittle announced that he would no longer employ his wife as his campaign fundraiser. Instead, he said, he would hire an outside fundraiser., ''Associated Press'', January 12, 2007 But in July 2007, his campaign reported expenses of $50,000 for fundraising by Sierra Dominion Financial Solutions during the April–June 2007 period. The company was also still owed $76,000 in commissions from the 2006 race.David Whitney,  , ''Sacramento Bee'', July 16, 2007\n\n\nKORUSEC, which employed Doolittle's wife (see above) and the U.S.-Malaysia Exchange Association, another non-profit firm operated by ASG, paid the total $29,400 cost of what was described as a \"fact finding mission\" in 2005 for Congressman Doolittle and his 12-year-old daughter to South Korea and Malaysia. This trip included a stop at the Berjaya Beach & Spa Resort on the Malaysian island of .\n\nKORUSEC and the U.S.-Malaysia Exchange Association, which were operated by the Washington lobbying firm, , were, as of November 2006, being investigated by the  as possible conduits for illegal influence in U.S. affairs; foreign corporations such as KORUSEC and foreign governments, such as USMEA, are prohibited from seeking such influence. A spokeswoman for Doolittle said that he believed that his trip was proper and that it had nothing to do with the earmarks he had approved in the federal budget.\n\n\n is a company owned by ; Doolittle has had significant involvement with both the company and its owner. Disgraced Congressman  admitted receiving hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash and favors from Wilkes for his efforts to help another of Wilkes' companies, ADCS Inc.\n\nIn 2002, Wilkes hired the  (ASG) for lobbying for his company. In November 2003, Wilkes hosted a fund-raising dinner for Congressman Doolittle. Between 2002 and 2005, Doolittle received at least $118,000 in campaign contributions from Wilkes, PerfectWave associates and their wives, and ASG lobbyists  and  (two former aides of ) and their wives.\n\nDoolittle, a member of the House Appropriations Committee, said in January 2006 that he had helped steer defense funds totaling $37 million to PerfectWave ($1 million in 2002, $18 million in 2003, and then $18 million in 2004.) Doolittle said that his support was based \"on the project's merits and the written support of the military.\"\n\nBut the '''' reported that \"The money was not requested by the Navy but was instead inserted by the Appropriations Committee as part of the closed-door congressional ing process.\" They further reported that \"[T]he only evidence Doolittle's office could provide to show military support for the project was a letter of praise from Robert Lusardi, a program manager for light armored vehicles at the Marine Corps dated Feb. 25two and a half years after PerfectWave got its first earmark. By the time Lusardi wrote his letter, the company had received at least $37 million in earmarks.\"\n\nIn February 2006, Doolittle said that he was glad he supported PerfectWave, saying \"it has unique technology ... that ensures the safety of our armed forces in the war on terror.\"\n\n\nOn January 8, 2006, the '''' reported that \"Reps. John T. Doolittle and  joined forces with former House Majority Leader  of  to oppose an investigation by federal banking regulators into the affairs of Houston millionaire , documents recently obtained by ''The Times'' show.\" \"When the FDIC persisted [in seeking investigation], Doolittle and Pomboboth considered proteges of DeLayused their power as members of the House Resources Committee to subpoena the agency's confidential records on the case, including details of the evidence FDIC investigators had compiled on Hurwitz.\" The FDIC investigation was ultimately dropped.\n\nThe Times reported that \"Although Washington politicians frequently try to help important constituents and contributors, it is unusual for members of Congress to take direct steps to stymie an ongoing investigation by an agency such as the FDIC.\" The article concluded, \"in the Hurwitz case, Doolittle and Pombo were in a position to pressure the FDIC and did so.\"\n\nOn April 19, 2007, Doolittle resigned from the Committee on Appropriations in response to a raid by the FBI at his Northern Virginia home. The raid stemmed from possible involvement by his wife in the investigation of  for defrauding clients as a lobbyist and inappropriate influence.Werner, Erica (April 19, 2007). , , ''SF Gate''\n\n\n\n\nDemocrat , a retired Lt. Colonel who had narrowly lost to Doolittle in 2006 by 3 percent of the vote, announced in February 2007 that he would run again in 2008. In the first and second quarters of 2007, Brown raised more campaign funds than Doolittle; as of June 30, he had a net cash balance of $251,000; Doolittle had a negative balance of $32,000. Analysts believed that the continuing corruption investigation caused the decline in support for Doolittle.\n\nIn August 2007, former  Republican Party chairman Ken Campbell, a longtime financial backer of Doolittle, said he was withdrawing his support. Campbell cited a recent  report on votes in 2007 on spending bills, where Doolittle scored 2 percent, compared to the Republican average of 43 percent.\n\nIn July 2007, Eric Egland, a 37-year-old Air Force reservist and security consultant, announced that he would seek the Republican nomination for the seat held by Doolittle. In August 2007,  City Councilman Mike Holmes announced that he also was entering the 2008 race. Holmes ran unsuccessfully against Doolittle in the primary for the Republican nomination in 2006, getting 33 percent of the primary vote to 67 percent for Doolittle.\n\nOn August 30, 2007, State Assemblyman Ted Gaines announced the establishment of an exploratory committee to begin raising money to run for Congress against Doolittle, stating \"I think voters have lost faith in his leadership ability ... when you lose the moral ability to lead, you kind of have to re-evaluate.\"Peter Hecht, , ''Sacramento Bee'', 30 August 2007\n\nDoolittle said, \"After spending the last month talking to local voters, I have seen strong support for my candidacy and a strong desire to focus on solving problems instead of plotting for political advantage ... I will gladly place before the voters my record of over 30 years of service to the Republican Party to Ted Gaines' less than one year.\"\n\nAfter much speculation, on January 10, 2008, John Doolittle announced he would finish his current term, but would not run for re-election.\n\nAfter Doolittle's retirement announcement, Councilman Holmes quit the race and instead endorsed former Republican Congressman , who announced on February 1, 2008, that he is running for Doolittle's seat. Ose faced opposition from former California State Senator  (R-San Andreas), who announced his candidacy on January 10, 2008.  When California State Senator  (R-Thousand Oaks) announced that he too was running for Doolittle's seat on March 4, 2008, Oller dropped out of the race, and decided to give his endorsement to McClintock. Although he didn't live in the district, McClintock beat Charlie Brown in the general election by only 1,800 votes.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*  at \n*  – Official campaign site\n* Legislation sponsored or cosponsored\n** 107th Congress    \n** 108th Congress    \n** 109th Congress    \n** 110th Congress    \n'''Articles'''\n*  Dennis Zaki, ''AlaskaReport.com'', September 27, 2007\n*  Susan Schmidt and James V.     "pages": }\n\n'''James Ross Johnson''' (September 28, 1939 &ndash; August 16, 2017) was an American politician and lawyer. He was the first person in the California Legislature to become his party's leader in both the State Assembly and State Senate.\n\nFrom , Johnson went to  and . He practiced law. Johnson served in the  from 1978 to 1995 and then served in the  from 1995 to 2004. Johnson was involved with the . From 2007 to 2010, Johnson served as the chair of the .\n\nOn August 16, 2017, Johnson died of cancer in  at the age of 77.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n#\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Sally J. Lieber''' (born April 24, 1961) is an American politician from the state of  who has served as a member of the  since 2023. She was previously a member of the  City Council and the . She represented the  that includes the cities of , ,  and portions of  and  which are all located in . In February 2022, Assemblywoman Lieber was endorsed by the California State Democratic Party for Board Member of the California State Board of Equalization, District 2. She won the seat in the California general election held on November 8, 2022.\n\nLieber held the office of   in the 2007-2008 legislative session. In the November 7, 2006 general election she was re-elected to her third and final term in the assembly, beating her  opponent Roger Riffenburgh by 68.8% to 31.2%. In 2008, she was  out of the office.\n\nLieber currently serves as an advisor to the , an agency that was created through her legislation, and served on Attorney General 's transition team working on women's rehabilitation and mental health.\n\n\nLieber was born in  on April 24, 1961. As a youth growing up in the 1960s and 1970s, she was interested in the antiwar and s.\n\nAfter graduating from high school, Lieber worked restoring Victorian houses and specialized in hanging historical wallpapers. She spent 10 years at this job. As she hung wallpaper, Lieber's interest in politics grew as she listened to  and this encouraged Lieber to return to school.\n\nIn her late 20s, she began taking night classes at . In 1992, she met her husband David Phillips. The two ran into each other at , an arts festival held every year in the Nevada desert.\n\nAfter they married in 1993, Lieber moved to the  and transferred to , where she started going to school full-time and became involved in student government. She worked on issues of child care for student parents, campus access for the disabled and student health care. In the mid-1990s, Lieber transferred to  with a  major, working with .\n\n\nThe 37-year-old Lieber, still a senior at Stanford, launched her campaign for Mountain View city government in 1998. Lieber won this election, as the top vote-getter of seven candidates, and served as Vice Mayor and Mayor. She also served as the City's representative on the Valley Transportation Authority's Board of Directors and as Chair of the Santa Clara Valley Water District's Water Commission.\n\nLieber ran for the 22nd Assembly District seat in 2002. She ran against  person Rod Diridon Jr., who was endorsed by most party heavyweights, and fellow  City Councilperson . She surprised political spectators when she won the Democratic primary with 44 percent of the vote. Her volunteers walked to 58,000 households during the campaign. Lieber won the general election against    Stan Kawczynski.\n\nLieber announced in December 2006 that she would be running for the , District 5 in the 2008 election against . She later withdrew from that race.\n\nLieber was also a 2012 candidate for California's newly drawn 13th State Senate District, which includes northern  and much of , but lost to   on .\n\n\n\n\n\nDuring her first term she served as Assistant Speaker pro Tempore. During this term she was the only woman to serve as an officer of the Assembly. She took the oath of office for Speaker pro Tempore on October 24, 2006, becoming the third woman to serve in this role since 1849. She also served on the Assembly's Committee on Insurance, Committee on Judiciary, Committee on Local Government, Committee on Health and as the Chair of the Assembly's Select Committee on Mobilehomes. She previously served as the Assembly Chair of the legislature's Joint Committee on Ending Poverty in California.\n\n\nSally Lieber's main legislative priorities include: increased educational and economic opportunities for all citizens of California, protection for the environment, improvements to , and increased .\n\nLieber authored legislation to increase the state's , co-authored a  reduction bill, and joint-author of a bill to legalize gay marriage (though that bill was later vetoed by Gov. ). Lieber was one of only a few heterosexual legislators to joint-author 's marriage equality bill. She has authored legislation that includes efforts increasing pupil immunizations, creating an independent sentencing commission, and improving the living conditions of inmates in California's overcrowded prisons.\n\nLieber has authored legislation providing for a death penalty moratorium, advocating for the rights of pregnant inmates in state prison (allowing them to have , providing larger clothes as they got larger with pregnancy, anti-shackling during childbirth), fighting for victims of human trafficking and battling toxic-dumping corporations. Most recently, she advocated a mandatory vaccine against , the virus that causes .\n\n\nIn April 2006, Lieber spent several days living as if she were homeless in , in an attempt to understand the problems the homeless face, and how the legislature can help them. She begged for money, and collected cans and bottles, in order to buy food on the streets of Mountain View and . Lieber used the experience to encourage the Governor to keep cold weather shelters open for the homeless.\n\n\nIn 2004, Lieber introduced extremely controversial legislation regarding the State vehicle , which was signed into law by Governor . The bi-ennial test previously exempted vehicles over 30 years old, while Lieber's legislation fixed the cutoff date at 1976 in perpetuity. Historical vehicles are not exempt. Car collectors, including , noted that this legislation imposed severe penalties for negligible benefit.\n\n\nLieber was in the press in January 2007 by announcing she was planning on introducing a bill that will make it illegal in California to spank a child three years-old or younger. She may have been inspired by the law in  which prohibits spanking children under the age of 2 years or over the age of 11 years, which was passed in 2004. The proposed bill has since been opposed by some on the basis of the practical aspects of enforcing it, though there are those who support it as well (early polling suggests that it is supported by 23% of Californians).\n\n\nLieber has been rated at 100% by the  California, the California , , , the California , and the California Labor Federation . She has received low ratings from the  and the California .\n\n\nLieber ran for the  in the . On June 7, 2022, Lieber became the Democratic Party's nominee going into the November general election run-off, which she won.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* http://www.smartvoter.org/2002/03/05/ca/state/vote/lieber_s/\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
