    "pages": }\n\n'''Ann Miller Ravel''' (born April 6, 1949) is an American attorney who was a Democratic Commissioner on the  (FEC), an independent regulatory agency created by Congress to administer and enforce  law.\n\nRavel was appointed by  on June 21, 2013, and, after unanimous confirmation by the , took office on October 25, 2013. She was Chair of the commission for 2015, and Vice Chair in 2014. Ravel resigned from the commission on February 19, 2017, effective March 1, 2017. Ravel is currently a professor at the .\n\nAnn Ravel was a candidate in the 2020 election for  in District 15, but lost to .\n\n\nRavel was born in the U.S. to an American father and Brazilian mother. At age five, Ravel moved from the U.S. to  where her father had a job with the U.S. government before moving back to , when her father took a teaching position at .\n\nAfter graduating from  in San Jose, Ravel received a B.A. from the  in 1970 and her J.D. from the  in 1974. She lives in Los Gatos, California with her husband, Stephen, an independent adoption attorney. She has three children, two granddaughters and one grandson.\n\n\nRavel has served as Chair of the Federal Election Commission (FEC) and led the California Fair Political Practices Commission (FPPC).\n\nPrior to joining the FEC, Ravel was appointed by California   in February 2011 to serve as the Chair of the  (FPPC). At the FPPC, Ravel oversaw the regulation of campaign finance, lobbyist registration and reporting, and ethics and conflicts of interest related to officeholders and public employees. In Ravel's most significant case as chair, the FPPC pursued a year-long investigation into the methods used by donors who seek to influence political campaigns by anonymous methods.  In October 2013, the FPPC fined the center to Protect Patient Rights and Americans for Responsible Leadership $1 million for forwarding $15 million in \"dark money\" contributions to a California committee without disclosing the source of those contributions. Ravel testified about the case before the Senate Rules and Administration Committee considering the issue of nondisclosure by political groups on April 30, 2014. While at the FPPC, Ravel sought to leverage technology to \"enhance efficiency, improve governance and repair the relationship between the public and their government.\" To that end, the FPPC adopted regulations to allow political contributions to be made by text message and created an online, searchable database of California public officials' Statements of Economic Interests. During Ravel's tenure, the FPPC also released a mobile phone application to track gifts received by public officials and held a hackathon to explore creative options to better disclose the Agency's public data. As Chair of the FPPC, Ravel created the Regulation Clarification Project, an effort to clarify and streamline California regulations. This project was designed to make the law more understandable to the public, promote easier and less onerous compliance for state and local officials, and ensure that the regulations complied with the governing statutes and courts decisions. Among other changes, the FPPC created guides to analyze gift laws and reorganized the regulations by topic. During her tenure at the FPPC, she established the States Unified Network (SUN) Center, a nonpartisan group of state and local jurisdictions promoting transparency in campaign finance.  The group shares enforcement, litigation, and campaign finance data through a public website, which provides nationwide disclosure and aids in enforcement.\n\nBefore joining the FPPC, Ravel was  Deputy Assistant Attorney General for Torts and Consumer Litigation in the Civil Division of the .  She also worked as an attorney in the Santa Clara County Counsel's Office, ultimately serving as the appointed County Counsel from 1998 until 2009.  Ravel represented the county and its elected officials, provided advice on the state Political Reform Act, initiated programs in elder abuse litigation, educational rights, and consumer litigation on behalf of the Santa Clara County government and the community, and joined a group of California municipal attorneys suing to overturn the state's ban on same-sex marriage.\n\nRavel has served as an elected Governor on the Board of Governors of the State Bar of California, a member of the , and Chair of the Commission on Judicial Nominees Evaluation. Ravel received the Professional Woman of Achievement Award from the San Jose Mercury News and the Commission on the Status of Women in 1980, the Elizabeth Ent Award for her contributions to law and justice in 1995, and the Circle of Service Achievement Award from the California State Association of Counties in 2004. In 2007, the State Bar of California recognized Ravel's contributions to public service, naming her Public Attorney of the Year. In 2014, she was named as a California Attorney of the Year by ''California Lawyer'' magazine for her contributions to Government law.\n\nRavel was appointed member of the  (FEC) by  on June 21, 2013, and took office on October 25, 2013, after being confirmation by the . On October 24, 2014, Ravel called for \"a reexamination of the commission's approach to the internet and other emerging technologies...\"  \"The suggestion on its face should have been non-controversial: 'As a Commission, we need to consider the changing role of technology in our elections and recognize how technology is changing our politics. For that reason, next year, I will bring together technologists, social entrepreneurs, policy wonks, politicos, and activistsfrom across the spectrumto discuss new and emerging technologies and how the Commission's current approach may or may not fit with future innovations.'\" Then-FEC chairman  \"characterized the suggestion as an attempt to regulate speech.\"\n\nIn May 2015, Ravel told the New York Times that it is unlikely that the FEC will be able to regulate the coming 2016 presidential election. \"The likelihood of the laws being enforced is slim,\" she told The New York Times. \"I never want to give up, but I'm not under any illusions. People think the FEC is dysfunctional. It's worse than dysfunctional.\" Ravel resigned from the FEC on February 19, 2017, effective March 1, 2017.\n\nIn 2019, Ravel began a campaign for California state senator. During the campaign, Ravel attracted controversy for her past opposition to the recall of  over his handling of the  including from  who led the petition drive for the recall campaign with Dauber and other leaders of the recall campaign releasing an open letter critical of Ravel and her employer attorney James \"Jim\" McManis who also opposed the recall and claimed  consented to Brock Turner's sexual assault with the letter calling on Ravel to return McManis's $2,000 campaign donation. McManis told a Vogue reporter that \"This woman (Miller) was not attacked...\". Ravel said she only defended Persky against the recall \"on principle\" and still supports the campaign against the recall's \"underlying cause\". Democratic Activists for Women Now (DAWN) then voted to rescind its endorsement of Ravel as a result of refusing to return McManis's campaign donation and her opposition to .\n\nRavel also received criticism, mainly from rival candidate , from receiving campaign donations from insurance companies and related  such as the Personal Insurance Federation of California Agents & Employees PAC and the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company Federal PAC despite Ravel insisting she would run a grassroots campaign and thus wouldn't accept contributions from PACs such as the campaign donations in question.\n\nOn March 3, 2020, in California's  concurrent with then , Ravel placed in 2nd place and thus was able to move on to the general election with then- for District 3  placing in 1st place. But in the , Ravel lost to Cortese.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Elton William Gallegly''' (born March 7, 1944) is a former  from California. A , he last represented . He previously represented the 23rd and 21st Districts, and served from 1987 to 2013. He did not seek re-election in 2012.\n\nGallegly is the longest-serving Congressional representative in  history. Gallegly Center at Cal Lutheran}}\n\n\nBorn in  on March 7, 1944, Gallegly attended  but did not graduate. He worked as a  before entering politics. Gallegly is a former member of the  . He became Simi Valley's first elected mayor in 1982.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1986, incumbent Republican U.S. Congresswoman  decided to retire to run for the U.S. Senate. Gallegly won the primary with 50% of the vote over Tony Hope, the son of famed entertainer . In the general election, he won with 68% of the vote. He won re-election in 1988 with 69% and in 1990 with 58%. In 1992, he defeated Democrat  54%–41%. Since then, he won re-election with at least 58% of the vote, except in 2000. That year, he defeated Democrat Michael Case 54%–41%.\n\n;2006\nOn March 10, 2006, Gallegly announced his intent to retire from the House of Representatives after the 2006 mid-term elections, citing health concerns. He had already filed nomination papers to seek another term, however, and attempted to have his name removed from the Republican primary ballot. California election law, though, makes it clear that a candidate's name can only be withdrawn in the case of their death and, as a result, that Gallegly's name would have to remain on the ballot. The following week, after learning that he could not have his name removed from the ballot and that no new challengers would be allowed to enter the race, Gallegly changed his mind and decided to seek what he said would be his final term. He won re-election with 62% of the vote.\n\n;2008\nGallegly won re-election with 58% of the vote.\n\n;2010\nGallegly won re-election with 60% of the vote.\n\nThe top 5 groups or industries that have contributed cash to Representative Gallegly's  2009/2010 campaign are:\n(1) Retirees:                     $39,484\n(2) Real Estate:                  $35,578 \n(3) Lawyers/Law Firms:            $29,374\n(4) Pharmaceuticals:              $22,500, and\n(5) Crop Production/Processing    $20,179.\n\n\nGallegly's activism has focused on the issue of animal rights.  Gallegly himself wrote a bill, enacted in 1999, which made it a federal crime to sell videos of dogfights and other depictions of animal violence, which enabled people to profit from animal cruelty. However, on April 20, 2010, the Supreme Court of the United States, in an 8–1 ruling written by Chief Justice John Roberts, overturned Gallegly's law on the ground that the law violated the First Amendment right to freedom of speech, and created a \"criminal prohibition of alarming breadth.\"\n\nIn his defense, Gallegly argued that the bill he wrote contained \"exceptions for religious, political, scientific, educational, journalistic, and artistic expression [that] may have provided too many loopholes within the legislation. Bob Stevens was convicted of committing animal cruelty as defined by the law, but claimed that his rights to free speech and artistic expression protected him against prosecution.\" Representative Gallegly objected to Stevens’ defense, claiming that the videos \"promote violence and, as such, are not protected by the Constitution.\".\n\nIn 2011, Gallegly voted for the .\n\nGallegly was a supporter of gifted and talented education, having introduced the Gifted and Talented Students Act of 1998 to provide funding for gifted education.\n\n\n* '''''' (Vice Chair)\n** \n** \n* ''''''\n** \n**  (Chairman) \n\n\nGallegly is married to the former Janice Shrader and has four children. Gallegly is of partial .\n\nA gallery has been named for him at the . The Elton and Janice Gallegly Center for Public Service and Civic Engagement at  is a non-partisan center named in honor of Congressman Gallegly.\n\n\nIn January 2012, it was reported that Gallegly received so-called \"VIP\" or \"Friends of Angelo\" loans from troubled mortgage lender , in which loans were granted at lower rates than were available to the public. Gallegly and names of other legislators were forwarded to the , which begun an investigation into the issue. Gallegly denied knowing that he was part of Countrywide Financial's special loan program.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John L. Harmer''' (April 28, 1934 – December 6, 2019) was an American  who served in the  as a  from 1966 to 1974. Harmer served as the  from 1974 to 1975. He was also the founder of the Lighted Candle Society and the author of several books. Harmer was also a member of .\n\n\nJohn L. Harmer was born in 1934 in , . His parents were Earl W. Harmer and Mabel Spande. He was one of their five children. Harmer attended the . While there, Harmer was part of the Frosh Handbook committee in 1954, that helped inform new freshmen about college life at the university. They made sure freshmen were aware of school events and activities. He was involved with debate, and was an intramural debate finalist in 1954. Harmer was part of the Phi Eta Epsilon fraternity. He was also one of the school's Vigilantes. These vigilantes were campus policemen who played roles in student government. They were also responsible for being judges for school elections.\n\nHarmer later obtained a law degree from . Harmer was involved with the student court, serving as the Chief Justice of the student court in 1959. He married Carolyn Jonas on June 24, 1960, in the  and the couple had 10 children. Harmer was a member of . Throughout his life, Harmer has been interested in .\n\n\n\nHarmer was a member of the . He first entered politics by participating in 's political campaign in 1952. He was later an aide to   hired through the 's . After, Harmer worked as an attorney in . Before his election as a state senator, Harmer was also the director of public affairs with the National Association of Manufactures; he also worked for the Americans for Constitutional Action as a field representative. In 1966, Harmer was a member of the Republican State Central Committee,  State Central Committee, United Republicans of California, as well as being part of California Republican Associates, , and Republican Associates. By this time, he had also founded the  Business and Professional Association.\n\n\nHarmer served in the  as a  from 1966 to 1974. During his time in the senate, he authored SB 462, along with Anthony Beilenson, Alan Short, and Lewis F. Sherman. This act pertained to abortion. Harmer ran for  in 1970 and lost. He resigned from the California State Senate in 1974 and ran for the United States Senate in 1976, but lost.\n\nIn 1970 while serving in the state senate and a candidate for state attorney general, Harmer sought permission to film a Los Angeles production of '''' to gather evidence for his suit to prevent \"irreparable damage to the morals of the community.\"\n\nHe went on to serve briefly as the   from 1974 to 1975, after the resignation of  on October 4, 1974 due to being convicted of . Departing   appointed him to the post. He only served for three months to cover the rest of Reinecke's term. Harmer was referred to, however, as \"one of the legislature's most conservative members.\"\n\nWhile living in California, Harmer was a regent of the . He also served as a trustee of the California State University System and was a chairman for the Legislature Select Committee on Large Urban School Districts.\n\n\nHe and his family moved to  in 1980 and later moved to . In Utah, Harmer was appointed the chairman of the National Center for Constitutional Studies. He also worked as a private attorney. He fought to eliminate indecency on cable television programs. In 1988, he was appointed chairman of Eyring, Inc.\n\nIn 1999, Harmer traveled to  as an attorney and was briefed in the  on the 's plans to use  against the U.S. in the 1970s and 1980s. This experience influenced him to write the book ''Ere His Floods of Anger Flow''.\n\nHarmer became vice president of -USA, the American Division of the Chinese car maker Geely that along with  is one of the first Chinese automobile manufacturers to export to North American shores. Harmer founded the Lighted Candle Society in 2001. He served as chairman of the Lighted Candle Society, an organization opposed to , and has filed briefs with the  against pornography.\n\nHarmer authored several books including ''We Dare Not Fail'' (1968), ''Among the Living Are the Dead'' (1970), and ''The Sex Industrial Complex'' (2007). He also wrote ''Reagan: Man of Principle''.\n\n\n\n\n\n* at , . Includes Harmer's correspondence on Native American affairs.\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| children = 1\n| module         = \n}}\n'''John Ferraro''' (May 14, 1924 – April 17, 2001) was an American politician and businessman who was a  member of the  from 1966 until his death in 2001, the longest tenure of any member in the city's history. Before politics, he was an insurance broker, and had been an all-American football player at the .\n\n\n\n\n\nFerraro was born May 14, 1924, in the working class  of , just south of , \"the youngest son of a family of eight children whose Italian immigrant parents ran a macaroni factory before going broke during the \" He attended  in , where he graduated in 1942, and he earned a  degree in  from the  after World War II.\n\n\n\nFerraro enlisted in the U.S. Navy during World War II and was commissioned as an  in . He served on a tanker with , later the  under . \"Christopher got Ferraro interested in politics during long, early morning discussions when they were stationed in the .\"\n\n\n\nHis excellence on the  field at Bell Highhe was a unanimous choice for the All-City teamled to his receiving a scholarship at , where he earned  honors in 1944 and 1947 and played as a  in three . He was inducted into the  in . As an adult he stood 6 feet, 4¼ inches tall and weighed 245 pounds, earning him the  \"Big John.\"   Ferraro was drafted in the sixth round of the 1946 NFL draft by the Green Bay Packers.\n\n\n\nFerraro was an insurance broker with the John Ferraro Company, beginning in 1951, and he invested shrewdly in stocks and real estate that made him a millionaire.\n\n\n\nHe was married to Julie Marie Luckey, daughter of Democratic State Senator , and they had a son, Luckeygian, or Lucky, born about 1956. The Ferraros were divorced in 1972. His second wife was , widely known as  and  Margie Hart in the 1940sand then as a  who even later made money through real-estate investments. They met at a reception in support of Democrat 's unsuccessful U.S. Senate campaign in 1964, and they were married in 1982. She died in 2000.\n\n\n\nFerraro was diagnosed with cancer of the  in August 1999 and underwent . Mayor  was at his side, along with family members, when he died at the age of 76 in Santa Monica on April 17, 2001. A crowd of nearly a thousand filled , Ferraro's parish, for a funeral mass conducted by Cardinal . Family present included Ferraro's brother, Steve, sisters Mary and Rose and his son, Gianni Luckey.\n\n\n\n\nHe entered government service in 1953, when Mayor  appointed him to the city Police Commission, where he served for thirteen years. During that period, he advocated more-stringent gun laws and backed African-American , former Los Angeles Dodgers star, to do community relations work for the Police Department after the 1965 .\n\n\n\n\n in 1974.]]\n\nSupported by Mayor  and seen as a \"product of the old guard of conservative if nominally Democratic politicians who used to dominate local politics,\" he was appointed in May 1966 from among thirteen applicants to represent  after the death of incumbent . Because of his height, when he took office carpenters had to remove a drawer from his desk so that his legs could fit under it.\n\nDuring his term, which at thirty-five years was the longest in City Council history, the 4th District covered (in 1955) much of the  and in general was bounded by , ,  and Catalina Street and (in 1975)  from Fairfax and Highland Avenues on the west, to  on the north, the  on the east and  on the south (1945). In 1986 it was considered a contorted district that included the old areas as well as , , Forest Lawn Drive and parts of the central  to Colfax Avenue and . In 1989 the district stretched from  to .\n\nIn 1974, Ferraro ran unsuccessfully against fellow Councilman  for a seat on the , and in 1985, he made a futile run against  for .\n\nIn 1999, he was fined $3,300 by the Los Angeles Ethics Commission for receiving campaign contributions in 1997 above a newly established limit. It and penalties levied against Councilmen  and  were the first to be made under a law effective in 1985.\n\n\n\nFerraro's election as City Council president in 1977 to replace  allowed him to make committee appointments and set a general direction for the council. In that year he restructured the committee system to \"reflect concerns about the environment and city finances.\" It advanced him to the second most powerful position in the city and made him acting mayor when  was out of town. Ferraro later denied he used his committee appointing power \"to reward allies and punish enemies,\" but he admitted to being practical: \"Anybody who mistreats their friends to benefit their enemies is not practicing good politics,\" he said. \"You don't get reelected to the presidency that way.\"\n\nIn Ferraro's 1997 reshuffle of committee seats, the biggest loser was , \"the frequent butt of Ferraro's jokes, who was ousted from all three of his committees and given far lower-profile assignments,\" Jodi Wilgoren reported in the ''Los Angeles Times.''\n\nIt was said that Ferraro often calmed disputes on the City Council \"with humor and a firm hand\" and that after his death it was \"unlikely such a dominant figure will again emerge,\" because of newly imposed  at City Hall.\n\n\n\nFerraro was noted for \"spearheading the refurbishment of the \", for \"bringing the new  arena to a revitalized downtown\" and helping to attract the  to Los Angeles. Other activities:\n\n'''1984.''' Ferraro's \"biggest citywide leadership role was in helping bring the  to Los Angeles, serving on early committees trying to attract the Games.\"\n\n'''1985.''' Ferraro was considered pro-development, and he usually supported most everything that  leaders wanted, one exception being  because of the large number of elderly renters in his district.\n\n'''1989.''' He opposed building underground transportation lines (subways), believing instead that mass transit should run along freeways or, in the , along existing rail lines.\n\n'''1996.''' The City Council president opposed Mayor 's plans for a  revision commission to be elected by the voters, on the grounds that it would be chaotic and would undermine the council's authority. He wanted a committee of experts in public policy and constitutional law appointed by the City Council itself. In the end, both panels were set up and worked on their own drafts for a charter revision.\n\n'''1997.''' With County Supervisor , Ferraro opposed a plan by  to add 5.9 million square feet to its  attractions in , with  and additional . The two legislators urged the proposal be cut by 40%.\n\n\n\nFerraro was elected to the board of the  in 1995, and in March 1996 the  named him Citizen of the Year, the  gave him its Asa V. Call Achievement Award and the  gave him a community-service award.\n\nFor his contribution to sports in Los Angeles, he was honored with a   plaque by the Coliseum commissioners.\n\n\n\n\nOn November 16, 2000, in honor of his more than five decades of public service, the City of Los Angeles renamed the landmark Department of Water and Power's General Office Building to the John Ferraro Building.  The building was designed by the architects  and opened in 1964.\n\nThe Margaret and John Ferraro Chair in Effective Local Government was established at the School of Policy, Planning and Development of the University of Southern California.\n\n\n\n* About Mayor : \"Morally, he's corrupt. His desire to be governor is so overwhelming, it's eating him up. He will sell out City Hall to be governor.\"\n* About his USC football days: \"I was a tackle. Sure, we never got any glory, no headlines, and that's been my philosophy.\"\n\n\n\nAccess to some ''Los Angeles Times'' links may require the use of a library card.\n\n\n\n\n* \n* Gilman, Jane. She is a  representing the , encompassing  and the western parts of the .\n\n\nCecilia grew up in western . She went to  and earned her degree in . After going to school and working in the  for several years, she moved back to her hometown of Winters. She is a co-owner of her family's  farm in Yolo County. Prior to her election to the Assembly, she was the first female Mayor of .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n and  in 2020.]]\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100%\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Leo Tarcissus McCarthy''' (August 15, 1930 – February 5, 2007) was an  and businessman. He served as the  from 1983 to 1995.\n\n\nMcCarthy, whose parents were both natives of , was himself born in , New Zealand, on August 15, 1930 but emigrated to the United States with his parents Daniel and Nora McCarthy, and siblings when he was three years old. The McCarthy family sailed from the Port of  on the Union Steam Ship ''Makura'', which arrived at the Port of , California, on February 9, 1934. He went to elementary school at . He then went to high school at . He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in  from the  and a  from , now integrated to .\n\n\nMcCarthy joined the  in March 1951, and served for twenty-one months until the end of 1952, as an enlisted man. He was in an intelligence unit at the  and was stationed at  for seventeen months. While at the Strategic Air Command, he spent a few weeks deployed to  taking part in a mission to simulate the start of . He also served in the United States Air Force Reserves for a few years.\n\n\nIn 1958, the year that saw the Democrats capture statewide offices for the first time since World War II, McCarthy managed the successful campaign for State Senate of . After the election, McCarthy served as McAteer's administrative assistant.\n\nMcCarthy first ran for office in 1963, when he was elected to the . He served there until 1967. In 1968, he was elected to the , serving as  from 1974 to 1980. (, elected mayor of San Francisco in 1988, had his political start as McCarthy's first legislative assistant, and later as the speaker's chief of staff.) As speaker, McCarthy earned a reputation as a partisan, take-no-prisoners insider in Democratic Party politics.\n\nMcCarthy unexpectedly lost the speakership to  in 1980. McCarthy had been facing a stiff challenge from . Seeing his fellow Democrats so divided, Brown worked with Republicans to gain the speakership. Both of the losers in this struggle soon left the legislature. Berman ran for Congress and McCarthy ran for statewide office.\n\n\nMcCarthy was first elected to statewide office to the first of three consecutive four-year terms as  in , at the same time that   was elected . In 1986, the incumbent McCarthy ran against Republican , the former Lieutenant Governor and McCarthy's immediate predecessor as well as a former film producer and music promoter with a reputation for opposing drug use by artists. In a hotly-contested race for lieutenant governor that centered largely around violent crime and drug policy, McCarthy alleged that Curb made a fortune in making 'exploitation films' that glorified drugs, sex, and violence. Curb was so incensed at the charges that he filed a $7-million libel and slander suit against McCarthy, who ultimately won the election.\n\nAfter his failed 1988 Senate campaign, McCarthy won a third term as lieutenant governor in 1990, while his 1988 opponent  won the election for governor.\n\n\n\nIn , McCarthy ran for the . He easily won the Democratic Party nomination but was defeated in the general election by the Republican incumbent and future Governor . As of 2021, this was the last time a Republican won a U.S. Senate seat in California. McCarthy's 4,287,253 votes set a record for the most votes given to a losing Democratic Senate candidate that lasted until it was broken by  of Texas in 2020. McCarthy was the first person to get more than 4 million votes in a losing Senate campaign.\n\n\nIn , McCarthy entered the Democratic primary election for the U.S. Senate but lost the nomination to  (and later general election winner) .\n\nMcCarthy retired from public office at the end of his third term as the state's longest-serving Lieutenant Governor after 12 years in office on January 2, 1995, choosing not to seek re-election to a fourth term in , even though he was eligible for one more term and would not have been term-limited until 1998. He was succeeded by a fellow Democrat, then- and later future Governor . McCarthy's 12 years are the longest any  lieutenant governor has served. Upon leaving politics, he created an investment company, The Daniel Group, named for his father and located in San Francisco.\n\n\nHe helped found the Leo T. McCarthy Center for Public Service and the Common Good at the .\n\n\nMcCarthy was Catholic. He was married on December 17, 1955, to the former Jacqueline Lee Burke. They had four children (Sharon, Conna, Adam, and Niall) and eleven grandchildren.\n\nAfter a long illness, McCarthy died from a kidney ailment at his home in San Francisco on February 5, 2007.\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n'''William John \"Pete\" Knight''' (November 18, 1929&nbsp;– May 7, 2004) (, ) was an American , ,  combat , , and .  He was one of twelve pilots who flew the , an experimental  jointly operated by the U.S. Air Force and .  He was also selected for participation in the  program.\n\nOn October 3, 1967, Knight piloted , the program's fastest flight.  Flying at a maximum  of 6.7 and a maximum speed of 4,520  (7,274&nbsp;km/h), he set a  for flight in a winged, powered aircraft.  The flight was made in the X-15A-2, the second of three planes in the X-15 fleet.\n\nTwo weeks later on October 17, Knight flew , reaching a maximum altitude above 50 miles.  This qualified him as an astronaut according to  of the boundary of space.  However, this altitude did not surpass the , the internationally accepted boundary of 100 kilometers (62 miles).\n\n\nKnight was born November 18, 1929, in , to parents William T. Knight (1906–1968) and Mary Emma Knight (1909–1959). Following high school, Knight attended  and . He graduated with a  degree in  from the U.S.  in 1958.\n\n\nKnight was married to Helena Stone and they had three sons, , Peter, and David. Helena predeceased Knight. Knight remarried and at his death in 2004 he was survived by his widow Gail, a brother, three sons, four stepchildren and 15 grandchildren.\n\n\nKnight joined the  in 1951. While only a , he flew an  at the National Air Show in 1954 and won the Allison Jet Trophy.\n\nStarting in 1958, following his graduation from both U.S. Air Force Institute of Technology and the  (Class 58C), Knight served as a test pilot at , . He was a project test pilot for the , ,  and later,  and  test programs. In 1960, he was one of six test pilots selected to fly the , which was slated to become the first winged orbital space vehicle capable of lifting reentries and conventional landings. After the X-20 program was canceled in 1963, he completed the astronaut training curriculum through the  (Class 63A) at Edwards AFB and was selected to fly the .\n\nHe had more than his share of eventful flights in the X-15. While climbing through  at  4.17 on June 29, 1967, he suffered a total electrical failure and all onboard systems shut down. After reaching a maximum altitude of , he calmly set up a visual approach and, resorting to old-fashioned \"seat-of-the-pants\" flying, he glided down to a safe emergency landing at Mud Lake, .  For his remarkable feat of airmanship that day, he earned a .\n\n\nOn October 3, 1967, Knight set a world aircraft speed record for manned aircraft by piloting the X-15A-2 to  ( 6.70), a record that still stands today. During 16 flights in the aircraft, Knight also became one of only five pilots to earn their  by flying an airplane in space, reaching an altitude of .\n\nAfter nearly ten years of test flying at Edwards AFB, he went to  in 1968, where he completed a total of 253  in the  during the . Following his combat tour, he served as test director during development of the  at  in . He also was the program director for the International Fighter (F-5) Program at Wright-Patterson. In 1979, he returned to Edwards AFB, and served as a test pilot for the .\n\nAfter 32 years of service and more than 6,000 hours in the cockpits of more than 100 different aircraft, he retired from the U.S. Air Force as a  in 1982.\n\n\nIn 1984, he was elected to the city council of , and four years later became the city's first elected mayor.  In 1992, he was elected to serve in the  representing the 36th District. He served in the  representing the 17th District from 1996 until his death on May 7, 2004. Knight's youngest son,  served as assemblyman for the 36th Assembly District from 2008 to 2012, the seat previously held by his father.\n\n\n\nKnight's brother and son came out as gay, and Knight pursued anti-LGBT legislation in his  political work. During his term in the Senate, Knight gained statewide attention in 2000 as the author of , a.k.a. the \"Knight Initiative\", the purpose of which was to ban : \"Only marriage between a man and a woman is valid or recognized in California.\" The proposition passed with 61.4% approval and 38.6% against. On March 9, 2004, Knight's son, David Knight, who is gay, married his partner during the period when  in defiance of state law. These marriages were  nullified by the  in 2004. The Court later found Proposition 22 to be unconstitutional in '''' (2008).\n\nKnight's  younger brother died of -related complications in 1995 at age 60. Of his younger brother's homosexuality, Knight said \"We never talked about it.\"\n\n\n*  (30 min., free, taped 4-1-2004)\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* , 1967\n*  , 1968\n* Enshrined in the  in 1988.\n* Inducted into the  in 1990.\n* Inducted into the  in 1998.\n\nIn the city of Palmdale,  was opened in his memory. The school began its first year in the school year of 2003–2004 and celebrated its first graduating class in 2007.\n\n\n\n\n\n* Thompson, Milton O.     "pages": }\n\n'''James Franklin Battin''' (February 13, 1925 – September 27, 1996) was a   from , and later was a  of the .\n\n\n\nBorn in , , Battin moved with his parents to  in November 1929. He was educated in the s of , then the third largest city in the state, graduating from  there in 1942. He enlisted in the  and served for three years, two and a half years of which were in the  theater of operations. He returned to his studies and graduated with a  degree in 1948 from  (now ) in Billings. He received a  from  in 1951, and was in private practice of law in  from 1951 to 1952, then in Billings from 1953 to 1960. He was a deputy county attorney of , Montana from 1953 to 1955, then general counsel and secretary of the City-County Planning Board of Billings in 1955. In 1955 he became an assistant city attorney of Billings, and was the city attorney from 1957 to 1958. He served as member of the  in 1958 and 1959. Battin was elected as a  to the  and to the three succeeding Congresses, and served from January 3, 1961, until his resignation February 27, 1969, to become United States District Judge.\n\n\n\nBattin was nominated by President  on February 20, 1969, to a seat on the  vacated by Judge . He was confirmed by the  on February 25, 1969, and received his commission on February 27, 1969. He served as Chief Judge from November 16, 1978, to February 13, 1990. He assumed  on February 13, 1990. His service terminated on September 27, 1996, due to his death in Billings.\n\n\n\nThe  in Billings is named for him. Battin's son, , was elected to the  in 1994.\n\n\n\nOne of the cases that Battin handled was the conviction of four counts of  of the   business agent , the one who supplied the immunized testimony that sent  to prison.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|years=1969–1990}}\n\n\n|years=1978–1990}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert Dale Dutton''' (October 13, 1950 – July 23, 2022) was an American politician of the . After serving two years as a  for the , from 2002 to 2004, Dutton served as a  representing the  from 2004 to 2012, and was the state senate's  from 2010 to 2012. He made an unsuccessful run for the U.S. House of Representatives in 2012. In 2014, he was elected as Assessor-Recorder-County Clerk of  and re-elected in 2018, holding the position until his death.\n\n\nDutton was born in  in 1950. In 1972, he received an A.A. in real estate from . In 1976, he became President of the local .\n\nHe served in the  in 1969 and then went on to serve on the . Dutton owned the real estate company Dutton & Associates, Inc. He was also involved with the  and the .\n\nHe began his public service as a man for .\n\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting, incumbent Republican state assemblyman  decided to retire in order to run for a seat on the . Dutton decided to run in the vacant  and won the Republican primary with 45% of the vote in a three candidate field. He won the general election by defeating  nominee Donna Wallace 61%–39%.\n\nIn 2004, he decided to retire from his seat in the 63rd Assembly district in order to run for , vacated by retiring Republican state senator . He defeated Democratic nominee Marjorie Mikels 60%–40%. In 2008, he won re-election to a second term with 59% of the vote.\n\n\n;2011–2012\n*Emergency Management Committee\n*Labor and Industrial Relations Committee\n*Audit Committee\n*Rules Committee\n\n;2009–2010\n*Budget and Fiscal Review Committee (Vice Chair)\n*Transportation and Housing Committee\n*Rules Committee\n*Joint Legislative Budget Committee\n\n\n\nIn January 2012, Dutton decided to retire from the California Senate to run in the newly redrawn , based in , and vacated by retiring U.S. Congressman . Dutton lost the general election to fellow Republican  by a 55% to 45% margin.\n\n\nIn September 2013, Dutton announced his candidacy for the San Bernardino County Assessor-Recorder, vacated by retiring County Assessor-Recorder Dennis Draeger. Dutton won the June 3, 2014 California Primary Election to Dan Harp, receiving over 50% of the vote and avoiding a November run-off election.\n\nAs a division of the Assessor-Recorder-County Clerk responsibilities, Dutton was the keeper of the historical archives.\n\nIn 2018, Dutton was re-elected unopposed. At the time of his death, he was seeking another term in the 2022 election, and was again unopposed.\n\n\n;2014–2022\n*California Assessor's Association – Legislative Committee \n*County Recorder's Association of California \n\n\nHe married Andrea Guillen in 1981, and they had one daughter. Dutton died from cancer on July 23, 2022, at the age of 71.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Douglas Arlo Ose''' (born June 27, 1955) is an American businessman and politician who served as the  for  from 1999 to 2005. He is a member of the . On March 16, 2021, Ose announced his intention to run for Governor of California in the  of . On August 17, 2021, Ose announced that he was withdrawing from the race after suffering a heart attack.\n\n\nOse was born and raised in . He graduated from  and in 1977, earned a B.S. in business administration from the . At Berkeley, he was a member of . After graduating from college, Ose began his career as a real estate developer.\n\n\n  in 2002]]\nDuring his time in Congress, Ose was named a \"Hero of the Taxpayers\" by , a \"Guardian of Small Business\" by the  and earned a \"Tax Fighter\" award from the National Tax Limitation Committee. \n\nIn 2001, Ose voted for one of the largest tax cuts in American history, a $1.35 trillion tax reform package that ended the  tax, lowered the  and increased child tax credits. \n\nIn December 2003, Ose introduced a bill (H.R. 3687) to outlaw the broadcast of 's \"\", including \"compound use (including hyphenated compounds) of such words and phrases with each other or with other words or phrases, and other grammatical forms of such words and phrases (including verb, adjective, gerund, participle, and infinitive forms)\". The bill omitted \"tits\", but included \"asshole\", which was not one of Carlin's original seven words. The bill was referred to the  in January 2004, where it was tabled.\n\nAs Chairman of a House Government Reform Committee, Ose held hearings to promote legislation to change rules governing gifts to presidents. \n\nIn an effort to complete construction of a border fence originally started in 1996, Ose, along with , co-authored a bill that would grant the  authorization to ignore all laws deemed \"necessary to ensure the expeditious construction of the barriers and roads under this section\".\n\nAccording to '''', during his congressional tenure, Ose appeared regularly in lists of the wealthiest members of Congress. This was based on the value of his real estate holdings purchased in the 1980s. According to financial disclosures his net worth is between $51.5 million and $175 million.\n\nOse honored a self-imposed  pledge and declined to run for re-election to the U.S. House in 2004.\n\n\n*  (Chair)\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\nIn 1998, Ose decided to run for . In the open primary, he ranked first with 30% of the vote. His next closest competitor, Democrat Sandie Dunn, received 23% of the vote. \n\nOse and Dunn qualified for the general election, in which Ose defeated Dunn by a margin of 52%–45%. Ose won re-election in 2000 with 56% of the vote and again in 2002 with 62% of the vote.\n\n\nIn 2008, Ose ran in the primary election in , a seat being left vacant by retiring Congressman .  Ose lost the primary bid to .\n\n\n\nOn September 3, 2013, Ose formally announced his candidacy for his old district, which had been renumbered as the , in hopes of facing freshman Democrat , who unseated  in 2012. On June 3, Ose qualified for the November general election by ranking second in the open primary with 26% of the vote. He defeated Republicans Igor Birman and . Bera ranked first with 48% of the vote and faced Ose in the general election. The '''' rated the contest as a \"Pure Toss-up\"; and even eight days after the November 4 election, the race was still undecided, with Bera leading Ose by just 711 votes at the time with 19,000 ballots yet to be counted. Ultimately, Ose lost the race to Bera by 0.8%.\n\n\n\nOse hinted in 2017 that he was considering running for  in the 2018 election, telling the '''' that he was \"gravely concerned\" about the state's future, elaborating \"there's no other way to describe it – we've gone backwards. I don't care whether you're talking about housing or quality of jobs that are available or road maintenance or the homeless question. There's nobody in office today that's doing anything about it.\" He announced he would run in January 2018. In February, however, Ose determined this was not the right time. While discussing his decision to not pursue the office at that time, Ose told Fox Business' Stuart Varney: \"Cost of housing is out of control, K-12's failing, homeless everywhere, traffic gridlock, no jobs, it's just like...go down the checklist and they're 0 for life.\" Ose then formed Rebuild California Foundation, a 501(c)(3) Tax-Exempt Educational Organization, to research and propose solutions for the top issues affecting the lives of everyday Californians.\n\n\n\n\nOn March 16, 2021, Ose announced his intention to run for Governor of California in the recall election of . However, on August 17, 2021, Ose announced he was dropping out of the race after suffering a heart attack. Despite having withdrawn from the race, he received 0.4% of the replacement candidate vote.\n\n\nSince his departure from Congress, Ose has been a member of the board of directors of the , a more traditional conservative movement of Members of Congress. The 501(c)(4) is tied to more than 60 current Members of Congress.\n\n\n\nOse is married to Lynnda Ose. They have two daughters, Erika and Emily, who attended Ose's former high school, Rio Americano High School. Their main residence is in the unincorporated area of Sacramento County.\n\nIn 2011, when budget constraints forced the closure of Gibson Ranch Park in , Ose applied to run the facility as its private operator. Since Ose began managing the park in April 2011, the regional park was open daily and welcomed about 250,000 visitors.  The park, as of December 1, 2019, is now being managed by the  Department of Regional Parks.\n\nAlong with then-Senator , Ose had a cameo appearance in the 2002 '''' episode \"Those Lazy-Hazy-Crazy Days\".\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jimmy Gomez''' (born November 25, 1974) is an American politician serving as the  for  since 2017. His district includes the  neighborhoods of , , , , and other communities. A member of the , Gomez served in the  from 2012 to 2017.\n\nBefore entering electoral politics, Gomez was a labor organizer, serving as the legislative and political director for the United Nurses Associations of California/Union of Health-Care Professionals (UNAC/UHCP) and the political representative for the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME).\n\nGomez serves on the , and is vice chair of the . He is a founding member of the Medicare for All Caucus. He is also a member of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, the Congressional Progressive Caucus, the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus, and the Congressional LGBTQ Equality Caucus.\n\n\nBorn and raised in , Gomez is the son of working-class immigrant parents. His mother was a domestic worker and a nursing home laundry attendant. His father was a ''bracero'' (farm worker).\n\nAfter graduating from high school, without any plans to attend college, Gomez worked at  and .  He eventually attended  and earned his B.A. in political science with a minor in urban planning from the  and his M.A. in public policy from the .\n\nA former labor organizer, Gomez worked for the United Nurses Associations of California/Union of Health Care Professionals (UNAC/UHCP) in 2009. He also served as the Political Representative for the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees (AFSCME).\n\nGomez was a staffer for former U.S. Representative . He was elected to the California State Assembly in 2012, and served there until his election to Congress.\n\n\"To see her son not only go to college, graduate, but then to run for public office and get elected ... it means a lot. It means that there's still a lot of opportunities for immigrants ... It means we're part of this larger American story\", said Gomez.\n\n\n\nGomez was a member of the , representing the . He was first elected in 2012, and reelected in 2014 with over 83% of the vote. California's 51st Assembly district includes  and unincorporated . He served as State Assembly Majority Whip from 2013 to 2014.\n\nGomez was a member of the California Latino Legislative Caucus. Before being elected to the Assembly in 2012, he was the political director for the United Nurses Association of California, an affiliate of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn December 5, 2016, Gomez announced his candidacy for the  to succeed  in the  for . Gomez received endorsements from Los Angeles Mayor , Assembly Speaker  and Senate leader , among others.\n\nOn April 4, 2017, Gomez came in first during the special election. Since he did not receive a majority of the vote, he faced a fellow Democrat,  Planning Commissioner Robert Lee Ahn, the runner-up, in a  on June 6. Gomez won with 60% of the vote. He is only the third person to represent this district since its creation in 1963 (it was numbered as the 30th from 1963 to 1975, the 25th from 1975 to 1993, the 30th from 1993 to 2003, the 31st from 2003 to 2013, and has been the 34th since 2017).  won this district in 1963 and handed it to Becerra in 1993.\n\n\nGomez faced Green Party candidate  in the general election and won with 72.5% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\nGomez was challenged in the 2020 election by   board member and fellow Democrat David Kim. On November 3, Gomez defeated Kim in a closer than expected race, with 53% of the vote to Kim's 47%.\n\n\n\n\nDavid Kim challenged Gomez again in 2022. Gomez won, but by a smaller margin than in 2020.\n\nOn October 22, 2022, member-elect  alleged that a female canvasser for Gomez and Assemblymember  made anti-Asian comments about their challengers, David Kim, who is , and Mia Livas Porter, who is , respectively, while visiting Hernandez's home. In late October 2022, a Highland Park voter made similar allegations except this time it involved two female canvassers. In response, both Gomez's and Carrillo's campaigns offered an apology to their challengers and reached out to Hernandez via  and separate phone conversations assuring that they had taken action to ensure the canvasser(s)-in-question were no longer part of the campaign.\n\n\nGomez's term began on June 6, 2017. He was sworn into office on July 11, 2017.\n\nOn October 1, 2020, Gomez co-signed a letter to Secretary of State  that condemned ’s offensive operations against the -populated enclave of , denounced ’s role in the , and called for an immediate ceasefire.\n\nIn November 2020, Gomez was named a candidate for  in the .\n\nIn January 2021, Gomez introduced legislation to expel Representative  from the House for some of her social media postings from before her 2020 election to Congress.\n\nAfter Greene heckled President Biden at his State of the Union address on March 2, 2022, Gomez once again introduced a resolution of expulsion, but added Representative , who had joined her in the heckling. Gomez also spoke about the \"triggering\" feeling he experienced after he returned to the Congressional Gallery for the first time since  insurrectionists had attacked those chambers in an attempt to halt the counting of electoral votes on January 6, 2021.\n\n\n\n* Assistant whip, Democratic Caucus of the House of Representatives\n* Vice chair, Committee on Oversight and Reform\n*  \n* House Trade Working Group\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n* \n** \n** Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations (Ranking Member)\n\n\nGomez is a member of several dozen caucuses.     "pages": }\n'''Paul Joseph Cook''' (born March 3, 1943) is an American politician serving as a  Supervisor since 2020, previously serving as the  for  from 2013 to 2020. A member of the , Cook also served on the  Town Council from 1998 to 2006 and represented the  in the  from 2006 to 2012.\n\nIn September 2019, Cook announced that he would not run for re-election to Congress in , and instead run for a seat on the  . In the March 3, 2020 primary election, Cook defeated three opponents with an outright majority to avoid a November runoff and succeed Robert A. Lovingood, making him the new supervisor from San Bernardino County's 1st district. Cook resigned his U.S. House seat and assumed his new office on December 7, 2020.\n\n\nCook was born in  in 1943. He was raised in Meriden and did not permanently move to California until the end of his military career. In 1966, he graduated from , earning a B.S. in teaching. Later that year, he joined the . As an infantry officer, Cook served in the . His actions in combat earned him many honors, including the  and two s. He served in the Marine Corps for 26 years.\n\nAfter he retired from the Marine Corps in 1992 as a colonel, he earned an  from  in 1996 and a master's in political science from  in 2000.\n\n\nFrom 1993 to 1994, he was Director of Yucca Valley Chamber of Commerce. From 1998 to 2002, he was a professor at . Cook taught courses on political violence and terrorism at  since 2002.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2006, Cook ran for California's 65th Assembly District. Cook won a five candidate Republican primary field with 29% of the vote. In the general election, Cook defeated Democrat Rita Ramirez-Dean 60%–37%. In 2008, he won re-election to a second term, defeating Democrat Carl Wood 53%–47%. In 2010, he won re-election to a third term, defeating Wood again 58%–42%.\n\n\nThe 65th district included the cities of , , , , , , , , , , , ,  and other smaller communities and unincorporated areas in , ,  and .\n\nThe California Chamber of Commerce and the California Taxpayers Association gave Cook a perfect 100% rating, 2007–2011. In 2010, Democratic   appointed Cook to chair the Veterans Affairs Committee, the first time a Democratic speaker had appointed a Republican to chair a committee since 2002.\n\n\n* Accountability and Administrative Review Committee\n* Budget Committee\n* Emergency Management Committee\n* Governmental Organization Committee\n* Higher Education Committee\n* Inland Empire Transportation Issues Committee\n* Master Plan for Higher Education\n* Preservation of California's Entertainment Industry Committee\n* Sunset Review Committee\n* Veterans Affairs Committee (Chair)\n*Judiciary Committee\n\n\n\n\n\nIn January 2012, 34-year incumbent  announced he would not seek re-election in November. Cook entered the primary for the district, which had been renumbered from the 41st to the 8th in redistricting. He finished second in the 13-candidate all-party open primary. He earned 15% of the vote. Fellow Republican and conservative activist Gregg Imus ranked first with 16% of the vote. Cook was endorsed by the California Off-Road Vehicle Association (CORVA) past presidents, the , National Vietnam and Gulf War Veterans Coalition, the County Farm Bureau, state Assemblyman , state Senator , and U.S. Congressman . Thoughts from Colonel Paul Cook|url=http://www.joinpaulcook.com/blog/|publisher=Paul Cook|access-date=1 March 2013}} In the November election, Cook defeated Imus 58%–42%.\n\n\n\nIn 2013, Cook co-signed a letter to then-president , urging him to finalize the , stating that it was about \"jobs, jobs jobs.\" He also expressed fear that  \"is ready to take advantage of America's missteps with the Keystone pipeline.\"\n\nEarly in 2017, Cook voted in favor of . His reason for voting for the repeal was to ensure that \"every American has access to quality care to fit their budget.\" In August 2017, he voted in favor of outlawing , unless the woman was a victim of rape or incest or that her life was threatened.\n\nCook voted in favor of the . By voting for the bill, Cook says that the bill will \"deliver crucial tax relief for middle-class and low-income Americans.\" He voted for this bill because more than 90 percent of taxpaying constituents will receive a tax break. He also supports it because it simplifies the tax code.\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n* ''''''\n** \n** \n* ''''''\n** \n** \n\n\n* Congressional Cement Caucus\n* \n*\n*\n\n\nIn the first session of the , Cook was ranked the 33rd most bipartisan member of the  by the Bipartisan Index, a metric published by  and   to assess  bipartisanship.\n\nCook opposes abortion, as well as .\n\nCook supports repealing the  (\"Obamacare\"). He supports legislation that \"decreases premiums, makes it easier for employers to offer affordable healthcare options for their employees, and allows greater freedom for people to purchase a plan of their choice.\"\n\nCook believes that the  (DACA) is unconstitutional.\n\n\nCook resides in  with his wife, Jeanne.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Courken George Deukmejian Jr.''' ( \n; June 6, 1928May 8, 2018) was an American politician who served as the  from 1983 to 1991. A member of the , he was the state's first governor of .\n\nBorn in , Deukmejian moved to California in 1955. He was elected to the  in 1962 to represent . Four years later he was elected into the  and later served as the Senate's minority leader. In , Deukmejian unsuccessfully ran for , finishing fourth in the Republican primary. In  he secured the nomination and defeated  to become the state's 27th attorney general. As attorney general, he led a veto override against Governor , who had vetoed legislation to authorize the  in .\n\nAfter Governor Brown did not seek reelection in , Deukmejian won the Republican nomination for governor and faced   in the general election. Although opinion polls showed that Bradley had a favorable lead in the race, Deukmejian narrowly won the election outright. In , Deukmejian defeated Bradley again for a much larger victory. As governor, Deukmejian made a name for being tough on crime, presenting himself to be in favor of \"\". Under his administration, the California prison population nearly tripled, and he increased spending for the building of new prisons.\n\nDeukmejian retired from front-line politics in 1991 and was succeeded as governor by fellow Republican .\n\n\nDeukmejian was born Courken George Deukmejian Jr. in . His parents were  born in the , who emigrated from the  (present-day ) to the United States in the early 1900s. His father, Courken George Deukmejian, whose sister was killed during the , was a rug merchant born in . Deukmejian's mother, Alice Gairden, was born in ; in the United States she worked for  and later for New York State.\n\nDeukmejian attended local schools. For college, he graduated in 1949 with a  in  from . He earned a  (J.D.) from  in New York City in 1952. From 1953 to 1955, he served in the , assigned to the  (JAG).\n\nDeukmejian moved to California in 1955 where his sister, Anna Ashjian, was living and there was a large Armenian community. She introduced him to his future wife , a bank teller whose parents were also immigrants from . They married on February 16, 1957. He and his wife had three children: two daughters, born in 1964 and 1969; and one son, born in 1966.\n\n\n  signing the 1973 California death penalty bill.]]\nDeukmejian entered politics in California after a short period of private legal practice in  alongside . In 1962, Deukmejian was elected to represent Long Beach in the .\n\nIn 1966, he was elected as a , serving from 1967 to 1979. He was a high-profile advocate for . By 1969, he was the  of the California State Senate.\n\nHe first ran for  in 1970, finishing fourth in the Republican primary. He won the election for Attorney General in  and served from 1979 to 1983. During this time, he led a high-profile campaign against  in northern California, which later became the . Additionally, he led a veto override against Governor , who had vetoed legislation to authorize the .\n\n\nDeukmejian was elected in  to his first term as . He first defeated  , a  owner, in the Republican primary. One of his early primary backers was former gubernatorial candidate Joe Shell of , a conservative who had opposed  in the 1962 California primary. Upon his victory, '''' reported, \nThe image that comes across of Mr. Deukmejian  a devoted family man, an Episcopal churchman, an ice cream lover  led one reporter to write, \"California may have accidentally elected Iowa's Governor\".\n\nIn the general election, Deukmejian ran as a conservative supporter of public safety and balanced budgets. In addition, he was strongly critical of outgoing Governor Jerry Brown and promised to run a very different administration. He strongly criticized the , which was dominated by Brown appointees, notably controversial Chief Justice .\n\n and County Sheriff , 1986.]]\nDeukmejian narrowly defeated    in the general election. Deukmejian won the election by about 100,000 votes, about 1.2 percent of the 7.5 million votes cast. The victory came despite s leading up to the election that consistently showed Bradley with a lead, and despite ing conducted after voting closed that led some news organizations on the night of the election to make early projections of a Bradley victory. The discrepancy between the polling numbers and the election's ultimate results would come to be termed the \"\", which refers to a hypothesized tendency of white voters to tell interviewers or pollsters that they are undecided or likely to vote for a black candidate, but they actually vote for his opponent.\n\nDeukmejian's governorship was a departure from that of his predecessor, . He vowed not to raise taxes, later saying that he was \"business friendly\". In addition, he presented himself as a \"law and order\" candidate, proposing new efforts to fight crime. He faced a Democrat-dominated  during his two terms as governor. He was the sole Republican statewide officeholder until  was appointed , following the death of Treasurer .\n\nIn 1983, Deukmejian abolished the   and reduced state spending for bicycle projects from $5 million to the statutory minimum of $360,000 per year. In 1984, he vetoed A.B. 1, the first bill to ban discrimination against gays and lesbians, which passed the Legislature.\n\n in the , 1983]]\nIn , Bradley sought a rematch, and Deukmejian defeated him by a 60% to 37% percent margin. He was generally regarded as a moderate-to- Republican.\n\nThe Deukmejian administration began during a national economic . He halted the hiring of new state employees and banned out-of-state travel for those in government. He rejected the legislature's demands for tax hikes, and pared $1.1 billion from its budget by selectively vetoing spending items. One year later, further cuts, along with a nationwide economic rebound that benefited the state, created a billion dollar  for 1985. His 1985 budget slightly increased spending in highway construction, but cut deeply into the education, health, welfare and environmental budgets. For this he was roundly criticized, and the cuts probably led to his low polling numbers at the end of his tenure as governor. 3 years later, Deukmejian faced his own billion dollar deficit. He supported a raise in the state minimum wage in 1989. Deukmejian largely made his career by being tough on crime. When he was in the legislature, he wrote California's  law. As a candidate for re-election, in 1986 he opposed the retention election of three Brown-appointed justices of the  due to their consistent opposition to the death penalty in any and all circumstances. The best known of these was , the first female Chief Justice of the Court (and the first one to be voted off). Deukmejian elevated his friend and law partner, , from  to , and appointed three new associate justices. Under Deukmejian, the California prison population nearly tripled&nbsp; as of December 31, 1982, the total prison population stood at 34,640 inmates. He increased spending for the building of new prisons.\n\nIn 1988, then-   for the  that year. During a trade mission to  in August, Deukmejian sent a letter saying he could not be considered for nomination, refusing to leave the governorship to Democratic Lieutenant Governor .\n\nDeukmejian did not seek re-election to a third term as governor in the . The Republicans instead nominated sitting United States Senator , who defeated  in the general election. He was the last governor not affected by the two-term limit that was passed by voters in 1990.\n\nOn October 1, 1989, Deukmejian signed legislation authorizing the purchasing of health insurance by uninsured Californians suffering from catastrophic serious illnesses, such as , , , and , to be funded through  revenues.\n\nIn 1991, in his last days in office, he vetoed the property tax exemption bill that applied to companies building solar in California. This exemption was focused toward the  (SEGS) plants then being built by . The veto led to the bankruptcy of Luz.\n\n\n (left),  (center) and Deukmejian (right) in September 2010]]\nDeukmejian was a partner in the law firm of  from 1991 until 2000 when he retired. He reentered public life by serving on special committees, including one to reform the California penal system, and a charter-reform committee in his hometown of Long Beach. He oversaw a revamping of the  Willed Body Program after a scandal involving the sale of human body parts . In 2013, a courthouse in Long Beach was named in his honor. Deukmejian received an honorary doctor of laws degree from , in 2008, because of his support for education, state law, and Long Beach. In 2015, he was given the  of Long Beach.\n\n\nDeukmejian died of natural causes at his home on May 8, 2018, at the age of 89. California Governor  said on : \"George Deukmejian was a popular governor and made friends across the political aisle. Anne and I join all Californians in expressing our deepest condolences to his family and friends\". He resided in the  neighborhood of Long Beach for over 51 years. Throughout his adult life, he was a member of  in Long Beach.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* , California State Library.\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Nicholas James Melvoin''' (born 1985) is an American attorney, former teacher, and  serving as member of the  Board of Education for District 4 since May 16, 2017. A member of the , Melvoin is the second youngest member of the board after .\n\n\nMelvoin was born in  to television writer  and photojournalist Martha Hartnett Melvoin, and is the older brother of Charles \"Charlie\" Melvoin. He graduated from  in 2004 and from  in 2008, earning a  from  and a  from the .\n\n\n  (to the right), with other LAUSD officials in 2021.|250px|left]]\nMelvoin started teaching at Edwin Markham Middle School through the  program and had served as a  for the . He was also the director of policy, communications and associate counsel for Great Public Schools Now and a consultant to Educators 4 Excellence and Teach Plus. After his first year at Markham Middle School, he was laid off along with 70% of teachers due to budget cuts. Melvoin worked on the ACLU’s  Reed v. California lawsuit, which challenged LAUSD’s seniority-based teacher layoff policies, as well as testifying in the  lawsuit.\n\nIn 2016, Melvoin announced that he would be a candidate for the  Board of Education for District 4, held by member and Vice President of the Board Steve Zimmer. Melvoin said he ran because he realized that there \"was a lot outside my classroom that was affecting what was happening inside.\" The race was joined by candidates Allison Holdorff Polhill and Greg Martayan. On February 23, 2017, all four candidates debated on the role of , undocumented students, and the budget for the District at a  forum.\n\nMelvoin and Zimmer competed in a runoff after the general election where Polhill and Martayan were eliminated. Melvoin was endorsed by the , the , the , and . Melvoin's campaign was criticized for receiving significant third-party spending support to defeat Zimmer, including the  who spent more than $5 million for his campaign. The election itself was also criticized for being what was believed to be the most expensive school board election in U.S. history.\n\nOn May 17, 2017, Zimmer conceded to Melvoin in the race during a speech to his supporters, calling it devastating while saying that he would never run for office again. Melvoin won against Zimmer by fourteen points, and with his win, Melvoin replaced Zimmer as a board member for District 4. After the election, the charter-backed candidates, including Melvoin, had a majority on the Board of Education.\n\nDuring the , Melvoin said that the District couldn't afford the teacher's demands. In 2019, Melvoin announced that he would seek re-election, and was endorsed by Teamsters Local 572 in his successful campaign. He won re-election against two other candidates with nearly 60% of the vote. With the Board election, the teachers' union candidates won back control of the Board, and in 2023, Melvoin was replaced by Scott Schmerelson as the vice president of the Board of Education.\n\nIn 2023, Melvoin announced that he would run for , an open seat vacated by incumbent 's run for . He stated that he believed that his young age would match the voters' \"desire for new blood and new vision.\" He lost the primary against  and Alex Balekian.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
