    "pages": }\n (2013–2023) (2023–present)\n|term_start   = January 3, 2013\n|term_end     = \n|predecessor  = \n|successor    = \n|office1      = President of \n|term_start1  = December 2006\n|term_end1    = December 2008\n|predecessor1 = Position established\n|successor1   = \n|office2      = Member of from the 1st district\n|term_start2  = December 2000\n|term_end2    = December 2008\n|predecessor2 = Harry Mathis\n|successor2   = \n|birth_name   = Scott Harvey Peters\n|birth_date   = \n|birth_place  = , U.S.\n|death_date   = \n|death_place  = \n|party        = \n|spouse       = \n|children     = 2\n|education    =  () ()\n|website      = \n| module              = \n}}\n'''Scott Harvey Peters''' (born June 17, 1958) is an American lawyer and politician serving as the  from  since 2023, previously representing the  from 2013 to 2023. His district includes both coastal and central portions of , as well as the suburbs of  and .\n\nA member of the , Peters served two terms on the  from 2000 to 2008, and was the first person to hold the post of president of the city council from 2006 to 2008. He served as a commissioner for the Unified  before becoming a member of Congress.\n\n\nPeters was born in 1958 in . He was raised in . His father was a , and his mother was a homemaker. Peters has said that he took out student loans and participated in his school's work-study program, through which he was given jobs answering phones and cleaning pigeon cages. He received his undergraduate degree from  in 1980.\n\nPeters served as an economist on the staff of the U.S.  (EPA), Retrieved February 28, 2012. then earned a  degree from the  (’84). Before his election to the city council, he worked as a deputy county counsel for  and as an attorney in private practice focusing on environmental law. He gained notability in a lawsuit against a local shipbuilder.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2002, Peters was appointed to the . He served one three-year term on the Commission. A coalition of environmental groups gave his votes an environmental score of 31% in 2002, 52% in 2003 and 40% in 2004. He was \"involuntarily retired\" in 2005 when new State Assembly Speaker  did not renew his appointment.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2000, Peters ran for the 's 1st district. In the open primary, he ranked second with 24% of the vote, qualifying for the November general election. Businesswoman Linda Davis ranked first with 32% of the vote. Peters defeated Davis, 53%-47%.\n\nIn , he came in first with 48% of the vote. Businessman Phil Thalheimer ranked second with 31% of the vote. In the November election, Peters was reelected, defeating Thalheimer 55%-45%.\n\n\nIn 2004, San Diego city residents voted to change the structure of city government from a council-city manager form to a mayor-council form, which made the mayor the city's chief executive officer. Serving as a member of the city council during this time, Peters was elected to chair the transition committee in charge of this project.\n\nIn 2005, Peters's fellow council members elected him to serve as the first president of the San Diego City Council, which under the new form of government made him the chief officer of the city's newly defined legislative branch. In 2008, San Diego's mayor vetoed a 24% pay raise for the city council that Peters and four other council members had voted for.\n\nPeters was a member of the San Diego City Council during the . In 2002, he voted with the majority to underfund the employee pension system. The ensuing  investigation cleared Peters and the other council members of fraud, but the Kroll Report investigation called them \"negligent.\" The city spent $7 million defending officials involved in this case, including $631,000 defending Peters. During the 2012 congressional election campaign, his Republican opponent, , made the scandal a major issue.\n\nIn 2007, Peters was criticized for excessive water use during a drought. He ended the year having consumed more than 1 million gallons of water for his home, which sits on a 34,848-square-foot lot near , and for an adjacent landscaped parcel.\n\nPeters cited a reduction in sewer spills and beach closure days as accomplishments during his city council tenure. He stated that the city averaged one spill per day when he was elected in 2000, but that the incidence of such spills fell 80% during his terms in office. He was involved in the push to ban alcohol from the city's beaches, as well as to ban smoking from public beaches and parks.\n\n\nHaving reached the end of his eight-year term limit on the city council, Peters ran for  in , challenging incumbent City Attorney . In the open primary, state legislator  ranked first with 32% of the vote. The incumbent ranked second with 29% of the vote, qualifying for the runoff election. Peters ranked third with 20% of the vote and did not advance to the runoff. He later served as deputy county counsel for the .\n\n\n\nPeters was a port commissioner from 2009 through 2012, serving as chair of the Port Commission in 2011. He was sworn in as a commissioner in January 2009, after having been appointed by the . He represented the City of San Diego on the Port Commission, making decisions about the uses of  and its adjacent waterfront land. Retrieved February 28, 2012.\n\nPeters's fellow commissioners chose him to serve as chair of the board of commissioners for 2011. January 11, 2011. In January 2011, he said one of his top priorities was to decommission the South Bay Power Plant in Chula Vista to make room for better use. In the year Peters served as chair, the board of commissioners reached a deal with the former operator of the plant for its demolition. The Port also conducted community outreach for six months to gather ideas for improving San Diego's waterfront \"front porch\" between the airport and Seaport Village.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPeters ran for the newly redrawn  in 2012. The district had previously been the , represented by  incumbent . In the final month of the race, Peters lent $1.25 million to his own campaign. In the open primary, Bilbray ranked first with 41% of the vote. Peters ranked second with 23% of the vote, qualifying for the November general election ballot. He narrowly edged out State Assemblywoman , a fellow Democrat, who earned 22% of the vote. The other candidates all received single-digit percentages. During the primary, Peters received the endorsement of retiring congressman  of the neighboring . On election night the vote was too close to call, but Peters's small lead increased each day as more absentee, vote-by-mail, and provisional ballots were processed. On November 16, Bilbray conceded to Peters. Peters defeated Bilbray 51%-49%, a difference of 6,956 votes. He became the first Democrat to represent what is now the 52nd since 1991, when  was unseated in what was then the 44th district (it was renumbered the 51st in 1993 and the 50th in 2003).\n\n\n\n\n\nIn the June 2014 primary, Peters was opposed by three Republicans. Peters was the top vote-getter with 42%. Under California's \"top two\" primary system, he faced the second-place finisher, former city councilman , in the November general election. Peters was a member of the 's Frontline Program. The program is designed to help protect vulnerable Democratic candidates. In August, Peters was endorsed by the , which usually endorses Republicans. Peters was supported by 100  that had supported the Republican incumbent, Brian Bilbray, in the previous cycle.\n\nIn a poll conducted by SurveyUSA for U-T San Diego and  during September 11–15, 2014, Peters polled at 47% and DeMaio at 46%. The same poll taken October 2–6 showed DeMaio with a 3-point lead over Peters, within the margin of error. An earlier Survey USA poll showed Peters leading by one point.\n\nOn election night the result was too close to call, with DeMaio ahead by 751 votes. Over the next few days Peters pulled into the lead. By Friday, Peters had a lead of 4,491 votes, and the Associated Press called the election for him. The final result was Peters 51.59% and DeMaio 48.41%.\n\n\n\n\nPeters was re-elected in 2016 with 56.5% of the vote, handily defeating Republican Denise Gitsham.\n\n\n\nPeters was reelected with 63.8% of the vote over Republican Omar Qudrat.\n\n\n\nPeters was reelected with 61.6% of the vote over Republican Jim DeBello.\n\n\nAfter his district changed to the , Peters was reelected with 62.8% of the vote over Republican Corey Gustafson.\n\n\nPeters supported reauthorizing the  in early 2013. In April of that year, he voted for the , a bill that would allow federal intelligence agencies to share cybersecurity intelligence and information with private entities and utilities. Peters co-sponsored the  in March 2013. In May, he voted against repeal of the  (PPACA). The same year, he co-sponsored the . In October 2013, Peters was one of nine Democratic co-sponsors of HR3425, an unsuccessful proposal to delay any penalties under the PPACA until four months after the program's website was fully functional. As of late 2013, Peters had voted the same way as Republican   nine of the 16 times that Boehner had cast a vote.\n\nIn 2014, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, a Republican-affiliated lobbying group, said Peters voted with the Chamber's position on key bills 69% of the time. Also in 2014, Peters said he would prefer that Congress develop a strategy to deal with climate change, but that in lieu of congressional action, he would support President Obama's moves to bypass Congress and look for an international climate change deal.\n\nPeters signed the  in early 2015. Months later, the Supreme Court decided '''', making the act ''de facto'' federal law.\n\nPeters co-sponsored the Safe Drinking Water Act Improved Compliance Awareness Act, which would have required lead in drinking water to be reported to the public. In June 2016, House Democrats staged a  to protest the lack of a vote on gun control. The Speaker pro tem, , declared the House was in recess, and the video feed to  was shut off. But after a brief interruption, C-SPAN was able to broadcast the sit-in because Peters streamed the activity using his  account. That same month, Peters voted in support of the .\n\nIn 2019, Peters sponsored the bipartisan Super Pollutants Act, which according to a press release from his office \"aims to slow climate change by regulating black carbon, hydrofluorocarbons, and methane–some of the most potent greenhouse gases. These short-lived climate pollutants, also called super pollutants, are significantly more potent than carbon dioxide.\"\n\nIn 2021, Peters voted against moving forward with the , leading to protest from environmentalist and progressive groups.\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n** \n* \n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\nPeters is a moderate Democrat. He is vice-chair of the centrist New Democrat Coalition. A 2016 analysis found that Peters was among the House members \"most likely to vote against his fellow party members.\" He was quoted saying \"I’m proud of my independent record.\" Peters endorsed , saying that \"we need an alternative to Sen. Sanders and Sen. Warren... I disagree with them more on policy.\"\n\n\n\nPeters is . He has a 100% rating from  and an F rating from the , an anti-abortion organization, for his abortion-related voting record. He opposed the .\n\n\n\n;LGBTQ+\nPeters supports .\n\n;Women's rights\nHis efforts to support women's rights earned him an endorsement from the  in 2012.\n\n\n\nPeters supports bipartisan climate action. Peters has called  \"a global emergency and imminent threat that requires us to work across party lines to take bold, immediate action.\"  He supports efforts to decarbonize the economy to become net-zero carbon, including . He also wants to regulate ,  and , which he believes contribute to climate change. Peters also wants to see the auto industry transition to electric vehicles.\n\n;Wildfires\nPeters acknowledges that  have increased due to climate change. He considers wildfires, and natural disasters, high priority in his district. He has sponsored legislation to ensure transparency in government spending on disaster responses. He also has supported the Wildfire Disaster Funding Act to fund wildfire suppression and prevention efforts.\n\n\n\nPeters called the Trump administration's response to COVID-19 \"abysmal\" and said that \"other countries look on with a mixture of horror and pity for how this has gone for us.” He pushed to oppose a patent waiver that would allow developing nations to create their own vaccines.\n\n\n\nPeters opposes expanding  and has supported efforts to ban it in the Gulf of Mexico. He supports  and investing in advanced nuclear technologies. In September 2023, Peters introduced the  in the House as H.R. 5551 alongside Senator  (), who introduced it in the . The bill's provisions direct the  to \"establish minimum interregional transfer capabilities\", better coordinating construction of  lines. The bill is part of broader push to accelerate permitting for clean energy.\n\n\n\nPeters supports .\n\n;Voting rights\n\nPeters opposes requiring photo ID to vote. He supports automatic voter registration for eligible voters and making election day a federal holiday.\n\n\n\nPeters supports background check requirements for every firearm sale and transfer.\n\n\n\nHe supports the  and opposes efforts to repeal it.\n\nIn 2019, Peters supported a bill to lower drug costs, but in 2021, he played a leading role in preventing its passage. Peters was one of three Democrats on the House Energy Committee to oppose allowing Medicare to negotiate drug prices, except in a small subset of cases. In September 2021, he and Representatives  and  joined Republican members to block committee passage of such a bill, 29-29. Peters appeared to be the leader of the opposition group. Peters has received consistent and considerable financial support from the pharmaceutical industry since he was first elected in 2012. Over his career, pharmaceutical PACs and employees have donated $860,465 to his campaigns, the second-most of any industry, according to . By mid-September in the 2022 election cycle, pharmaceutical industry contributions to Peters exceeded those of all other House members and candidates at $88,550.\n\n\n\nPeters considers housing and homelessness top concerns in his district. He supports affordable housing and building dense housing near transit, with the goal of getting more homes being built while improving transit infrastructure.\n\n\n\nPeters supports the  and creating paths to citizenship for longtime immigrant U.S. residents. He opposed the . Peters co-sponsored the Providing Justice for Asylum Seekers Act to make it easier for immigration judges to reschedule cases to avoid automatic deportation of people seeking asylum.\n\n\n\nPeters has led efforts to improve infrastructure at . He has encouraged the building of new Navy ships based in San Diego. He supports a new  training facility in the San Diego area.\n\n\n\nPeters co-sponsored the . He believes in partnering with law enforcement officers \"to change the culture.\"\n\n\n\nPeters considers the border relations between San Diego and Mexico one of his district's top priorities. He opposed the  and supports the . He has led efforts to upgrade the  to reduce border waits. He also supports modernizing border security.\n\n\nIn 2022, Peters was one of 16 Democrats to vote against the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act of 2022, an antitrust package that would crack down on corporations for anti-competitive behavior.\n\n\nPeters lives with his family in . He and his wife, Lynn E. Gorguze, have two children. Gorguze is president and CEO of Cameron Holdings, and his family has a net worth of $112 million. As of 2014, Peters was the sixth-.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n*  campaign website\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Charles S.''' \"'''Chuck'''\" '''DeVore''' (born May 20, 1962) is an American  who served as a  member of the  from 2004 to 2010 when he lived in  and represented the , which includes portions of . DeVore was Vice Chair of the Assembly Revenue and Taxation Committee as well as Vice Chair of the s Affairs Committee. He also served on the Budget Committee and was a member of the Joint Legislative Audit Committee. After losing a 2010 bid for Republican nomination for the , in 2011 DeVore moved to Texas to work for the  where he is now Vice President for National Initiatives.\n\n\nDeVore earned a full Army ROTC scholarship that allowed him to obtain a bachelor's degree in Strategic Studies (cum laude) in 1985 from . He was named a Distinguished Military Graduate. He studied abroad at , Egypt. He's a graduate of the U.S. Army's Command and General Staff Officer Course.\n\n\n\nDeVore served as Special Assistant for Foreign Affairs to the  during the Reagan administration from 1986 to 1988. In 1992, his national guard unit was activated during the . He later worked as Vice President of Communications and Research for -based aerospace company  from 1991 to 2004.\n\n\n\nDeVore resigned his position as Chief Republican  in February 2009 in protest of a $12 billion per year tax increase agreed to by Republican leadership. While a California lawmaker, DeVore favored offshore oil drilling along the California coast as well as the development of modern nuclear power plants. He opposed the federal stimulus package in 2009. He is pro-life. DeVore signed the official ballot argument against California's  act in the November 4, 2008 election.\n\n\n\nDeVore has voiced reluctance to commit the U.S. military to open-ended nation building efforts. He criticized President Obama's 2009 plan for Afghanistan, saying, \"(The) piecemeal buildup will not defeat the Taliban...\" and \"...such a strategy expends resources now sorely needed to rebuild our military and retool it for future challenges from a rapidly modernizing People's Republic of China to a revanchist Islamic Republic of Iran.\" He appeared on Fox Business News to warn about the Libyan intervention.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDeVore declared his candidacy for the 2010 Republican nomination for the  seat held by three-term  senator .\nIn the Republican primary on June 8, DeVore finished third out of five candidates with 19.3% of the vote with  winning the Republican nomination. DeVore raised $2.6 million for his primary effort.\n\nDeVore's campaign was sued for copyright infringement by musician  for use by the campaign of two parodies of two songs by Henley, \"After the Hope of November is Gone\" (after \"The Boys of Summer\") and   \"All She Wants to Do is Tax\" (after \"All She Wants to Do Is Dance\"). Henley eventually prevailed;\nDevore and a campaign worker issued a public statement apologizing to Henley.\n\n\nDeVore moved to Texas in late 2011 to accept a job as a visiting scholar at the nonprofit  writing about 's low taxes and regulations and its effects on business climate, in contrast to other states. By the summer of 2012, DeVore had been named a vice president at the conservative think tank.\n\n\n''The Crisis of the House Never United: A Novel of Early America'' in 2022.\n\n''The Texas Model: Prosperity in the Lone Star State and Lessons for America'' in 2013. A new edition of the book was published in 2014:\n\nCo-authored ''China Attacks'' in 2000, Chinese language edition published in 2001.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''George C. Runner Jr.''' (born March 25, 1952) is an American politician from  who served on the , the only publicly elected tax commission in the United States. A , he represented the Board's 2nd District from 2011 to 2015 and the renumbered 1st District from 2015 to 2019.\n\nFrom 2004 to 2010, he was a  representing the , and was the Republican  Chair (the Senate's second-highest Republican leadership post) from 2004 to 2009.  From 1996 to 2002, he was a man representing the , which at the time consisted of portions of .\n\n\nBorn in , Runner moved with his family to  as a young child.  After attending local public schools in Lancaster, Runner earned a  in  from the  and a graduate certificate in  from .\n\n\n\nWith his wife Sharon, George Runner founded the .\n\nWe wanted a school for not only everyone else's children, but for our own children, where we knew they were going to hear about God in an exciting way; a place where their faith was not just some parallel subject matter, but was integrated effectively throughout history, math, science and English.\n\n\nIn 1992, Runner was elected to the Lancaster .  He served as Lancaster's  from 1994–95 and as  of Lancaster from 1995 to 1996. During his mayoral term, the ''California Business Journal'' named Lancaster the number one mid-size city with which to do business.\n\n\nIn 1996, Runner was elected to represent the  and served in the State Assembly for three terms, from 1996 to 2002. During this time of service, Runner served as Vice Chair of the Assembly Budget Committee.\n\nIn 2004, he was elected to the Senate to represent the .\n\nRunner served in 2007-2008 as the Chair of the Senate Republican Caucus.  He also served as Vice Chair of the Senate Banking, Finance, and Insurance Committee, Vice Chair of the Senate Environmental Quality Committee, and as a member of the Senate Appropriations Committee, Senate Revenue and Taxation Committee, and the Senate Select Committee on Defense and Aerospace Industries.\n\nDuring his legislative career, Runner was named Legislator of the Year by:\n* The California State s Association\n* Crime Victims United\n* California Sexual Assault Investigators Association\n* Coalition of Chief Probation Officers\n* California Coalition of Directors of Environmental Health\n*  Trustees\n* \n\nHe also received the Pursuit of Justice Award from the Association of s–.\n\n\nIn 2002, Runner authored California's  system, which has successfully utilized the  to involve the general public in the search for abducted children and has aided in numerous successful parent-child reunions.\n\n\n\nIn 2006, along with his wife, then-Assemblywoman , George Runner authored , California's version of . The measure passed with the support of 71% of California voters, and passed in 57 of California's 58 counties.\n\nJessica's Law ensures that all sexual offenders who are convicted of activity with children under the age of 14 are put into a prison with a mandatory minimum sentence of 15 years or 25 years to life. It eliminates all \"first-offense\"  provisions from California law.\n\nIt also eliminates all \"good-time\" credits for sexual offenders serving prison terms; under the authored provisions they are required to serve their entire sentence and will not be released for good behavior. The law requires that sex offenders who are released from prison wear a  for life. It also creates a 2,000-foot (615 meter) zone around schools and parks in which registered sex offenders are prohibited from residing.\n\n\nOn February 3, 2010, Runner introduced SB 944, the nation's first  legislation.\n\nOn July 19, 2010, Governor  signed the bill into law, making California the first state in the union to have a permanent  Day.  Ronald Reagan Day would be celebrated each February 6 as a \"day of special significance\" in California, which would not be a state holiday, nor would give any workers a day off, but rather would be a day that schools \"are encouraged to conduct exercises remembering the life of Ronald Reagan, recognizing his accomplishments, and familiarizing pupils with the contributions he made\" to California.  Ronald Reagan Day is California's third day of special significance honoring a specific person, after  Day, and .\n\n\nIn 2010, Runner authored California's  system, which authorizes the  to use the  when a  has been killed, seriously wounded, or assaulted with a deadly weapon.\n\n\nSince 2009, Runner has served with  as a taxpayer advocate on local tax issues in California.\n\n\nIn February 2009, Runner announced his candidacy for the District 2 seat on the .\n\nIn his bid for the Republican nomination for the BOE, Runner was endorsed by the , the California Republican Assembly, the , radio talk show hosts , former Governor , and former Republican Gubernatorial Nominee , among others.\n\nRunner won the Republican nomination for BOE after defeating Assemblyman  and incumbent BOE Member  in the June 2010 primary.  Runner is the first person to defeat an incumbent BOE member's reelection bid since 1978 and only the fifth person to do so in California history.  Runner won the November 2010 general election for the seat, defeating Democrat tax attorney Chris Parker.  Alby inexplicably resigned on December 31, 2010, four days before Runner was to be sworn in.\n\nConsequently, Runner's Chief of Staff, , was sworn in as acting BOE Member until Runner could be sworn in on January 3, 2011, at which point Wallentine became Runner's Chief Deputy at the BOE.\n\nDuring his time on the Board, Runner has sought to improve California's tax policies and practices and to create and retain more private sector jobs in that state. Among his accomplishments, Runner cites helping end a requirement that new businesses provide a security deposit to the Board, resulting in the return of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of security back to business owners; leading a successful effort to reform an inefficient use tax collection program aimed at small businesses; and clarifying that farmers who purchase solar equipment are eligible for the same tax exemptions as those who purchase diesel generators.\n\nRunner is a leader in the fight against the state's controversial fire tax; he supports a class action lawsuit that seeks to overturn the tax and return millions of dollars back to taxpayers.\n\nIn February 2014, Runner announced that he would seek re-election to a second term, citing early endorsements from Congressman and Majority Whip , the , the California Association of Highway Patrolmen, CDF Firefighters, among others.\n\nAs a result of redistricting, he ran in the first district, which was being vacated by Democrat . He easily won re-election, besting Democrat Chris Parker by wide margins in both the June primary and November general elections. Democrat  won his seat in the second district.\n\nIn February 2018, his colleagues selected him to serve as the Board's Chairman.\n\n\nHe married  in 1973. She succeeded him as the 36th District Assemblymember in 2002. Senator George Runner and Assemblywoman Sharon Runner were the first husband and wife to serve concurrently in the , doing so from 2004 to 2008. She succeeded him as Senator in 2011. Sharon Runner died at her home on July 14, 2016, due to \"respiratory complications.\" She was survived by her husband, two children (Micah and Rebekah (who serves in the ) and their spouses, and  four grandchildren.\n\n player  is Runner's nephew.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Lois Wolk''' (born May 12, 1946) is an American  and former member of the . A , she represented the , which encompasses  the  region and portions of the .\n\nWolk was a member of the California Legislative Jewish Caucus. Before being elected to the State Senate in 2008, she served in the , where she represented the , and the  after the 2010 . She is also a former member of both the   and the  City Council.\n\n\nWolk was born in . She earned a B.A. from  in 1968, and an M.A. from  in 1971. She has taught history, Social Studies and French in grades 7 through 12 in both public and private schools. Wolk lives in  with her husband, Bruce Wolk, formerly a Professor of Law at . They married in 1968 and have two sons, Adam and Dan. Dan is the former mayor of Davis, California.\n\n\nWolk won a seat on the Davis City Council in 1990, and served two terms as Mayor from 1992 to 1994 and 1996 to 1998. She then served as   from 1998 to 2002, chairing the Board in 2000.\n\nWolk was elected to the  in 2002, and won re-election in 2004 and 2006.\n\nWolk was Chair of the Assembly Water, Parks and Wildlife Committee and she served on Assembly Committees on Budget, Local Government, and Natural Resources, as well as the Budget Subcommittee on Transportation and Information Technology. In addition, Wolk served on numerous Select Committees including Biotechnology; California Children's School Readiness and Health; Domestic Violence; Growth and Infrastructure; Ports; Water, Infrastructure and the Economy; Rural Economic Development; and Wine.\n\nIn her five years in the Assembly, Wolk succeeded in authoring 56 new laws. In 2007, Governor  signed many Wolk-authored bills including legislation to improve flood protection in flood-prone areas of California's Central Valley; improve safety on a treacherous stretch of State Highway 12; require more planning for state parks and recreation opportunities for the Central Valley; and provide the Department of Fish and Game with the authority to control highly invasive species that threaten California's water delivery and natural ecosystems.\n\nWolk has been honored by many organizations for her public service, including the Planning and Conservation League, which named Wolk its 2007 Legislator of the Year for her leadership in water policy and legislation, and for championing a landmark package of flood protection bills to strengthen flood protection in California's Central Valley and  region.\n\nIn 2007, both the Highway 12 Association and Solano Transportation Authority honored Wolk for her tireless work to develop a Highway 12 safety package with the California Department of Transportation and , and for authoring legislation to establish a safety enhancement double fine zone on a dangerous stretch of State Highway Route 12.\n\nWolk  of the Assembly in 2008 and was succeeded by Mariko Yamada.\n\nIn 2008, Wolk ran for the California State Senate in the 5th district, the seat held by . Wolk defeated her  opponent, fellow assembly-member  of .\n\nIn 2015, Wolk co-sponsored, with , the SB-128  which allows residents of California who meet strict criteria to exercise their  through .\n\nWolk was termed out in 2016 and was succeeded by Bill Dodd.\n\nWork, who is Jewish, is a member of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Eunisses Hernandez''' (born 1990) is an American activist and politician, currently serving as a member of the  for the  since 2022. A member of the  and the , Hernandez defeated incumbent councilmember  during the primary in an  in the .\n\nA self-described  and , Hernandez was endorsed by  groups and leaders like City Councilman  and , and the ''''. Hernandez declared victory on June 18, 2022, before the final vote tally, which was certified on July 1, 2022. Cedillo conceded the same day.\n\n\nHernandez was born in 1990 to Mexican immigrants, Juan and Leticia Hernandez, and grew up in . Early in her life, Hernandez thought about becoming a . She attended  and later  for one year in 2009, where she majored in civil engineering. During her employment at , she graduated from  with a bachelor's degree in criminal justice in 2013. It was during her time at CSU Long Beach where she \"experienced [...] a revelation\" after she took a class for criminology and the .\n\n\n in 2020.]]\nHernandez started her career in 2014 as a policy coordinator for the  where she advocated for the passing of Senate Bill 180 and . In 2018, she moved to JustLeadershipUSA as a campaign coordinator for  where she pushed for a halt to a plan to build a new $3.5 million women's jail at the county's Mira Loma facility in . In 2019, she was appointed by the  to be a community stakeholder for an Alternatives to Incarceration working group.\n\nIn 2020, she co-founded La Defensa with Ivette Alé, a women-led organization that supports reducing the number of incarcerated people in Los Angeles County. That same year she co-chaired Measure J, a ballot initiative that would allocate at least 10% of Los Angeles County's funding for community reinvestment and incarceration alternatives. She co-chaired the ballot initiative campaign with future   and future councilmember ; the initiative passed with 57.12% of the vote. In 2021, the measure was temporarily blocked by  Judge Mary Strobel, who ruled that Measure J violated California law by infringing on the County Board of Supervisors' authority to set budgets; in 2023, however, the  reversed this ruling, allowing the measure to take effect.\n\n\nOn October 8, 2021, Hernandez announced her campaign for  in the . After three other candidates were disqualified, she was the only opponent against incumbent . Hernandez was endorsed by multiple  groups and leaders, with Council-member  and  endorsing her in the primary. Hernandez ultimately unseated Cedillo with 53.9% of the vote, avoiding the need for a runoff.\n\nIn May 2023, Hernandez was the only member of the Los Angeles City Council to vote against Mayor 's first budget. Hernandez cited the $3.2 billion allocated to the  as the motivation for her vote, giving a speech in which she said that \"we are celebrating moving pennies around, while we put a quarter of our entire budget into just one department.\"\n\nIn May 2023, Hernandez spoke at a press event to reveal “\", a piece of grated metal on a pole intended to provide shade and lighting for bus riders at a bus stop. The bus stop structure was criticized for failing to provide any meaningful shade.\n\nIn August 2023, Hernandez along with  and  voted against a four-year package of raises and bonuses for rank-and-file police officers. They argued that it would pull money away from mental health clinicians, homeless outreach workers and many other city needs. They warned of the financial consequences for other agencies, particularly if the city is confronted with a major economic downturn. Hernandez and Raman reeled off a list of services that they said are in need of more money  streetlights, sidewalk repairs, building inspections, alley resurfacing and other city operations. \n\nIn 2024, Hernandez introduced a motion to suspend private construction of a $300 million 1.2 mile  connecting Union Station to Dodger Stadium. She put forward a motion to provide $500,000 to consultants to study traffic to the Dodger Stadium.\n\nIn 2024, there was a major push in the L.A. City Council to implement ethics reform in the aftermath of a number of corruption and harassment scandals. During negotiations to implement more stringent ethics reforms, Hernandez introduced a series of late amendments that watered down the reform.\n\n\nIn 2023, she reversed an effort by her predecessor to remove  in a section of Chinatown. During her campaign for the city council, Hernandez blamed rising housing prices and evictions on new housing developments. She said, \"My plan to fight gentrification is to be the biggest barrier I can to luxury and market-rate development.\" \n\nIn 2022, she expressed support for the discretionary permit system in Los Angeles, which gives City Council members discretionary power over land-use decisions, allowing them to veto proposed projects. In 2023, Hernandez took no position on a proposal by Mayor Bass to convert the Mayfair Hotel, a 294-room facility in L.A.’s  neighborhood, into housing for the homeless. Hernandez said, \"At this time, we are awaiting additional details regarding the project and its potential outcomes.\"\n\nIn 2023, Hernandez supported a motion in the City Council to prohibit the sale or rental of  for use as housing.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Eleni Kounalakis''', }} (née '''Tsakopoulos''';, }} born March 3, 1966) is an American politician, businesswoman, and diplomat serving as the 50th  since 2019. A member of the , she is the first woman and the first  elected to the office.\n\nKounalakis graduated from  with a  degree before attending , where she obtained a . After graduation, she worked for AKT Development Corporation, a Sacramento-based real estate company founded by her father, , eventually serving as president of the company until 2010.\n\nKounalakis was appointed by President  to serve as the  from 2010 to 2013. She was , and . As lieutenant governor, she attempted to disqualify  from the  following the 's ruling in . She was subsequently  and , part of a . \n\nOn April 24, 2023, Kounalakis announced her candidacy for  in the .\n\n\nEleni Kounalakis is the daughter of , a Sacramento developer. Kounalakis is of  descent and grew up a member of the .\n\nKounalakis received her undergraduate degree from  and a Master of Business Administration from the 's .\n\n\n\n\nBefore 2009, Kounalakis was President of AKT Development Corporation, a family-owned real estate, farming, ranching, water, minerals, building, land development and property investment company, based in Sacramento, California, founded by Angelo K Tsakopoulos, her father, in 1964. \n\nKounalakis and her husband, print and broadcast journalist , founded two university chairs in Hellenic studies, the Markos and Eleni Tsakopoulos Kounalakis chair at , held by the scholar of late Classical and early Hellenistic Greek literature, Alexander Sens, and the Tsakopoulos Kounalakis chair in honor of  at , held by . Both chairs focus on the understanding of the origins of . They also established the Tsakopoulos Kounalakis lecture series at the  to focus on democracy and international relations.\n\nKounalakis served for nearly ten years as a Trustee of the World Council of . In recognition for her work with the WCRP, she was awarded the medal of St. Paul, the 's highest honor. San Francisco Mayor  appointed her to serve as a Trustee of the . San Francisco Mayor  appointed her to serve on the Port Commission Board.\n\n\nKounalakis served four times as a delegate to the  and as an at-large member of the California State Democratic Central Committee. She also served as a member of the , and the California Blue Ribbon Commission on Autism. She served as a Trustee of Robert Redford's Sundance Preserve and on the 's National Forum on Children and Nature. She is also a senior advisor at .\n\nIn 2009, Kounalakis accepted President 's nomination to an ambassadorship.\n\nOn April 24, 2017, Kounalakis announced her bid for the office of  in the . After her candidacy announcement, she visited all 58 counties in California during her campaign. Her grassroots campaign earned the recognition of ''Time'' magazine for engaging hundreds of volunteers to text over 1 million voters before Election Day. She came in first place on June 5, 2018, in the top-two statewide primary; Democratic State Senator  placed second. On November 6, Kounalakis was elected by a 56.6% to 43.3% margin against her opponent, becoming the first female elected Lieutenant Governor of California in history;  was appointed in an acting capacity in 2009 following the resignation of  but was not elected to the post. Kounalakis and Governor-elect  took office on January 7, 2019.\n\nKounalakis was re-elected lieutenant governor . She announced her candidacy for  in the  on April 24, 2023.\n\nKounalakis serves on the Regents of the University of California (the  holds one seat). In September 2023, she voted to delay approval of an eight-story, 545-bed dorm for UCLA students in Los Angeles's affluent  neighborhood due to concerns of undersized dorms. The board approved the project in November 2023.\n  \nFollowing her efforts to disqualify  from the , she was  and , part of a .\n\n\nEleni Tsakopoulos married  in 2000. They have two sons. \n\nIn 2011, she received an Honorary Doctor of Law from the .\n\n\n\n\n - PDF}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* at \n* of the California Lt.     "pages": }\n\n'''Kenneth W. Maddox''' (born February 29, 1964, in ), also known as '''Ken Lopez-Maddox,''' is a former man who served from 1998 until 2004, representing part of . After this term, he entered a State Senate primary, but was defeated by his opponent.\n\nHe received his Bachelor of Science degree from  and is a member of the fraternity .  He has his Master of Arts degree in management from the National University and was a past Senior Fellow of Public Policy at UCLA.\n\nHe was a deputy sheriff for Los Angeles County and a  in  prior to his election to the assembly. He remained a reserve police officer during his tenure in the legislature. He has also been a , and served in the  and Army Reserve from 1981 to 1989.  He received a Reserve Commission in the United States Army while attending the University of Texas at Arlington and was branched Armor.  He returned to serve in the military following the .\n\nKen Lopez-Maddox is a member of the Lutheran Church Missouri Synod\n\n\nHe was elected to the assembly in November 1998.\n\nWhile in the legislature, Maddox served on a variety of policy committees including Public Safety, Insurance, Utilities and Commerce, Governmental Organization, Environmental Safety and Toxics, Agriculture, Education and Local Government.  He served on the Select Committee on Elder Abuse and the Select Committee on Police Conduct, among others.  He received the Order of California from Governor Gray Davis for his efforts on behalf of military veterans.\n\nHe authored California's Amber Alert legislation,  Safe Surrender for Newborns and ocean water quality legislation to protect Huntington Beach's coastline and marine life.\n\nHe was also the Republican lead in an investigation into corruption at the Department of Insurance.\n\nPrior to serving in the legislature, he served on the  City Council. Maddox was on the City Council during major resort developments along the Harbor Corridor south of . He was also involved in the construction of an education center and the recruitment of national restaurant chains to the area.\n\nMaddox's  as a California State Assemblyman was reached in 2004.\n\n\n\n\nHe lost a  primary in 2004 to , an Assemblyman from a neighboring district. Maddox got 30% of the vote in the primary compared to Campbell's 61% of the vote. Maddox considered running for  in 2006 but ultimately did not.\n\n\nMaddox became Senior Advisor on Legislation and Tax Policy for  Member  in 2007.\n\n\nIn 2008, he was elected to a seat on the  of the  after the incumbent was removed by the electorate in a . The Capistrano Unified School District was the highest performing large school district in the state during his tenure on the Board. He served on the board of trustees for two years.\n\n'''Emergency Service District'''\n\nOn June 1, 2021, he was appointed as a Commissioner of Emergency Service District 4 for Bexar County, Texas.  This appointment was made by the Bexar County Commissioners Court.\n\n\n\n \n  3.https://www.latimes.com/socal/dai-pilot/news/tn-dpt-xpm-2004-03-04-export14655-story.html\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Howard Lawrence Berman''' (born April 15, 1941) is an American attorney and retired politician who served as a  from  from 1983 to 2013. A member of the , he represented the state's  until redistricting and the which both encompassed parts of the for a combined 15 terms.\n\n\nBerman was born in , to  parents, the son of Eleanor (née Schapiro) and Joseph Berman. His maternal grandparents immigrated from . He graduated from  in 1959 and earned his  in  in 1962 and his  in 1965 at the  where he befriended future congressman . Blanche Bettington, his high school civics teacher, inspired him to enter politics and government.\n\nHe was a  volunteer (1966–1967) in  and , and was an  at a  , Levy, Van Bourg & Hackler (1967–72) specializing in .\"Howard L Berman\", ''Carroll's Federal Directory'', , 2008. Reproduced in Biography Resource Center. Farmington Hills, Mich.: Gale, 2008. http://galenet.galegroup.com/servlet/BioRC Document Number: K2415002198. Fee, via .\"Howard Lawrence Berman.\" Marquis Who's Who TM. , 2008. Reproduced in Biography Resource Center. : , 2008. http://galenet.galegroup.com/servlet/BioRC Document Number: K2017593147. Fee.\n\n\n\nBerman won election to the Assembly in 1972 from a district in the , unseating the incumbent Republican speaker pro tempore. His brother Michael,  in 's 1968 Assembly race, again ran a targeted mail operation.\n\n\nIn 1974, Berman and Waxman both opposed 's unsuccessful revolt against  , who rewarded Berman's loyalty by appointing him the youngest  in Assembly history. McCarthy fired Berman when Berman tried to replace him in 1980. Although McCarthy failed to retain the speakership, Berman failed to win it and Brown became speaker. Other members remarked on what a tough politician he was; the Bermans helped arrange a  defeat for at least one colleague () who had opposed his bid.\n\n\nHe also served as Chairman of the Assembly Democratic Caucus and on the Policy Research Management Committee of the Assembly.\n\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting made the 26th district significantly more Democratic, incumbent Republican Congressman  decided to run in  in 1982. Berman won the Democratic primary for the open seat with 83% of the vote, and the general election with 60% of the vote.\n\n\nBerman was reelected 14 times, never dropping below 61% of the vote, from 1984 through 2010.\n\nThe  allocated California one new House seat, 53 in all. Berman, \"dad of the delegation\" on redistricting, made a deal with Republicans  and  to keep 34 safe seats for Democrats, add one new Republican district, and protect nineteen incumbent Republicans. Many California Democrats in the House and  hired Michael Berman, Howard Berman's brother, as a redistricting consultant, for a fee of $20,000 each. When the August 2001 plan was unveiled, Congressman , a fellow Democrat from California, complained that it undermined the safety of his seat with too many  voters, saying, \"Howard Berman stabbed me in the back.\" Berman agreed to redraw the boundary between their districts, giving himself 56% and Sherman 37%  population. The redistricting plan survived a court challenge from the , which argued that the redistricting diluted Hispanic representation. The Republicans suffered some slippage; they had only 19 members in the  to the .\n\nFrom 2001 to 2006, Berman paid his brother Michael Berman's consulting firm Berman & D'Agostino $195,000 from campaign funds. In the 2002 campaign, Berman & D'Agostino was paid $75,000 in political consulting fees. In 2005, $50,000 in consulting fees were paid to the company, and Michael Berman himself was paid a further $80,500 in campaign management and consulting fees. In 2006, $70,000 was paid in consulting fees.\n\n\n\nFollowing redistricting, Berman decided to run in the newly redrawn , facing fellow Democrat . Sherman had the advantage because he previously represented over half of the district. About 60% of voters of the new  resided in Sherman's former district, while just 20% of voters resided in Berman's.\n\nThe race, unprecedented in pitting two very similar candidates of the same party against each other in the general election, was called a \"slugfest\". Berman received the endorsements from about two-thirds of California's Democratic congressional delegation. Among Sherman's endorsements were then-  of California, then-  of California, former President , and Congressman  of Michigan.\n\nOn June 5, 2012, Sherman ranked first in the seven-candidate open primary, with 42% of the vote. Berman ranked second, with 26% of the vote. The state's top-two primary system, implemented in 2010, allows for two candidates of the same party to face-off in the general election. Berman ran as the more conservative Democrat, hoping to divide the Democratic vote and dominate in the independent and conservative vote. However, in the November general election, .\n\n\nBerman has been described as \"one of the most creative members of the House, and one of the most clear-sighted operators in American politics\". He has been an active legislator on several issues, but has also been described as \"not one who gets much publicity\".\n\nBerman was the House sponsor of the 1986  that authorized  by . It led to recoveries for the United States Government exceeding $1 billion dollars.\n\nBerman has championed protecting American film industry jobs from  (\"\"). He has also voted against amending the  to , against banning the , against the , and against restrictions on .\n\nHowever, Berman concurs with many on the  on a number of issues, particularly  and . Berman voted in support of the invasion of  in both  and , as well as for the , positions that have hurt his standing among many liberals in his district. While he generally supports  - for instance, voting in favor of the  (NAFTA) and various trade agreements with specific countries -, he voted against the more recent  (CAFTA). He opposes withdrawing U.S. support for the . In that same year, he also voted to phase out many  programs put into place by the administration of President  as part of the \"\".\n\nIn Congress, Berman led the investigation into the conduct of House members in the .\n\nIn May 2012, Berman co-sponsored a bill with Republican Congressman  of California to reinstate tax credits given to films produced mainly in the United States. The credits were active from 2008 until 2011, and were aimed at keeping films in . Berman stressed that we \"must make every effort to keep American productions here in the United States\".\n\n\nBerman is known for his protection of  interests, and his alliances with the entertainment industry; he was sometimes referred to as the \"representative from \". The major industry contributing to his election campaigns has been the entertainment industry. He proposed legislation under which copyright holders would be able to employ technological tools such as file blocking, , , and decoysamong othersto curb piracy (Peer to Peer Piracy Prevention Act). He has been named as one of the primary politicians involved in the creation of the  (SOPA) and the  (ACTA). In a September 2008 hearing of the House  Subcommittee, Berman criticized the 's policy requiring NIH-sponsored research to be submitted to a database open to the public by saying that \"the N in NIH shouldn't stand for .\"\n\n\nAccording to '''', \"Berman played a key and under-appreciated role in securing passage of a resolution that gave President  broad authority to use force\". The ''National Journal'' reports that Berman, \"played a critical role in winning passage, by a wide margin, of the Iraq War resolution in October 2002. He strongly supported military action against Iraq, and in September, he organized a group of Democrats who shared his views. Berman's discussions led to House Democratic   agreement with the administration on the terms of the resolutiontalks that undercut the demands of other senior Democrats, including then House Democratic   and  Chairman . In June 2006, Berman voted for the Republican resolution to reject a timetable for withdrawal from Iraq.\"\n\n\nBerman is also a supporter of , telling the Jewish newspaper, '''', after being appointed Chairman of the , \"Even before I was a Democrat, I was a .\" He has sponsored the Anti-Boycott Act in the House, which prohibits American individuals and organizations from actively boycotting i goods.\n\n\nIn 2003, Berman expressed his concerns over the Patriot Act with then- , specifically on the method to hold illegal immigrants until they prove they are not terrorists.\n\nIn 2000, Berman, along with then-Senator  of , proposed an amnesty, which would have granted legal status to hundreds of thousands of undocumented farm laborers. In exchange, requirements that growers provide housing to guest workers, and pay them a minimum wage adjusted annually for inflation, would have been relaxed. In 2005, Berman was part of the bi-partisan group in Congress that fought for immigration reform efforts. That path to citizenship was also supported by President  and Senator .\n\n\n\nFINANCE:  U.S. Lawmakers Invested in Iraq, Afghanistan Wars\n -->\n named 151 members of Congress who had investments (as of year end 2006) in companies that do business with the , suggesting that such holdings conflict with their responsibility for U.S. security policy. The most important such companies, ranked by estimated total value of members' holdings, were , , , , , , , , , and .  identified the top ten members of Congress, and the report named no other members among the 151, save  Senator  and Representative Berman. None of the firms listed above ranked among the top ten  contractors in 2008, nor in the top twenty for 2009.\n\n\n,  of the , resigned from the committee after he himself became the subject of an ethics complaint. Berman had been its senior Democrat 1997–2003, and on 2006-10-05,   re-appointed him to replace . Berman served on the subcommittee investigating the  in the wake of the . \"This is an honor I could have done without.\"\n\n reported in 2006 that members of the House Ethics Committee and their staffs had taken many privately sponsored trips, about 400 trips from 2000 to mid-2005, at a total expense nearly $1 million. Of these, Democrats took about 80% of the trips at about 70% of the cost. Berman and his staff were at the top of the chart, with trips costing more than $245,000. Berman himself had taken 14 trips at the 's expense, including two to  with Mrs. Berman. Aspen replied that its events for members were like graduate seminars, and did not push any policy agenda. \"Gene Smith, Berman's chief of staff, said that the bulk of the congressman's foreign travel can be attributed to his being a senior member on the House Committee on International Relations.\" Five private groups (, , the ,  and ) jointly sent a letter to the ethics committee urging it to ban or restrict such travel.\n\n\n*  ()\n* \n** \n\n\n* Congressional Children's Working Group\n* Congressional Diabetes Caucus\n* \n*\n\n\nBerman joined Washington, D.C. law firm  as a senior advisor in March 2013.     "pages": }\n'''Lee R. Brand''' (born April 5, 1949) is an American politician and businessman who is the 25th mayor of . He took office as the successor for  on January 3, 2017. Upon inauguration, Brand became the oldest to assume the mayoralty of Fresno beating the previous holder  by 3 years and 21 days.\n\n\nBrand was born in The Dalles, Oregon. His father was Archie L. Brand better known as ‘Brandy,’ of English descent, and his mother was Florence G. Trosi. His parents, his brother and he lived in a small motel room with no indoor bathroom. Archie and Florence worked for his grandfather Archie M. Brand better known as A.M. as dishwashers and general labor at the café, gas station, motel and small zoo A.M. operated.\n\nBrand's mother was from Fresno, and his maternal grandfather and grandmother, Ralph Trosi and Pierina Trosi immigrated to the U.S. from .\n\nThe Brand family moved to Fresno when A.M. no longer ran the roadside business and started a career as a sea lion trainer, touring the county with his ‘Sparky the Seal’ act. Brand's family arrived in Fresno in 1954 where he and his brother began Elementary school.\n\nGrowing up in a poor household, Brand began committing petty theft while in elementary school. While in junior high, Brand and some friends were arrested for breaking and entering several schools and served time in the juvenile hall work program. In 1964, when Brand was only 15, his father died in a plane crash.\n\nAt  in Fresno, Brand was an average student who competed on the cross country and track teams and ran a 1:59 half-miler in his junior year. He became a voracious reader is senior year and his grades started improving.\n\nAfter graduating in 1967, Brand briefly attended  before enlisting in the .\n\nAfter less than half a year in active duty as a technician, Brand returned to Fresno and engaged in a lifestyle he described as \"sex, drugs, and rock and roll\" before experiencing a \"calling from God\" in 1971. Brand began taking heavy course loads at Fresno City College and later  (Fresno State) and graduated in 1973 from Fresno State summa cum laude. Brand paid for his education by working at a local  and doing weekend patrol for the California Air National Guard. He later received an honorable discharge from the Guard.\n\n\nBrand completed his  at the  in 1974 via a project instead of thesis. From 1974 to 1978, Brand was an assistant mental health administrator for . On the side, Brand  and eventually opened a real estate business, Brand-Glenn & Associates, and car stereo store named The Sound Machine. Brand's real estate business became Brand & Associates in 1981, and Brand co-founded Westco Equities in 1987.\n\n\nIn 1996, Brand managed the successful campaign of Fresno City Council candidate Ken Steitz.\n\nAfter an unsuccessful campaign for the city council in 2000, Brand began serving on the Fresno Planning Commission as an appointee of mayor .\n\nBrand won election to the City Council in 2008 for the northeast Fresno seat previously held by Jerry Duncan. He was re-elected to a second four term in 2012. During his eight years on the Fresno City Council, he wrote 19 legislative acts focused on fiscal management and better\ngovernment. In 2011, he served as the Council President.\n\nIn 2016, Brand ran for the Mayor of the City of Fresno. He finished second in the primary and won the November runoff. He was sworn in as the 25th Mayor of Fresno on January 3, 2017.\n\n\nLee Brand concluded his term as Mayor of Fresno on January 5, 2021. After finishing his political career, he began researching his family ancestry finding surprising information about his father and grandfather.\n\nThis motivated him to write a book about family relationships through generations. His debut novel ''Discovering the Family I Never Knew'', is a fictional book inspired by real people and events in his life.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Joaquin Arambula''' (born May 17, 1977) is an American  currently serving in the . He is a  representing the , which encompasses southern and western , including the cities of , , , and the west side of .\n\nArambula was elected to the assembly in a 2016  to replace former Assemblymember , who resigned to work as a  for .\n\nHe is a member of the California Latino Legislative Caucus and the . Before being elected to the assembly, he was an  . He is the son of former 31st District Assemblyman .\n\nArambula was arrested on December 10, 2018, on suspicion of willful cruelty to a child, a misdemeanor under California domestic violence statutes. The assemblymember thanked the teachers at his daughter's school and police officers “for doing their job” in starting the investigation. One of his daughters had alleged that her father hit her on the face while he was wearing a ring. During trial, photos were shown to jurors that showed a 1-inch bruise on the child's right temple. On the witness stand during his trial, his daughter largely described the incident as an accident. In May 2019, a Fresno jury found Arambula not guilty.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Isaac Gregory Bryan''' (born January 16, 1992) is an American politician serving as a Member of the  where he represents the , which includes much of . Bryan was previously the executive director of the 's Black Policy Project, head of the Public Policy Division for the Million Dollar Hoods Project, and served as the Director of Public Policy for the  Ralph J. Bunche Center. From July to November 2023, he served as Assembly Majority Leader.\n\n\nBryan was born in  to a teenage mother in poverty who gave him up at birth. Bryan was  as an infant and has lived in California since he was in the sixth grade. His family served as a  for hundreds of children over two decades and adopted him and eight others from the child welfare system. David Bohnett Foundation|url=http://www.bohnettfoundation.org/dbf-fellow/isaac-bryan/|access-date=2021-03-12|website=www.bohnettfoundation.org}}\n\nBryan attended seven public schools and two California community colleges before earning a  in  and  from the . He worked as a  for the Rombach Institute on Crime, Delinquency and Corrections. During his time with the Rombach Institute, Bryan worked on  and  reform. He also worked with a team of federal monitors to enforce a  Consent Decree with the .\n\nBryan went on to earn a  from . In 2017, Bryan was named a  fellow, where Bryan previously served in   's Office of Reentry, where he co-authored the city's first report on the  needs of Angelenos with justice system involvement.\n\n\n\nBryan is the founding director of UCLA's Black Policy Project (BPP). The BPP aims to build connections between black scholarship at UCLA and public policy decision making. Bryan also serves as director of Public Policy for UCLA's  Center for African American Studies. Bryan also serves as director of public policy for the Million Dollar Hoods (MDH) Project which seeks to map the costs of  in Los Angeles and the United States broadly.\n\nDuring his time at UCLA, Bryan has authored numerous studies and reports. Bryan and MDH issued several reports on the interactions between students and . Bryan regularly provides media commentary on issues of . During the summer of 2020, after the murder of , Bryan led peaceful protests in Los Angeles.\n\n\nBryan was one of the leading scholars who articulated that \"\" was really a call to question the size of our tax contributions to policing and criminalization at the expense of social services. Bryan was the co-chair for Los Angeles County's Measure J, which was approved by over 2.1 million voters and diverts at least 10% of the county's general funds \"to address the disproportionate impact of racial injustice through community investment and alternatives to incarceration\". Bryan regularly writes and provides commentary on policing and criminal justice reform in the United States. He has been an outspoken advocate on the need to do away with .\n\nBryan also served as a Commissioner on the  task force that was convened to study how to reinvest the money cut from the school police budget.\n\n\n\nIn 2021, Bryan announced that he would be a candidate for the California Assembly to succeed fellow Democrat , who was elected to the . Bryan had served as a senior adviser to Assemblymember . Bryan's campaign for the Assembly was endorsed by , , , , , , , and , among others.\n\nBryan won the special election to represent the 54th district and was sworn into office.\n\nOn July 3, Bryan was named Majority Leader of the Assembly, replacing .\n\nBryan is a member of the .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100%\n}}\n\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100% \n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Leonard''' (born October 29, 1947) is a    who served as a member of the  from 2002 until his resignation in March 2010.\n\n\nAfter earning his  in  from the , Leonard worked in  and .\n\n\nLeonard served on the  of the  Municipal Water District before being elected to the  in 1978 on the  of .\n\nIn 1988, after serving five terms in the Assembly, he was elected to the , representing an  district.  During his time in the Senate, Leonard was the longest-serving Republican  Chairman, holding the post from 1990 until s forced him to leave the Senate in 1996.\n\nDuring his time in the Senate, Leonard wrote California's , the only law in the United States to extend  rights to students at  s and .\n\nIn 1996, by a margin of 63%–37%, voters returned Leonard to the Assembly, where he served as Republican  from 1997 to 1998. He was re-elected in 1998 with 72% of the vote and in 2000 with 58% of the vote in a three-way race.\n\nAfter term limits forced Leonard to leave the Assembly in 2002, he won election to represent the Second District on the five-member  with 59% of the vote. He was re-elected in 2006 with 55.8% of the vote.\n\nLeonard resigned from the State Board of Equalization in March 2010 in order to join Governor 's administration.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Mara Woodworth Elliott''' (born October 3, 1968) is an American lawyer and politician serving as the  since 2016. A member of the , she is the first woman and the first  to hold the position.\n\n\nElliott received her undergraduate degree from the , majoring in English and Philosophy. She then received her  degree from the .\n\n\n\n\nElliott was one of four Democrats to run for city attorney. The incumbent city attorney , her former boss, could no longer run after 8 years in the position due to term limits. Unlike her opponents, Elliott did not receive many of the typical endorsements from the various local democratic groups. Her second-place victory in the June primary was considered an upset due to her opponents out raising and out spending her. In the November runoff, she defeated Robert Hickey, a Republican, by a margin of 57 to 42.\n\nElliott said she hoped to make the position less politicized, and take on a role as legal counsel for the San Diego City Council and mayor as opposed to being a public figure.\n\n\nIn the 2020 election, Elliott ran for re-election for San Diego City Attorney in California against attorney Cory Briggs. Elliott won in the general election on November 3, 2020, receiving over 66% of the votes.\n\n\nWhile running for city attorney in 2016, Elliott opposed Measure C and Measure D, which would have built a Chargers football stadium using hotel taxes. She stated the taxes would divert money from city services.\n\n\nElliott challenges Trump's travel ban.\n\n\nElliott successfully compelled the City Council to sign amicus briefs which show support for gay rights and transgender students in cases before the Supreme Court.\n\n\nElliott was asked by councilman David Alvarez about the extent of power by a San Diego mayor to change the city budget. Mayor Faulconer tried to earmark an extra $5 million in the city budget to fund a special election to expand the  and re-purpose . When his addition was not included in the year's budget by the city council, Faulconer tried to veto their budget and force his changes through with a simple 50% majority. When asked for clarification whether Faulconer would actually need a supermajority of 6 votes to add new items to the budget, Elliott stated that the City Charter gives the mayor power over the budget to \"either approve, veto, or modify any line item approved by the Council.\" Therefore, in her opinion, Faulconer's actions were legal until the City Charter was changed to say otherwise.\n\n\nA state audit found that San Diego only tests about half of the rape kits it collects. While other cities identified in the audit have started testing all rape kits, San Diego is the only city that has not changed its policy. Elliot has repeatedly stated that she believes San Diego should test 100% of rape kits. She has said, \"The experience in other jurisdictions shows that the evidence in untested kits can prove valuable in solving cold cases and identifying serial rapists. That alone is good reason.\"\n\n\nIndependent groups in San Diego were in charge of running local recreational programs for 4 decades leading up to 2017. In 2017, there were revelations that money was being spent unevenly by the independent councils. For example, Carmel Valley began 2017 with more than $400,000 available for recreational services, while Stockton's account had $51. The independent councils also weren't following city rules about spending tax money. Elliot issued a legal opinion that tax money must be controlled by the city and could not be used to run non-regulated independent groups.\n\n\nElliott issued a statement that short-term rentals are currently illegal in San Diego. She said there are no laws or legal definitions in the San Diego city code regarding short-term rentals, and her legal opinion is that the city considers new housing activity illegal until it is defined in the city code. She has said she hoped this statement would spur the city to take action one way or the other. However, no action by the city or  has yet been taken to either legalize or restrict short-term rentals in the city code.\n\n\n* Voice of the Year 2017 – The nonprofit news organization  named Elliott Voice of the Year in 2017 for driving the year's biggest civic discussions\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n City of San Diego Official Website|url=https://www.sandiego.gov/city-clerk/elections/city/160607primary|website=www.sandiego.gov}}\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

He is a  representing the 59th Assembly District, encompassing parts of North  County, and small parts of  County.  The district includes the cities of , , , , , , , , and . Prior to being elected to the state assembly, he was a school board trustee for the .\n\n\nChen graduated from Servite High School in .\n\n\nIn 2002, Chen earned his  in  from . In 2005, Chen earned a  degree from . In 2014, Chen earned a  of  from the .\n\n\nChen is the owner of a  company.\n\nIn 2013, Chen became an Adjunct Faculty Professor at the USC Sol Price School of Public Policy.\n\nChen is a former Los Angeles County Reserve Sheriff’s Deputy. Chen was appointed by former   to the Governor’s Office of Criminal Justice Planning, overseeing California’s juvenile justice programs. He was a member of the State Advisory Group, Juvenile Justice Legislative Committee and Juvenile Justice Native American Committee.\n\nChen was appointed to serve as a Board Member for the California Physical Therapy Board and worked as a health deputy to former  .\n\nChen also served as adjunct faculty at  from 2007-2008 and at  in 2016.\n\n\nChen was elected in November 2011 to the  and re-elected to a second term in 2015.\n\n for the .  He lost the  with a third place finish.  woman  went on to easily win the general election.\n\nChen was elected to the  in November 2016, when Chang left the State Assembly in an unsuccessful run for the .  H e was appointed to serve in leadership as Deputy Whip to the Assembly Republican Caucus.  His committee membership consists of the Banking and Finance Committee (where he serves as Vice-Chair), the Business and Professions Committee, the Insurance Committee, the Jobs, Economic Development and the Economy Committee, and the Utilities and Energy Committee.\n\nIn 2018, in the wake of California's growing  and  epidemic, Chen authored Assembly Bill 2156, to clarify and fine tune the definition of “gravely disabled”. Chen later pulled that bill from consideration by the Assembly's Health Committee. That same year, Chen also introduced AB 3005 which aimed to protect the sensitive personal information of children in foster care. Like his other bill, Chen also requested this bill to be pulled from consideration by the relevant committee.\n\nIn 2019, Chen introduced AB 517 to create a Property Crime Task Force in  to prevent crimes as well as identify and arrest criminals who participate in property crimes. Chen's bill died after clearing the public safety committee.\n\nTo address the growing number of homeless encampments, Chen introduced AB 1908, the Homeless Encampment and Litter Program (HELP), putting more accountability on Caltrans in coordinating access to housing and supportive services for those who need it most. The bill died in committee with no action taken. A few days after introducing AB 1908, Chen introduced AB 2021 in an effort to preserve open space in Southern California. The bill would have required the California Department of Parks and Recreation to seek opportunities for acquiring land to expand . The bill unanimously passed the Water, Parks and Wildlife Committee, but then died in the Appropriations Committee.\n\nIn 2021 Chen helped secure funds for the  at . Chen, a graduate of the school, said that although the school is outside his district, many students are constituents in his district, and the bridge would be a great investment in the students.\n\n\n | medals =\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\nChen founded the CSUF Wushu Club in 1997 as president and coach. The team competed in the Collegiate Wushu Tournament for the first time in 1999. During this time, the club grew in its standing in the university and became a for-credit course. Chen was the tournament director of the 2001 Collegiate Wushu Tournament hosted at CSUF.\n\nChen was an A-team member of the 1999  and competed at the  in Hong Kong, where he finished seventh in nanquan and tenth in nandao. A year later at the 2000 , he was the Pan American champion in nandao and additionally won silver medals in nanquan and nangun. The following year, Chen was again an A-team member of both the Berkeley and Baltimore US Wushu Teams but did not compete in the following World or Pan American championships.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n went on to win the general election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100.0\n}}\n\n\n\n\n| percentage = 100.0 \n}}\n\n\n\n\nChen and his mother are small business owners who own and operate a property management company. Chen's brother, David, is a Deputy District Attorney with the Orange County District Attorney's  office.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
