    "pages": }\n\n'''Mary Hayashi''' ( '''Chung'''; August 13, 1967) is a Korean-American healthcare advocate and , who represented 18th Assembly District in the . Hayashi was elected to the California State Assembly in November 2006 and served six years.\n\nShe served as a member of the leadership team for Assembly Speaker , Assembly Speaker  and Assembly Speaker , serving as Chair of the Assembly Committee on Business, Professions and Consumer Protection.  Previously, Hayashi served as a member of the California Board of Registered Nursing and Commissioner on the California Mental Health Services Oversight and Accountability Commission, which was created to monitor the implementation of . Hayashi ran unsuccessfully for  in 2014 finishing third place in the race.\n\n\n\nPrior to serving in the , Hayashi served as the Alameda County Coordinator in the winning campaign to pass , which provides increased funding for prevention and treatment services in county and statewide mental health programs.\n\nHayashi served as a Commissioner on the California Mental Health Services Oversight and Accountability Commission, which was created to monitor the implementation of .  She is also a member of the Executive Committee for the , a public-private partnership that helps guide the implementation of the goals and objectives of the National Strategy for .\n\nHayashi has worked for several non-profit and philanthropic organizations dedicated to healthcare issues including the , the Foundation Consortium for California's Children and Youth, and the National Asian Women's Health Organization. In 2016 Mary Hayashi was appointed Project Director of the Women's Sport Safety Initiative, a special project fund of Silicon Valley Community Foundation dedicated to protecting the lives of women and girls by raising awareness of .\n\nHayashi served as a member of the California Board of Registered Nursing and as Chair of the  Golden Gate Political Action Committee. She was a board member of the  and Research!America, which successfully doubled the federal budget for the . She is a former board member of Girls Inc of Alameda County, and served as the honorary chair for their \"Strong, Smart and Bold\" annual luncheon.\n\nHayashi's journey from her childhood in  to prominence as a health care leader is documented in her book, ''Far from Home: Shattering the Myth of the Model Minority''.\n\nShe has been honored by diverse organizations for her work on behalf of minority health and women, from '''' and '''', to  Affiliates of California and the Didi Hirsch Community Mental Health Center.\n\nShe was named Legislator of the Year by the  and the . She also received the Distinguished Public Service Award from the Alameda County Democratic Lawyers Club. She earned her Bachelor of Science degree in Applied Economics from the  and her Master in Business Administration degree from .  She lives in  with her husband Dennis Hayashi, a judge with the .\n\nHayashi unsuccessfully ran for  seat 2 in 2012. She came in third after Richard Valle and  Mayor Mark Green.\n\n\nIn the Legislature, Mary authored a number of bills focused on health and education reform.  Among her bills that have been signed into law is AB 25, a concussion safety bill that placed California alongside Washington as the states with the toughest return-to-play laws for student athletes.\n\nShe authored AB 108, prohibiting health plans and insurers from rescinding an individual health insurance policy, protecting consumers from losing their health care coverage during the times they need it most. In addition, she authored AB 235, a mental health parity bill that requires insurers to cover treatment for psychiatric emergencies without prior authorization, and AB 509, which served as the catalyst for establishing California's first Office of Suicide Prevention. She has also championed public education, authoring AB 142 to help increase funding for schools through changes to the California State Lottery.\n\n\n\nIn late October 2011, Hayashi was charged with theft after being caught shoplifting $2,445 worth of merchandise from San Francisco's  store. She denied that she was responsible for the shoplifting incident, citing a medical condition and distraction. Hayashi subsequently   to a charge of misdemeanor grand theft, and was sentenced to a $180 fine and three years' probation.\n\n\nIn February 2014, Hayashi announced her candidacy in the 2014 Democratic primary election for the , in the .  On June 3, 2014, Hayashi placed third in the District 10 blanket primary behind Democrat  and Republican Peter Kuo, with Wieckowski later defeating Kuo in the runoff election on November 4.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Virginia Strom-Martin''' (born March 29, 1948) served in the California state Assembly from 1996 until she was termed out in 2002. She has been a member of the Unemployment Insurance Appeals Board since February 5, 2003. She was appointed by former Assembly Speaker .\n\n\nDuring her three terms, Ms. Strom-Martin chaired the following the Assembly Education Committee; the Joint Legislative Committee on Fisheries and Aquaculture; the Select Committee on Rural Economic Development; and Budget Subcommittee 3, Resources. In addition, she was Vice Chair of the Joint Committee to Develop a Master Plan for Education, Kindergarten-Higher Education, and Vice Chair of the School Bond Conference Committee. During 2001, she also chaired the Legislative Women's Caucus. During her legislative service, she was a member of numerous committees, task forces, and caucuses.\n\n\nThe California Society of Pediatric Dentists recognized Strom-Martin for her outstanding contributions and service to the children of California in 2001 and the Primary Care Association recognized her for her efforts on behalf of rural health clinics. In 2000 she received the PAWPAC award, which recognized her work on behalf of animals.\n\nIn 1999, Strom-Martin was given the Land Conservation Achievement Award by the prestigious Trust for Public Land. She was honored with the Upstream Swimmer Award (for environmental service in the face of adversity) from the Sonoma County Conservation Action and was honored by the Sonoma County Environmental Council and the Friends of the Russian River for fisheries advocacy.\n\nThe Town Council of Fairfax honored her in the fall of 2002 for her stellar legislative record on the environment and human and civil rights issues.\n\n\nMs. Strom-Martin was a teacher at the Wright Elementary School in  from 1972 until 1996. In 1994, she received, along with five of her colleagues, the Jack London Excellence in Education Award from  for their restructuring efforts and creative classroom curriculum. In 1993, she was selected as one of 75 educators nationwide to participate in the first \"China Breakers\" Conference on Education, sponsored by RJR Nabisco, in Leesburg, VA.\n\n\nMs. Strom-Martin graduated from Petaluma High School in 1966. She graduated from the University of California in Berkeley with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Art and a minor in Psychology; received her Elementary Teaching Credential from Sonoma State University; and in 1976, received her Master of Arts degree in Counseling from Sonoma State University.\n\n\nFor the past 25 years, she has lived on the Russian River in the town of Duncans Mills along with her husband, Donald Martin, and their daughters, Hannah and Caitlin, now college students.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Matthew Craig Haney''' (born April 17, 1982) is an American politician from  currently serving as a member of the  from the , covering the eastern portion of the city. A  member of the , Haney had represented  on the  from 2019 to 2022 and previously served as a commissioner on the  from 2013 to 2019.\n\nIn 2022, Haney won a  to the California State Assembly to succeed , who became . He placed first in the  and defeated former supervisor , a fellow Democrat, in a runoff. He was sworn in on May 3, 2022.\n\n\nHaney was born in , raised in the  and attended public schools in . His mother, Kris Calvin, served on the  .\n\nHe has a  in 2005 from the , and an  in human rights from the , where he was a Senator . He has a  in 2010 from the  and a  in 2010 from . Haney worked at both the  and at the JFK School of Law, and Sociology at , where he taught education law. Haney taught Education Law at the JFK School of Law in addition to teaching Sociology at  and served as a Fellow and Adjunct Faculty at the Stanford Design School.\n\n\nAfter graduating from UC Berkeley in 2005, Haney was a  for long-time  . He was the Executive Director of the .\n\nHaney is the former National Policy Director for . In 2015, he co-founded , an Oakland-based national nonprofit designed to end mass incarceration, with  and .\n\n\nIn April 2012, Haney announced his candidacy for the  election for one of four open seats. He was elected in the , placing fourth behind three incumbents. Haney replaced , who forwent re-election to run for the .\n\nUpon his election, Haney was the youngest member of the commission and one of the only members of an urban school board in California under the age of 35. Prior to his election, he served two years on ’s Public Education Enrichment Fund Community Advisory Committee and Restorative Justice Committee.\n\nHaney, , and  authored a resolution that required the district's food vendor to disclose the origin of their food products. It passed with a unanimous vote in May 2016.\n\nWhile serving as president of the school board, Haney proposed on  that  should be renamed to honor poet , an alumna of the school. He cited objections to 's role as a . He also  but not painting over the '''' mural by  inside of the school. He cited his objection to its depiction of slavery and dead Native Americans. Haney and Commissioner Stevon Cook co-authored a  to establish a panel to examine which schools to rename.\n\nHaney introduced a resolution calling for the end of the current all-choice-based student-assignment system.\n\nPresident  endorsed Haney during his re-election campaign in 2016. It was one of the 150 endorsements he made the weekend prior to the . Haney was previously a volunteer for Obama's  but had not sought out the endorsement.\n\n\nIn September 2017, Haney filed to run in the  to represent District 6.\n\nHaney was elected Supervisor for District 6 on November 6, 2018, receiving 14,249 first preference votes (56.24 percent of all valid votes). (San Francisco has  voting.)  After allocation of preferences from eliminated candidates in San Francisco's ranked-choice voting system, Haney received 63.12 percent of final-round votes, compared to 36.88 percent for runner-up Christine Johnson, a former planning commissioner. Haney was sworn in at the Board of Supervisors' January 8, 2019, meeting, replacing , who was ineligible to run for re-election after .\n\nA \"progressive\" majority was created upon his and 's election to the board.\n\nPer the law, Haney resigned as supervisor before being sworn into the Legislature for the state Assembly's 17th district on May 3, 2022. Mayor  appointed  to fill Haney's spot as supervisor.\n\n\nHaney's views in housing shifted during his time on the Board of Supervisors, becoming increasingly supportive of additional housing and regulatory streamlining for housing construction. During the 2018 campaign for Supervisor, Haney ran against a leader of the  movement and questioned the need for every neighborhood to build housing, stating \"I'm not going to pick fights on the other side of the city.\" Haney initially opposed state bill , which streamlined housing production in cities that were falling short of state-mandated minimums, but later came to support the bill. In 2021, Haney supported state action to ensure cities allow the construction of more housing, and supported a local bill to legalize  on lots zoned for .\n\nIn October 2021, Haney supported the construction of a 495-unit apartment complex on a parking lot next to a BART station, but was the proposal was voted down 7-4 by his colleagues. That same month, Haney voted against the construction of 316 micro-homes in Tenderloin, 13.5% of which would have been designated as affordable housing.\n\n\nIn 2020, Haney authored the nation’s first ‘Overpaid CEO Tax’ (Proposition L). The tax charges companies in San Francisco a 0.1% surcharge on their annual business taxes if their top executives earn more than 100 times more than their ‘typical local worker’. The measure is one of the first in the country to address growing income inequality between workers and CEOs in the United States. This Proposition was passed during the 2020 elections with 65.18%.\n\nHaney wrote an  in the '''' endorsing a No vote on . The proposition would have granted app-based transportation and delivery companies like DoorDash, Uber, Lyft and other gig-economy companies an exception to  by classifying their drivers as \"\".\n\n\nHaney introduced Proposition B, which amends San Francisco’s Charter to form the Department of Sanitation and Streets by splitting it from the , in 2020. It would also create the Sanitation and Streets Commission and a Public Works Commission to provide oversight to the departments. The Board of Supervisors placed it on the ballot with a 7 to 4 vote. Proposition B passed in the November 2020 elections with 200,251 votes or 60.87%.\n\n\nHaney supported opening a  in his district by the Tenderloin district. Haney represents the Tenderloin and , two districts most impacted by fatal s within the city.\n\n\n\n\nHaney ran to serve for the remainder of 's term, who vacated the seat upon his appointment to . Haney and former supervisor  garnered the most votes in the primary election on February 15, 2022, but neither had more than 50% of the vote (Haney's 36.44% to Campos's 35.67%). Therefore, both candidates headed to the  on April 19, 2022. According to the ''Wall Street Journal'', the election centered on the issue of \"Which candidate wants to build more housing.\" Haney won the runoff with 62% of the vote, and was sworn in on May 3, 2022.\n\nHaney is a member of the .\n\n\nHaney has a brother and a sister. His sister, Erin Haney, is senior counsel for #cut50, a nonprofit he co-founded.\n\n\n\n\n\n* }}\n* }}\n* }}\n*  \n\n\n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Strickland did not meet those requirements and had to drop out of the race.\n\nIn February 2010, Audra Strickland announced her intention to run for  Supervisor of the 2nd District, which consisted primarily of the city of , and included Oak Park and the Santa Rosa Valley.     "pages": }\n\n'''Vernon James Ehlers''' (February 6, 1934 – August 15, 2017) was an American physicist and politician who represented  in the  from 1993 until his retirement . A , he also served eight years in the  and two in the .\n\nEhlers was the first  to be elected to Congress; he was later joined by  (-) and  (-).\n\n\nBorn in , Ehlers attended  in Grand Rapids for three years before transferring to the , where he earned an undergraduate degree in physics and, in 1960, a  in .  His doctoral dissertation, \"The nuclear spins and moments of several radioactive gallium isotopes\", is available from University Microfilms International as document number 0227304. After six years of teaching and research at Berkeley, he moved back to Michigan and took employment at Calvin College in 1966, where he taught physics for 16 years and later served as  of the Physics Department.\n\nEhlers died on August 15, 2017, at the age of 83.\n\n\nEhlers served on the  Board of Commissioners from 1975 to 1982. Ehlers served from 1983 to 1985 in the  and then served from 1985 to 1993 in the .\n\n\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n* '''''' (Chairman and Ranking Member) \n* ''''''\n** \n**  (Ranking Member)\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n** \n\n\n* Co-chair of the STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) Ed Caucus\n* Peak Oil Caucus\n at a hearing of the House Administration Committee.]]\nEhlers served as chairman of the  in the  after  resigned from the position.\n\nA portrait of Ehlers during his service as chairman of the Administration Committee is in the House collection.\n\n\nEhlers was a moderate Republican. According to the ''National Journal,'' in 2006 his votes split 50-50 between \"liberal\" and \"conservative.\"  While strongly anti-abortion and supportive of lowering taxes, he was willing to break with his party on environmental and government spending issues. He was a member of the  and . He was the only member of the  Congressional delegation of either party to vote to raise fuel economy standards for automobiles in 2001 and 2005. \n\nEhlers was a staunch advocate of a federal prohibition of online . In 2006 he cosponsored H.R. 4411, the -Leach Internet Gambling Prohibition Act and H.R. 4777, the Internet Gambling Prohibition Act.\n\nOwing to his votes in favor of the  in both 2004 and 2006, as well as his votes against hate crimes legislation and , Ehlers was given a 0% rating by the , indicating a voting record generally opposed to . However, in December 2010, Ehlers was one of fifteen Republican House members to vote in favor of repealing the 's \"\" ban on  service members,Chris Geidner,  , '''' (December 15, 2010), , '''' (December 15, 2010) and one of eight Republicans to vote for the .\n\n\n\n\nIn 1993 Ehlers won a special election for the 3rd District, which had been vacant since Congressman  died six months into his fifth term. He won a full term in 1994 and was re-elected six times with little significant  opposition. Ehlers retired from Congress in 2010.\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*  ''official campaign site''\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Leonard E. \"Lee\" Timberlake''' (1896–1973) was a British-born American politician who served as a member of the  from 1945 to 1969. Before entering politics, Timberlake was a railroad employee and travel bureau owner.\n\n\n\nTimberlake was born May 3, 1896, in , the son of F. and Emily Timberlake. After completing high school, Timberlake took a year of  at the . He was a member of the  and the Los Angeles Breakfast Club. He was a Methodist and a Democrat. He lived in Los Angeles between 1920 and 1923 and also after 1938.\n\nTimberlake began his working career between 1916 and 1920 as a railroad agent for the . His succeeding jobs were passenger agent, , 1920–22; , , 1922–23; accountant, Union Pacific, 1923; chief , , 1923–27; general ,  system, 1927–32. He next went into the , with a half interest in the Southern California Tourist Bureau, after 1932. Later he was full owner of the agency, which became the largest independent  in California. He also worked at times for the  and .\n\nHis first marriage resulted in two daughters, Betty Strebe and Beverly Watson.  His second marriage was on May 7, 1933, to Cynthia Wyatt Mitchell of Atlanta, Georgia. They also had two children, Cynthia Lynn and Carole Ann. They lived at 10210 South Hobart Boulevard in Gramercy Park.\n\nHe died July 17, 1973. His last address was .\n\n\nTimberlake was one of the longest-serving council members, \"The length of service of the 73-year-old council dean is matched only by that of former Councilman , who retired July 1, 1967, at [age] 74,\"  of the ''Los Angeles Times'' wrote when Timberlake announced his retirement in May 1969. As , Timberlake may have set a record as acting mayor, Baker wrote, because of Mayor 's extensive travels outside the country.\n\n\n\nTimberlake first ran for the  seat against the incumbent, , in 1943 and lost, 8,841 for Gay to 8,404 for Timberlake. In that election, Gay's campaign raised a question as to why Timberlake had waited until 1940 to become an American citizen, to which Timberlake replied that he did not \"deem it necessary to dignify these scurrilous attacks by replying thereto.\"\n\nIn his next try, though, in 1945, Timberlake won a narrow victory over Gay. He was reelected in the primary vote in every election thereafter until his retirement in 1969. In that year the 6th district included the , , ,   and  and -.\n\n\n\n'''Housing, 1952–53.''' Timberlake was in dispute with Council President  over many issues, including a controversial $1 million plan to build  in Los Angeles (Timberlake being the leader of the prohousing bloc and Henry opposing), with Timberlake disputing many of Henry's , as council president. One of Timberlake's objections upset Henry so much that in January 1953 he was led to exclaim, \"Mr. Timberlake, if you persist in this intolerable situation, there will be ways devised to prevent you!\"\n\n'''FEPC, 1958.''' He was opposed to establishing a  in the city of Los Angeles. The council vote was a tie, 7-7.\n\n'''Chavez Ravine, 1958.''' Timberlake locked horns with fellow Council Member  over the use of  as a stadium for the Los Angeles Dodgers, which Timberlake favored and Holland vehemently opposed. Timberlake at one point told Holland in a council meeting that \"You are the lowest thing I ever heard of!\" He was angry because, he said, Holland had \"sent slanted press releases to papers in my district.\"\n\n'''Yorty, 1963–65.''' Timberlake was roundly criticized by Mayor  when the former, as acting mayor, appointed one of Yorty's bitterest foes, , to the city Airport Commission while Yorty was out of the country, touring Europe. \"It is a tragic thing that Timberlake assumed such action while the duly elected mayor is away on a duty trip,\" Yorty said. Though Timberlake was described as a Yorty opponent, he was later said to have become \"increasingly friendly\" with the mayor.\n\n\n\nAccess to the ''Los Angeles Times'' links may require the use of a library card.\n\n\n\n----\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jovanka Beckles''' (born 1963) is an American politician serving as a member of the  Board for Ward 1. She previously served as a member of the .\n\n\nBeckles was born in ,  and immigrated to the United States with her family in 1972. She attended  on a full basketball scholarship, and graduated cum laude in 1988 with a  degree in Psychology. She later earned an  degree from the . She moved to the Bay Area in 1989 and worked as a counselor, youth educator, housing case manager for the homeless, and mental health specialist.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2008 she first ran for the Richmond City Council as part of the  and lost. She ran again in 2010 and won, and in 2014 she was reelected despite Chevron spending $3 million on opposing candidates, and became vice mayor. She was Richmond's first openly lesbian councilwoman. \n\nDuring her time on the City Council, Beckles worked on implementing rent control in Richmond. She voted against or abstained on several proposals to build housing in Richmond.\n\n\nIn 2018, she ran for California State Assembly in the 15th District to replace Tony Thurmond, who chose to run for California State Superintendent of Public Instruction. She was endorsed by fellow Richmond City Councilmember (and former mayor) , former Black Panther , Senator , the ,  1021, , and the . She took second place in the June 12 primary, but lost to  in the general election.\n\nDuring the campaign, Beckles said she wanted to retain local control over housing, \"I really think that cities need to be able to have more control in terms of building, because they know best.\" On housing, she argued that cities like San Francisco, Oakland and Berkeley are \"building lots of new housing\" but that the problem is that the housing is not affordable. She added, \"I don't think that we have a housing crisis. I think that we have an affordable housing crisis.\" She called for a repeal of the Costa-Hawkins Rental Housing Act, which would enable cities in California to expand rent control.\n\n\nOn July 18, 2020, Beckles announced she would run for  Board in Ward 1 against 20-year incumbent Joe Wallace. Her platform included keeping transit fare-free and strengthening labor rights for transit workers. She won the general election with 50% of the vote, defeating Wallace and a third candidate, Ben Fong. She was sworn in on December 4, 2020.\n\n\nIn 2023, Beckles announced she would run for California State Senate in the 7th District to replace , who is term-limited.\n\n\nShe is described as . She is currently associated with .\n\n\nBeckles supported , establishing single-payer healthcare system. Beckles posted a statement on Instagram, citing that \"Our current healthcare system has placed corporate profit over people, both patients and workers, time and time again.\n\nHonored to receive the endorsement of National Union of Healthcare Workers and join them in the fight for higher wages, safer staffing levels, and single-payer healthcare! #TogetherWeWin\" from her Instagram page after National Union of Healthcare Workers. \n\n\nJovanka Beckles supported increasing minimum wage to $15.\n\n\nWhen asked about the Green New Deal, she agreed that the Green New Deal would bring more representation and can help improve the transportation and housing.\n\n\nShe opposes taking money donations from corporates. She claimed that lawmakers that promised to address climate change, and building more affordable housing and infrastructure were all denied or forged with progressives and those who are .\n\n\nBeckles supported housing as a human right. She worked with Berkeley council people on capping rent. She supports rent control and wants to push for affordable housing on public property paid with public funds rather than increase the supply of market-rate housing being built.\n\n\nBeckles is openly . She married Nicole Valentino in 2013.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Amerish Babulal'''  '''Bera''' ( ; born March 2, 1965) is an American physician and politician who has been serving as a member of the  from California since 2013. He is a member of the Democratic Party and represents , which is in .\n\nPrior to his time in Congress, Bera worked as a physician and served as the  for Sacramento County. He has also been involved in various community organizations, including the  and the .\n\nBera is also a member of the  and has been a strong advocate for diplomacy and global engagement. He has been recognized for his leadership on issues related to healthcare, foreign policy, and environmental protection.\n\n\nBera's father, Babulal Bera, immigrated to the  from  in 1958. Two years later, Babulal Bera was joined by his wife, Kanta. Ami Bera was born in  and raised in the  city of . He attended  while living there. Bera's parents are from , , and he can understand .\n\nBera has a bachelor's degree in  from the , also earning his  degree there in 1991. From 1997 to 1999 he was the medical director of Care Management at the Mercy Healthcare for Sacramento. He served as the  for the  and later as the associate dean for admissions at the . From 2005 to 2012, he served as a clinical professor at the University of California Davis School of Medicine.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n]]\nBera challenged three-term    in the general election for . He ran unopposed for the Democratic nomination. He raised more money than Lungren for the five quarters through mid-2010, making him the only Democratic challenger with more cash than a sitting Republican member of the House. Bera was one of 17 candidates the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee targeted to take over Republican-held or open seats in 2010.\n\nLungren was the only incumbent Republican whose race was rated a \"tossup\" by , but it was rerated \"Lean GOP\" in the campaign's final days, and the race was considered competitive by both parties. Polling by  in September showed Lungren leading Bera, 46%–38%. Bera cited health care, education and economic recovery among his top legislative priorities. In November, Lungren won reelection, defeating Bera 51%–43%.\n\nIn 2010, after Bera accepted a $250 donation from , executive director of the Sacramento chapter of the  (CAIR), the California Republican Party called on him to return the money. Bera returned the money after these concerns were raised.\n\n\n\n\nBera announced a rematch against Lungren in 2012. The district had been renumbered the 7th district, and made somewhat more compact. It lost all of its territory outside of , making it slightly friendlier to Democrats.\n\nOn November 13, 2012, Bera attended freshman orientation as congressman-elect while votes were still being counted. Candidates in these tight races sometimes attend the orientation by the Committee on House Administration, whose chairman was Bera's opponent, Lungren.\n\nOn November 15, 2012, the  called the race for Bera, who won 51%–49%.\n\n\n]]Bera ran for reelection in 2014, facing former Republican congressman , who had represented what was then the 3rd from 1999 to 2005. The '''' rated the 7th district \"Lean Democratic,\" but '''' reported that Bera was \"viewed by both parties as one of the most vulnerable Democrats in the country.\" Bera was a member of the 's Frontline program, designed to support vulnerable candidates. In June 2014, '''' reported that the DCCC planned to support Bera with $1.7 million in ads throughout fall 2014, and the House Majority PAC, a political action committee designed to support Democratic candidates, reserved $200,000 for late-election television ads.\n\n'''' reported that Bera's campaign received donations from parents of another Democratic candidate, , only to have Bera's parents then donate a similar amount to Strouse's campaign. According to '''', \"The donations appear legal, campaign finance experts say, though two said any agreement among the parents to trade donations could be viewed as an attempted end run around contribution limits.\" In May 2016, Bera's father, Babulal, pleaded guilty to two felony counts of elections fraud.\n\n co-founder and former  advisor  said of Bera, \"He is the most important member of our Problem Solversof the entire group. He stepped up immediately as a freshman to take a leadership position. He was out early advocating on our big issues like ''No Budget, No Pay''.”\n\nIn response to a poll by the American Sikh Committee to Evaluate Congressional Candidates, Bera did not answer two questions about the Indian government's part in the  in which 8,000 s were massacred after Indian Prime Minister 's assassination. Instead, he noted that in 2005, Indian Prime Minister  had publicly apologized to the Sikh community for the government's role. Bera also stated that, while it was a tragedy, he was more focused on the treatment of Sikhs in the U.S. and could not dictate how the Indian government should approach the matter. In response, some members of the Sikh-American community, and some PACs representing them, publicly withdrew their support for Bera. But with the majority of the Sikh-American population coming from outside of Bera's district, the advocates acknowledged that they were unlikely to affect the outcome of the race.\n\nOn election night, Bera \"was down by more than 3,000 votes...but came back to win after all the absentee and mail-in ballots were in.\" In the end, he won 50.4% of the vote to Ose's 49.6%.\n\n\n\n\nBera ran for reelection in 2016. He faced     in the general election. In January 2016, the Elk Grove-South County Democratic Club, Bera's home club, voted against endorsing him, citing concerns with his record on trade and Syrian refugees.\n\nBera's 2016 race was \"one of the nastiest Congressional races with allegations and insinuations being bandied back and forth\" and was also \"one of the last two House races in the entire nation yet to be called.\" As he began his third term, he was joined by three new Indian-American House members:  from Illinois,  from Washington, and  from California.  entrepreneur  said Bera \"was the first Indian American to be in Congress in a long time and now can actually lead a Caucus...able to shepherd Pramila, Raja and Ro and get them going during their freshman year.\"\n\nA coalition of dissatisfied groups prevented Bera from garnering his party's endorsement in January, but at the state Democratic convention in February, he was endorsed, with 90% of the delegates voting to endorse.\n\nDuring the 2016 campaign Bera's father, Babulal Bera, was sentenced to one year and one day in federal prison, and fined $100,200, for federal campaign finance violations that helped fund two of his son's campaigns.\n\nBera narrowly defeated Jones in the general election, with 51% of the vote to Jones's 49%. The margin of victory was 4,802 votes.\n\nSince 2016, which saw the election to the House of three other Indian-Americans and to the Senate of the first Indian-American Senator, , Bera has been described as the \"Godfather\" of Indian-Americans on .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2018, Bera was reelected, garnering 155,016 votes (55%) and defeating Republican Andrew Grant, a former  official, who received 126,601 (45%).\n\n\n\n\nIn 2020, Bera was reelected, garnering 217,416 votes (56%) and defeating Republican Buzz Patterson, a retired  Lieutenant Colonel who received 166,549 (43%).\n\n\nDuring his first five terms in office (2013–2022), Bera was a cosponsor of 95 legislative items that became law and an original cosponsor of none. \nActs designating a name for a Federal property accounted for 44 of the 95, typically with 50 or more cosponsors. Another 37 were general consensus items cosponsored by at least one third of the 435-member House, of which 27 were cosponsored by at least two thirds. Bera cosponsored only one successful item with fewer than 30 cosponsors. He was the final of 7 cosponsors for H.R.3399 in the 116th Congress, which became law on 30 October 2020. \nThe law authorized the Nutria Eradication and Control Act of 2003 to continue through 2025 and made California eligible for program grants.  are an invasive species of large, semiaquatic rodents whose burrowing could threaten levees in the , where productive farmland lies below sea level.\n\nIn an interview covered in the ''Elk Grove Citizen'', Bera said his first year in Congress \"was about being focused here in the district but also building my reputation in Washington, D.C.\"\n\nIn October 2013, Bera announced that he would give up his federal pay for the duration of the government shutdown. He also announced that in response to sequester cuts, he would donate 8.2% of his check each month to local organizations affected by sequester cuts.\n\nIn a 2015 op-ed supporting the  in the '''', Bera copied several sentences from documents produced by the  and  and from an Obama White House report. He received criticism, including from labor groups like the California Labor Federation, for parroting lobbying firms. Bera later wrote an apology, though he stood by the sentiment of the op-ed.\n\nAs of October 2021, Bera had voted in line with 's stated position 100% of the time.\n\nIn 2022, Bera was bitten by a  fox on  and received the appropriate . Coinciding with , Bera introduced legislation, the Affordable Rabies Treatment for Uninsured Act, which would create a government program that would reimburse health care providers who administer the treatment to people who are uninsured. A five-shot regimen of  and  can cost over $5,000.\n\n\nAccording to ''The Hill'' in 2014, \"Bera, who faces a tough race this fall against Republican Doug Ose, is a strong advocate for tackling climate change, but global warming isn't his focus when he talks about  with constituents.\"\n\n\nBera supports the  (Obamacare) and has voted against repeal efforts.\n\n\nOn November 19, 2015, Bera voted for HR 4038, legislation that would effectively halt the resettlement of refugees from Syria and Iraq to the United States.\n\n\nIn 2016, Bera called on the Pakistani government \"to take responsibility and start cracking down\" on terrorists based in its country, and praised the Indian government for its restraint in the face of a recent attack on an Indian air force base by Pakistan-based militants.\n\n\nBera called a June 2016 speech by Indian prime minister  to a joint session of the U.S. Congress \"the perfect speech for this moment in time\" and claimed that India was becoming \"a global leader and a global partner with the United States.\" \"As an Indian American and a ,\" Bera said, \"I was thrilled by the prime minister's speech.\"\n\n\nBera voted to provide Israel with support following . \nBera boycotted Prime Minister 's address to a joint session of Congress on 25 July 2024, saying that Netanyahu is \"the one person standing in the way\" of a cease-fire and hostage release.\n\n\nIn 2017, Bera voted against the .\n\n\nIn 2022, Bera was one of 16 Democrats to vote against the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act of 2022, an antitrust package that would crack down on corporations for anti-competitive behavior.\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n**  (Ranking Member)\n* \n** \n** \n* \n\n\n\n* \n*  (vice chair of outreach)\n* \n* \n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\nHe is pro choice. He opposed the , calling it a \"blow to women's rights and reproductive health care\".\n\n\nBera and his wife, Janine Bera, have one child. They reside in , which is outside of his district.\n\nOn April 4, 2022, Bera was one of nine people attacked by a  fox outside the US Capitol. He said afterward, '\"I expect to get attacked if I go on Fox News; I don't expect to get attacked by a fox.\"\n\nBera is one of three  in Congress.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n*  campaign website\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Travis Ethan Allen''' (born September 14, 1973) is an American politician who served as a  member of the . Allen was first elected in November 2012 to represent , which includes the cities of , , , and , most of , portions of  and of , and the unincorporated communities of  and .\n\n\nTravis Allen was born in , and was raised in . He is an avid short board , and he participated with 65 other people in a  ride for the most number of riders on a single surf board. He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in economics from .\n\n\nTravis Allen is a  and has managed client investment accounts since 1996. He has owned a financial advisory and wealth management practice, the Wealth Strategies Group, since 2001.\n\n\nIn 2012, Allen began his political career by running for California State Assembly's 72nd district. The seat was open due to term limits. He finished second in the June primary with 19.9% of the vote, trailing establishment Republican frontrunner  City Councilman Troy Edgar, who won 28% of the vote. In the general election Allen surpassed Edgar by an 11.4% margin. Under recently passed  this was the first California election to take place under a , in which the top two candidates advanced to the general election, regardless of party preference.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAllen unsuccessfully ran for  in the . He announced his candidacy in June 2017. Incumbent  was unable to run at the end of his term due to term limits.\n\nAllen came in fourth place in California's open primary where the top two candidates get on the ballot in the November election. He had 440,409 votes, or 9.2% of the overall vote, trailing the leading candidate Democrat  by over one million votes and trailing Republican rival  by 800,000 votes.\n\n\n\nAllen ran on a campaign based on populist, conservative, anti-establishment themes, much like President  used in his 2016 Presidential campaign, and he is considered to be \"California's Trump.\" He has used the slogans \"Take Back California\" and \"Make California Great Again\" for his campaign.\n\nAllen is considered by many to be a controversial politician and candidate for California governor due to his far-right populist politics, for being an outspoken proponent of Donald Trump, for a sexual harassment allegation made against Allen by a former coworker (in which he was given a verbal warning but not disciplined for) in 2013, and for making many disputed public statements.\n\nHe has stated that he was running on a platform of spurring job creation and business growth by cutting California's high tax rate; using existing tax revenues to fix the state's deteriorating freeway and road infrastructure, opposing California's gas tax, and preventing future water shortages by increasing water storage capacity and completing the landmark California Water Project. He proposed redacting recently implemented laws (, , and ). He states they are responsible for an uptick in violent crime rates in California. However, there has not been an uptick in violent crime, and in fact it has been decreasing. The nonpartisan  found crime to be at a historic low.\n\nAllen used his efforts to repeal the SB 1 gas tax increase and his opposition to illegal immigration as key stances in his campaign. He also supports more \"tough-on-crime\" policing measures and additional water support for Central California Valley farmers.\n\nOn May 1, 2018, Allen spoke at a California Republican primary forum in . Allen delivered his opening speech, stating that he wants to undo recent voter-enacted soft on crime laws and promised to \"get rid of the state-mandated Common Core [educational curriculum].\"\n\nDuring his campaigning for California governor and subsequently, Allen has repeatedly made many disputed statements to the public and media. He has been criticized by pundits and  sites for these claims. He has made claims on the Oroville Dam regarding water capturing measures he wants to implement if elected, about high crime rates in California, and about the so-called \"sanctuary laws\" in California. In 2018, Allen made the claim that a new bill in California would \"literally\" \"ban the sale of the Bible\", a claim he has repeated despite having been fact-checked by several media outlets. He has also made the claim multiple times that California legalized child prostitution.\n\nWhile campaigning he made the promise that if he gets elected governor that \"every Californian will have a green lawn and take long showers.\"\n\nAllen was criticized for missing several days of work at the California State Assembly while he was out campaigning.\n\nAfter losing in the primary elections, Allen didn't immediately endorse his Republican rival , but eventually decided to do so in July 2018. He also said that he wants his supporters to \"stand up and fight\" to \"take back California\". He started the .\n\n\nMidway through his campaign for California Governor, in 2017 Allen raised $447,236 for his campaign and had expenditures of $654,602 during that time according to an official campaign filing. After Allen lost the Primary, his most recent campaign finance records showed $37,539 cash on hand and $17,866 in unpaid bills. In 2018, fundraising efforts and campaign finance reports show his top contributors were \"individual donations\" and \"other donations\" (small donations under $200.00), according to .\n\n\nAccording to , Travis Allen ranked 4th in the Gubernatorial race for Governor\n\nDuring his annual Commonwealth Club lecture on May 2, 2018, Willie Brown said Allen's candidacy represented \"The greatest threat to the Democratic front runner, Lieutenant Governor Gavin Newsom.\"\n\nA Berkeley IGS Poll from April 2018 showed Allen and his opponent, Cox, going head to head for 2nd place with the scores of 18% (Cox) and 16% (Allen) within the poll's margin of error of ±4% points.\n\nIn May 2018, at the California Republican Party Convention in San Diego, John Cox received 55.3% of the delegates' votes while Allen received 40.5% of the delegates' votes. Neither candidate was able to reach the 60% threshold set by the California Republican Party for an official endorsement. In a Berkeley IGS Poll from December 2017, it showed Allen tied at 9 percent with Republican John Cox.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn February 2018, Travis was accused of several sexual harassment allegations during this time as a state assemblyman, a claim which he vehemently denied as being politically motivated, stating “I’m sure I’ve shaken many people’s hands, tapped many people on the shoulder, and have even tapped people’s feet accidentally. But there has never been anything in any of my actions that has been inappropriate, and nor will there ever be.” On November 15, 2018, Allen announced his candidacy for the chairmanship of the . \"For too long, the California Republican establishment has told us that we must look more like Democrats in order to be elected in the state of California,\" Allen said, adding that \"This sort of backwards thinking has lost seats and races across the state to where, today, the Republican party is at the lowest point it's been since the 1880s.\" He lost to Jessica Milan Patterson, who became the state party's first female leader.\n\n\n\nAllen has described himself as pro-life. He received a 0% score from  Affiliates of California in 2013, 2015, and 2017.\n\nIn 2014 Allen received a 55% score from Planned Parenthood Affiliates of California. On this scorecard he was ranked positively for his support of AB 1755 (which mandated a 15-day limit to notify the  of a breach of patient data), AB 1841 (which expanded the definition of “technical supportive services” who are allowed to handle medication), AB 2051 (which streamlined the Medi-Cal enrollment process), and SB857 (an omnibus health bill). Allen opposed SB 1053 (contraceptives and health care coverage) and SB 1094 (sale of assets in non-profit health care facilities).\n\nIn 2016 Allen received a 67% score from Planned Parenthood Affiliates of California. He was scored positively for voting yes on AB 1561, a bill which proposed to \"exempt from those taxes the gross receipts from the sale in this state of, and the storage, use, or other consumption in this state of, tampons, sanitary napkins, menstrual sponges, and menstrual cups\"; and SB 999, a bill intended to require that health insurance companies \"cover up to a 12-month supply of FDA-approved, self-administered hormonal contraceptives\".\n\n\n\"The only major-party candidate to support the death penalty is Assemblyman Travis Allen, R-Huntington Beach (Orange County), who said it was 'absolutely necessary in cases where heinous crimes have been committed.' He said he would deny commutation to any condemned inmate who had been 'rightfully convicted and sentenced'.\" He is also critical of the high yearly cost associated with preserving the lives of over 700 people who are on death row in California prisons.\n\n\nAllen has stated that he opposes mandatory full-day kindergarten, because he believes that children are being indoctrinated by \"liberal curriculum\". Allen wants to end Common Core's application at the state level, instead allowing local districts to set their own curricula.\n\n\nAllen has called  and sea-level rise \"unsettled,\" “absolute nonsense,” and “bogus science\". He states, \"These policy prescriptions of the Democrats of more regulation and higher taxes that they try to justify with tenuous climate change \"science\" are not benefiting Californians, nor are they benefiting the environment.\" Allen has stated that he opposes the  (CEQA) of 1970 because it \"strangles new housing development\".\n\nIn 2017 the  scored Allen at 6% for his voting record on similar bills. His only vote aligned with this organization's goals was for a bill to do with disclosure of ingredients in cleaning products. In the same year, Allen was rated 25% by the California Environmental Justice Alliance, and 25% by the  of California.\n\n\nAllen sponsored a proposed 2018 ballot initiative to repeal Senate Bill 1, legislation enacted by the Democratic-controlled legislature which increased the state gas tax by 12 cents a gallon and the diesel tax by 20 cents, and “as much as $175 more in annual car registration fees.”  Although this initiative did not qualify for the ballot, another initiative to repeal the gas tax increase and to require voter approval of future gas and vehicle taxes did qualify for the ballot as Proposition 6.\n\nAccording to , some of Allen's statements about the gas tax have been incorrect and problematic, which he disputes. According to Allen, the tax (SB1) allocates money to \"transportation-related projects\", which he considers to be a vague description of where the funding could be spent and makes the point repeatedly during many of his public appearances. He alleges that the money will be spent on Democratic \"budgetary mistakes\".\n\nPolitiFact does agree with Allen's point that “the congested corridor program cannot fund general purpose freeway lanes, which are the main lanes used by most drivers,” because “the legislation does, in fact, prohibit spending this money on those.” However, Politifact gave Allen a “mostly false” rating because he “distorted the purpose of the tax,” which is to reduce “vehicle miles traveled, greenhouse gases, and air pollution,\" and to “reduce people's dependency on their cars.”\n\n\nIn 2015, the Firearms Policy Coalition gave Allen an \"A\" rating in recognition of his support for Second Amendment rights. In 2014 Allen received an \"A-\" grade score from the , followed by a 93% score in 2016. and an A from the Gun Owners of California (a branch of ). In 2018, the Gun Owners of California again awarded Allen an A.\n\nAllen authored a failed bill which would have changed California into a  state.\n\n\nAllen opposed the proposed Medicare expansion and child vaccination policy under . He has stated opposition to  noting its high cost and crippling effect on the state budget. Allen's solution includes introducing competition into the California healthcare market, “The solution is to open our markets to companies across the United States to compete for Californians’ business.” He also noted the need to increase the allowances on Health Savings Accounts.\n\n\nAllen voted no on  (2017) when it came to the California State Assembly for a floor vote on September 15, 2017. He has vocally opposed the \"Sanctuary State\" bill speaking out against it publicly for the first time on February 1, 2017, on the  show on  AM 640. SB 54 passed the Senate and Assembly and was signed into law by Governor Jerry Brown on October 5, 2017, with an effective date of January 1, 2018.\n\nAllen continued his opposition to SB 54 and, as he called it, the \"illegal sanctuary state\" on January 2, 2018, when he appeared on the  show,  where he invited President Donald Trump and United States Attorney General  to sue Sacramento over the new \"Sanctuary State\" law. He would appear several more times on Fox News and other networks repeating this invitation throughout 2018.\n\nAllen made this a cornerstone of his failed 2018 campaign for California Governor, vowing \"to reverse the illegal sanctuary state in [his] first 100 days in office.\"\n\nAllen has disputed statements about the details of the bill and about support for it. His assertions regarding public support for the sanctuary state are based on various polls, Polls come from different focus groups, conservative vs. liberal although this has been a point of debate as well.\n\n\nIn 2016, Allen introduced legislation in opposition to the  (BDS) campaign - AB 1552: a bill that would prohibit state government entities from doing business with companies that officially join the BDS campaign, and AB 1551, another bill that would forbid state government entities from investing in companies engaged in political actions to damage or limit commerce with Israel and Israeli companies. Allen's AB 1552 was eventually signed into law as AB 2844, of which Allen was principal author.\n\n\nIn the State Assembly, Allen earned 100% ratings from the , the  and the California Manufacturers and Technology Association. Allen's support for lower taxes and opposition to tax increases earned him A+ ratings from the .\n\n\nAllen is a supporter of , specifically in California, and has made this a part of his platform for his race for governor in California.\n\nHe has stated publicly and via his social media accounts, that there is voter fraud in California. His \"controversial\" statement was, “Eleven counties in California have more total registered voters than citizens over the age of 18. How is this possible?” In the opinion of some newspaper editorialists, a statement which never had any evidence for and which has been proven incorrect. He \"made up\" inaccurate numbers for the number of registered voters in California, according to newspaper opinion writer, Dan Morain.\n\nIn August 2017,  on behalf of the (Election Integrity Project California, Inc.) sent a notice-of-violation letter to the state of California alleging that public records obtained on the Election Assistance Commission's 2016 Election Administration Voting Survey and through verbal accounts from various county agencies show eleven California counties - Imperial (102%), Lassen (102%), Los Angeles (112%), Monterey (104%), San Diego (138%), San Francisco (114%), San Mateo (111%), Santa Cruz (109%), Solano (111%), Stanislaus (102%), and Yolo (110%) - have more registered voters than voting-age citizens; and that Los Angeles County officials “informed us that the total number of registered voters now stands at a number that is a whopping 144% of the total number of resident citizens of voting age.” In December 2017 Judicial Watch filed a federal lawsuit against Los Angeles County and the State of California over their alleged failure to clean their voter rolls and to produce election-related records as required by the federal National Voter Registration Act (NVRA)().\n\n\nAllen is divorced and single.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Edward Randall Royce''' (born October 12, 1951) is an American politician who served as a member of the  from  from 1993 to 2019. A member of the , Royce served as Chairman of the  from 2013 to 2019. He previously served as a member of the  from 1982 to 1993.\n\nHe was reelected to his seat in , having spent over $3.5 million on his campaign. On January 8, 2018, Royce announced that he would retire from  at the end of his term and not run for reelection in .\n\nIn September 2020, Royce joined the law firm .\n\n\nRoyce was born in , . He graduated from  in . He earned his  degree in  and  in 1977 from .\n\n\nRoyce was a business owner and  manager for a  company before becoming a  in 1983, serving in that post until his election to the U.S. House of Representatives.\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting following the , incumbent Republican U.S. Representative  decided to retire and run for the . Royce won the Republican primary for what was then , which included most of northern Orange County and southern Los Angeles County.\n\nHe defeated Democrat Molly McClanahan in the general election with 57% of the vote.\n\nHe won re-election to the 39th district four more times with at least 63% of the vote. After redistricting after the , his district was renumbered the 40th and cut back to northern Orange County. He won re-election from this district five more times with at least 63% of the vote.\n\n;2012\n\nAfter redistricting, Royce's home in Fullerton was drawn into the 39th district. That district had previously been the 42nd District, represented by fellow Republican . Although it was geographically more Miller's district than Royce's, Royce would have been favored in a primary battle with Miller–which would have been the real contest in this heavily Republican district. Ultimately, Miller opted to move to the neighboring 31st District, effectively handing the seat to Royce.\n\nRoyce defeated Jay Chen in the general election.\n\n\n\nIn 2012 he was endorsed by 11 of 14 Republicans as chairman of the  and has served as chairman since January 2013.\n\nRoyce voted in favor of the .\n\n\n meet   at the  in ,  in 2016]]\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n* ''', Chair'''\n\n\n* Human Rights Caucus\n* Congressional Military Family Caucus\n* Congressional Internet Caucus\n* House Recycling Caucus\n* Victim's Rights Caucus\n* International Conservation Caucus\n* Congressional Caucus on Korea\n* Congressional Caucus on India and Indian Americans\n* Congressional Caucus on Vietnam\n* Taiwan Caucus\n* U.S. Philippines Friendship Caucus\n* Congressional Cement Caucus\n*\n* \n* ''''''\n* Co-chair \n\n\nSituated in a district that supported  in the 2016 Presidential election by a margin of eight points, Royce was widely viewed as one of the most vulnerable members of Congress. As of December 2017, polling in the 39th District showed a 36% approval rating for Royce and a 60% disapproval rating for . Additionally, the data showed that a large majority of voters disapproved of Royce's public support and vote in favor of the Republican . Acknowledging the difficult campaign ahead and the end of his six-year term as Chairman of the , Royce decided to announce his retirement and decision to not run for reelection in 2018 via  on January 8, 2018. Thirty minutes following his announcement,  formally nominated Royce's wife  to be . In retiring, Royce joined the \"casualty list\" of 36 Republican members of the 115th Congress who have left or announced their intention to leave the .\n\n\n\nRoyce voted in line with President Trump's position in 97.9% of the votes in the . For the , Royce was ranked as the 27th most bipartisan member of the U.S. House of Representatives (and the most bipartisan member of the U.S. House of Representatives from California) in the Bipartisan Index created by  and the  that ranks members of the United States Congress by their degree of bipartisanship (by measuring the frequency each member's bills attract co-sponsors from the opposite party and each member's co-sponsorship of bills by members of the opposite party). Over his career, Royce has received nearly $7 million from PACs.  In the 2016 race, he raised over $4.2 million and spent over $3.5 million.\n\nHis campaign committee received funds from Northwest Excavating, ,  and NorPac. The Sunlight Foundation gave Royce's web site a 24 percent rating for transparency, with 40 percent being considered a passing score. Royce's website highlights support from  groups such as   and business organizations such as the  and . He received praise from the American Share Holders Association, , and the Small Business Survival Committee.\n\nFor the 113th Congress, the Washington Post named Royce as one of the “10 most effective lawmakers in the U.S. Congress”, citing his authorship of the Global Anti-Poaching Act (H.R. 2494) and the Hizballah International Financing Prevention Act of 2015 (H.R. 2297).\n\n\nRoyce's voting record, his scores on VoteMatch, and ratings by the  indicate mixed or moderate positions on ,, issues2000.org; accessed April 3, 2017., ontheissues.org; accessed April 3, 2017.  of , campaign finance, and tax reform.\n\n\n\nRoyce is pro-life.\n\n\nOne of Royce's early signature issues was banking deregulation. He has sponsored legislation on , small businesses, and credit. Many of his biggest campaign contributors have been banks: his five top contributors in 2006 were Credit Union National Assn, Irvine Co., Wells Fargo, Orange County Teachers Fed Credit Union, and GUS plc. He is among the representatives receiving the largest percentage of their campaign contributions from the banking industry.\n\nOn November 13, 2013, Royce introduced the  into the House. The bill would expand federal deposit insurance to include  (IOLTAs) and similar escrow accounts housed within credit unions.\n\n\n\nRoyce has a \"C\" rating from  regarding his voting record on -related matters. He voted against allowing veterans access to , if legal in their state, per their Veterans Health Administration doctor's recommendation.\n\n\n\nRoyce had a \"A\" rating from the  regarding his voting record on -related matters.\n\nIn the wake of the 2016 , Royce posted on Facebook: \"We need to defeat the terrorists and make it our top national security priority to prevail in the war against radical .\"\n\n\nHe has received 14 \"Taxpayer Friend Awards\" from the National Taxpayers' Union. Royce opposes funding for the  (OPIC). Royce has posited that these overseas investments expose taxpayers to a serious potential liability, just like the S&L crisis did.\n\n\nRoyce sponsored anti-stalking legislation signed into law by President Bill Clinton, which was based on legislation Royce had authored as a California State Senator. In 2003, he sponsored another bill as US representative related to victims.\n\n\nOn May 4, 2017, he voted to repeal the  (Obamacare) and pass the .\n\n\nIn , Royce's voting record has earned a 0% rating from the peace organization . In 2011, Royce voted against the  as part of a controversial provision that allows the government and the military to indefinitely detain American citizens and others without trial.\n\n\nIn 2016, Royce criticized the Iran nuclear agreement and Obama administration harshly, saying the deal was \"a financial windfall” for Iran and a \"a cash bonanza, a boost to its international standing, and a lighted path toward nuclear weapons.\" He called for re-introducing sanctions on Iran. Later, in 2017, after Donald Trump had become president, Royce said that he was in favor of staying in the Iran nuclear agreement.\n\n\n and House Speaker  face  from the  in 1997]]\nRoyce serves as a senior member of the Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asia. He and has been especially involved in policy regarding North Korea, working on issues such as human rights, counterfeiting of U.S. currency, nuclear proliferation, and stopping repatriation of refugees. Royce's district includes , which has a large population of Korean immigrants. During a slow-rolling crisis in 2017 between the US and North Korea, Royce introduced legislation expanding sanctions against North Korea and requiring that its designation as a state sponsor of terror be reinstated.\n\n\nRoyce was a supporter of the US wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. In 2002, he voted in favor of authorizing   to use force in Iraq. , unitedforpeace.org; accessed April 3, 2017. In 2003, he voted yes on an emergency appropriation of $78 billion for the  and . From 2003 to 2006, he voted in favor of the annual supplemental spending bill to continue funding for the Iraq war. In 2005, he voted against Amendment 214 to HR 1815, which called on Bush to develop a plan for withdrawing U.S. troops from Iraq; in favor of Amendment 488 to HR 2601 to keep troops in Iraq; and in favor of HR 612 opposing a timetable for withdrawal of troops from Iraq. In 2006, he voted for HR 861, a resolution labeling the war in Iraq as part of a .\n\nHe has supported U.S. broadcasting efforts in Asia, initiating legislation to create  and  on the model of /. Royce had a mixed voting record on the 2011 . In 2015, he supported the .\n\n\nIn 2018, Royce condemned the  of the  minority in  and called for a stronger response to the crisis, saying that \"Defining these atrocities for what they are is critical to building international public awareness – and support – to stop them.\"\n\n\nRoyce was formerly chair of the Africa Subcommittee. He co-led, with , a delegation to observe 's  and led a delegation to  to bring attention to the ongoing  in 2005 and led efforts in the House to bring , the former , to stand trial before the Special Court of .\n\n\nOn April 26, 2013, Royce introduced the , a bill that would increase U.S. sanctions on . Royce said that \"by shutting down North Korea's illicit activities, we deprive the Kim regime of the money he needs to pay his generals and to conduct nuclear weapons research.\" Royce also argued that \"North Korea is undoubtedly one of the most significant security threats that we here face and our allies face.\"\n\nOn June 27, 2013, Royce introduced the , a bill that would direct the  to establish a multiyear strategy to assist countries in  develop an appropriate mix of power solutions to provide sufficient  access to people living in rural and urban areas in order to alleviate  and drive economic growth.\n\nOn November 13, 2013, Royce introduced the  into the House. The bill would allow the sale of several s to , , and . Four naval vessels would be sold to Taiwan for about $10 million each. Mexico and Thailand would each receive two vessels as a grant. Royce argued in favor of the bill saying that \"these ships would bolster Taiwan's defense.\" Royce also said that \"these transfers help support the priorities of the U.S. Navy while strengthening the capability of allies and our close partners to meet our share maritime security objectives.\"\n\nIn January 2017, Royce introduced a House resolution condemning the , which condemned  in the occupied  as a violation of international law.\n\n\n*  with Grand Cordon – Republic of China\n*  with Special Grand Cordon – Republic of China\n\n\nRoyce is married to , a businesswoman, former professor at , and the .\n\nRoyce is .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| children            = 1\n| education           =  ()\n}}\n'''Ellen O'Kane Tauscher''' (November 15, 1951 – April 29, 2019) was an American businesswoman, diplomat, and  politician who was the  for  from 1997 to 2009. From 2009 to 2012, she served as the . She then served as Special Envoy for Strategic Stability and Missile Defense at the State Department.\n\nWhile in Congress, Tauscher was a leading centrist Democrat, and the chair of the , a caucus of moderate Democrats in the House of Representatives. She also served as vice-chairwoman of the  from 2001 to 2005.\n\n\nEllen Tauscher was born in , the daughter of John E. O'Kane, a  for the  union at a  store in , and his wife Sally, a secretary for  in New York City. She graduated in 1974 from , where she obtained a  degree in .\n\nShe then worked as an  with  and, at age 25, was the youngest and one of the first women to become a member of the . She also served as an officer of the  from 1979 to 1983, after which she worked for  and a subsidiary of .\n\nIn 1989, Tauscher moved to California and later founded the ChildCare Registry, the first national research service to help parents verify the background of childcare workers. She also published ''The ChildCare Sourcebook'' and headed the Tauscher Foundation, which provided funds for elementary schools to buy computers and .\n\n\nBefore running for the , Tauscher was active in  circles as a  and also chaired 's successful  and .\n\nIn 1996, Tauscher was recruited to run against two-term  incumbent  in , which included several wealthy suburbs in the East Bay. During the campaign, Tauscher emphasized balancing the federal budget, her support for business, the environment, and the military. She also charged that Baker was too  for the district, particularly given his opposition to  and . She narrowly defeated Baker, claiming victory by a margin of 1.45% of the vote. The race was ranked as the fourth most expensive of that year's 435 House races.\n\nTauscher was re-elected in  and  against vigorous Republican opposition. While the 10th district was once considered \"solid Republican territory,\" most Bay Area Republicans tend to be more moderate than their counterparts in the rest of California and since the 1990s have been increasingly willing to support Democrats at the national level.\n\nIn 2000, during the statewide redistricting process, some of the more Republican-leaning parts of Tauscher's district were removed and replaced with more Democratic territory near  and in . She was subsequently re-elected to four more terms, facing no substantive opposition and receiving more than 65 percent of the vote after .\n\nIn the House of Representatives, Tauscher served on the  and the . She chaired the , which oversees the country's nuclear weapons stockpile, missile defense program, and the national labs. Tauscher was the only member of Congress who had two national labs in her district,  and the California campus of . At the time she left Congress, Tauscher also was the senior member from California serving on the  and the  of the . From her position on the Transportation Committee, Tauscher brought $33 million to her district for transportation and infrastructure projects.\n\n,  and  Fund panel discussion, \"\", Washington, D.C., June 29, 2017]]\n\nOn March 18, 2009, President Obama nominated Tauscher to the position of . She was confirmed by the  on June 25, 2009, by . Notwithstanding her appointment, confirmation and acceptance, she served as  on June 26, 2009, when the House narrowly passed (219–212) a  global warming bill. Tauscher resigned her seat on June 26, 2009, after voting was finished on the . Her resignation necessitated a . Tauscher served as  until her appointment on February 6, 2012, as Special Envoy for Strategic Stability and Missile Defense. Tauscher retired from the State Department on August 31, 2012.\n\nAs Under Secretary of State, Tauscher successfully negotiated the  treaty with the Russian Federation in March 2010. The first major agreement signed with Russia in nearly 20 years, the treaty was signed by Presidents Barack Obama and  on April 8, 2010, and ratified by the U.S. Senate on December 22, 2010. Tauscher represented the United States at the  that is held every five years to review the status of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty (NPT). The 2010 conference was the first in 10 years to result in an consensus agreement. Tauscher was also the lead official in the State Department working on the bilateral agreements with Poland, Romania, and Turkey for the European Phased Adaptive Approach missile defense system, negotiating timely agreements that allowed the President's deployment timeline to be met.\n\nIn 2008, Tauscher was a strong supporter of 's candidacy for president. She traveled around the country as a surrogate for Clinton's campaign in the primary. In 2013, she was one of the first prominent elected officials to join the  effort which became one of the largest independent grassroots efforts on behalf of an undeclared Presidential candidate in history.\n\n\nA leading  Democrat, Tauscher was the chairwoman of the , a  of moderate Democrats in the House. She also served as vice-chairwoman of the  from 2001 to 2005.\n\nTauscher received an 11% lifetime rating from the , and a 95% rating for her 2008 voting record from .\n\nWhile in Congress, she supported  and, in particular, covering  children through the  (SCHIP). She also supported scaling back the , tightening  rules, and expanding .\n\n\nTauscher was strongly . She received a 100% positive rating from . She voted against bans on  and .\n\nShe also supported federal funding of , voting in favor of both s.\n\n\nTauscher was in favor of more extensive gun control. She expressed her support for the , but has also said that \"we should keep guns out of the hands of criminals and those with history of violence.\" She called for \"common sense gun safety legislation that strikes a balance between Second Amendment protections and protections for the public.\"\n\nWhile in Congress, she supported arming commercial , requiring s of legal gun owners, and banning s. She received an F rating from the .\n\n\nIn October 2002, Tauscher voted in favor of the , approving the  . However, she later became a critic of the , while continuing to vote for funding for the War (see HR 1585\"HR-1585 Iraq War Funding\" Retrieved from http://www.my-representative.org/report.php?csn=110&RegionCode=CA-10). In December 2005, Tauscher led a group of twenty-two other House Democrats in sending a letter to   urging him to , expressing the hope that the \" takes increased responsibility\" for its political and security needs. She later voted to redeploy troops out of Iraq within 90 days and even to  over the war.\n\n\nTauscher was an early proponent of same-sex marriage, publicly stating in 2004 in response to President George W. Bush's call for a constitutional amendment to ban same-sex marriage, \"It is clear to me that this is the civil rights issue of the 21st century, and it is unambiguous in my mind that the government cannot discriminate by gender the rights conferred by the state in marriage.\" In 2006, she voted against the , which would have  defined marriage as being between a man and woman.\n\nOn March 3, 2009, Tauscher introduced the  of 2009 to the , which would have repealed Don't Ask, Don't Tell. The bill eventually passed in a slightly different form in 2010 after Tauscher had left the House, repealing Don't Ask, Don't Tell.\n\nShe was opposed to  . She had a 100% rating from the , the largest  advocacy group in the .\n\n\nAfter leaving the State Department, Tauscher assumed a number of publicly held corporate and non-profit board positions, including serving on the boards of / (EIX) in Rosemead, California, and eHealth (EHTH) in Mountain View, California. She served on the Board of Advisors of  and the Board of Directors of ,  Corporation, and . She was a member of the Board of Governors of . She served as vice chair of the  and was a member of the .\n\nShe also served as chairman of the Board of Governors for  and , a member of the board of directors of the , and was chairman of the board of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network Foundation.\n\nIn August 2013, the  elected Tauscher as independent chairperson. The Alliance is a coalition of some of the largest clothing retailers and brands in North America, including Wal-Mart, Target, the Gap, Costco, and VF Brands. The Alliance is working with the government of Bangladesh, factory owners, and international organizations to improve worker safety for Bangladeshi garment workers.\n\nTauscher was also a strategic advisor to the Washington, D.C. law firm of  on matters of defense, transportation, energy, and health care.\n\nTauscher was a member of the ReFormers Caucus of .\n\n\nTauscher lived in  and later , during her Congressional career. Prior to their  in 1999, she was married to William Tauscher, former chairman and  of , current  of , and founder of the Tauscher Group, which invests and assists in the management of enterprises in home products, , security and . She had a daughter, Katherine (born 1991).\n\nOn the same day as her taking the office of Under Secretary, she married widower James Cieslak, a retired pilot for . They divorced in 2011.\n\nIn July 2010, Tauscher was diagnosed with Stage 3 esophageal cancer, one of the fastest growing cancers in the United States and one of the deadliest, with a survival rate of 18%. After a grueling regimen of chemotherapy, radiation, and surgery to remove her esophagus, Tauscher was declared cancer-free in December 2010. Following that time, she was active as a board member of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) and as chair of the NCCN Foundation, as well as speaking around the country, advocating for more information, more funding and earlier screening for the disease.\n\nTauscher died of pneumonia on April 29, 2019, at the age of 67 at the , in .\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Anna Marie Caballero''' (born April 18, 1955) is an American politician serving in the . A , she represents the ,  which includes ,  and  Counties and part of the . She previously served in the  representing the , encompassing the  and  Valleys in the , from 2016 to 2018 and the  from 2006 to 2010.\n\n\nBorn in  to a family of copper miners, Caballero moved to the  to work for California Rural Legal Assistance. She received her B.A. degree from the  and her  degree from the .\n\n\n\nAs an attorney, Caballero represented striking farm workers and fought side by side with unions to prevent plant closures. She, along with three partners, founded the law firm Caballero, Matcham & McCarthy, in 1982 to provide low cost legal service. Caballero was recognized with the Athena Award for entrepreneurial excellence.\n\nCaballero served on the Planning Commission and was later elected to the   in 1991. She was then elected Mayor in 1998. As Mayor, she navigated Salinas through budgetary problems and closed Salinas's libraries as reported by NBC New. Caballero was elected to the State Assembly in 2006.\n\nCaballero ran for the California State Senate in 2010 to replace term-limited Republican incumbent , who ran successfully for Congress. She lost to     in an .\n\n  appointed Caballero to lead the  on March 22, 2011, serving until 2015. In 2016, she was again elected as a  to the  .\n\nIn 2018, Caballero announced that she would again run for the state Senate to succeed Cannella, who was ed.\nShe won the seat, defeating    Rob Poythress.\n\nCaballero has also served as the executive director of Partners for Peace, a nonprofit organization dedicated to bringing the community together to prevent gang violence and focus on literacy, early childhood education, and providing services to families. Caballero is also a wife and mother. Her husband, Juan Uranga, is the Director of the Center for Community Advocacy in Salinas.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He is a  representing the , which encompasses a portion of the , including most of the city of . He is a candidate in the  for Mayor of Sacramento.\n\nMcCarty is a member of the . Prior to being elected to the Assembly in 2014, he served on the  representing the 6th district, which includes part of the eastern and southeastern parts of the city.\n\n\nMcCarty was born in Washington D.C., the son of Barbara and Eliot McCarty. His mother is  and his father is . After his parents separated when he was a small child, his mother moved with her children to Sacramento. \n\nMcCarty graduated with a  in  from  and has a  in public policy and administration from . Before his service as an elected official, McCarty served as Policy Director to former California Lieutenant Governor , and as an Assembly Budget Committee consultant to then-Assemblywoman . While on the City Council, McCarty worked as a legislative advocate for Preschool California.\n\n\n\nMcCarty served on the  from 2004 to 2014. Representing many of 's older neighborhoods, McCarty advocated for safe housing, inspections of Sacramento's numerous rental housing units, , and the creation of after-school programs.  Council member McCarty along with Darrell Fong voted against a $257 million subsidy to develop a downtown entertainment and sports complex for the Sacramento Kings.\n\nIn 2014, incumbent  Assemblyman  ran for the , leaving the  vacant. McCarty ran again and this time was successful, defeating fellow man Steve Cohn. As a result of the 2020 census, McCarty's  neighborhood was redistricted to the , from which he was re-elected in 2022 election.\n\nMcCarty is a member of the . \n\nHe is a candidate in the  for Mayor of Sacramento. He has advanced to the November runoff, narrowly defeating former state senator  for the runner-up spot in the primary.\n\n\nHe currently resides in the  neighborhood with his wife, Leticia García, and their twin daughters Victoria and Barbara.
