    "pages": }\n'''Peter Rey Aguilar''' ( ; born June 19, 1979) is an American politician who has been  since 2023. He has been the  for  (renumbered from the 31st after the 2020 redistricting cycle) since 2015. He served as mayor of , from 2010 to 2014, and as the president of the Inland Empire Division of the . Aguilar served on the Redlands City Council from 2006 until his election to .\n\nAguilar chairs the  and is the highest-ranking  in Congress.\n\n\nAguilar was born in , and grew up in a working-class family in . He is of  descent. He graduated from the , where he studied government and business administration.\n\n\nAguilar began his career in public service in 2001 when then-California Governor  appointed him deputy director of the Inland Empire Regional Office of the governor, eventually becoming the Interim Director. In 2006, Aguilar became the youngest member of the Redlands City Council in the city's history when five council members, Democrat and Republican, picked him out of 11 candidates to fill an open seat. He was elected a year later. His fellow council members appointed him mayor in 2010 and again in 2012. As mayor, Aguilar was regarded for his professionalism, leadership during difficult financial times, balancing the city budget while building financial reserves, road improvements, government transparency, and fair treatment of municipal employees. Aguilar served as mayor and councilman until December 2014.\n\n\n\n\n became more favorable to the  as a result of redistricting following the . The  rates the district D+5. In January 2012, Aguilar announced he would run for the seat held by incumbent Republican . Although the top Democratic vote-getter, with 22.6% of the vote, he finished behind Miller and , the  Republican Leader. Because of California's open primary, both Republicans advanced to the November general election. In March 2013, Aguilar announced he would run again. In the June 2014 primary, he finished second, qualifying for the November general election, where he defeated Republican  with 51.4% of the vote. Aguilar defeated Chabot again in the 2016 election with 56.1% of the vote.\n\nIn the 2018 primary, Aguilar faced Kaiser Ahmed and Sean Flynn, a Republican economist and aikido artist. Aguilar received 45.96% of the vote to Flynn's 45.45% and Ahmed's 8.59%. In the general election, Aguilar won 58.7% of the vote to Flynn's 41.3%.\n\nAguilar won his 2020  with 61% of the vote, defeating Republic Agnes Gibboney. Aguilar was elected Vice chair of the House Democratic Caucus.\n\nRedistricting from the 2020 US census, placed Aguilar in the new . He defeated Republican John Mark Porter and won re-election during the . He was also elected as  Chairman, becoming the highest ranking Latino-American in congress, in congressional history.\n\n\n\nAguilar's time in Congress has focused on immigration, job creation, trade practices, , national security, LGBT issues, veteran affairs, drug prevention, student loan debt, and environmental protection. Aguilar has supported legislation to attract individuals in the cybersecurity field to join the military; prevent discrimination against LGBT people by government contractors; provide funding for homeless veterans; and provide funding for research into opioid addiction. He has introduced the Grace Period Alleviation (GPA) Act, which would give college graduates an optional grace period before beginning to repay certain types of loans. With Senator  and Representative , Aguilar introduced legislation to protect the habitat along the . He has vowed to fight the repeal of the  and to protect women's reproductive rights. In addition, he has worked closely with law enforcement and local, state and federal officials and agencies to help communities recover costs incurred from the emergency response to the , which took place in Aguilar's district, and helped secure additional funding for survivors of the attack.\n\n;Immigration\nDuring the  Administration, Aguilar supported expanding the  (DACA) program for undocumented children and creating the  (DAPA) program. He introduced the Academic Success Centers and Education Networks for Dreamers (ASCEND) Act, which would establish grants for college and university programs and services to benefit undocumented students. Aguilar voted in favor of legislation that would effectively halt the resettlement of refugees from Syria and Iraq to the U.S., citing national security concerns, but subsequently criticized President 's  as \"xenophobic\" and said it sent a message of \"hate and bigotry to the rest of the world.\" Aguilar criticized Trump and his staff for citing the  in defending the executive order. In 2018, with Representative , Aguilar authored legislation that would provide a path to citizenship for DACA recipients and address border protection concerns.\n\n;Job creation\nAguilar released a job-creation initiative for his district that includes cutting taxes on small businesses, investing in infrastructure, expanding job-training programs, expanding , increasing the , and equal pay for women. He has introduced a number of bills focusing on small businesses, including legislation to provide tax credits to small businesses for on-the-job training expenses, tax credits for small business for full-time newly hired employees, legislation to make it easier for small businesses to repay loans, and legislation making it easier for small businesses to advertise job openings. Aguilar annually hosts a jobs fair that connects job-seekers with employers in his district. In April 2017, he started a quarterly \"Job For a Day\" tour where he works throughout the Inland Empire doing jobs such as train conducting for Metrolink, sorting Goodwill donations, and bagging groceries at local markets. The tour's goal is to interact with community members directly and learn about local businesses' daily operations.\n\nIn 2017, Aguilar introduced a bill that would provide active-duty service members and reservists access to training for commercial drivers’ licenses granted by the . He authored the Active Duty Voluntary Acquisition of Necessary Credentials for Employment (ADVANCE) Act and the OPPORTUNITY (Offering Promising Persons Occupations Relevant To Upholding National Interests For Years) Act, both of which Trump signed into law in 2018. The latter bill connects students of color with the Department of Defense Cyber Scholarship program.\n\n;Trade policy\nAguilar introduced the Displaced Jobs Relief Act, which increases authorization of funds for the  for Firms program (TAA-F) to help businesses that have been negatively affected by trade. He has urged the  to find that imported steel subsidized by ,  and  creates unfair competition and hurts steel manufacturers in his district.\n\n;Gun control\nAguilar has advocated for reforms to curb gun violence by closing loopholes that terrorists have used to obtain guns and banning . After the 2016 , Aguilar participated in the  to show support for gun control legislation.\n\n\nAt the start of the , Aguilar was in the House Well, at the US Capitol building during the . On July 1, 2021, Speaker Pelosi appointed eight House members, including Aguilar, to the . After the announcement, Aguilar said of the committee and its investigation: \"We owe themand we owe the American peoplea fair, thorough and evidence-based investigation into what happened that day so that we can ensure it never happens again.\"\n\nOn June 16, 2022, Aguilar and John Wood, an investigative counsel for the Select Committee, led the committee's third televised hearing, focusing on Trump's efforts to pressuring  into decertifying the . The witnesses were , Pence's counsel, who told Pence he did not have the authority to decertify the election results, and , a retired conservative judge on the , who called Donald Trump and his allies and supporters \"a clear and present danger to American democracy.\"\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n** \n** \n\n\n* Chair, \n* \n* Pro-Choice Caucus\n* \n* Latino-Jewish Caucus\n* Diabetes Caucus\n* Work for Warriors Caucus\n* Joint Strike Fighter Caucus\n* Veterans Jobs Caucus\n* Former Mayors Caucus\n* Wine Caucus\n* Native American Caucus\n* \n* Hunger Caucus\n* \n*\n*\n\nAguilar announced his candidacy for vice chair of the  in September 2018, but lost to  by a vote of 144–90. By a vote of 148–82, he defeated  for the no. 6 spot in the . The position became vacant after Clark decided to run for Assistant Speaker in the . Aguilar then became vice chair in the 117th Congress and voted in as chair in the 118th Congress.\n\n\nAguilar's top contributors throughout his career have been JStreet PAC, League of Conservation Voters, Credit Union National Association, Matich Corporation, and New World Medical. Since 2011, he has not contributed personally to his own campaign, and relies mostly on individual contributions from community members. He has obtained nearly $5.3 million in contributions from individuals (63.86% of total donations). Top donations are generally from Democrats, but also include lawyers and law firms, Leadership PACs, and labor unions. His total career campaign donations are $8.2 million.\n\n\n]]\n\n\n\nAguilar opposed the , calling it a \"devastating decision\".\n\n\nIn 2022, Aguilar was one of 16 Democrats to vote against the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act of 2022, an antitrust package that would crack down on corporations' anti-competitive behavior.\n\n\nAguilar voted to provide Israel with support following the .\n\n\n\n •  •  •  • \n\n\n election, 2022\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n election, 2020\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n election, 2018\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n election, 2016\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAguilar has lived in , since 1997. He and his wife, Alisha, have two sons.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n* campaign website \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kevin Paffrath''' (born January 28, 1992), also known as '''Meet Kevin''', is an American , , , and entrepreneur. He has been a licensed investment advisor since September 2022 but states that he does not give personalized financial advice through his videos. In 2019, he was described by '''' as a \"landlord \". Paffrath was a  candidate to replace fellow Democrat  in the unsuccessful , winning 9.6% of the vote.\n\n\nPaffrath was born in Germany on January 28, 1992. His parents immigrated from  to the United States when he was 18 months old, and his parents divorced when he was six years old. As a teenager, Paffrath initially wanted to work in , and participated in a law enforcement explorer program, in which he rode along with police officers and learned about the career. While on a high school trip to , Paffrath met his future wife, Lauren Stewart. In the summer before his senior year of high school, Paffrath moved to California to live with Lauren and her family, while finishing high school at . Lauren's parents worked in real estate, and Paffrath became interested in the field.\n\nPaffrath attended , and then the . At UCLA, he studied economics, accounting, and political science.\n\nKevin and Lauren Paffrath have two sons, two twin daughters, and triplets (two identical girls and one boy). The last 5 were carried by surrogate. Lauren, who began to  when she was 18 years old, works as a property manager for The Paffrath Organization. , the Paffraths live in , California. Kevin Paffrath is a financial advisor and manages the \"Meet Kevin Pricing Power\" ETF, listed on the NYSE, ticker $PP. He also operates HouseHack.\n\n\nPaffrath earned his  in 2010 and the same year purchased a  house with his future wife and . They then began renovating additional homes and renting them out. Paffrath and his wife Lauren own the real estate business The Paffrath Organization, through which they buy, renovate, and rent properties in southern California. In 2017 they began to offer construction services through their organization but ended the venture 18 months later after losing $1million, which Paffrath attributed to narrow cost margins not allowing room for error. , Paffrath and his wife reportedly owned 22 properties, including one in which they live.\n\nPaffrath started his YouTube channel, ''Meet Kevin'', in September 2010. The channel reached 1million subscribers in December 2020 and had over 1.7million . His videos have discussed topics including real estate, the stock market, COVID-19 stimulus checks, , and . Paffrath also teaches online courses on the Teachable platform.\n\nSteven T. Wright publishing in the real estate website ''Curbed'' about \"landlord influencers\" included a profile of Paffrath. In the article, he described some of Paffrath's \"arguably incendiary opinions on landlord-tenant relations\", including Paffrath's requirement that his tenants have a  of 700 or higher, and his advice that property owners should mislead tenants by concealing the fact that they own the property, or are the sole owner.\n\nIn November 2020, Paffrath's channel and real estate career were featured on 's ''Millennial Money'', which publishes profiles of s and how they earn and spend their money. CNBC found that Paffrath earns most of his income from YouTube advertising revenue and , not real estate or stock market investing. Paffrath was among a group of finance YouTubers profiled by Adlan Jackson in a March 2021 '''' article, which discussed their shift during the  from offering advice on becoming multimillionaires towards creating videos to provide \"any little update\" on stimulus payments. In the article, Jackson said that Paffrath was \"exceptionally talented at talking to a camera, a natural salesman\", but also wrote that he was \"a multimillionaire landlord who once extolled the virtues of misleading tenants and vigorously refusing to rent to people with suboptimal credit scores\".\n\nIn August 2021, CNBC reported that Paffrath earned close to $10million from YouTube over the last 12 months.\n\nIn November 2022, after the collapse of the  cryptocurrency exchange, Paffrath posted an apology video in which he claimed he was paid $2,500 every time he mentioned FTX in one of his videos. He believed he had one of the smaller deals and claimed other influencers had six-figure deals with the exchange. In a telephone interview with '''' from a cruise with family, he said, \"If I could go back in time, I would undo it all in a heartbeat. We failed here. Everybody was fooled\". Paffrath claimed the income from the FTX deal only accounted for three percent of his total income for the year. In an interview with the '''', he referred to this as a \"scar\" on him as an influencer.\n\nOn November 29, 2022, Paffrath launched \"The Meet Kevin Pricing Power ETF\" under ticker symbol $PP. He also operates HouseHack.\n\n\nRamsey Solutions, a media company, owned by finance personality , sued Paffrath in 2018. Ramsey alleged , stealing s, and  statements. Paffrath had posted videos critical of Ramsey and his business practices. One video was entitled \"Dave Ramsey: Exposed\" where Paffrath claimed Ramsey's business provided \"cold-as-ice \" for real estate sales and collected a fee for \"doing nothing\". Paffrath stated that he had ended his relationship with Ramsey Solutions before making the videos and believed he did not violate a contract. Paffrath also claimed the lawsuit was an attempt at censorship which violated his . The case moved to federal court in 2019, and was settled privately out of court later that year. Paffrath's videos mentioned in the lawsuit are no longer on YouTube.\n\nPaffrath made numerous YouTube videos criticizing the business model of real estate personality Grant Cardone. In an effort to bring more attention to his other videos, in 2018, Paffrath delivered flowers to Cardone's office staff while dressed as a , reportedly running through Cardone's offices. Paffrath was charged with  and , but the charges were later dismissed. In a May 2021 interview with  discussing his gubernatorial candidacy, Paffrath expressed regret for the \"YouTube prank\" and said he had gotten \"carried away with the entertainment aspect of YouTube\".\n\nPaffrath was amongst a number of finance YouTube stars who were sued in a class action lawsuit filed March 15, 2023 in the Southern District of Florida in relation to their alleged promotion of the cryptocurrency exchange . The suit alleged that Kevin Paffrath amongst a number of other defendants “promoted, assisted in, and/or participated in” the sale of “unregistered securities” by FTX. Paffrath subsequently agreed the terms of a settlement for his part in the case, the details of which have not yet been disclosed.\n\n\n\nOn May 17, 2021, Paffrath announced his candidacy as a Democrat in the 2021 California gubernatorial recall election, which was held on September 14, 2021, and ultimately resulted in sitting governor Gavin Newsom not being recalled. Paffrath was one of nine Democratic candidates to replace Newsom who qualified to appear on the ballot, out of 46 total candidates; the thin pool of Democrats was attributed to the 's strategy, which focused on defeating the recall and discouraged established Democratic candidates from entering the race.\n\n briefly removed Paffrath's campaign announcement post from their platform. According to Paffrath, Instagram notified him that they had removed his post, in which he described Newsom as a \"weanie baby\", under its harassment guidelines. Paffrath told  he suspected the post was taken down intentionally and that the removal was related to its parent company 's donations to Newsom's causes. A Facebook spokesperson said the company's donations had gone towards coronavirus relief, not the governor's campaign. The ''Los Angeles Times'' has reported that such donations by Facebook and other social media companies were \"behested\" payments, or indirect payments to government causes on Newsom's behalf. Shortly after Fox News inquired about the removal of the post, it was restored, and a spokesperson said it had been removed in error.\n\nPaffrath sued the Secretary of State of California to allow him to be listed on the ballot as \"Kevin 'Meet Kevin' Paffrath\". The court denied his petition on July 21, finding that \"Meet Kevin\" was nonetheless a brand and not a nickname or formal name.\n\nIn August 2021, Paffrath's attorneys sent a  letter to CNN related to their reporting that \"no Democrats are competing against their own party's governor.\" Fox News reported the CNN article was subsequently revised to state, \"no party-backed Democrats are competing against their own party's governor\" and suggested CNN should have been aware of Paffrath from recent press coverage.\n\n61.9% of voters opposed recalling Newsom. In the ballot question asking which candidate should replace Newsom if the recall was successful, Paffrath came in second place to Republican , with around 706,000 votes (9.6%) to Elder's 3.5million (48.4%).\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Mark Leno''' (born September 24, 1951) is an American politician who served consecutively in both houses of the  from 2002 to 2016. A , he represented the , which includes  and portions of , from 2012 to 2016. Until the 2010 redistricting came into effect, he represented the  (2008–2012). Prior to being elected to the State Senate in 2008, Leno served in the , representing the .\n\nA member of the , Leno was the first openly  elected to the State Senate. He was previously one of the first two openly gay men (along with ) to serve in the .\n\nBefore his time in the Legislature, he served as a member of the  from 1998 to 2002. Leno is the owner of Budget Signs Inc., a small business; following his departure from the Legislature he was a candidate in the , which he narrowly lost to .\n\n\nLeno is the grandson of  immigrants. A native of , Wisconsin, he attended  and later the . He was valedictorian of his graduating class at the American College in , where he earned his  degree. Leno also spent two years in nical studies at  in New York. Afterward, he moved to San Francisco on the invitation of his sister (Jamie Leno Zimron). He lived his first four years in the Tenderloin before moving to the  neighborhood.\n\nIn 1978, Leno started Budget Signs as owner and operator. The business incorporated in 1982. Working with his life partner, Douglas Jackson, the business continued to grow and their involvement in community affairs steadily expanded. Jackson died from complications related to  in 1990.\n\n\nPrior to his election, his political background included raising money for candidates and causes such as  services, the , the , and the Democratic Party.\n\n\n\nLeno was appointed to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors by  in April 1998. He was elected citywide to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors in November 1998 and re-elected in the reinstated district races of 2000. Leno's district included , , , , , , and the westernmost part of the .\n\nLeno introduced legislation to allow tenants to replace a roommate without losing their lease, measures to aid those with /AIDS, and a measure to promote the federal  to help low income residents. He authored legislation to ban s, one of the first such proposals in the country. In 2000, as a supervisor, he supported Proposition L, the slow-growth measure and authored legislation to protect neighborhood business districts from . He was a statewide spokesman for the No on  campaign.\n\nIn 2001, Leno successfully introduced an ordinance providing equal access to the city's health plan for  employees of San Francisco.\n\n\n\nLeno was elected to the  in 2002 and was re-elected in 2004 and 2006. He was the chair of the Assembly's Appropriations Committee, as well as the Select Committee on Childhood Obesity & Related Diabetes.\n\nIn 2005, Leno authored AB 849, a bill legalizing s that became the first bill of its kind to pass a legislative body in the United States. The bill passed both the  and the  but was vetoed by Governor . In 2007, Leno introduced AB 43, the Religious Freedom and Civil Marriage Protection Act, that would have allowed for same-sex marriage. This bill passed the Assembly and Senate but was again vetoed by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger. Same-sex marriage was legalized by the  in a May 2008 , becoming effective June 16, 2008.\n\nIn 2006, Leno and Republican Assemblyman  co-authored a bill that would legalize the cultivation of non- . The bill does not conflict with the federal  and would mandate that hemp be tested to ensure it is non-psychoactive. He authored California Assembly Bill Number AB 1668, on February 23, 2007  a bill encouraging Open Document Formats  in California.\n\nIn Leno's first two terms in the Assembly, 58 of his bills were signed into law. He co-authored AB 32 to cap . He authored AB 706 to prohibit the use of fire retardants in upholstered furniture. He authored AB 2573 to allow San Francisco public utilities to install  on public infrastructure. He also authored Assembly Bill 1358, the California Complete Streets Act, to require cities and counties to consider including walking and bicycling in their s. He coauthored the AB 583, California Clean Money and Fair Elections Act, to bring public financing to political campaigns.\n\n\nIn 2008, he won the  nomination for  with 43.8 percent of the vote, defeating  Senator , who had 28.6 percent of the vote, and former Assemblyman , who had 27.6 percent of the vote. Leno was a principal co-author of SB 840, the Single-Payer Universal Health Care Act, which would have provided  coverage for all Californians and would have replaced hundreds of  companies with state-provided coverage.\n\nDuring his 14-year term in the State Legislature, Leno authored numerous bills including:\n* SB 810, the California Universal Health Care Act.\n* The Airline Passenger Bill of Rights. The bill requires airlines to provide basic needs for passengers, such as water, snacks, fresh air, sanitary restrooms, and lights if a plane is delayed on a tarmac at a California airport.\n* A  amendment regarding the Public Records Act. The amendment clarifies that local governments must comply with requests for publicly available documents, and requires local governments to pay in full the costs of those requests. The amendment was approved by voters in the November 2014 election as Proposition 42.\n* The Fair Education Act, which ensures LGBT and disabled people are included in social science history curriculum.\n* Legislation to require disclosure of the use or absence of flame retardant chemicals on existing furniture labels.\n* A smartphone \"kill switch bill\", requiring phones sold in the state to include an anti-theft technology.\n* Legislation to establish Harvey Milk Day in California, making California the first state in the nation to officially honor the civil rights activist.\n* SB 178, the California Electronic Communications Privacy Act which strengthened the  rights of California citizens.\n* The state's minimum wage increase to $15 per hour in 2022.\n* Legislation to limit and restrict the use of solitary confinement in juvenile facilities.\n* Legislation to add electronic cigarettes to the state's existing smoke-free laws and require the packaging to be child-resistant.\n* California's first major reform of the state's public utilities commission.\n* Legislation to exempt Single Room Occupancy units from the Ellis Act.\n* The California Community Corrections Performance Incentive Act of 2009, which helps reduce California's prison admissions.\n\n\nLeno has been recognized by LGBT organizations, civil rights advocacy groups, and non-profits throughout his tenure for his commitment to public service and for authoring legislation to combat discrimination, protect the rights of all Californians, and lift millions out of poverty.\n\nIn 2003, Leno earned recognition from the , the California Association of Food Banks and . In 2004, Leno received the Award of Courage from  and was honored by the Lesbian and Gay Lawyers Association of Los Angeles at their 25th Anniversary. Also in 2004, Leno (and Chris Reynolds and Steve Sampson) received a President's Award as part of the Pantheon of Leather Awards.\nLeno was the first out  to be a state legislator in the United States. He also served as Chair of the .\n\nIn 2005, he was honored by the California Attorneys For Criminal Justice with their Scales of Justice Award in recognition to his fair and balanced approach in chairing the Assembly Public Safety Committee. He received the \"Lifetime Friend and Champion\" award from the  and was chosen by '''' as one of 2005's \"Most Intriguing Gay Men.\" In 2006, he was honored by the  in  with their  Trail Blazer Award, the Lazarus Project's Lazarus Award for Marriage Equality, the California Young Democrats' Mentor of the Year, Partners Ending Domestic Abuse's  Leadership Award, and Temple 's 2006 Herman Humanitarian Award.\n\nIn 2011, the Consumer Attorneys of California presented him with the Leadership of the Year Award and he received the Transgender Law Center's Community Ally Award in 2010. He received the California Community Choice Aggregation Champion award in 2014 for his dedication to green energy by Marin Clean Energy.\n\nIn 2015, he received the leadership award from the Northern California Innocence Project for advancing legislation to prevent wrongful conviction and the Women's Human Rights Award by Friends of the Commission on the Status of Women.\n\nIn 2016, he was recognized by the Coachella Valley Harvey Milk Diversity Coalition for his leadership on LGBT issues, the Mental Health Association of San Francisco for his work on mental health issues, the Western Center on Law and Poverty for his dedication to public service, and the  for his work to protect digital privacy, among other recognitions.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n* \n* , Dan Pine, jweekly.com, 13-Oct-16\n* , Matthew S. Bajko, The Bay Area Reporter, 17-Nov-16\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Roderick Devon \"Rod\" Wright''' (born July 3, 1952) is an American  politician who previously represented  until his resignation on September 22, 2014. He previously represented the  from 2008-2012. Wright also represented  from 1996 until he was term limited in 2002.\n\n\nSenator Wright obtained his degree in Urban Studies and City Planning at .\n\nPrior to  his initial entrance into elected office in 1996, Senator Wright was the District Director to Congresswoman  where he assisted citizens with federal matters such as Social Security, Medi-Care and veterans issues among others.\n\n\nWright was then elected to the California State Assembly in 1996 representing the 48th Assembly District covering much of south Los Angeles County. From 1998 until 2002, Wright served as Chair of the Assembly Committee on Utilities and Commerce (U&C) which held legislative jurisdiction over electricity, natural gas, telecommunications, private water corporations and other issues related to commerce. Wright has been recognized for his work in the areas of public safety, education, energy and utilities, small business, family law and .\n\n\nEntering the 2008 primary season, Wright had been out of politics for six years and was initially not considered a strong candidate against the front runner, former Lieutenant Governor and Congressman . However, with his own fundraising and help from independent expenditure groups, Wright was able to overcome his lack of name recognition in the area – most of the area Wright represented in the  is in .\n\n\nIn April 2010, California Senate leaders secretly approved a $120,000 settlement in a harassment claim against Wright.\n\n\nIn September 2010, a Los Angeles County grand jury unsealed an eight-count felony indictment against Wright accusing him of filing a false declaration of candidacy,  and  beginning in 2007, when he changed his voter registration to run for the legislature.\n\nWright was convicted of eight counts of voter fraud on January 28, 2014. In September, he was sentenced to ninety days' confinement and banned from public office for the rest of his life.\n\nWright resigned from the State Senate on September 22, 2014.\n\n\nOn November 21, 2018, , , pardoned Wright.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Howard Arthur Finn''' (September 20, 1917 – August 12, 1986) was an expert in city planning, a builder and a land-use consultant who represented part of the San Fernando Valley on the Los Angeles City Council from 1981 until his death in 1986.\n\n\n\nFinn was born September 20, 1917, in . His family operated a grocery store there, and when Howard was fourteen, they moved to California \"in search of new opportunities,\" Finn earned a  in chemistry from the , in 1939. His first job was as a statistician studying  for the . ''Los Angeles Times,'' August 13, 1986\n\nIn World War II, Finn worked in Britain as an analyst with the U.S. . With peace, he returned to California and began to design and build homes. He was \"generally regarded\" as an expert in city planning and became a \"successful construction consultant and land-use activist.\"\n\nAfter his election to the City Council in 1981, the \"gray-goateed Finn\" was known as a \"mild-mannered man who preferred discussions of such practical matters as garbage and sewage to more general political topics.\" Politically, he was a \"former Democrat-turned-Republican-turned-registered-Independent.\"\n\nFinn was stricken while he was conducting a meeting of the council's Planning and Environment Committee at the City Hall. He was taken to  in , where he died on August 12, 1986. He was survived by his wife of 44 years, the former Anne Volk, and daughters Bonnie Haskell, Jocelyn Wyma and Melinda Marchuk. After a tribute in an overflowing City Council chamber, Finn was buried in  in , with a service conducted by Rabbi Stephen Robbins of Temple Emanuel of .\n\n\n\n\n, whom he lost the election to.|upright]]\nFinn lost his bid for the  seat to  in 1973 and to  in 1977. In that era, the 1st was the largest City Council district in the city with a sixth the total area of Los Angeles.\n\nFinn was next appointed by Mayor  to the city Board of Zoning Appeals, where he served three years, two of them as board president. Finn was also on the Mayor's Committee on Affordable Housing. He \"doggedly attended community meetings and built a strong network of backers\" by 1981, the ''Los Angeles Times'' reported. \"People who try to run a slick, grabby campaign out here will be surprised on election day, and my plain talking doesn't hurt because I have roots in this area,\" Finn said.\n\nIn 1981 the 63-year-old Finn was seen as \"an underdog who finished a surprising second\" to former Assemblyman  in the primary race and who suffered from a \"plodding campaign stylea tendency to speak in fuzzy, convoluted sentences and technical language.\"\n\nNevertheless, he beat Keysor in the final by 1,700 votes despite the fact that the latter had key political endorsements and outspent Finn by almost 2 to 1. Finn was criticized for a last-minute mailing engineered by Harvey Englander, his campaign chief, \"falsely suggesting that Keysor had withdrawn from the race,\" the ''Times'' reported. Finn denied that his mailings had brought him victory.\n\nFinn was reelected in the 1981 and 1985 primaries.\n\n\n\nOf his tenure, the ''Los Angeles Times'' said that Finn's \"most telling impact on city affairs came in his role as chairman of the Planning and Development Committee, where the more combative side of his nature came into play in confrontations with , who claimed he was pro-.\" Finn denied the charge, calling his critics \".\" The ''Times'' obituary added: \"His legislative accomplishments included sponsorship of a law making it difficult to open new liquor stores in the city, and of legislation to protect horse owners, many of whom live in his district, from encroachment of new housing.\"\n\n\n\nAfter Finn's death, his widow, Anne Finn, sought appointment to his seat by the City Council, but the council instead took the opportunity to redraw council lines to provide for a district that might elect a  as a member, as ordered to do by a federal court, and it transferred the  bodily out of the  into . A Hispanic, , was the next incumbent for that district.\n\n\n\nAccess to some ''Los Angeles Times'' links may require the use of a library card.\n\n\n\n----\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Roberta Achtenberg''' (born July 20, 1950) is an American attorney and civil rights advocate who served as a commissioner on the . She was previously assistant secretary of the , becoming the first openly  or  public official in the United States whose appointment to a federal position was confirmed by the . This confirmation hearing garnered a lot of publicity, opposition, and support.\n\nAchtenberg went to school at different branches of the University of California and later attended the University of Utah. Before her political career, she worked as an attorney, director, educator, and founded organizations. Achtenberg is married with a son, and has been locally and nationally recognized with many awards and has made many publications throughout her career. Board of Trustees  CSU |url=http://calstate.edu/BOT/bios/achtenberg.shtml |access-date=2023-05-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180404073140/http://calstate.edu/BOT/bios/achtenberg.shtml |archive-date=2018-04-04 }}\n\n\n\n\nAchtenberg's father was Jewish and immigrated to the United States from the , while her mother was from . Both parents had minimal formal education. They owned a grocery store in Los Angeles and raised Roberta and her three siblings in California.\n\n\nAfter graduating from  in , Achtenberg attended , and the transferred to the  and graduated in 1972 with a Bachelor of Arts in history. At Berkeley, she graduated . Achtenberg also met her ex-husband, David Chavkin at Berkeley. LGBTHistoryMonth.com |url=https://lgbthistorymonth.com/roberta-achtenberg?tab=biography |access-date=2023-03-26 |website=lgbthistorymonth.com |archive-date=2023-03-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230323034915/https://lgbthistorymonth.com/roberta-achtenberg?tab=biography |url-status=live }} She began law school at , before eventually receiving her  from the  in 1975.\n\n\nRoberta Achtenberg divorced from David Chavkin in a cordial manner in 1977, and soon after came out to her family as a lesbian. After Achtenberg came out publicly, she received national support and opposition. LGBTQ+ people and allies rallied in her support, and religious and conservative groups lobbied against her.\n\nAchtenberg met her former partner, , judge on the San Francisco Municipal Court, in 1979, and became partners in 1982. In 1985, Achtenberg and Morgan had a child named Benjamin. Achtenberg and Morgan were one of the most visible lesbian couples with a child at the time of Achtenberg's political career. During a San Francisco Gay and Lesbian , Achtenberg and Mary Morgan hugged and kissed while riding a float with their son, which generated controversy during her entrance to her federal political career. In 1995, Achtenberg gave a speech at the San Francisco  and Gay Pride March.\n\nIn 2015, she spoke at the University of Utah's 's Commencement ceremony.\n\n\nBefore becoming a public official, Achtenberg worked for more than 15 years as a civil rights attorney, public interest advocate, nonprofit director, and legal educator.\n\nBetween 1975 and 1976, she served as a teaching fellow at  Law School. In 1976, Achtenberg became the Dean of the . Achtenberg supported the  community early in her political career. Her activity included co-founding the  in 1977, along with . The center works for LGBTQ+ individuals, and provides them with legal services and counsel, advocacy, and education services.\n\nAdditionally, in 1978 Achtenberg represented LGBTQ rights while in the Anti-Sexism Committee for the . While working for the organization, she edited ''Sexual Orientation and the Law'' (1985). One issue this project highlighted was making a guide for how to give lesbian and gay people appropriate representation. The paper outlines how to properly represent LGBTQ+ juveniles, how to tackle First Amendment issues regarding LGBTQ+ people or speech, and more.\n\nAchtenberg has formerly worked at the  on the Board of Directors from 1997 to 2002 where she chaired the Affordable Housing Committee, and worked as a Staff Attorney for the Lesbian Rights Project of Equal Rights Advocates. In 2000, she became the Director of Andrew J. Wong, Inc, and has worked there since. In 2018 she was named to the Policy Transition team of Mayor of San Francisco, , to help address a variety of issues including LBGTQ policies.\n\nShe is the founder and a partner at ABK City Advisors, also serves as a Senior Advisor at , and is the Vice Chair of the Board of Directors of the Bank of San Francisco.''''''\n\n\nAchtenberg unsuccessfully ran for a seat in the 1988  special election to replace , losing to . She was elected as a member of the  in 1990, in the first time that two lesbians (alongside ) won seats to the board. In her tenure on the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, she worked on issues from individuals' rights to small businesses to making domestic violence shelters. While still serving on the Board of Supervisors in 1992, Achtenberg was appointed to the committee drafting the National Democratic Party's platform.\n\nIn 1993, she was appointed Assistant Secretary for the  by President , becoming the first 'out,'  person to be appointed and confirmed to a position within a cabinet office. In her role as Assistant Secretary, Achtenberg successfully integrated a previously all-white town in Vidor, Texas. There was  opposition to this public housing integration. She additionally worked to help find housing for displaced families due to a hurricane in 1994, and worked on improving fairness in the housing systems. Her group was also awarded Vice President Gore's . From 1995 to 1997, she was appointed as the senior advisor to the Secretary of . U.S. Commission on Civil Rights |url=https://www.usccr.gov/about/roberta-achtenberg |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230226210750/https://www.usccr.gov/about/roberta-achtenberg |archive-date=2023-02-26 |access-date=2023-03-23 |website=www.usccr.gov}}\n\nAchtenberg left the post in 1995 to run for , and placed third behind  and  (who would win in the runoff).  From 1998 to 2004, Achtenberg helped develop the policies for both the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce and the San Francisco Center for Economic Development. She served as Senior Vice President for Public Policy at the  Chamber of Commerce until January 2005. In 2004 during her time as the Senior Vice President, she helped a same-sex couple, , obtain the first marriage license issued for a same-sex couple by San Francisco.\n\nIn 2000, she was appointed to the Board of Trustees of  by  , becoming chair of the board in May 2006, serving on the CSU Board of Trustees until 2015. Achtenberg served 16 years on the California State University Board of Trustees, serving two years as chair, where she developed the Access to Excellence Plan. Achtenberg also was crucial in the formation of the CSU Institute for Palliative Care, and was a member of the Palliative Care's National Advisory Board. Because of her extensive work with California State University, she was awarded a .\n\nAchtenberg was in charge of the Housing and Urban Development Department's Agency Review Team that assisted the  during its transition to office in 2008. On January 26, 2011,  named Achtenberg as a Commissioner for the . She served until 2016.\n\n\nRoberta Achtenberg was nominated, by President Bill Clinton, to be the Assistant Secretary of Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity in the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Her confirmation was announced during the lift of the ban on letting gay people in the military. Her confirmation hearing was held in front of the Senate's Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs and started on April 29, 1993.\n\nAfter debates lasting three days, including nine and a half hours of s on May 19 and 20, Achtenberg was confirmed by the 103th Senate on May 24, 1993, securing a vote of 58 YEAs to 31 NAYs, with 1 voting as present and 10 not voting. Roberta Achtenberg was the first openly LGBTQ+ individual to go through the senate confirmation process, and the subsequently was the first LGBTQ+ individual to hold a federal position.\n\nDuring the hearing, Achtenberg was questioned by many Senators, including Senators , , and . Throughout the process, she was loudly opposed by , who called her \"a damn lesbian\" that the Senate should refuse to confirm to the position. Achtenberg also received opposition from the , due to her radical lesbian activism. Achtenberg received endorsements from many organizations and people, such as the National Fair Housing Alliance, San Francisco Bar Association, the National Association of Human Rights Workers, , and .\n\nShe also expressed her own viewpoints and goals related to the position. Achtenberg stated that in the role of Assistant Secretary, she would strive to eradicate housing discrimination and allow people to make free and fair choices surrounding their housing.\n\n\n*Advocate Article, a gay and lesbian magazine, named Achtenberg the advocate's woman of the year in 1993.\n*Awarded the Visibility Award in 1994 from  Media Awards\n*Recognized five times as one of the \"50     "pages": }\n\n'''William Emmerson''' (born October 28, 1945) is a former   who represented the  in . He previously represented the 37th Senate District, having been elected in a June 8, 2010, special election and sworn into office the next day.  Preceding his tenure in the State Senate, Emmerson served as man from the  representing the counties of Riverside and San Bernardino, having been first elected in November 2004.\n\n\nBorn in , his family moved to  when his father opened a dental practice in , then moved again to , where he attended .\n\nEmmerson received a  degree in history and  from  in . He then studied  at  in , while working as an aide for Congressman . Emmerson moved back to  and joined the staff of the Assembly Majority Leader W. Craig Biddle, where he worked from 1969 to 1974 while also continuing his post graduate studies at .\n\n\nHe then enrolled in The School of Dentistry of . Upon graduating with his D.D.S. (1980) and M.S. (1982) degrees, Emmerson embarked upon a 26-year orthodontic practice in . He served as president of Tri-County Dental Society, chair of the California Dental Association's Council on Legislation, and chair of the Association's Political Action Committee.\n\n\nEmmerson helped to establish the  program at  and to rehabilitate  Fire Station 1, and served on the alumni association of Loma Linda University. He is active in the  Club of Hemet, and he serves as a board member on the Ramona Bowl Advisory Board and as a volunteer with the Kiwanis Club of Redlands and Redlands Bicycle Classic.\n\n\nBill and his wife, Nan, have two daughters, Kate and Caroline.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n* Pratte, Bob. \"A capitol friend,\" '''', November 4, 2004\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Henry Isaac Stern''' (born April 12, 1982) is an American politician elected to the . He is a  representing the , encompassing parts of  and  counties. He was elected in November 2016. Prior to being elected to the State Senate, he was an environmental attorney and senior advisor to his predecessor . He is the first  elected to the California State Senate.  He was also an American law lecturer at the  and .\n\nStern has served as counsel to Representative  on the  to help construct clean energy projects for businesses. He has also taught civics, founded a tech incubator, and advocated for juvenile justice.\n\n\nHenry Isaac Stern was born to a  family in ,  on April 12, 1982. His father is actor , who is best known for his role as Marv Murchins in the films '''' and ''''.\n\nA former high school and collegiate water polo player, Stern graduated from . He went on to graduate from the , before becoming an environmental attorney.\n\n\n\nHenry Stern represented the Democratic Party in the 2016 race for California's 27th State Senate district against Republican Steve Fazio. On November 8, 2016, he was elected for California's 27th District State Senate.\n\nStern ran on a platform of five main issues in the 2016 elections. These included standing up to oil and gas companies; fighting to create incentives for companies to create \"clean transportation and renewable energy infrastructure;\" improving the economy with small businesses, , good-paying jobs and job training; supporting education by securing funding; and creating safer communities by providing funding to local governments.\n\nDuring the 2016 election, Stern was endorsed by Senator Fran Pavley, the Sierra Club, the California League of Conservation Voters, teachers and school board members from Los Angeles and Ventura county school districts, the Association of Los Angeles County Sheriffs, and the California Association of Highway Patrolmen. He was endorsed by elected officials such as President Barack Obama and Governor Jerry Brown, among many more. Publications such as the Ventura County Star and Ventura County Signal endorsed him as well.\n\n\nStern announced his candidacy for the District 3 seat on the  in 2022. On June 22, Stern conceded the race after receiving 24% of the vote in the June 7 primary.\n\n\nHenry's father, Daniel Stern, performed the narrative voiceover of adult Kevin Arnold for the hit television series '''' for six seasons. At the end of the show's , Henry delivered the next-to-last line of the entire series when he called to his fatherin voiceover\"Hey Dad, wanna play catch?\" to which his father replies \"I'll be right there.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Brian Phillip Bilbray''' (born January 28, 1951) is an American politician who served in the  from 1995 to 2001 and again from 2006 to 2013. He is a member of the .\n\nBilbray was Chairman of the  and a member of the influential . His subcommittee assignments on the Energy and Commerce Committee were as follows: Oversight and Investigations, Communication and Technology, and Energy and Power.\n\n\nBilbray was born in , and grew up in . He graduated from , where he played on the football team as a , and attended , a  in . He worked as a tax consultant before entering politics. A , he and his wife, Karen (née Walker), have five children, one of whom, Brian Pat, is a current member of the Imperial Beach city council.\n\nBilbray is a cousin of former   Representative .\n\nAn avid surfer, he has compared surfing to politics.\n\n\nBilbray became interested in politics when an extensive program of eminent domain was proposed for . He ran successfully for the city council as a , serving during 1976–1978, and was mayor during 1978–1985.\n\nAs mayor, Bilbray attempted to build a yacht marina in the Tijuana Estuary and to build a 1.5 mile breakwater off the beach of Imperial Beach. Both projects were stopped by the opposition of local surfers and environmentalists. The  Estuary is now a  and . The breakwater project was halted with the help of the then fledgling . From 1985 to 1995, Bilbray was a member of the  .\n\n\nIn 1994, Bilbray won the Republican nomination for the , now the 53rd district, which included most of , and defeated freshman   in the Republican landslide of that year. The 53rd was one of several marginal districts to go Republican in that cycle. Bilbray was reelected in 1996 and 1998. In 2000, he was defeated by  . \n\n\nIn 2001, Bilbray registered as a federal lobbyist. His clients included ; the ; the San Diego Regional Airport Authority; Conquer Cancer and Alzheimer's Now; ; and . \n\nBilbray is a member of the ReFormers Caucus of .\n\n\n\n\n\nBilbray ran in the 2006 special election to fill the vacancy in  caused by the resignation in December 2005 of fellow Republican , who pleaded guilty to felony charges of conspiracy and tax evasion, and subsequently went to jail. In March 2005, Bilbray moved to , to take care of his mother, who owns a home there.\n\nThe race to assume Cunningham's seat was highly contested, especially on the Republican side, with 14 Republicans (compared with only 2 Democrats) officially running for the position. Leading up to the initial all-candidate election that would determine the parties' candidates in a runoff election, Bilbray was in a virtual tie with Republican businessman Eric Roach, slightly ahead of former State Assemblyman . Four days before the election, businessman Alan Uke, one of the major Republican candidates, ran an attack ad accusing Roach of  thousands of jobs at the expense of American workers. In the initial all-party special election on April 11, 2006, Bilbray was the Republican candidate with the most votes, receiving 15% of the total vote to Roach's 15%. He then faced the top vote getters of all the other parties in a  on June 6, 2006: Democrat ,  Paul King, and William Griffith, an independent.\n\nDuring the campaign, Arizona Senator  canceled a planned fundraiser for Bilbray at the last minute, after Bilbray called McCain's immigration bill \"amnesty\" for illegal immigrants.\n\nBilbray won the runoff with 49% of the vote, and was sworn in on June 13, 2006, as a member of the Congress. The Republican Party considered this a  race because this district had \"the perfect storm in favor of the Democrats\" according to , the RNC Chairman at the time of the special election. The 's Voting Rights Institute raised several concerns about the fairness and accuracy of the vote count. An election contest lawsuit sought a hand recount.\n\nHowever, Bilbray was sworn in before the vote count was official. The court dismissed the suit on the basis that, once the House of Representatives had sworn in Bilbray, the court lacked  to hear the challenge.\n\n\nBilbray and Busby each won their party's primary, and faced each other again in the November general election. Bilbray defeated Busby by a margin of 54%–44%. Bilbray ran as an  opponent of illegal immigration. With the advantage of incumbency and the Republican edge in registrations in the district, Bilbray was initially a clear favorite to win in November. Both the ''Cook Political Report'' and ''CQPolitics'' first rated the race as ''Republican Favored''. But Busby gained in October, with a late-October poll by SurveyUSA showed Bilbray ahead by just 3 points, for a number of reasons: the general political climate seen as disadvantageous to the GOP, Busby's outraising Bilbray, and Bilbray's low profile campaign. On October 23, ''CQPolitics'' changed their rating to ''Leans Republican''.\n\n\nRunning unopposed in the June primary, Bilbray overcame a strong challenge from Democrat  in the November . With help from the  and $1 million in donations, Leibham ran a string of TV attack ads against Bilbray. Democrats thought they had a chance at winning the district due to the hostile environment plaguing Republicans in general, and shifting demographics locally. Bilbray won, 50% to 46%, with 4% of the vote going to  candidate Wayne Dunlap.\n\n\n\nDue to district realignment after the 2010 census, Bilbray  as the incumbent in the  in 2012. An all-parties primary was held on June 5, 2012. A runoff between Bilbray and  Commissioner , a , was held on November 6. The initial vote was very close, so that a winner was not declared until ten days after the election as provisional ballots were counted. On November 16, with Peters ahead by 51% to 49%, Bilbray conceded defeat.\n\n\nSince his loss to Congresswoman Susan Davis in 2000, Bilbray has maintained residences and properties in ; ; and . In response to requests to District Attorney , by the local Democratic Party and neighbors of the congressman, a San Diego County  was convened to investigate claims against Bilbray's declared residency for the special and general elections in 2006. The investigation was dropped in May 2007.\n\nQuestions about Bilbray's residency again arose after his reelection on November 6, 2010, when he personally, as well as his children Briana and Patrick, claimed to not live in California and not qualify for in-state tuition in a class-action lawsuit against the University of California. Brian Bilbray appeared as a named plaintiff residing in Virginia.\n\n\n\nDuring the 109th Congress Bilbray served on the House Armed Services, Veterans Affairs and Government Reform Committees. During his first term Bilbray co-authored legislation that led to the transfer of the Mount Soledad Veteran's Memorial from the City of San Diego to the federal government. He also authored legislation that would have reformed the federal budget process.\n\nBilbray positioned himself as moderate on some social issues while conservative on immigration and fiscal matters. He is a signer of the Taxpayer Protection Pledge.\n\nDuring his second run for Congress in the 50th district, Bilbray won over many of the district's most conservative voters with his hard line stance on illegal immigration.  Since then Bilbray's voting record has been considerably more conservative than it was during his first term. He is a member of both the moderate  and the conservative , two groups with conflicting positions on policy. For example, the RMSP supports embryonic stem cell research and opposes the , while the RSC opposes embryonic stem cell research and supports the FMA. He is also a member of .\n\nBilbray voted in agreement with President  93% of the time, and as a result was given a 93% Presidential Support Score by  in 2006. He served multiple terms in the U.S. House of Representatives. He represented California's 49th congressional district, which includes parts of San Diego County. He was elected to Congress in a special election in 2006 and subsequently reelected.\n\nIn October 2011, Bilbray voted for a bill that would prohibit public funding for abortions. It passed 251–172 in the House. Bilbray almost always has voted for free trade agreements in the past years, specifically with Korea, Colombia, and Panama, all of which passed.  The following month, he introduced  a new bill which would benefit veterans. It provides job training and internships paid for by federal grants.\n\nIn 2011, he voted for the  as part of a controversial provision that allows the government and/or the military to indefinitely detain American citizens and others without trial.\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n** \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  ''official U.S. House website''\n*  ''official campaign website''\n* \n* \n*  ''Swing'' magazine, March 1996\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Juan Arambula''' (born January 29, 1952, in ) is a former man. He represented the 31st district. Arambula was elected to the assembly in 2004. While Arambula had announced that he would retire in 2008, he ran again that year and won his final term. He was a  until June 2009, when he became an . He was ed in 2010.\n\n\nHe graduated with high honors from , and went on to earn a Master's degree in Educational Administration and Policy Analysis from the  and a  (J.D.) from the .\n\nArambula is the son of immigrant farm workers. In his youth, he harvested crops with his family throughout California. He lives in Fresno with Amy, his wife of 30 years. He has four adult children: , Carmen, Diego and Miguel. His religion is \"decline to state.\"\n\n\nPrior to his election to the assembly, Arambula served on the Fresno  from 1997 to 2004. He earned the  Award for Ethics in Leadership in 2002 for his public service.\n\nEarly in his career, Assembly Member Arambula served as an attorney for the Agricultural Labor Relations Board. He also performed legal services for California Rural Legal Assistance (CRLA) in its Delano office.\n\nFrom 1987 to 1996, Arambula served on the  Board, where he worked to meet the needs of a diverse student population while maintaining financial stability during lean budget years. Arambula also served on the Board of Directors for the California School Boards Association and the California State Association of Counties.\n\n\nJuan Arambula has stated that his top legislative priorities include efforts to improve California's business climate, to encourage job creation and retention, as well as efforts to improve the health care system, student academic achievement and school accountability. He is also working to tackle air pollution in the , the shortage of health care professionals, and California's infrastructure challenges.\n\n\nJuan Arambula was named \"Legislator of the Year\" by the California Small Business Association.\n\n\nDemocratic Speaker  stripped Arambula of his chairmanship of the Public Safety Committee in retribution for Arambula leaving the Democratic Party to become an independent.\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Zoltan Istvan Gyurko''', professionally known as '''Zoltan Istvan''' (born March 30, 1973), is an American transhumanist, journalist, entrepreneur, political candidate, and futurist.\n\nFormerly a reporter for the , Istvan now writes , ,  and political-themed articles for major media, including ''''. He believes  will grow into a mainstream social movement in the 2020s. Istvan is the author of '''', a  science fiction novel.\n\nIn late 2014, Istvan announced he was running for  in the . He ran for his own  to raise awareness for  issues but did not place his name on any state ballot. Later, in 2017, Istvan ran for  in the  as a member of the . In 2019, Istvan ran for the  in the  against President .\n\n\nZoltan Istvan was born in Los Angeles in 1973 to his Hungarian immigrant parents Ilona and Steven (István) Gyurko. He was a nationally ranked swimmer and waterpolo player in his youth. Istvan later graduated from  in  with a degree in philosophy and religion. During his freshman year, Istvan was arrested by undercover cops for selling $80 worth of  to fellow students. His arrest and subsequent  conviction, which was later dismissed and expunged, influenced how he views the U.S. government's .\n\n\n\n\nIstvan was an online and on-camera reporter for the . His writings have appeared in a blog of the '''', and ''''. His work has been covered in publications such as ''''. Istvan's coverage of the war in  was made into a documentary, ''Pawns of Paradise'', distributed by Janson Media. Australia's '''' has acquired non-exclusive Australian rights to the show.\n\nAccording to Istvan, he invented, pioneered and popularized the  of .\n\nIstvan is an entrepreneur who works in real estate. He also owns  properties in Mendoza, Argentina, Bordeaux, France, and California's Napa Valley. Istvan owns a 68 acre island in Nova Scotia, Canada in the Atlantic Ocean.\n\n\nAfter publishing ''The Transhumanist Wager'', Istvan began actively promoting transhumanism and other futurist issues via speeches, media interviews, activism and his writings.\n\nIstvan's writings and ideas on transhumanism, philosophy, atheism and futurist issues have been featured in major media Istvan has also written for '''', ''New Scientist'', ''Salon'', ''TechCrunch'', ''The Daily Dot'', ''International Business Times''  ''Singularity Hub'', ''TechInsider'', ''Newsweek'', ''Futurism'' and ''''.\n\nIstvan gives talks on futurist and transhumanist topics, which include speeches at the ,  (Global Future Council), Congreso Futuro, Moogfest, the 's annual conference, and '''' Camp Alphaville conference.\n\nHe appeared in the 2016 documentary ''''.\n\n\nIn October 2014, Istvan announced that he was \"in the very early stages of preparing a campaign to try to run\" for U.S. President in 2016. He stated that his goals would be to support scientists in \"overcoming human death and aging within 15–20 years\" to encourage Americans to embrace \"radical technology and science\" and to set up safeguards against dangers including potential abuse of such technology.\n\nIn October and November 2014 interviews, Istvan explained that he aimed to unify the transhumanist community, which otherwise was splintered, and to establish a single voice. He said great changes in society could happen and that Transhumanism could provide ideas, safeguards and policies. He said the aim for a Transhumanist Party would be to get onto as many state ballots as possible.\n\n\nIn March 2015, Istvan reported progress in organizing a campaign and explained his wish to get major candidates to address issues. He hoped to be included in some debates, at least with third parties. He himself had funded nearly all of his campaign's expenses to date and he noted donations were needed.\n\n\nIstvan helped to publicize his campaign in late 2015 by driving a bus shaped like a casketthe \"\"across the United States. Istvan planned the bus tour to raise awareness of life extension. At the end of the Immortality Bus tour, Istvan delivered a \"Transhumanist Bill of Rights\" to the U.S. Capitol. His 20-point platform includes a universal basic income, increased funding for space travel and taking money from the military and putting it into science and medicine.\n\nIn February 2016, it was reported that Istvan was likely to vote , placing himself \"somewhere between Bernie and Hillary in terms of political ideologies\", but later in 2016 he also wrote articles supporting Libertarian presidential candidate . On October 15, 2016, Istvan stated on his social media accounts that he would be voting for himself.\n\nIstvan was not on the ballot in any state, though he claimed to have substantial potential  backers.\n\n\nIstvan emphasized science, technology, longevity, transhumanism and Libertarian values in his California gubernatorial run, along with support for . He suggested basic income could be paid for without raising taxes through a \"Federal Land Dividend\". Under this program, the government would allocate monthly payments to households by leasing out federal land. In his debut editorial for '''' magazine, he argued that reparations for harm caused to marijuana users during the federal government's  may be appropriate. He suggested reparations could be paid as tax credits or through the sale of federal lands, so as not to put further burden associated with the drug war on taxpayers.\n\n\nIn December 2017, Istvan announced he was considering running for the 's Presidential nomination. In March 2019 during an interview on the Bread and Circuses podcast, Istvan told Caleb Salvatore and Nick Koehler that he was again considering a run for President. Istvan announced a run for the  on November 19.\n\n\nIstvan states that in the 21st century, as modern man confronts the finitude of life, everyone faces a Transhumanist Wager, a concept that is explored in . The Transhumanist Wager follows from a life philosophy Istvan calls Teleological Egocentric Functionalism (TEF). Istvan summarizes the Transhumanist Wager as follows:\n\n\n\nIstvan is the creator of the concepts of Theistcideism, Omnipotism, the AI Imperative, the Singularity Disparity, Speciation Syndrome, Post-earthism, Delayed Fertility Advantage, and Jethro's Window, a possible solution to the . Istvan is also a populizer of AI Day, the transhumanist olympics, the Jesus Singularity, cryothanasia a robot AI President, and quantum archaeology (technological resurrection). Istvan proposed and developed the concept of a Longevity Peace Prize at the XPRIZE Foundation in 2019. Writing for The New York Times opinion section, Istvan argued conservatives should consider supporting artificial wombs to move the abortion debate forward. Istvan also argued to allow surfing during the Covid lockdowns in The New York Times Opinion section.\n\nIstvan authored an article entitled \"Transhumanism and Theistcideism\" for publication in '''' (2017). Istvan wrote the short fictional story \"The Jesus Singularity\" on a religious AI that goes rogue and destroys the world. It was published in '''' magazine.\n\nIstvan has a chip implanted in his hand and consulted with the U.S. Navy on broad about the use of the implant in humans. According to Istvan's novel, the three laws of Transhumanism are:\n\n# A transhumanist must safeguard one's own existence above all else.\n# A transhumanist must strive to achieve omnipotence as expediently as possibleso long as one's actions do not conflict with the First Law.\n# A transhumanist must safeguard value in the universeso long as one's actions do not conflict with the First and Second Laws.\n\n\nWithin the transhumanist community, reactions to Istvan's U.S. Transhumanist Party have ranged from enthusiastic to sharply critical. Some transhumanist critics, such as Peter Rothman, have questioned whether the Transhumanist Party adds value to the overall goals of transhumanism.\n\n\nIstvan resides in  with his wife, who is a physician, and his daughters. He identifies as an atheist.\n\nIn February 2015, he helped launch BiZoHa, the world's first free-thinker orphanage, in Mukhoya, , western . Istvan's promotional article on the topic in '''s'' ''Motherboard'', helped a  campaign to achieve success in raising $5,820 to provide funding for the orphanage.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Nicole M. Parra''' (born February 3, 1970) is an American attorney and politician who served as a member of the  from 2002 to 2008. A , she represented the , which includes a portion of California's .\n\n\n\n\nParra was born in , and raised in . Her father, Pete, served on the  and her mother works for the Bakersfield Adult School. After attending , she graduated from the  in 1992 with a  in . In 1998, she earned a  from the  in \n\n\nParra served as  's campaign manager in 2000 and as his District Director from 1998 to 2002.\n\n\nParra was elected to the Assembly in 2002 by a margin of 266 votes. She served as Chair of the Agriculture Committee. She also served on the Banking & Finance, Insurance, and Water Parks and Wildlife Committees. Parra's 2004 re-election campaign was endorsed by the .\n\nIn 2008 Parra was not eligible to seek a fourth term because of term limits. She chose to endorse her opponent from the 2006 campaign to replace her, Republican , over the Democratic party nominee,  Mayor .\n\nDuring her final months in office, Parra was kicked out of her Capitol office by then-Assembly Speaker  after refusing to vote on a state spending bill.\n\n\n\nIn late January 2009, Parra accepted an appointment from   to be Director of the Governor's Regional Development Initiatives under the Business, Transportation and Housing Agency.  On July 16, 2009, Parra announced that she would resign from the agency.\n\nIn 2010, Parra supported the candidacy of , a Republican, to the .\n\nIn 2014 she started serving as an adjunct professor at , teaching political science. She also served as campaign manager for a local bond measure to benefit the .\n\nIn December 2020, Parra filed to run for Congress in the  against incumbent Representative , a , in the . The 21st district was redrawn in 2021 by the state's  and then renumbered as the .\n\nOn December 30, 2021, Parra ended her congressional campaign and filed to run for district 16 in the state senate. She was , finishing in 3rd place with 12% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Charles Jeremy Lewis''' (October 21, 1934 – July 15, 2021) was an American politician who was a , last serving  . He was first elected to Congress in 1978, and previously represented the 40th, 35th, and 37th districts. A , he was chairman of the , serving in that role during the . In January 2012 he announced that he was not running for re-election and would end his congressional career in January 2013.\n\n\nLewis was born in , . In 1952 he graduated from  in , where he captained the swim team. In 1956 he received a  degree from . Lewis served as a  fellow in . After college, Lewis was in the insurance business.\n\nLewis died on July 15, 2021, in , at the age of 86.\n\n\nHe was a member of the San Bernardino School Board from 1964 to 1968. He was on the staff of Congressman  in 1966.\n\nHe was a member of the  from 1969 to 1978. In January 1974, he ran in a special election for the , losing to Democrat . In the campaign, Ayala noted that two-thirds of the $130,000 that Lewis raised came from 43 donors  22 of whom were  lobbyists.\n\n\n]]\n\n\n\nIn November 1978, Lewis was elected as a Republican to the , in what was then the 37th Congressional district, with 61% of the vote. He was subsequently re-elected 16 times. He never won re-election with less than 61% of the vote. In fact, he only dipped below 65% four times (1990, 1992, 2006, and 2008).\n\nIn 2008, Lewis received his strongest challenge in decades from San Bernardino attorney Tim Prince, who won a 4-candidate Democratic primary. Lewis was forced to spend over a million dollars to retain his seat. He declined Prince's challenges for a debate. The incumbent defeated him with 62% of the vote.\n\nOn January 12, 2012, Lewis announced his retirement.\n\n\nLewis employed his wife, Arlene Willis, as the chief of staff in his office. Before they were married, Willis was her husband's top aide when he came to  in 1979.\n\nIn 1994, he was named chairman of the VA-HUD and Independent Agencies Subcommittee, where he worked until 1999 to improve oversight to uncover fraud and abuse in large housing programs and reduce spending on wasteful programs within a number of federal agencies.\n\nHe steered federal dollars to the state and to the region for projects such as the planning and construction of the  near . Among his proudest achievements came early in his career as a state assemblyman, pushing for the establishment of the first air quality committee in the state Legislature, which led to the formation of the South Coast Air Quality Management District in the mid-1970s.\n\nIn 1998, he secured start-up funding for 's Proton Beam treatment center, which has led to the installation of similar cancer treatment centers across the U.S.\n\nLewis placed special riders in a series of appropriations bills that freed up nearly $100 million to the , the state and the county to remove more than a million trees in the San Bernardino National Forest killed by drought and bark beetle infestation. He worked with U.S. Senator  to secure an additional $500 million to reduce the fire danger in the  and throughout .\n\nLewis also secured $15 million for a pilot program to refurbish houses repossessed by the  and providing them to qualified low income families. The program, according to Lewis' office at the time was successful in Redlands, Highland, and San Bernardino.\n\n\nLewis was a member of the  and supported . Lewis considered himself to be , opposed most public funding of , but encouraged  efforts which are opposed by many . He voted against banning adoption by  in the . He thought gun-control efforts should center on stiff prison terms for repeat criminals who use firearms, but was open to considering requiring s and other child safety measures for law-abiding gun owners. The  gave Lewis' 2008 voting record 84 out of 100 points. The liberal  gave him 0 out of 100 for 2005 (most recent available). Lewis was a signer of the .\n\n\n\nIn its 2009 report,  (CREW) named Lewis one of the 15 most corrupt members of Congress, saying that his \"ethics issues stem primarily from the misuse of his position as chairman of the House Appropriations Committee to steer hundreds of millions of dollars in  to family and friends in direct exchange for contributions to his campaign committee and political action committee.\"\n\nLewis was also included in the group's report in 2006, 2007, and 2008.\n\nIn 2010, the  closed the case without filing charges. It was never submitted to federal prosecutors.\n\n\nLewis' aide in charge of tracking defense appropriations, Marine Lt. Col. Carl Kime, was \"a military officer on 's payroll, an apparent violation of House rules and a possible conflict of interest\".  regulations state that military personnel can work on committee staffs but not on the personal staff of an individual member. Kime apparently worked for Lewis since 2001 while being on the Pentagon payroll. Congressional watchdogs call Kime's role a conflict of interest and defense experts state that his position may have given the  greater leverage over contracts and earmarks on the Appropriations Committee.\n\nOn February 22, 2006, '''' reported that the Pentagon was recalling Kime from Lewis's office. Kime's \"service for Lewis appeared to violate the Members' Congressional Handbook issued by the Committee for House Administration, which defines a detailee as a 'non-congressional federal employee assigned to a committee for a period of up to one year.' The handbook also states that 'detailees may not be assigned to a member office' and cites the relevant section of U.S. law: 2 USC Section 72a(f).\"\n\n\nIn July 2007, '''' reported that since 2004, Lewis had earmarked $2.75 million for the \"\" area of Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. \"Neither I nor my spouse has any financial interest in this project,\" Lewis said of the improvements being funded by the earmarks. But the congressman's wife, who was also his chief of staff, owns a three-bedroom home valued at $943,000 that is four blocks from the work being paid for by the earmarks. CBS also reported that Tip Tipton, a property owner in the area and a member of the board of directors of the redevelopment project receiving the earmarks, is a top Washington lobbyist who is also a longtime Lewis friend and campaign donor.\n\n\nFrom 1998 to 2003,  received $167.2 million in congressional earmarks. That made it the number one academic recipient in the country, with its total nearly $60 million more than the runner up, the . In 2000, Loma Linda University was the single largest recipient of higher education earmarks, at $36 million, largely brought in by Lewis. Several grants were from the , including $5 million from  for space radiation research.\n\nIn 2008, Loma Linda University received nearly $9.5 million, of which $5 million came from the Defense Department.\n\n\nLewis was chair of the  from 1989 to 1992. In January 1995, he became chairman of the Veterans Affairs, Housing and Urban Development  and Independent Agencies Appropriations subcommittee. He was the first representative from California to be chairman of the powerful . He also served as chairman of the House Defense Appropriations Subcommittee from 1999 to 2005.\n\nLewis was the chairman of appropriations committee during the .  In the  and , he was the Ranking Member on the committee. He sought the chairmanship for the , but it was instead given to  (R-KY).\n* ''''''\n**  (Vice Chair)\n** \n** \n** \n** \n\n\n* Congressional Fire Services Caucus\n* Congressional Unmanned Systems Caucus\n* \n* Sportsmens Caucus\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
