    "pages": }\n\n'''Bill Brough''' (, ; born October 15, 1966) is an American politician who served three terms in the . A , he represented the , encompassing southern . Prior to being elected to the state legislature, he was a  man. Previously, Brough served as chief of staff to California State Assemblywoman , White House liaison at the  in the  administration, and aide to former congressman . In 2016, he founded the California Legislative  Caucus.\n\n\nAfter high school, Brough enlisted in the , serving on active duty 1986–1990, and graduated from the  in 1995. Brough and his wife have two children.\n\n\n\nIn June 2019, two women accused Brough of making unwanted sexual advances to them in public settings.  Supervisor  charged that Brough cornered her in a local restaurant in March 2011, when both were serving on the  City Council, and pressed his groin against her.  After she broke free and left, she filed a complaint against him with the city.  Also, a Laguna Beach real estate agent who worked on campaigns for Bartlett and Brough, said Brough harassed her about five years prior, before he was sworn into the state Assembly in 2014.  Brough has denied the allegations.\n\nOn May 27, 2020, Brough was stripped of all his committee assignments after the California State Assembly Workplace Conduct Unit found that Brough had improperly touched and propositioned female staff members, including impliedly offering political favors in exchange for sexual activity. In 2020, The ''Orange County Register'' reported that at least six women accused Brough of sexual assault or harassment over the previous decade.\n\nIn spite of the sexual harassment allegations against him, Brough sought reelection to a fourth term in 2020.  He was soundly defeated in the primary, coming in fourth place.    , a fellow Republican, went on to win the general election.\n\nIn December 2020, days after Brough left the State Assembly, a former legislative aide filed a criminal complaint against him, accusing him of raping her in 2015.\n\n\nIn August 2019, the California Ethics Commission announced it would investigate Brough's alleged misuse of campaign funds.  He is charged with spending campaign contributions to pay off his family's cell phone bill, eat at expensive restaurants, and take a personal trip to a  game, among other personal expenditures.  The total payments in question since he took office add up to nearly $200,000.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert A. Wieckowski''' (born February 18, 1955) is an American attorney and  who served in the . A , he represented the , which encompassed the central and southern portions of the  and .\n\nHe announced a bid to replace  as the representative for , but dropped out a few weeks later.\n\n\nWieckowski is a small business owner and a .  He received his B.A. from  and his J.D. from .\n\nWieckowski was first elected to the  in 2010 to represent the , then the  in 2012 after redistricting. Before being elected to the legislature, he served as vice-mayor and a city councilman in .\n\nWieckowski served as chair of the Assembly Judiciary Committee. He was also a member of the Assembly Insurance, Health, and Public Employees, Retirement and Social Security committees.\n\nIn his first term in office, Wieckowski passed 24 bills through the legislature, 21 of which were signed into law by  . He launched the Made in California Jobs Initiative to expand California manufacturing, invest in biotechnology research, and fight for small businesses.\n\nWieckowski lives in Fremont with his wife, Sue Lemke, and her son Luke. Wieckowski's parents are Gene and Helen Wieckowski.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''John Stephen Horn''' (May 31, 1931 – February 17, 2011) was President of  and later a five-term  man from  from 1993 to 2003.\n\n\nHorn was born on May 31, 1931, in , , Horn served in the  from 1954 until 1962.\n\nHorn earned his bachelor's degree from  in 1953 and went on to earn a  from 's  in 1955. In 1958 he earned his Ph.D. at .\n\n\nIn 1959, Horn became administrative assistant to  . In 1960, he went to work for then U.S. Senator  (R-CA) as a legislative assistant and served in that capacity until 1966, when he left to become a Senior fellow at the . Horn played a major role in the 1964 presidential campaign of  in California. He also served as Vice Chairman of the  from 1969 to 1980 and as a member of the  from 1972 until 1988 (serving as chairman from 1984 until 1987).\n\n\nHorn was President of  from 1970 until 1988 when he stepped down to run for Congress.\n\nAs President of CSULB, Horn reformed the university's graduation and  to emphasize learning skills, , and  education, as well as creating the first university and  opportunities course requirement in the United States.  Horn also gained passage of legislation allowing California's s to take courses for reduced fees on all 23 campuses of the . Horn established one of America's first programs for women returning to college. He also created the CSULB Disabled Resources Center, which served as a model to institutions across the United States.  Horn led the university through 11 major construction projects, including the North Campus Center and buildings for Engineering/Computer Science, Social Science/Public Affairs, and Student Services Administration.\n\n\nHorn first ran for Congress in 1988 in a race to succeed Republican  but lost the primary to conservative .California Journal Vol. XIX, No.5 (May 1988) \"Campaign '88\".  StateNet Publications, May 1988.\n\nAfter the 1991 reapportionment, his home in  was drawn into the neighboring 38th district, then held by veteran Democratic incumbent .  When Anderson announced his retirement in 1992, Horn jumped into the race to succeed him.  He narrowly won an 8-way Republican primary before beating Anderson's stepson, then Long Beach city councilman Evan Anderson Braude, in the general election.California Journal Vol. XXI, No.12 (December 1992) \"Election Results\".  StateNet Publications, December 1992.\n\nA moderate Republican, Horn won his Democratic-leaning district with relative ease four more times. In 1994 he rode the Republican tide to an easy victory over a weak opponent. In 1996, his reelection was eased when he became the only Republican west of the Mississippi River to be endorsed by the Sierra Club;California Journal Vol. XXVII, No.10 (October 1996) \"Election 1996\".  StateNet Publications, October 1996. In 1998 he once again bested his 1994 foe despite a strong year for Democrats statewide in California. Only in 2000 did he have a close race, beating Democrat Gerrie Schipske by less than 1 percent.\n\nAfter the 2001 reapportionment, Democrats in the California legislature made this already Democratic-leaning district even more so.California Journal Vol. XXXIII, No.10 (January 2002) \"Redrawing California\".  StateNet Publications, January 2002.  Horn subsequently announced his retirement and did not seek reelection in 2002.  He did, however, give a surprise endorsement to Democrat , who ran to succeed Horn in the re-drawn seat (now numbered 39) and finished second to  in the Democratic primary.\n\nIn 2003, , a government watchdog group, awarded Horn with its first ever Good Government Award for his contributions to government transparency and oversight, particularly his advocacy for public access to government information.\n\n\nHorn died on February 17, 2011, at the age of 79, of complications from .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*  at the \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| children        = 2, including \n| education       =  () () ()\n| signature       = \n| module          = \n| occupation = \n|j=Jyu4 Gong1 Jyut6 Gwai3|p=Yú Jiāng Yuèguì}}\n}}\n\n'''March Fong Eu''' (; March 29, 1922 – December 21, 2017) was an American diplomat and politician who served as the 24th  for five terms from 1975 to 1994. A member of the , she served in the  from 1967 to 1974 and later as the  under  from 1994 to 1996.\n\nThe daughter of  immigrants, Eu was the first  woman to hold statewide constitutional office in the United States and was also the first woman to serve as Secretary of State of California. She is the adoptive mother of , a  who served one term as .\n\n\nEu was born March Kong on March 29, 1922, in , a city in the , where her Chinese immigrant parents Yuen Kong and Shiu Shee ran a hand-wash laundry. Her grandparents immigrated to the U.S. from Huaxian County (now ) in the  province of . The family later moved to .\n\nEu earned a  in  from the  in 1943 and a  from . She earned an  from the  in 1954.\n\n\nShe became a  working in the  and served a term as president of the American Dental Hygienist Association. She served on the Alameda County Board of Education from 1954 to 1964.\n\n\nIn 1966, Eu was elected as a  to the  from the 15th District, representing  and . She served four terms. She is perhaps best known for her successful campaign to ban , arguing that they discriminated against women since urinals were free.\n\n\n\nEu was elected  in , becoming the first  woman ever elected to a  office in the United States. She remained the only woman to serve as California Secretary of State until 2006, when voters elected . Eu was elected Secretary of State five times.  In 1978 she won every county in the state, even heavily  , making her one of only five  Democrats to win the county in a statewide race in the last half century. She resigned in 1994 when President Bill Clinton nominated her for an ambassadorship.\n\nInnovations she introduced during her 19 years as Secretary of State included voter registration by mail; providing absentee ballots to anyone who requested them; posting results on the Internet; and including candidate statements in ballot pamphlets. In 1976, she became the first woman to serve as , serving as acting governor while Governor  was out of the state.\n\n\nIn 1987, Eu was a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the U.S. Senate, running against  for the right to challenge the Republican incumbent, . Amid poor fundraising totals and her husband's unwillingness to release details of his business interests, Eu dropped out later that year.\n\n  appointed Eu as  in 1994. She served in that post until 1996, when she resigned to work on .\n\nEu campaigned for her son Matt in the , when he was the Republican nominee against incumbent Democratic senator . In 2002, Eu, then age 79, ran again for Secretary of State, saying she was doing so because \"Florida made me angry\", referring to the  during the . She lost in the Democratic  to , who went on to win .\n\n\nEu resided both in California and Singapore with her second husband Henry Eu, a multimillionaire industrialist. Eu was assaulted by a burglar who broke into her Hancock Park home in 1986. Her adopted son, , was a  activist who served as  for a four-year term that began January 1995. She also had a daughter, Suyin. Her hobbies in retirement included Chinese brush painting and calligraphy. Eu died in , on December 21, 2017, following a fall; she was 95 years old.\n\n\nIn 2019 California's Secretary of State building in Sacramento was named after Eu (as the March Fong Eu Secretary of State Building); this made it the first state-owned building to be named for an Asian-American woman.\n\nThe  gives an annual March Fong Eu Award to \"the individual who or organization that, in the judgment of the Association's Executive Committee, has done the most to improve the standards, image and quality of the office of Notary Public.\" Eu was the first recipient of the award in 1979, named after her \"for her extraordinary leadership in spearheading enactment of progressive Notary reform legislation, despite opposition from powerful lobbies who preferred lower notarial standards.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
